1289419_11_ITEM1_P185_S0	Investment advisory and broker-dealer businesses are subject to extensive regulation in the United States at both the federal and state level, as well as by self-regulatory organizations.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P185_S1	Financial services companies are among the nation s most extensively regulated.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P185_S2	The SEC is responsible for enforcing the federal securities laws and oversees federally registered investment advisors and broker-dealers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P186_S0	As of December 31, 2010, four of our subsidiaries, Ibbotson Associates, Inc., Ibbotson Associates Advisors, LLC, Morningstar Associates, LLC, and Morningstar Investment Services, Inc. are registered as investment advisors with the SEC under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, as amended (Advisers Act).
1289419_11_ITEM1_P186_S1	As registered investment advisors, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Advisers Act.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P186_S2	Such requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, and standards of care, as well as general anti-fraud prohibitions.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P187_S0	In addition, because these four subsidiaries provide investment advisory services to retirement plans and their participants, they may be acting as fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_11_ITEM1_P187_S1	As fiduciaries under ERISA, they have duties of loyalty and prudence, as well as duties to diversify investments and to follow plan documents to comply with the applicable portions of ERISA.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P188_S0	Morningstar Investment Services is a broker-dealer registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Exchange Act) and a member of FINRA.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P188_S1	The regulation of broker-dealers has, to a large extent, been delegated by the federal securities laws to self-regulatory organizations, including FINRA.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P188_S2	Subject to approval by the SEC, FINRA adopts rules that govern its members.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P189_S0	FINRA conducts periodic examinations of the operations of Morningstar Investment Services.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P190_S0	Broker-dealers are subject to regulations that cover all aspects of the securities business, including sales, capital structure, record-keeping, and the conduct of directors, officers, and employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P190_S1	Violation of applicable regulations can result in the revocation of a broker-dealer license, the imposition of censures or fines, and the suspension or expulsion of a firm or its officers or employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P191_S0	Morningstar Investment Services is subject to certain net capital requirements under the Exchange Act.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P191_S1	The net capital requirements, which specify minimum net capital levels for registered broker-dealers, are designed to measure the financial soundness and liquidity of broker-dealers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P192_S0	Realpoint, LLC, one of our subsidiaries, is an NRSRO specializing in structured finance.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P192_S1	As an NRSRO, Realpoint is subject to the requirements and regulations under the Exchange Act.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P192_S2	Such requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, governance, and conflicts of interest.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P193_S0	Our subsidiaries that provide financial information services and advice in Australia, Morningstar Australasia Pty Limited and Ibbotson Associates Australia, must hold an Australian Financial Services License and submit to the jurisdiction of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC).
1289419_11_ITEM1_P193_S1	This license requires them to, among other things, maintain positive net asset levels and sufficient cash resources to cover three months of expenses and to comply with the audit requirements of the ASIC.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P194_S0	Morningstar Associates Europe Limited and OBSR Advisory Services Limited are authorized and regulated by the U.K. Financial Services Authority as an investment advisor.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P194_S1	As authorized firms, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Financial Services Authority.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P194_S2	Such requirements relate to, among other things, financial reporting and other reporting obligations, record-keeping, and cross-border requirements.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P195_S0	Additional legislation and regulations, including those relating to the activities of investment advisors and broker-dealers, changes in rules imposed by the SEC or other U.S. or non-U.S. regulatory authorities and self-regulatory organizations, or changes in the interpretation or enforcement of existing laws and rules may adversely affect our business and profitability.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P195_S1	Our businesses may be materially affected not only by regulations applicable to it as an investment advisor or broker-dealer, but also by regulations that apply to companies generally.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P196_S0	We have a variety of other entities (in Japan, Korea, Thailand, and France) that are registered with their respective regulatory bodies; however, the amount of business conducted by these entities related to the registration is relatively small.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P197_S0	We had approximately 3,225 employees as of December 31, 2010, including approximately 600 data analysts, 65 designers, 320 investment analysts (including consulting and quantitative research analysts), 820 programmers and technology staff, and 520 sales and marketing professionals.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P197_S1	Our employees are not represented by any unions, and we have never experienced a walkout or strike.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P198_S0	As of February 28, 2011, we had 10 executive officers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P198_S1	The table below summarizes information about each of these officers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P199_S0	Joe Mansueto founded Morningstar in 1984.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P199_S1	He has served as our chairman since our inception and as our chief executive officer from our inception to 1996 and from 2000 to the present.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P200_S0	He holds a bachelor s degree in business administration from The University of Chicago and a master s degree in business administration from The University of Chicago Booth School of Business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P201_S0	Chris Boruff has been president of Morningstar s Software division since January 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P201_S1	He is responsible for overseeing strategy, development, and distribution of technology products for individual investors, financial advisors, and institutions, as well as custom solutions for institutions.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P202_S0	He joined us in 1996 as product manager for Principia, and from 1997 to 1998, he served as senior product manager of advisor products.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P202_S1	From 1999 to 2000, he served as vice president of advisor products, where he was responsible for all marketing related to financial advisors.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P202_S2	From 2000 to 2009, he was president of Morningstar s advisor software business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P202_S3	He holds a bachelor s degree in economics and psychology from Northwestern University.

1289419_11_ITEM1_P216_S1	Our Annual Report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to any of these documents are available free of charge on this site as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports are filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P216_S2	We also post quarterly press releases on our financial results and other documents containing additional information related to our company on this site.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P216_S3	We provide this website and the information contained in or connected to it for informational purposes only.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P216_S4	That information is not part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P217_S0	You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the other information included in this Form 10-K when deciding whether to invest in our common stock or otherwise evaluating our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P217_S1	If any of the following risks materialize, our business, financial condition, or operating results could suffer.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P217_S2	In this case, the trading price of our common stock could decline, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P218_S0	Failing to maintain and protect our brand, independence, and reputation may harm our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P218_S1	Our reputation and business may also be harmed by allegations made about possible conflicts of interest.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S0	We believe that independence is at the core of our business, and our reputation is our greatest corporate asset.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S1	We offer products and services to our institutional clients, which include banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies, mutual fund companies, media outlets, and retirement plan providers and sponsors.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S2	Our institutional clients have generated a significant percentage of our consolidated revenue in recent years.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S3	We provide ratings, analyst research, and investment recommendations on mutual funds and other investment products offered and securities issued by our institutional clients.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S4	We also provide investment advisory and investment management services.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S5	The fact that our institutional clients pay us for certain products and services, as well as the fact that in some cases we make investment recommendations within the framework of client constraints, may create the perception that our ratings, research, and recommendations are not impartial.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S6	This perception may undermine the confidence of our customers and potential customers in our reputation as a provider of independent research.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P219_S7	Any such loss of confidence or damage to our reputation could hurt our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P220_S0	Any failure to uphold our high ethical standards and ensure that our customers have a consistently positive experience with us (either intentionally or inadvertently) could damage our reputation as an objective, honest, and credible source for investment research and information.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P221_S0	Our reputation may also be harmed by factors outside of our control, such as news reports about our clients or adverse publicity about certain investment products.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P222_S0	Downturns in the financial sector, global financial markets, and global economy may adversely impact our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P223_S0	Although market conditions improved in 2009 and 2010, we believe that ongoing economic weakness continues to cause uncertainty and pressure on consumer discretionary spending.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P223_S1	The financial crisis of 2007 and 2008 also led to spending cutbacks among asset management firms and other financial services companies, which make up a large percentage of our client base.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P223_S2	Some institutional clients also implemented additional review processes for new contracts or began to provide certain services, particularly investment advisory services, in-house rather than hiring external service providers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P224_S0	If financial markets around the world experience negative performance and volatility, demand for our products and services may decline, and our revenue, operating income, and other financial results could suffer.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P224_S1	Our business results may also be impacted by negative trends in Internet advertising sales.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P224_S2	The financial markets and many businesses operating in the financial services industry are highly volatile and are affected by factors, such as U.S. and foreign economic conditions and general trends in business and finance, which are beyond our control.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P225_S0	Our revenue from asset-based fees may be impacted by market declines as well as the impact of cash outflows.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P226_S0	In 2010, revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 12% of our consolidated revenue and a greater percentage of our operating income.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P226_S1	The amount of revenue we earn from asset-based fees depends on the value of assets on which we provide advisory services, and the size of our asset base can increase or decrease along with trends in market performance.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P226_S2	The value of assets under advisement may show substantial declines during periods of significant market volatility.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P226_S3	The size of these portfolios can also be affected if net inflows into the portfolios on which we provide investment advisory services drop or if these portfolios experience redemptions.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P226_S4	If the level of assets on which we provide investment advisory services goes down, we expect that our fee-based revenue will show a corresponding decline.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P227_S0	Our investment advisory operations may subject us to liability for any losses that result from a breach of our fiduciary duties.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P228_S0	Our investment advisory operations involve fiduciary obligations that require us to act in the best interests of our clients.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P228_S1	We may face liabilities for actual or claimed breaches of our fiduciary duties, particularly in areas where we provide retirement advice and managed retirement accounts.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P228_S2	We may not be able to prevent clients from taking legal action against us for an actual or claimed breach of a fiduciary duty.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P228_S3	Because we provided investment advisory services on more than $107.2 billion in assets as of December 31, 2010, we could face substantial liabilities if we breach our fiduciary duties.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P229_S0	In addition, we may face other legal liabilities based on the quality and outcome of our investment advisory recommendations, even in the absence of an actual or claimed breach of fiduciary duty.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P230_S0	Changes in laws applicable to our investment advisory operations, compliance failures, or regulatory action could adversely affect our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P231_S0	Our investment advisory operations are a growing part of our overall business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P231_S1	Our acquisitions of Ibbotson Associates in 2006 and Intech Pty Ltd in 2009 substantially increased our business in this area.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P231_S2	We also expanded our investment advisory operations with our recent acquisitions of Old Broad Street Research Ltd. in the United Kingdom and Seeds Group in France.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P232_S0	The securities laws and other laws that govern our activities as a registered investment advisor are complex.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P232_S1	The activities of our investment advisory operations are primarily subject to provisions of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 (the Advisers Act) and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_11_ITEM1_P232_S2	In addition, our investment management business is conducted through a broker-dealer registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the Exchange Act) and is subject to the rules of FINRA.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P233_S0	We also provide investment advisory services in other areas around the world, and our operations may be subject to additional regulations in markets outside the United States.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P233_S1	It is difficult to predict the future impact of the broad and expanding legislative and regulatory requirements affecting our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P233_S2	The laws, rules, and regulations applicable to our business may change in the future, and we may not be able to comply with any such changes.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P233_S3	If we fail to comply with any applicable law, rule, or regulation, we could be fined, sanctioned, or barred from providing investment advisory services in the future, which could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P234_S0	The increasing concentration of data and development work carried out at our offshore facilities may have a negative impact on our business operations, products, and services.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P235_S0	We now have approximately 820 employees working in our data and technology development center in Shenzhen, China, or about one-fourth of our total workforce.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P235_S1	Over the past several years, we have moved a significant percentage of our data collection and development operations to this location.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P236_S0	Because China has a restrictive government under centralized control, we cannot predict the level of political and regulatory risk that may affect our operations.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P236_S1	The concentration of development and data work carried out at this facility also involves operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P236_S2	Any difficulties that we face in successfully maintaining our development center in China may harm our business and have a negative impact on the products and services we provide, particularly because of our increasing reliance on this facility.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P237_S0	We have approximately 270 employees who work at our data collection facilities in Mumbai and New Delhi, India, which may also be subject to political and regulatory risk.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P237_S1	Like the Shenzhen operation, these facilities also involve operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P238_S0	Failing to differentiate our products and continuously create innovative, proprietary research tools may negatively impact our competitive position and business results.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P239_S0	We attribute much of our company s success over the past 25 years to our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P239_S1	We cannot guarantee that we will continue to successfully develop new product features and tools that differentiate our product offerings from those of our competitors.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P239_S2	If tools similar to Morningstar s proprietary tools become more broadly available through other channels, our competitive position and business results may suffer.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P240_S0	Failing to successfully integrate acquisitions could harm our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P241_S0	We ve completed numerous acquisitions over the past three years, including seven acquisitions in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P241_S1	We cannot guarantee that we will successfully integrate the employees, product lines, business systems, marketing and branding, or other operations following any acquisition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P241_S2	We expect to continue making acquisitions and establishing investments and joint ventures as part of our long-term business strategy.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P242_S0	Acquisitions, investments, and joint ventures involve a number of risks.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P242_S1	They can be time-consuming and may divert management s attention from day-to-day operations, particularly if numerous acquisitions are in process at the same time.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P242_S2	Financing an acquisition could result in dilution to our shareholders from the issuance of equity securities, reduce our financial flexibility because of reductions in our cash balance, or result in a weaker balance sheet from incurring debt.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P243_S0	Acquisitions might also result in losing key employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P243_S1	We may fail to successfully complete an acquisition, investment, or joint venture.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P243_S2	We may also fail to generate enough revenue or profits from an acquisition to earn a return on the associated purchase price.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P244_S0	Our operations outside of the United States are expanding and involve additional challenges that we may not be able to meet.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P245_S0	Our operations outside of the United States have expanded to $157.1 million in revenue in 2010 from $129.2 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P245_S1	Several of our recent acquisitions have added to our business operations in Europe, Australia, and other areas outside the United States, and we recently established a business presence in Latin America.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S0	There are risks inherent in doing business outside the United States, including challenges in reaching new markets because of established competitors and limited brand recognition; difficulties in staffing, managing, and integrating non-U.S. operations; difficulties in coordinating and sharing information globally; differences in laws and policies from country to country; exposure to varying legal standards, including intellectual property protection laws; potential tax exposure related to transfer pricing and other issues; heightened risk of fraud and noncompliance; and currency exchange rates and exchange controls.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S1	These risks could hamper our ability to expand around the world, which may hurt our financial performance and ability to grow.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S2	As our non-U.S. revenue increases as a percentage of consolidated revenue, fluctuations in foreign currencies present a greater potential risk.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S3	We don t engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S4	Our reported revenue could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar, although the impact on operating income may be offset by an opposing currency impact on locally based operating expense.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P246_S5	In addition, because we use the local currency of our subsidiaries as the functional currency, our financial results are affected by the translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P247_S0	A prolonged outage of our database and network facilities could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S0	The success of our business depends upon our ability to deliver time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S1	We rely on our computer equipment, database storage facilities, and other office equipment, which are mainly located in our Chicago headquarters or elsewhere in the Chicago area.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S2	Our operations and those of our suppliers and customers are vulnerable to interruption by fire, earthquake, power loss, telecommunications failure, terrorist attacks, wars, Internet failures or disruptions, computer viruses, and other events beyond our control, including disasters affecting Chicago.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S3	We maintain off-site back-up facilities for our database and network equipment, but these facilities could be subject to the same interruptions that may affect our headquarters.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S4	We re not currently able to immediately switch over all of our systems to a back-up facility.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S5	If we experience a significant database or network facility outage, our business may be disrupted until we fully implement our back-up systems.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P248_S6	Any losses, service disruption, or damages incurred by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P249_S0	Our business relies heavily on electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P249_S1	Any failures or disruptions could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P250_S0	Most of our products and services depend heavily on our electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P250_S1	Our ability to deliver information using the Internet may be impaired because of infrastructure failures, service outages at third-party Internet providers, malicious attacks, or increased government regulation.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P250_S2	If disruptions, failures, or slowdowns of our electronic delivery systems or the Internet occur, our ability to distribute our products and services effectively and to serve our customers may be impaired.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P251_S0	We could face liability related to our storage of personal information about our users.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P252_S0	Customers routinely input personal investment and financial information, including portfolio holdings and credit card information, on our websites.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P252_S1	We also handle personally sensitive information through our Portfolio Management Service, managed retirement accounts, and other areas of our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P252_S2	We could be subject to liability if we were to inappropriately disclose any user s personal information or if third parties were able to penetrate our network security or otherwise gain access to any user s name, address, portfolio holdings, or credit card information.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P252_S3	Any such event could subject us to claims for unauthorized credit card purchases, impersonation or other similar fraud claims, or claims for other misuses of personal information, such as unauthorized marketing or unauthorized access to personal portfolio information.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P253_S0	Certain products and services have historically made up a large percentage of our revenue base.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P253_S1	Our business could suffer if sales of these products and services decline.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P254_S0	In 2010, our five largest products based on revenue (Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar.com, and Morningstar Direct) accounted for approximately 59% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P254_S1	We believe that sales of these products and services will continue to make up a substantial portion of our consolidated revenue for the foreseeable future.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P254_S2	If we experience a significant decline in sales of any of these products for any reason, it would have a material adverse impact on our revenue and could harm our business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P255_S0	We could face liability for the information we publish, including information based on data we obtain from other parties.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P256_S0	We may be subject to claims for securities law violations, defamation (including libel and slander), negligence, or other claims relating to the information we publish, including our research and ratings on corporate credit issuers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P256_S1	For example, investors may take legal action against us if they rely on published information that contains an error, or a company may claim that we have made a defamatory statement about it or its employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P256_S2	We could also be subject to claims based upon the content that is accessible from our website through links to other websites.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P257_S0	We rely on a variety of outside parties as the original sources for the information we use in our published data.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P257_S1	These sources include securities exchanges, fund companies, transfer agents, and other data providers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P257_S2	Accordingly, in addition to possible exposure for publishing incorrect information that results directly from our own errors, we could face liability based on inaccurate data provided to us by others.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P257_S3	Defending claims based on the information we publish could be expensive and time-consuming and could adversely impact our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P258_S0	We may be unable to generate adequate returns on our cash and investment balance if we cannot identify attractive investment opportunities.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P259_S0	We held a total of $365.4 million in cash and investments as of December 31, 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P260_S0	Because of generally low prevailing interest rates on high-quality fixed-income securities, the rate of return we can generate with our cash and investment balance is relatively low.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P260_S1	We have used portions of our cash and investment balance to finance acquisitions over the past several years.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P260_S2	We cannot guarantee that we will be able to find suitable acquisition opportunities in the future.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P260_S3	As mentioned above, we may also fail to generate enough revenue or profits from an acquisition to earn a return on the associated purchase price.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P261_S0	Our results could suffer if the mutual fund industry experiences slower growth.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P262_S0	A significant portion of our revenue is generated from products and services related to mutual funds.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P263_S0	The mutual fund industry has experienced substantial growth over the past 25 years, but suffered along with the market downturn in 2008 and early 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P263_S1	Global mutual fund assets declined to about $23.7 trillion as of September 30, 2010, down from a peak of $26.1 trillion in 2007.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P263_S2	While mutual fund assets rose in 2010, equity-focused funds have continued to experience net cash outflows, suggesting that investors remain cautious about equity-related assets.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P264_S0	A significant portion of our fund research has historically focused on equity-related funds.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P265_S0	Continued downturns or volatility in the financial markets, increased investor interest in other investment vehicles, or a lack of investor confidence could reduce investor interest and investment activity in this area.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P265_S1	A slower growth rate or downturn in mutual fund assets could decrease demand for our products.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P265_S2	Competition could reduce our share of the investment research market and hurt our financial performance.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P266_S0	We operate in a highly competitive industry, with many investment research providers competing for business from individual investors, financial advisors, and institutional clients.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P266_S1	We compete with many different types of companies that vary in size, product scope, and media focus, including large and well-established distributors of financial information, such as Thomson Reuters; Standard Poor s, a division of The McGraw-Hill Companies; Bloomberg; and Yahoo!.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P266_S2	We compete with a variety of other companies in different areas of our business, which we discuss in greater detail in the Business Segments, Products, and Services section in Item 1 Business.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P267_S0	Many of our competitors have larger customer bases and significantly greater resources than we do.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P267_S1	This may allow them to respond more quickly to new technologies and changes in demand for products and services, devote greater resources to developing and promoting their services, and make more attractive offers to potential clients, subscribers, and strategic partners.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P267_S2	Industry consolidation may also lead to more intense competition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P267_S3	Increased competition could result in price reductions, reduced margins, or loss of market share, any of which could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P268_S0	The investment information industry is dominated by a few large players, and industry consolidation has increased in the past several years.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P268_S1	If providers of data and investment analysis continue to consolidate, our competitive position may suffer.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P269_S0	Consolidation among our clients may adversely impact our competitive position, our relationships with our clients, and business results.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P270_S0	Industry consolidation in the financial services sector has accelerated over the past several years.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P270_S1	We can t predict the impact on our business if one of our clients is acquired.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P270_S2	We may lose business following an acquisition of one of our clients if we re not able to continue providing services or expand our business with the combined organization.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P270_S3	Any loss of business because of increased consolidation could have a negative effect on our revenue and profitability.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P271_S0	The availability of free or low-cost investment information could lead to lower demand for our products and adversely affect our financial results.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P272_S0	Investment research and information relating to publicly traded companies and mutual funds is widely available for little or no cost from various sources, including the Internet and public libraries.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P272_S1	Investors can also access information directly from publicly traded companies and mutual funds.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P273_S0	The Interactive Data Electronic Applications (IDEA) database available through the SEC website provides real-time access to SEC filings, including annual, semi-annual, and quarterly reports.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P273_S1	Financial information and data is also widely available in XBRL (eXtensible Business Reporting Language), and many brokerage firms provide financial and investment research to their clients.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P274_S0	The widespread availability of free or low-cost investment information may make it difficult for us to maintain or increase the prices we charge for our publications and services and could lead to a lower demand for our products.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P274_S1	A loss of a significant number of customers would hurt our financial results.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P274_S2	We could be subject to fines, penalties, or other sanctions as a result of an investigation by the New York Attorney General s Office related to some of the services Morningstar Associates, LLC provides.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P275_S0	As we originally disclosed in 2004, the New York Attorney General s Office is conducting an investigation related to some of the products and services offered by Morningstar Associates, LLC.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P275_S1	See Item 3 Legal Proceedings for a description of these matters.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P275_S2	We cannot predict the scope, timing, or outcome of these matters, which may include the institution of administrative, civil, injunctive, or criminal proceedings, the imposition of fines and penalties, and other remedies and sanctions, any of which could lead to an adverse impact on our stock price, the inability to attract or retain key employees, and the loss of customers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P275_S3	We also cannot predict what impact, if any, these matters may have on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P275_S4	We have not established any reserves relating to these matters.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P276_S0	Our future success depends on our ability to recruit and retain qualified employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P277_S0	We experience competition for analysts and other employees from financial institutions and financial services organizations.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P277_S1	These organizations generally have greater resources than we do and therefore may be able to offer significantly more attractive compensation packages to potential employees.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P277_S2	Competition for these employees is intense, and we may not be able to retain our existing employees or be able to recruit and retain other highly qualified personnel in the future.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P278_S0	Our future success also depends on the continued service of our executive officers, including Joe Mansueto, our chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P278_S1	Joe is heavily involved in our day-to-day operations, business strategy, and overall company direction.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P278_S2	The loss of Joe or other executive officers could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P278_S3	We do not have employment agreements, non-compete agreements, or life insurance policies in place with any of our executive officers.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P278_S4	They may leave us and work for our competitors or start their own competing businesses.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P279_S0	Failure to protect our intellectual property rights could harm our brand-building efforts and ability to compete effectively.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P280_S0	The steps we have taken to protect our intellectual property may not be adequate to safeguard our proprietary information.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P280_S1	Further, effective trademark, copyright, and trade secret protection may not be available in every country in which we offer our services.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P280_S2	Our continued ability to market one or more of our products under their current names could be adversely affected in those jurisdictions where another person registers, or has a pre-existing registration on one or more of them.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P280_S3	Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property could harm our brand, devalue our proprietary content, and affect our ability to compete in the marketplace.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P281_S0	From time to time, we encounter jurisdictions in which one or more third parties have a pre-existing trademark registration in certain relevant international classes that may prevent us from registering our own marks in those jurisdictions.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P281_S1	It is possible that our continued ability to use the Morningstar name or logo, either on a stand-alone basis or in association with certain products or services, could be compromised in those jurisdictions because of these pre-existing registrations.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P281_S2	Similarly, from time to time, we encounter situations in certain jurisdictions where one or more third parties are already using the Morningstar name, either as part of a registered corporate name, a registered domain name or otherwise.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P281_S3	Our ability to effectively market certain products and/or services in those locations could be adversely affected by these pre-existing usages.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P282_S0	Control by a principal shareholder could adversely affect our other shareholders.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P283_S0	As of December 31, 2010, Joe Mansueto, our chairman and chief executive officer, owned approximately 50% of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P283_S1	As a result, he has the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to our shareholders for approval, including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P283_S2	He also has the ability to control our management and affairs.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P283_S3	This concentration of ownership may delay or prevent a change in control; impede a merger, consolidation, takeover, or other business combination involving us; discourage a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of us; or result in actions that may be opposed by other shareholders.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P284_S0	Fluctuations in our operating results may negatively impact our stock price.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S0	We believe our business has relatively large fixed costs and low variable costs, which magnify the impact of revenue fluctuations on our operating results.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S1	As a result, a decline in our revenue may lead to a larger decline in operating income.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S2	A substantial portion of our operating expense is related to personnel costs, marketing programs, office leases, and other infrastructure spending, which generally cannot be adjusted quickly.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S3	Our operating expense levels are based on our expectations for future revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S4	If actual revenue falls below our expectations, or if our expenses increase before revenues do, our operating results would be materially and adversely affected.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S5	In addition, we do not provide earnings guidance or hold one-on-one meetings with institutional investors and research analysts.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S6	Because of this policy and limited analyst coverage on our stock, our stock price may be volatile.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S7	If our operating results or other operating metrics fail to meet the expectations of outside research analysts and investors, the market price of our common stock may decline.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P285_S8	The future sale of shares of our common stock may negatively impact our stock price.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P286_S0	If our shareholders sell substantial amounts of our common stock, the market price of our common stock could fall.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P286_S1	A reduction in ownership by Joe Mansueto or any other large shareholder could cause the market price of our common stock to fall.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P286_S2	In addition, the average daily trading volume in our stock is relatively low.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P286_S3	The lack of trading activity in our stock may lead to greater fluctuations in our stock price.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P286_S4	Low trading volume may also make it difficult for shareholders to make transactions in a timely fashion.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P287_S0	Our shareholders may experience dilution in their ownership positions.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P288_S0	In the past, we ve granted options to employees as a significant part of their overall compensation package.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P288_S1	In 2006, we began granting restricted stock units to our employees and non-employee directors.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P288_S2	As of December 31, 2010, our employees and non-employee directors held options to acquire 1,856,425 shares of common stock, all of which were exercisable at a weighted average price of approximately $17.73 per share.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P288_S3	As of December 31, 2010, there were 822,855 restricted stock units outstanding, which have an average remaining vesting period of 33 months.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P289_S0	Generally speaking, the company issues a share of stock when a restricted stock unit vests.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P289_S1	To the extent that option holders exercise outstanding options to purchase common stock and shares are issued when restricted stock units vest, there will be further dilution.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P289_S2	Future grants of stock options or restricted stock units may also result in dilution.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P290_S0	We may raise additional funds through future sales of our common stock.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P290_S1	Any such financing would result in additional dilution to our shareholders.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P290_S2	Stock option exercises, share repurchases, and other factors may create volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P291_S0	Part of our cash provided by financing activities consists of proceeds from stock option exercises and excess tax benefits related to stock option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P291_S1	Excess tax benefits occur at the time a stock option is exercised if the intrinsic value of the option (the difference between the exercise price of the option and the fair value of our stock on the date of exercise) exceeds the fair value of the option at the time of grant.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P291_S2	Similarly, excess tax benefits are generated upon vesting of restricted stock units when the market value of our common stock at vesting is greater than the grant price of the restricted stock units.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P291_S3	These excess tax benefits reduce the cash we pay for income taxes in the year they are recognized.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P292_S0	It is not possible to predict the timing of stock option exercises or the intrinsic value that will be realized.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P292_S1	Because of this uncertainty, there may be additional volatility in our cash flows from financing activities.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P292_S2	In addition, our board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program allowing for the repurchase of up to $100 million of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P292_S3	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that management deems appropriate.
1289419_11_ITEM1_P292_S4	Changes in the amount of repurchase activity from period to period may also cause volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_11_ITEM1B_P0_S0	We do not have any unresolved comments from the Staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding our periodic or current reports under the Exchange Act.
1289419_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we lease approximately 323,000 square feet of office space for our U.S. operations, primarily for our office located in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	We also lease approximately 385,000 square feet of office space in 23 countries around the world.
1289419_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	We believe that our existing and planned office facilities are adequate for our needs and that additional or substitute space is available to accommodate growth and expansion.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	In November 2010, InvestPic, LLC filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware against Morningstar, Inc. and several other companies alleging that each defendant infringes U.S. Patent No. 6,349,291, which relates to methods for performing statistical analysis on investment data and displaying the analyzed data in graphical form.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P0_S1	InvestPic seeks, among other things, unspecified damages because of defendants alleged infringing activities and costs.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P0_S2	Morningstar is evaluating the lawsuit but cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	In June 2010, Egan-Jones Rating Co. filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania against Realpoint, LLC and Morningstar, Inc. in connection with a December 2007 agreement between Egan-Jones and Realpoint for certain data-sharing and other services.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	In addition to damages, Egan-Jones filed a petition seeking an injunction to temporarily prevent Morningstar from offering corporate credit ratings through December 31, 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P1_S2	In September 2010, the court denied Egan-Jones s request for a preliminary injunction against Morningstar s corporate credit ratings business.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P1_S3	Realpoint and Morningstar continue to vigorously contest liability on all of Egan-Jones claims for damages.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P2_S0	We cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P3_S0	In November 2009, Business Logic Holding Corporation filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois against Ibbotson Associates, Inc. and Morningstar, Inc. relating to Ibbotson s prior commercial relationship with Business Logic.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P3_S1	Business Logic is alleging that Ibbotson Associates and Morningstar violated Business Logic s rights by using its trade secrets to develop a proprietary web-service software and user interface that connects plan participant data with the Ibbotson Wealth Forecasting Engine.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P3_S2	Business Logic seeks, among other things, injunctive relief and unspecified damages.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P3_S3	Ibbotson and Morningstar answered the complaint, and Ibbotson asserted a counterclaim against Business Logic alleging trade secret misappropriation and breach of contract, seeking damages and injunctive relief.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P4_S0	While Morningstar and Ibbotson Associates are vigorously contesting the claims against them, we cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P5_S0	In December 2004, Morningstar Associates, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Morningstar, Inc., received a subpoena from the New York Attorney General s office seeking information and documents related to an investigation the New York Attorney General s office is conducting.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P5_S1	The subpoena asks for documents relating to the investment consulting services the company offers to retirement plan providers, including fund lineup recommendations for retirement plan sponsors.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P5_S2	Morningstar Associates has provided the requested information and documents.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P6_S0	In 2005, Morningstar Associates received subpoenas seeking information and documents related to investigations being conducted by the SEC and United States Department of Labor.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P6_S1	The subpoenas were similar in scope to the New York Attorney General subpoena.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P7_S0	In January 2007 and September 2009, respectively, the SEC and Department of Labor each notified Morningstar Associates that it had ended its investigation, with no enforcement action, fines, or penalties.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P8_S0	In January 2007, Morningstar Associates received a Notice of Proposed Litigation from the New York Attorney General s office.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P8_S1	The Notice centers on disclosure relating to an optional service offered to retirement plan sponsors (employers) that select 401(k) plan services from ING, one of Morningstar Associates clients.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P8_S2	The Notice gave Morningstar Associates the opportunity to explain why the New York Attorney General s office should not institute proceedings.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P8_S3	Morningstar Associates promptly submitted its explanation and has cooperated fully with the New York Attorney General s office.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P9_S0	We cannot predict the scope, timing, or outcome of this matter, which may include the institution of administrative, civil, injunctive, or criminal proceedings, the imposition of fines and penalties, and other remedies and sanctions, any of which could lead to an adverse impact on our stock price, the inability to attract or retain key employees, and the loss of customers.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P9_S1	We also cannot predict what impact, if any, this matter may have on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P10_S0	In addition to these proceedings, we are involved in legal proceedings and litigation that have arisen in the normal course of our business.
1289419_11_ITEM3_P10_S1	Although the outcome of a particular proceeding can never be predicted, we do not believe that the result of any of these other matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.

1289419_11_ITEM6_P1_S0	In 2010, we determined that the cumulative effect of adjustments related to prior periods were material, in aggregate, if recorded in our 2010 Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P1_S1	These amounts related primarily to our accounting for deferred taxes and, to a lesser extent, to expense adjustments associated with vacant office space and rent for one of our office leases.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P1_S2	We evaluated the effects of these errors on our prior periods Consolidated Financial Statements, individually and in the aggregate, in accordance with the materiality guidance provided by the SEC staff, as included in SAB Topics 1M and 1N, and concluded that no prior period is materially misstated.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P1_S3	However, in accordance with the provisions of these SAB Topics, we restated our Consolidated Financial Statements for years prior to 2010.

1289419_11_ITEM6_P1_S5	The following table reconciles the amounts as presented in this table of Selected Financial Data with the previously reported amounts:
1289419_11_ITEM6_P2_S0	Consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations (organic revenue) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under the regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
1289419_11_ITEM6_P2_S1	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P2_S2	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
1289419_11_ITEM6_P3_S0	Effective January 1, 2006, we adopted SFAS No. 123 (Revised 2004), Share-Based Payment (SFAS No. 123(R)).
1289419_11_ITEM6_P3_S1	In 2006, we began granting restricted stock units.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P3_S2	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day prior to grant.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P3_S3	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P4_S0	In May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares of restricted stock in conjunction with the acquisition of Realpoint, LLC.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P4_S1	The restricted stock vests over five years from the date of grant.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P4_S2	This grant resulted in an expense of $1.2 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P5_S0	The total expense for stock-based compensation is distributed with other employee compensation costs in the appropriate operating expense categories of our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P5_S1	Refer to Note 11 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for more information on our stock-based compensation.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P6_S0	Cash used for investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions; purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the sale of investments; and capital expenditures.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P6_S1	The level of investing activities can vary from period to period depending on the level of activity in these three categories.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P6_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for investing activities.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P7_S0	Cash provided by financing activities consists primarily of proceeds from stock-option exercises and excess tax benefits.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P7_S1	These cash inflows are offset by cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program which we began in the fourth quarter of 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P7_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources , for more information concerning cash provided by financing activities.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P8_S0	Free cash flow is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under SEC regulations.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P8_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P8_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P8_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required to be reported under GAAP, nor should this data be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P8_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P9_S0	We frequently invoice or collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_11_ITEM6_P9_S1	These amounts are recorded as deferred revenue on our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	The discussion included in this section, as well as other sections of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, contains forward-looking statements as that term is used in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	These statements are based on our current expectations about future events or future financial performance.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S2	Forward-looking statements by their nature address matters that are, to different degrees, uncertain, and often contain words such as may, could, expect, intend, plan, seek, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, potential, or continue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S3	These statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause the events we discuss not to occur or to differ significantly from what we expect.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S4	For us, these risks and uncertainties include, among others, general industry conditions and competition, including current global financial uncertainty; the impact of market volatility on revenue from asset-based fees; damage to our reputation resulting from claims made about possible conflicts of interest; liability for any losses that result from an actual or claimed breach of our fiduciary duties; financial services industry consolidation; a prolonged outage of our database and network facilities; challenges faced by our non-U.S. operations; and the availability of free or low-cost investment information.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S5	A more complete description of these risks and uncertainties can be found in Item 1A Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S6	If any of these risks and uncertainties materialize, our actual future results may vary significantly from what we expected.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P0_S7	We do not undertake to update our forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	All dollar and percentage comparisons, which are often accompanied by words such as increase, decrease, grew, declined, was up, was down, was flat, or was similar refer to a comparison with the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our mission is to create great products that help investors reach their financial goals.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	We offer an extensive line of data, software, and research products for individual investors, financial advisors, and institutional clients.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	We also offer asset management services for advisors, institutions, and retirement plan participants.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	Many of our products are sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P2_S4	As a result, we typically generate recurring revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Morningstar has two operating segments: Investment Information and Investment Management.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	The Investment Information segment includes all of our data, software, and research products and services.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	These products and services are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Investment Management segment includes our asset management operations, which operate as registered investment advisors and earn more than half of their revenue from asset-based fees.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	We emphasize a decentralized approach to running our business to empower our managers and to create a culture of responsibility and accountability.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	Historically, we have focused primarily on organic growth by introducing new products and services and marketing our existing products.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	However, we have made and expect to continue to make selective acquisitions that support our five key growth strategies, which are:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Enhance our position in key market segments by focusing on our three major Internet-based platforms; Create a premier global investment database; Continue building thought leadership in independent investment research; Become a global leader in fund-of-funds investment management; and Expand our international brand presence, products, and services.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	We generate revenue by selling a variety of investment-related products and services.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	We sell many of our offerings, such as newsletters, Principia software, and Premium service on Morningstar.com, via subscriptions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	These subscriptions are mainly offered for a one-year term, although we also offer terms ranging from one month to three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	We also sell advertising on our websites throughout the world.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S4	Several of our other products are sold through license agreements, including Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Equity Research, Morningstar Direct, Retirement Advice, and Licensed Data.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P7_S5	Our license agreements typically range from one to three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	For some of our other institutional services, mainly Investment Consulting, we generally base our fees on the scope of work and the level of service we provide and calculate them as a percentage of assets under advisement.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	We also earn fees relating to Morningstar Managed Portfolios and the managed retirement accounts offered through Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson that we calculate as a percentage of assets under management.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	Overall, revenue tied to asset-based fees accounted for about 12% of our consolidated revenue in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	We frequently invoice our clients and collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	As a result, we use some of this cash to fund our operations and invest in new product development.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	The businesses we acquired over the past several years have similar business models, and as a result, we acquired their deferred revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P9_S3	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and totaled $146.3 million as of December 31, 2010 and $127.1 million as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P9_S4	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill the service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our business requires significant investments to create and maintain proprietary databases and content.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	We strive to leverage these costs by selling a wide variety of products and services to multiple investor segments, through multiple media, and in many geographical markets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	In general, our businesses have high fixed costs, and we expect our revenue to increase or decrease more quickly than our expenses.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S3	We believe that while the fixed costs of the investments in our business are relatively high, the variable cost of adding customers is considerably lower, particularly as a significant portion of our products and services focus on Internet-based platforms and assets under management.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S4	At times, we will make investments in building our databases and content that will hurt our short-term operating results.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S5	During other periods, our profitability will improve because we re able to increase revenue without increasing our cost base at the same rate.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P10_S6	When revenue decreases, however, the significant operating leverage in our business may reduce our profitability.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	We classify our operating expense into separate categories for cost of goods sold, development, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and depreciation and amortization, as described below.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	We include stock-based compensation expense, as appropriate, in each of these categories.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	This category includes compensation expense for employees who produce the products and services we deliver to our customers.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	For example, this category covers production teams and analysts who write investment research reports.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	Cost of goods sold also includes other expense such as postage, printing, and CD-ROM replication, as well as shareholder servicing fees for Morningstar Managed Portfolios.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	This category includes compensation expense for programmers, designers, and other employees who develop new products and enhance existing products.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	In some cases, we capitalize the compensation costs associated with certain development projects.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	This reduces the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	We amortize these capitalized costs over the estimated economic life of the software, which is generally three years, and include this expense in depreciation and amortization.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our sales teams, product managers, and other marketing professionals.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	We also include the cost of advertising, direct mail campaigns, and other marketing programs to promote our products.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	This category consists mainly of compensation expense for each segment s management team, as well as human resources, finance, and support employees for each segment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	The category also includes compensation expense for senior management and other corporate costs, including corporate systems, finance and accounting, legal, and facilities expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Our capital expenditures consist of computers, leasehold improvements, and capitalized product development costs related to certain software development projects.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful life of the asset, which ranges from three to seven years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P17_S3	We amortize capitalized product development costs over their estimated economic life, which is generally three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P17_S4	We also include amortization related to intangible assets, which is mainly driven by acquisitions, in this category.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated economic useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	We have majority-owned operations in 24 countries outside of the United States and include these in our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	We account for our minority-owned investments in Japan and Sweden using the equity method.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	When our analysts evaluate a stock, they focus on assessing the company s estimated intrinsic value the value of the company s future cash flows, discounted to their worth in today s dollars.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	Our approach to evaluating our own business works the same way.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	Our goal is to increase the intrinsic value of our business over time, which we believe is the best way to create value for our shareholders.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	We do not make public financial forecasts for our business because we want to avoid creating any incentives for our management team to make speculative statements about our financial results that could influence the stock price, or to take actions that help us meet short-term forecasts but may not be in the long-term interest of building shareholder value.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	We provide three specific measures that can help investors generate their own assessment of how our intrinsic value has changed over time:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	Revenue (including organic revenue); Operating income (loss); and Free cash flow, which we define as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Organic revenue is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	We define organic revenue as consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions and foreign currency translations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	We present organic revenue because we believe it helps investors better compare our period-to-period results, and our management team uses this measure to evaluate the performance of our business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	Free cash flow is also considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P26_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and should not be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P26_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	To evaluate how successful we ve been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue, we calculate a retention rate.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	We use two different methods for calculating retention.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	For subscription-based products (including our print newsletters, Morningstar.com Premium Membership service, and Principia software), we track the number of subscriptions retained during the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S3	For products sold through contracts and licenses, we use the contract value method, which is based on tracking the dollar value of renewals compared with the total dollar value of contracts up for renewal during the period.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S4	We include changes in the contract value in the renewal amount, unless the change specifically results from adding a new product that we can identify.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S5	We also include variable-fee contracts in this calculation and use the previous quarter s actual revenue as the base rate for calculating the renewal percentage.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P27_S6	The retention rate excludes setup and customization fees, migrations to other Morningstar products, and contract renewals that were pending as of January 31, 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	We monitor developments in the economic and financial information industry on an ongoing basis.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	We use these insights to help inform our company strategy, product development plans, and marketing initiatives.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	Following a strong market rebound in 2009, the U.S. market gained 16.8% in 2010, as measured by Morningstar s U.S. Market Index, a broad market index.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	Most global markets also had positive returns for the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P29_S2	Morningstar s Global Ex-U.S. Index rose 12.6%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	Total U.S. mutual fund assets rose to $11.8 trillion as of December 31, 2010, compared with $11.1 trillion as of December 31, 2009, based on data from the Investment Company Institute (ICI).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Although aggregate cash flows to mutual funds were strong for the year, investors continued to heavily favor fixed-income funds rather than equity funds.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	U.S. stock funds had negative net cash flows for the year, although less so than in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	Global mutual fund assets showed a similar trend, with total assets increasing but asset flows favoring fixed-income funds.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	The number of mutual funds in the United States continued to contract slightly to about 7,600 in 2010 (excluding multiple share classes) from 7,700 in 2009, based on data from the ICI.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	The number of global mutual funds increased to about 69,000 as of September 30, 2010, compared with 66,000 as of September 30, 2009, based on ICI data.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	We estimate that hedge funds included in Morningstar s database had about $3 billion in net inflows through November 30, 2010, compared with $51 billion in net outflows for the same period in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	ETFs continued to increase in popularity relative to traditional mutual funds.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	The U.S. ETF industry closed out 2010 with nearly $1 trillion in assets under management based on Morningstar s data, up from about $780 billion at the end of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	Based on data from Nielsen/Net Ratings, aggregate page views and the time spent per visit for financial and investment sites in 2010 both declined by about 20% compared with 2009, while the number of unique visitors was down about 10%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	We believe these trends reflect individual investors lower level of interest in financial- and investment-related content in the wake of the market downturn.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	Metrics such as pages viewed per visit and time spent per visit also declined for Morningstar.com in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	Despite these trends, we believe online advertising spending by financial services companies rose sharply in 2010 after reductions in 2008 and 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	Magna, a division of Interpublic Group, estimates that global online advertising revenue rose about 7% across all industries in 2010, following a 3% decline in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	In the wake of the global financial crisis, regulators continued to implement new rules for financial services companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	One of the significant developments in Asia last year was the introduction of new regulations and requirements to enforce additional risk disclosures on investment products.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	Regulators introduced new documents such as the Key Facts Statements in Hong Kong and Product Highlights Sheets in Singapore in 2010 to enhance product transparency and to set an overall disclosure standard for investment product documents.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P37_S3	We ve continue to enhance our database and products to help our clients meet these new regulations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	In Australia, there are numerous regulatory reviews underway related to industry-wide standards for the superannuation industry, as well as fiduciary standards and compensation structures for financial advisors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	While we expect these reviews to put pressure on pricing for product providers and result in further consolidation, we believe the superannuation guarantee rates will support continued asset growth.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	We believe these trends, along with an emphasis on independent research, continue to make Australia an attractive market for Morningstar and other third-party research providers.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	In the European Union, Undertakings for Collective Investments in Transferable Securities (UCITS) is a set of EU Directives designed to enable funds to operate across the EU based upon authorization from one state regulator.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	UCITS IV, approved by the European Parliament in January 2009 and coming into effect in July 2011, is largely designed to reduce inefficiencies that exist within the current UCITS III framework.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	The directive includes several key sections, including requirements for a new Key Investor Information Document (KIID), an easy-to-read annual factsheet that replaces the Simplified Prospectus.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Every UCITS fund that is promoted to retail investors will have to produce a KID and issue an updated copy within the first 25 business days of each calendar year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	We ve developed prototype documents for the KID and expect to begin providing this service in 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	We re also monitoring the EU Transparency Directive.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	One of the key features of this piece of legislation concerns the disclosure of significant holdings of and by companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	This Directive has contributed to our expansion of the global ownership database, with additional coverage in Germany, France, and the United Kingdom.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P43_S2	We are reviewing the newly published EU Commission report on the Directive and potential revisions to the major shareholder obligations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	The United Kingdom s Retail Distribution Review (RDR), which emphasizes increased regulation of advisory fees, higher professional standards for financial advisors, and an emphasis on whole of market investment solutions, is scheduled to come into effect at the end of 2012.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Because advisors will be obligated to give clients a choice of all investment vehicles (including funds, ETFs, and other products) and demonstrate that they consider different investment options without bias, we believe it may increase the business need for investment information on multiple investment types, which we offer through products such as Morningstar Direct and Morningstar Advisor Workstation.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	In the United States, President Obama signed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act into law in July 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	The Act creates a number of new regulatory, supervisory, and advisory bodies and touches on the regulation of virtually every aspect of U.S. financial markets and activities.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P46_S2	The Act also left numerous matters to be addressed through rulemaking and other regulatory action, giving the regulators significant discretion in many areas.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P46_S3	As a result, the final shape and effect of the legislation are continuing to emerge.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	Aside from corporate governance and disclosure requirements that apply to all public companies generally, we believe the portion of the Act that is the most relevant to Morningstar is subtitle C of Title IX, which contains changes to the regulatory framework for credit rating agencies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	This section subjects Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organizations (NRSROs), including Realpoint, the subsidiary we acquired in May 2010, to greater oversight by the SEC.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	Among other things, it requires the SEC to remove the current exemption in Regulation FD for credit rating agencies, allows investors to bring private rights of action against credit rating agencies for failing to conduct a reasonable investigation of the facts or to obtain analysis from an independent source, and repeals Rule 436(g) under the Securities Act of 1933, which exempted credit rating agencies from being considered experts subject to liability for ratings included in registration statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	However, the SEC issued a no-action letter regarding the repeal of Rule 436(g) and extended the letter indefinitely.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	Aside from subtitle C and the general corporate governance and disclosure requirements, we believe the majority of the Dodd-Frank Act and related regulations will not have a direct effect on Morningstar.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	However, we continue to monitor the potential impact of these regulations on our clients.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P49_S2	For example, the SEC recently recommended that regulators adopt rules requiring that broker-dealers be subject to a fiduciary standard, which would impose additional requirements on commission-based advisors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	Overall, we believe the uncertainty in the financial services sector continued easing throughout 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	With the exception of continued weakness in consumer discretionary spending, business trends steadily improved during the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	As discussed in more detail in the Consolidated Operating Income section below, during 2010 we continued phasing in some of the benefits and other compensation-related expenses we previously reduced.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	The list below summarizes the key accomplishments and challenges that our management team has highlighted related to our 2010 performance:
