1289419_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	We made solid progress building a base for our credit research business and now offer credit ratings and reports on more than 720 corporate credit issuers.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	We acquired Realpoint, a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization that specializes in commercial mortgage-backed securities.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	We expanded our analyst research and investment consulting work on exchange-traded funds, closed-end funds, alternative investments, 529 plans, and target-date funds all areas that have seen strong investor interest.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	We continued to expand our equity research business, doubling our client base in just one year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	We continued building out our global operations, establishing a presence in Brazil, Chile, Mexico, and Luxembourg.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	We also expanded our international investment research and consulting businesses by acquiring Aegis, Seeds Group, and OBSR.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	Morningstar Direct had a record year with more than 1,200 new licenses added globally.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	Both renewal rates for contract-based products and services and retention rates for subscription products rose substantially compared with 2009, reflecting improved business conditions and healthier sales trends across most of our product lines.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	Morningstar s board of directors approved a 5 cent per share initial quarterly dividend and a $100 million share repurchase program, allowing us to return a portion of our cash balance to shareholders.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Operating expense rose faster than revenue in 2010, leading to a 4.2 percentage point decline in our operating margin, in part because we restored some incentive compensation and benefits after reducing them in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	We have more work to do in fully integrating some of our acquisitions and rebranding many of these businesses under the Morningstar umbrella.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	While advertising sales on Morningstar.com rebounded strongly U.S. Premium Membership subscriptions were 8% lower year over year as individual investors have been slow to return to the stock market and remain cautious about discretionary spending.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	In 2010, we determined that the cumulative effect of adjustments related to prior periods were material, in aggregate, if recorded in our 2010 Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	These amounts related primarily to our accounting for deferred taxes and, to a lesser extent, to expense adjustments associated with vacant office space and rent for one of our office leases.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P63_S2	We evaluated the effects of these errors on our prior periods Consolidated Financial Statements, individually and in the aggregate, in accordance with the materiality guidance provided by the SEC staff, as included in SAB Topics 1M and 1N, and concluded that no prior period is materially misstated.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P63_S3	However, in accordance with the provisions of these SAB Topics, we restated our Consolidated Financial Statements, as of and for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P63_S4	Please see Note 2 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information concerning the restated financial information.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	As noted in How We Evaluate Our Business , we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	Please refer to the discussion on page 49 for more detail.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	Because we ve made several acquisitions in recent years, comparing our financial results from year to year is complex.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	To make it easier for investors to compare our results in different periods, we provide information on both revenue from acquisitions and organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding revenue from acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P65_S2	We include an acquired operation as part of our revenue from acquisitions for 12 months after we complete the acquisition.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P65_S3	After that, we include it as part of our organic revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	Consolidated organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	The table below shows the periods in which we included each acquired operation in revenue from acquisitions:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	In 2010, our consolidated revenue increased 15.9% to $555.4 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	We had $47.9 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions during the year, mainly reflecting additional revenue from Logical Information Machines, Inc. (LIM), Realpoint LLC (Realpoint), Old Broad Street Research Ltd. (OBSR), and Intech Pty Limited (Intech).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P69_S2	Acquisitions contributed about 10 percentage points to our consolidated revenue growth.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	Excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations, consolidated revenue increased by about $24.1 million, or 5.0%, in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	Higher revenue from Morningstar.com advertising sales, Morningstar Direct, and Licensed Data were the main drivers behind the revenue increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	These positive factors as well as smaller contributions from advisor software and our Investment Management products helped offset the loss of revenue associated with the Global Analyst Research Settlement (GARS), which ended in July 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P70_S3	We had equity research revenue of $12.5 million related to GARS in 2009 that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	In 2009, our consolidated revenue decreased 4.7% to $479.0 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P71_S1	We had about $29.6 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions during the year, mainly reflecting additional revenue from Tenfore Systems Limited (Tenfore, now referred to as Real-Time Data) as well as 10-K Wizard Technology, LLC (10-K Wizard), the equity research and data business from C.P.M.S. (CPMS), Intech (now referred to as Ibbotson Australia), Fundamental Data Limited (Fundamental Data), and others.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P71_S2	However, this was more than offset by lower organic revenue, largely reflecting a drop in revenue from Investment Consulting as well as lower Equity Research revenue related to GARS in the second half of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P71_S3	Investment Consulting revenue declined because two clients did not renew their contracts, one in October 2008 and the other in May 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations):
1289419_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	While organic revenue and acquisitions had the most significant impact on revenue in 2010, we also enjoyed a benefit from foreign currency translations, primarily in the first half of the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P73_S1	The Australian dollar and the Canadian dollar were the primary contributors to the currency benefit, partially offset by the Euro and, to a lesser extent, the British pound.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P73_S2	In contrast, currency translations reduced revenue by nearly $9.0 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	Organic revenue growth improved each quarter in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	Revenue from international operations increased as a percentage of total revenue in 2010 and 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P75_S1	Our non-U.S. revenue increased to 28.3% of consolidated revenue in 2010, compared with 27.0% in 2009 and 24.2% in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P75_S2	Several of our recent acquisitions have operations outside the United States.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P75_S3	The majority of our international revenue is from Europe, Australia, and Canada.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P75_S4	Acquisitions contributed $17.0 million to international revenue in 2010 and $23.4 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	Foreign currency translations increased revenue by approximately $4.4 million in 2010, reversing the trend from 2009, when foreign currency translations had a negative impact of $9.0 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P76_S1	Excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations, our non-U.S. revenue rose 5.2% in 2010 and declined 5.5% in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	International organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P77_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P77_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	The tables below present a reconciliation from international revenue to international organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations):
1289419_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	Our five largest products based on revenue Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar.com, and Morningstar Direct made up about 59% of consolidated revenue in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P79_S1	While the percentage of revenue made up by our top five products has remained relatively consistent over the past three years, the relative size of products within the top five has changed each year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P79_S2	Licensed Data became our largest product in 2008 and has remained in that position in 2010 and 2009, partly because of incremental revenue from acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	Beginning in 2010, we included revenue from Ibbotson s plan sponsor advice service as Retirement Advice revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P80_S1	Previously, we included this revenue in Investment Consulting.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P80_S2	In 2010 and 2009, as a part of the changes to our organizational structure with a focus on our global product lines, we no longer include Morningstar Site Builder as part of Morningstar Advisor Workstation.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	Site Builder consists of a set of integrated tools, content, and reports that investment firms can seamlessly add to their existing advisor websites.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P81_S1	In addition, we re continuing to globalize the Premium subscriptions and advertising revenue generated by Morningstar.com websites, which operate in a variety of markets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P81_S2	As a result, we now include advertising revenue for all non-U.S. sites as part of Morningstar.com and have reclassified prior-year product revenue for consistency with current-year presentation.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	These reclassifications did not have any impact on the order of our top five products in 2009 or 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business , we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we ve been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	The following graph illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average renewal rate was between 90% and 95% and increased about 13 percentage points from 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P84_S1	The 2009 renewal rate was depressed partly because of the end of the Global Analyst Research Settlement period.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P84_S2	Excluding this factor, the 2010 renewal rate rose about 6 percentage points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P84_S3	This improvement reflects higher renewal rates for many product lines, including Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, institutional software, and advisor software.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P85_S0	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes and changes to the contract value upon renewal, as well as changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P86_S0	In 2010, we estimate that our retention rate for subscription-based products, such as Principia, Morningstar.com Premium Membership service, and print and online newsletters, was on the higher end of the range between 65% and 70%, up from 55% to 60% in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P86_S1	The change mainly reflects improved retention rates for individual software and Principia.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P87_S0	In 2010, our consolidated operating expense increased $80.0 million, or 22.6%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P87_S1	We completed seven acquisitions in 2010 and six in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P87_S2	Because of the timing of these acquisitions, our results include operating expense that did not exist in the same periods last year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P87_S3	Incremental operating expense from acquired businesses represented more than half of the operating expense increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P87_S4	In 2010, we restored some compensation and employee benefits after reducing them in 2009, contributing to the operating expense increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	Higher salary expense represented slightly more than one-third of the total operating expense increase, reflecting higher headcount from acquisitions and filling open positions, as well as salary increases made in July 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	We had approximately 3,225 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2010, a 23.8% increase from 2,605 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P89_S1	We added about 125 employees through acquisitions over the 12 months ending December 31, 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P89_S2	The remainder of the increase in headcount mainly reflects continued hiring for our development centers in China and India.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	Higher incentive compensation and employee benefit costs represented approximately 40% of the overall operating expense increase in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	In early 2010, we began phasing in some of the benefits and other compensation-related expense we reduced in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	As a result, bonus expense increased $16.3 million, or 77.6%, in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S3	Sales commissions increased $7.8 million in 2010, reflecting improved sales activity compared with 2009 as well as a change to one of our commission plans.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S4	Matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States increased $3.5 million in 2010 because we partially reinstated this employee benefit in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S5	In addition, healthcare benefit costs rose $2.8 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P90_S6	Operating expense in 2010 also included $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	Intangible amortization expense increased $5.9 million compared with 2009, reflecting additional amortization expense from recent acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	While operating expense generally increased in 2010, we recorded $9.5 million of operating expense in 2009 related to adjusting the treatment of some incentive stock options and penalties related to the timing of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P92_S1	In addition, the recorded expense related to increasing liabilities for vacant office declined by $2.2 million compared with the amount recorded in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue increased 4.2 percentage points in 2010, as the 22.6% increase in operating expense outpaced the 15.9% increase in revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	Our consolidated operating expense decreased $9.3 million, or 2.5%, in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P94_S1	To better align operating expense with revenue in a challenging business environment, we took a number of steps to reduce costs beginning in 2008, with the largest cutbacks effective January 1, 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P94_S2	We changed our bonus plan in 2009 to reduce bonus expense, our single largest discretionary cost.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P94_S3	As a result, bonus expense was down about $28.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P94_S4	The significant reduction in bonus expense also reflects a slowdown in our financial performance in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	We also suspended matching contributions to our 401(k) program in the United States, which reduced operating expense by about $6.6 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	In addition, we reduced discretionary spending on travel, advertising, and marketing.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P95_S2	Travel costs were about $4.5 million lower in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P95_S3	Advertising and marketing costs declined by $4.3 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P95_S4	In addition, we discontinued three publications previously published, which contributed to lower marketing expense in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	The positive impact of these cost reductions was partially offset by incremental costs from acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P96_S1	We completed six acquisitions in 2009 and six in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P96_S2	Because of the timing of these acquisitions, our 2009 results include operating expense that did not exist in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P96_S3	Headcount and salary expense increased year over year, partly because of incremental employees added through acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	We had approximately 2,605 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2009, a 9.7% increase from 2,375 employees as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P97_S1	We added approximately 170 employees through acquisitions over the 12 months ending December 31, 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P97_S2	The remainder of the increase in headcount reflects continued hiring for our development center in China.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	The cost reductions we implemented in 2009 were offset by a total of $9.5 million of operating expense for two separate matters.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	First, we recorded a $6.1 million operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options that were originally considered incentive stock options (ISOs).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	In 1998, 1999, and 2000, we granted ISOs to many employees.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	Upon exercise, ISOs typically have a favorable tax treatment for the employee relative to the tax treatment for non-qualified stock options (NQSOs).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	In 2009, we determined that certain ISOs granted to one former and two current executives should have been treated as NQSOs for the executives and our income tax purposes.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P100_S2	As a result, Morningstar paid these individuals a total of $4.9 million to compensate for the difference in tax treatment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P100_S3	We also recorded $1.2 million, primarily for potential penalties related to this matter.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P100_S4	This $6.1 million expense is included in our operating expense as a general and administrative expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	Second, we recorded an operating expense of $3.4 million for penalties related to the timing of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P101_S1	The expense impacted each of our operating expense categories, with approximately half recorded as general and administrative expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	For some companies, including Morningstar, it is common practice for taxes withheld on stock-based compensation to be paid with the company s regularly scheduled payroll deposit.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P102_S1	This approach, however, does not technically comply with Internal Revenue Service (IRS) guidelines concerning deposits of taxes withheld in connection with stock-based compensation, which generally require that if a company s cumulative deposit liability for all compensation exceeds $100,000, the tax withholding must be deposited by the following business day.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P102_S2	Transactions related to stock-based compensation frequently cause companies to exceed this threshold outside of their regularly scheduled payroll cycles, thus triggering the accelerated deposit rules.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	The subject of tax deposit penalties was part of an IRS audit that began in 2009 and concluded in early 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P103_S1	We have concluded the matter with the IRS and have increased the frequency of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P103_S2	Operating expense in 2009 also included additional rent expense of $3.2 million to increase a liability related to vacant office space, primarily for the former Ibbotson headquarters.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P103_S3	We increased the liability because we anticipated receiving lower sublease income and expected it would take more time than previously estimated to identify a tenant.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	Despite significant reductions to bonus expense, operating expense as a percentage of revenue increased 1.6 percentage points in 2009, mainly driven by the $9.5 million of incremental operating expense described above and other expense increases.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	Cost of goods sold is our largest category of operating expense, accounting for more than one-third of our total operating expense over the past three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P105_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and cost of goods sold includes the compensation expense for employees who produce our products and services.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	Cost of goods sold rose $28.5 million in 2010 after declining $1.5 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P106_S1	Approximately 60% of the increase in 2010 was related to recent acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P106_S2	Higher salaries, bonus expense, and other compensation-related expense also contributed to the increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P106_S3	The majority of the decline in 2009 was driven by lower bonus expense and lower fulfillment expense, partially offset by incremental costs from acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	Gross margin declined by about 1.4 and 1.0 percentage points in 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S0	Development expense increased $10.8 million in 2010 after declining $1.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S1	The increase in 2010 is mainly because of higher salaries, bonus, and compensation-related expense for our development teams.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S2	Development expense from recent acquisitions also contributed to the increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S3	We had approximately 760 employees included in development expense as of December 31, 2010 compared with 540 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S4	In 2010, we capitalized approximately $0.8 million of operating expense for software development, partially offsetting the increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P108_S5	The majority of the decline in 2009 was driven by lower bonus expense, partially offset by incremental costs from acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P109_S0	As a percentage of revenue, development cost was up slightly from the same periods in 2009 and 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $23.7 million in 2010, after declining $9.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S1	Higher sales commission expense, which rose $7.8 million in 2010, was the largest factor behind the increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S2	Commission expense rose partly because of improved sales activity.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S3	In addition, we recognized more expense in 2010 because of a change in our U.S. sales commission structure.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S4	Under this new commission plan, we record the entire commission expense in the quarter in which it is incurred.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S5	Under the previous commission structure, we recognized the commission expense over the term of the customer contract.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P110_S6	Other costs in this category, including salaries and bonuses, and, to a lesser extent, advertising, marketing, and travel, also increased.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	Approximately one-fourth of the increase in sales and marketing expense was related to recent acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P112_S0	Sales and marketing expense decreased $9.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P112_S1	Lower bonus expense and advertising and marketing were the two largest factors driving this change, with each contributing about 40% of the decline.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P113_S0	We reduced advertising and marketing from higher levels in 2008 because of the challenging business environment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P113_S1	In 2009, we also discontinued three of the publications we previously published in the first quarter of each year Morningstar Funds 500 , Morningstar Stocks 500 , and Morningstar ETFs 150 and therefore didn t incur costs to promote these publications.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P113_S2	Reduced spending on travel, training, and conferences also contributed to the decrease, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense increased about 2.2 percentage points in 2010, following a slight decrease in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P115_S0	General and administrative (G A) expense increased $9.2 million in 2010 following a decline of $1.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P115_S1	Bonus expense, salaries, and other compensation-related expense contributed to the increase in 2010, as did incremental expense related to acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P115_S2	G A expense in 2010 also includes $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	While most G A expense rose in 2010, certain G A expense recorded in 2009 did not recur in 2010, including the $6.1 million of operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options as well as $1.8 million of operating expense recorded to G A expense for the deposit penalty.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P116_S1	Expenses related to liabilities for vacant office space were $2.2 million lower in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	In 2009, G A expense decreased $1.9 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P117_S1	Most of the decline reflects lower bonus expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P117_S2	Decreases in travel, training, and conferences also contributed to lower expense in this area, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P117_S3	These cost reductions were partially offset by the operating expense related to the two matters mentioned above, which contributed $7.9 million to general and administrative expense in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	As a percentage of revenue, G A expense decreased 0.8 percentage points in 2010 and increased 0.5 percentage points in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	Depreciation expense rose $1.8 million in 2010 and $3.7 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P119_S1	The increase in 2010 reflects incremental expense from acquisitions and accelerated depreciation expense related to our existing office space in China, in advance of moving into new office space.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P119_S2	The increase in 2009 was primarily from higher depreciation expense associated with our new corporate headquarters in Chicago.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P119_S3	Amortization expense increased $5.9 million in 2010 and $2.3 million in 2009, reflecting amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization expense increased 0.4 percentage points in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost for the remaining life of the assets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P121_S1	Based on acquisitions completed through December 31, 2010, we estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be $25.7 million in 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P121_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by changes to the preliminary purchase price allocations associated with our 2010 acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	Stock-based compensation expense mainly relates to grants of restricted stock units (RSUs) and, beginning in 2010, includes expense related to restricted stock.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	Our stock-based compensation expense related to RSUs has increased over the past three years, reflecting annual grants.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P123_S1	We began granting RSUs in May 2006 and have made additional grants each year since then.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P123_S2	We recognize the expense related to RSUs over the vesting period, which is generally four years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P123_S3	We estimate forfeitures for these awards and typically adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience in the second quarter, which is when most of our larger equity grants typically vest.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P123_S4	We have not recorded any significant changes to stock-based compensation related to these adjustments.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	Restricted Stock: Beginning in 2010, we began recording expense related to restricted stock issued with the acquisition of Realpoint.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	In May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares that will vest over five years from the date of grant.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	This grant resulted in an expense of approximately $1.2 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P124_S3	We amortize this value to stock-based compensation expense ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P124_S4	We have assumed that all of the restricted stock will ultimately vest, and therefore haven t incorporated a forfeiture rate in this portion of our stock-based compensation expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	Stock options: Stock-based compensation expense related to stock options has declined over the past three years, as stock options granted in previous years were fully vested as of January 1, 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	Stock-based compensation expense is included in each of our operating expense categories, as shown below:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	Based on grants made through December 31, 2010, we anticipate that total stock-based compensation expense will be $13.5 million in 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P127_S1	This amount is subject to change based on additional equity grants or changes in our estimated forfeiture rate related to these grants.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	Bonus expense, which we include in each of our operating expense categories, increased $16.3 million in 2010 after declining $28.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	We reduced our bonus expense in 2009 as part of our efforts to better align our cost structure with revenue in the challenging business environment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P128_S2	In 2010, we reinstated a portion of the bonus expense that was previously reduced.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P128_S3	Bonus expense for newly acquired operations also contributed to the increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P129_S0	Overall, bonus expense as a percentage of revenue increased about 2.3 percentage points in 2010 and represents about 6.7% of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P129_S1	In 2009, bonus expense declined to 4.4% of revenue, compared with 9.9% in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P129_S2	The significant reduction in bonus expense also reflects a slowdown in our financial performance in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P129_S3	Prior to 2009, bonus expense represented approximately 10% to 12% of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	The amount of bonus expense is not a fixed cost.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P130_S1	Instead, the size of the bonus pool varies each year based on a number of items, including changes in full-year operating income relative to the previous year and other factors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P130_S2	We review and update our estimates and the bonus pool size quarterly.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P130_S3	We record bonus expense throughout the year and pay out annual bonuses to employees in the first quarter of the following year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	Consolidated operating income fell $3.6 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P131_S1	While revenue increased $76.4 million, our cost base rose more, leading to lower operating income.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P131_S2	The decline in operating income reflects higher incentive compensation, including higher bonus expense and sales commissions, modest compensation increases during the second half of 2010, and reinstating some of the employee benefits and other expenses we reduced in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P131_S3	In 2010, costs rose across all of our operating expense categories, with the exception of a $9.5 million operating expense recorded in 2009 that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P132_S0	With operating expense increasing more than revenue, our operating margin was 4.2 percentage points lower in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P132_S1	The margin decline mainly reflects higher compensation, bonuses, sales commissions, and employee benefits as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P132_S2	The loss of revenue from GARS also had a negative effect on margins.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P132_S3	Acquisitions represented approximately 2 percentage points of the margin decline for the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	Consolidated operating income decreased $14.2 million in 2009, as the $23.5 million decline in revenue was partially offset by a $9.3 million reduction in operating expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	We took a number of steps to reduce our cost structure in 2009 mainly by reducing employee benefit costs and bonus expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P134_S1	We reduced our single largest discretionary cost, bonus expense, by $28.9 million, with changes to the bonus plan in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P134_S2	We also suspended matching contributions to our 401(k) program in the United States, which accounted for about $6.6 million of expense in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P135_S0	While we reduced operating expense in several areas with these cost-savings initiatives, we also recorded a total of $9.5 million of unanticipated expense for two separate matters, including $6.1 million of operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of incentive stock options granted in previous years and $3.4 million of operating expense for penalties related to the timing of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	Because operating expense declined at a slower pace than revenue, the 2009 operating margin was down about 1.6 percentage points from 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	The $9.5 million of operating expense described above represented about 2 percentage points of the margin decline.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P137_S0	We define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P137_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P137_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P138_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P138_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P139_S0	We generated positive free cash flow in 2010, 2009, and 2008 as our cash provided by operating activities has consistently exceeded our level of capital expenditures, as shown below:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P140_S0	Free cash flow increased $19.8 million in 2010 after declining $11.9 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P140_S1	Cash provided by operating activities and capital expenditures followed similar trends, increasing in 2010 after declining in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P141_S0	Cash provided by operating activities : Cash provided by operating activities increased $22.2 million in 2010, mainly because cash paid in 2010 for bonuses was lower than in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P141_S1	We made bonus payments of $21.4 million in the first quarter of 2010, compared with $58.9 million in the first quarter of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P141_S2	The positive cash flow impact of a lower bonus payment was partially offset by $4.9 million in payments we made to one former and two current executives related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options (ISOs).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P141_S3	We recorded the operating expense related to this matter in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S0	Cash provided by operating activities decreased $48.1 million in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S1	The decline in cash provided by operating activities reflects a lower cash benefit from accrued compensation as well as an increase of $9.6 million for bonus payments.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S2	We made bonus payments of $58.9 million in the first quarter of 2009, compared with $49.3 million in the first quarter of 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S3	Bonuses paid in the first quarter of 2009 included $10.0 million in payments deferred from 2007.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S4	We revised our bonus program in January 2009 and no longer defer payment of a portion of bonuses recorded in the prior year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S5	In addition, cash provided by operating activities in 2008 included a $18.9 million benefit from deferred rent, primarily for tenant improvement allowances related to the construction of our new corporate headquarters.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S6	This benefit did not recur in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P142_S7	Excess tax benefits declined $17.9 million in 2009 because of a reduction in the number of options exercised and lower average stock prices on the exercise dates.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P143_S0	To provide investors with additional insight into our financial results, we provide a comparison between the change in consolidated net income and the change in cash provided by operating activities:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P144_S0	In 2010, cash provided by operating activities increased more than consolidated net income.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P144_S1	The $37.5 million decrease in bonuses paid in 2010 compared with 2009 was the primary driver behind the difference between net income and cash provided by operations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P145_S0	In 2009, cash provided by operating activities declined more than consolidated net income.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P145_S1	Deferred rent of $18.9 million, primarily for tenant improvement allowances received in connection with the build-out of our new headquarters in Chicago, benefited cash flow in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P145_S2	The tenant improvement allowance received in 2008 is being amortized as a reduction in office lease expense over the lease term and will be deducted from net income to arrive at cash provided by operating activities.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P145_S3	The $18.2 million increase in tax payments, the $9.6 million increase in bonuses paid in 2009, and a lower cash flow benefit from accrued compensation, primarily reflecting the reduction in the 2009 bonus expense, also contributed to the difference between net income and cash from operations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P146_S0	FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , requires that we classify excess tax benefits as a financing activity, which contributes to the difference between net income and cash from operations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P146_S1	In 2010, 2009, and 2008 we classified $7.5 million, $8.7 million, and $26.6 million of excess tax benefits, respectively, as financing activities.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P146_S2	We describe these excess tax benefits in the Liquidity and Capital Resources section.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P147_S0	Capital expenditures : We spent $14.8 million for capital expenditures in 2010, primarily for computer hardware and leasehold improvements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P147_S1	A significant portion of the capital expenditures in 2010 are for new office space in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P147_S2	This new office facility was substantially completed in early 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P147_S3	In 2009, capital expenditures were $12.4 million, a decrease of $36.1 million from 2008 mainly because of the timing of payments related to our new corporate headquarters in Chicago.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P148_S0	The Investment Information segment includes all of our data, software, and research products and services, which are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P149_S0	The largest products in this segment based on revenue are Morningstar Licensed Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar.com, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Site Builder and Licensed Tools, and Morningstar Principia.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P150_S0	Licensed Data is a set of investment data spanning all of our investment databases and available through electronic data feeds.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P151_S0	Advisor Workstation is a web-based investment planning system for advisors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P151_S1	Advisor Workstation is available in two editions: Morningstar Office for independent financial advisors and an enterprise edition for financial advisors affiliated with larger firms.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P152_S0	Morningstar.com includes both Premium Memberships and Internet advertising sales.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P153_S0	Morningstar Direct is a web-based institutional research platform.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P153_S1	Site Builder and Licensed Tools are services that help institutional clients build customized websites or enhance their existing sites with Morningstar s online tools and components.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P154_S0	Principia is our CD-ROM-based investment research and planning software for advisors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P154_S1	The Investment Information segment also includes Morningstar Equity Research, which we distribute through several channels.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P155_S0	From June 2004 through July 2009, our equity research was distributed through six major investment banks to meet the requirements for independent research under the Global Analyst Research Settlement (GARS).
1289419_11_ITEM7_P155_S1	The period covered by GARS ended in July 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P156_S0	Although the banks covered by GARS are no longer required to provide independent research to their clients, we entered into equity research contracts with two of the banks that were clients under GARS.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P156_S1	We also sell equity research to several other companies that purchase our research for their own use or provide our research to their affiliated financial advisors or to individual investors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P156_S2	In addition, we re continuing to provide broad equity coverage to individual investors, financial advisors, and institutions through a variety of other channels.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P156_S3	In 2010, we replaced approximately one-third of the lost annual GARS revenue with other equity research business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P157_S0	In December 2009, we began publishing research and ratings on corporate credit issuers.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P157_S1	We entered into our first credit research agreement with a major financial services firm to provide credit ratings and research to its 18,000 financial advisors beginning in the third quarter of 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P157_S2	The firm s internal credit research team also has access to Morningstar Select, our institutional credit research platform.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P157_S3	Although the revenue impact in 2010 was not significant, we believe this credit research agreement gives us an important foothold in this new area.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P158_S0	We also offer a variety of financial communications and newsletters, other investment software, and investment indexes.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P159_S0	This segment represented approximately 80% of our consolidated revenue in 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P160_S0	Revenue from our Investment Information segment increased $58.3 million, or 15.1%, to $445.0 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P160_S1	Acquisitions contributed $40.4 million of revenue in 2010 primarily from LIM, Realpoint, OBSR, and CPMS.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P160_S2	Revenue from acquisitions represents approximately 10 percentage points of the revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P160_S3	Excluding acquisitions, higher revenue in our software, data, and investment research products and services more than offset the loss of $12.5 million of revenue from GARS, which expired at the end of July 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P160_S4	Organic revenue for our software product lines was up approximately $18.2 million, driven by Morningstar.com, Morningstar Direct, and to a lesser extent from Advisor Workstation and Site Builder and Licensed Tools.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S0	In 2009, revenue for our Investment Information segment declined $4.1 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S1	Acquisitions contributed $25.9 million to segment revenue in 2009, partially offsetting the $30.0 million revenue decline experienced across a number of our product lines, including the loss of $9.4 million of GARS revenue in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S2	Revenue from our investment research products was down $17.2 million, or 24.1%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S3	Approximately $9.4 million of the decrease resulted from the end of GARS and an additional $3.2 million of the decrease reflects lower revenue from investment newsletters.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S4	Organic revenue for software product lines was down about $5.1 million, or 2.2%, driven by a $6.4 million decline in the U.S. version of Morningstar.com and a $0.3 million revenue decline in advisor software.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P161_S5	These declines were partly offset by a $2.4 million revenue increase for institutional software and data-related products and services.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P162_S0	Revenue for Morningstar.com, which includes Internet advertising sales and Premium Membership subscriptions, was the primary driver of the segment revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S0	In 2010, positive trends in Internet advertising sales were partially offset by continued decline in Premium Membership revenue in the United States.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S1	Internet advertising increased 76.2% in 2010, after declining 36.9% in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S2	Subscriptions for the U.S. version of the Morningstar.com Premium service declined to 138,732 as of December 31, 2010 compared with 150,473 as of December 31, 2009, and 177,518 as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S3	The shortfall in revenue was due to a weak trial pipeline but we believe our retention efforts stemmed the rate of decline in subscriptions in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S4	In addition, we moderately increased subscription prices for U.S. Premium Membership in both January 2010 and 2009, which partly offset the revenue decline associated with lower subscription levels.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S5	Morningstar Direct made positive contributions to segment revenue in both 2010 and 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S6	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to 4,773 worldwide as of December 31, 2010, compared with 3,524 as of December 31, 2009 and 2,961 as of December 31, 2008, with strong growth in the U.S. and internationally.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P163_S7	The growth in licenses reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients, as well as client migrations to Morningstar Direct from Institutional Workstation.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P164_S0	Advisor software revenue represented approximately 25.9% of the increase in segment revenue in 2010 as higher revenue from Advisor Workstation and Site Builder and Licensed Tools offset the decline in Principia revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P164_S1	In comparison, advisor software revenue was down in 2009 because lower Principia revenue more than offset the increase in Advisor Workstation and other products.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P164_S2	Principia revenue declined 6.6% in 2010 and 14.3% in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P164_S3	The decline partly reflects clients migrating from Principia to Advisor Workstation.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P165_S0	The number of U.S. licenses for Morningstar Advisor Workstation increased slightly to 153,170 as of December 31, 2010 from 148,392 as of December 31, 2009 and 151,874 as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P165_S1	Principia subscriptions totaled 32,681 as of December 31, 2010, down from 35,844 as of December 31, 2009 and 43,019 as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P166_S0	Licensed Data made positive contributions to segment revenue in both 2010 and 2009, reflecting strong renewal rates and new client contracts.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P167_S0	The Licensed Data service gives institutions access to a full range of proprietary investment data spanning numerous investment databases, including real-time pricing data.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P167_S1	The data packages we offer include proprietary statistics, such as the Morningstar Style Box and Morningstar Rating, and a wide range of other data, including information on investment performance, risk, portfolios, operations data, fees and expenses, cash flows, and ownership.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P168_S0	Investment research revenue declined in 2010 as well as in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P169_S0	As mentioned above, the period covered by GARS expired at the end of July 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P169_S1	Our post-settlement equity research revenue in 2010 replaced approximately one-third of the annual GARS revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P169_S2	GARS revenue was $12.5 million in 2009, compared with $21.9 million in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P170_S0	We entered into new equity research contracts with two of the banks that were clients under GARS.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P170_S1	In addition, we re continuing to provide broad equity coverage to individual investors, financial advisors, and institutions through a variety of other channels.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P171_S0	Revenue from our other investment research products was essentially flat in 2010 after declining in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P171_S1	In 2010, higher revenue from conferences and corporate credit ratings research helped offset the continuing decline in revenue from newsletters and books.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P172_S0	In the first quarter of 2009, we discontinued three of the print publications we previously published in the first quarter of each year: Morningstar Funds 500 , Morningstar Stocks 500 , and Morningstar ETFs 150 .
1289419_11_ITEM7_P172_S1	Lower advertising revenue from publications sold in Australia and lower revenue from the annual Morningstar Investment Conference held in the second quarter also contributed to the decline in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P173_S0	In 2010, operating income for the Investment Information segment decreased $10.7 million, or 7.7%, as operating expense increased more than revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P174_S0	Operating expense was up $69.0 million in 2010, with additional costs from acquisitions contributing approximately 45% of the increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P174_S1	Higher salaries (reflecting expanded headcount) and incentive compensation (including bonus and sales commission expense) also contributed to the increase.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P174_S2	Bonus expense increased $10.9 million in 2010, including incremental bonus expense from recent acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P174_S3	An increase in employee benefits expense, including employee healthcare benefits and the partial reinstatement of matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, also contributed to the increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P175_S0	Operating margin for the Investment Information segment declined 7.1 percentage points in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P175_S1	Approximately 6.4 percentage points of the margin decline reflects higher compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P176_S0	Acquisitions had a slightly negative impact on the margin.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P177_S0	In 2009, operating income for the Investment Information segment was $138.4 million, a slight decrease compared with 2008, as the $4.1 million decline in revenue was partially offset by lower operating expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P178_S0	Operating expense decreased $3.8 million in 2009 as cost reductions for bonuses, other compensation expense, and advertising and marketing were partially offset by additional operating expense from acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P178_S1	Bonus expense declined $11.0 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P178_S2	Most of this reduction reflects the changes we made to our bonus program for 2009 as part of our efforts to better align our cost structure with revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P178_S3	The reduction in bonus expense also reflects a slowdown in our financial performance in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P178_S4	Other compensation-related expense was down, primarily because we suspended matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, reducing operating expense by $4.3 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P179_S0	Sales and marketing costs decreased $8.3 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P179_S1	Most of the decline reflects lower spending on advertising and marketing (primarily direct mail expense) and lower travel costs, which we pared back because of the challenging business environment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P179_S2	As mentioned above, we discontinued three of the publications we previously published in the first quarter of each year, and therefore didn t incur costs to promote these publications in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P180_S0	The Investment Management segment includes all of our asset management operations, which operate as registered investment advisors and earn more than half of their revenue from asset-based fees.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P181_S0	The key products and services in this segment based on revenue are Investment Consulting, which focuses on investment monitoring and asset allocation for funds of funds, including mutual funds and variable annuities; Retirement Advice, including the Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson platforms; and Morningstar Managed Portfolios, a fee-based discretionary asset management service that includes a series of mutual fund, exchange-traded fund, and stock portfolios tailored to meet a range of investment time horizons, risk levels, and investment strategies that financial advisors can use for their clients taxable and tax-deferred accounts.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P182_S0	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P182_S1	The method of calculation varies by client; some contracts include provisions for calculating average assets based on daily data, while others use weekly or monthly data.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P182_S2	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P183_S0	Our Investment Consulting business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P183_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves investment management or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P183_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P183_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P184_S0	In our Retirement Advice business, our contracts may include fixed fees for advice and guidance, one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P185_S0	We do not disclose a fee range for our Investment Consulting and Retirement Advice businesses because our fee structures are customized by client.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P185_S1	In addition, we believe disclosing a fee range would be detrimental to our competitive position.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P185_S2	We disclose changes in the nature of the underlying services we provide or their associated fee structures (for example, a change from flat fees to asset-based fees) in our periodic filings to the extent that they are material to our financial results.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P186_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s average daily account balance.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P186_S1	Fees for our mutual fund and ETF portfolios generally range from 30 to 40 basis points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P186_S2	We charge 55 basis points for our customized stock portfolios.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P187_S0	This segment represented approximately 20% of our consolidated revenue in 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P188_S0	Investment Management segment revenue increased $18.0 million, or 19.5%, in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P188_S1	Acquisitions contributed $7.5 million of revenue in 2010, primarily from the Intech and OBSR acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P188_S2	Excluding acquisitions, revenue increased across all product categories in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P189_S0	Retirement Advice was the main driver of the revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P189_S1	We primarily earn license-based fees for the advice and guidance services we provide through our Retirement Advice platform.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P189_S2	Revenue for these services increased in 2010 primarily from Advice by Ibbotson, after declining in 2009 because of several smaller client non-renewals.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P189_S3	Investment Consulting and Managed Portfolios also contributed to the revenue increase in 2010, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P189_S4	Higher revenue from Investment Consulting in 2010 was partially offset by a client non-renewal that occurred in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S0	The revenue increase in 2010 represented a positive change from trends in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S1	In 2009, Investment Management revenue was down 17.4%, driven by two Investment Consulting non-renewals.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S2	In 2009, Investment Consulting, which was a leading contributor to revenue growth in previous years, accounted for about three-fourths of the segment s revenue decline.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S3	One client did not renew its contract when it expired in the fourth quarter of 2008 and another client did not renew its contract in May 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S4	Combined, these contracts represented about $17 million of revenue in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P190_S5	Acquisitions contributed $3.7 million to segment revenue in 2009, partially mitigating the revenue decline.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P191_S0	We had approximately $67.7 million in revenue from asset-based fees in 2010, an increase of approximately 21% compared with $56.0 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P191_S1	In 2008, revenue from asset-based fees was $66.6 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P191_S2	Revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 12% of consolidated revenue in both 2010 and 2009, down slightly from 13% in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P191_S3	Within the Investment Management segment, revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 60% of segment revenue over the past three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P192_S0	Total assets under advisement and management were $132.9 billion as of December 31, 2010, an increase from $82.6 billion as of December 31, 2009 and $78.8 billion as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P192_S1	About $39.0 billion of the total assets as of December 31, 2010 reflects a new fund-of-funds program that began in May 2010 for an existing Morningstar Associates client.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P192_S2	Previously, Morningstar created model portfolios for the same client, so the increase in assets represents incremental growth for an existing revenue stream.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P192_S3	Excluding assets from the new fund-of-funds program, total assets under advisement and management increased, mainly reflecting positive market performance.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P192_S4	Total assets under advisement also include approximately $3.4 billion from the Intech acquisition in July 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P193_S0	The asset totals as of the end of each year don t fully reflect the change in average asset levels during the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P193_S1	The asset-based fees we earn are primarily based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P193_S2	Average assets under advisement and management (calculated based on available quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $102.3 billion in 2010, up about 35% from $78.6 billion in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P193_S3	In 2009, average asset levels declined from substantially higher levels in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P193_S4	Average assets under advisement and management were $103.9 billion in 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P194_S0	We provided Investment Consulting advisory services on approximately $107.2 billion in assets as of December 31, 2010, compared with approximately $61.4 billion as of December 31, 2009 and approximately $66.2 billion as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P194_S1	The asset totals include relationships for which we receive basis-point fees, including consulting arrangements and other agreements where we act as a portfolio construction manager for a mutual fund or variable annuity.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P194_S2	We also provide Investment Consulting services for some assets under management for which we receive a flat fee; we do not include these assets in the total reported above.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P195_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P196_S0	As mentioned above, assets under advisement as of December 31, 2010 includes approximately $39 billion related to a new fund-of-funds program that began in May 2010 for an existing Morningstar Associates client.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P196_S1	Excluding assets from the new fund-of-funds program, assets under advisement for Investment Consulting increased slightly over 2009, mainly reflecting positive market performance partially offset by a client non-renewal that occurred in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P196_S2	Total assets under advisement for Investment Consulting as of December 31, 2009 declined approximately 7.3% compared with December 31, 2008, as assets under advisement from Morningstar Associates declined 27.4%, which was partially offset by assets under advisement from Ibbotson Associates, which increased about 9.0%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P196_S3	The majority of the asset decline in 2009 reflects the loss of one of the contracts discussed above, partially offset by positive market performance, and, to a lesser extent, from net inflows and new client wins in assets under advisement.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P197_S0	We cannot separately quantify cash inflows and outflows for these portfolios because we do not have custody of the assets in the majority of our investment management business.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P197_S1	The information we receive from our clients does not separately identify the impact of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P197_S2	We also cannot precisely quantify the impact of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P198_S0	Assets under management for Retirement Advice increased to $19.6 billion as of December 31, 2010, compared with $15.7 billion as of December 31, 2009 and $11.0 billion as of December 31, 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P199_S0	We cannot separately quantify the factors affecting assets under management for our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P199_S1	These factors primarily consist of employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P199_S2	We cannot quantify the impact of these other factors because the information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances due to market movement.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P200_S0	The tables below show the breakdown of retirement plan participants who had access to the services offered through Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson, as well as the number of plan sponsors and plan providers that provide this access.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P201_S0	Morningstar Managed Portfolios also contributed to the segment s revenue increase in 2010, although to a lesser extent than Retirement Advice.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P201_S1	The higher revenue mainly reflects higher average asset levels during 2010 compared with 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P201_S2	Assets under management for Morningstar Managed Portfolios were $2.7 billion as of December 31, 2010 compared with $2.1 billion as of December 31, 2009 and $1.6 billion as of December 31, 2008, reflecting positive equity market returns and net inflows.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P202_S0	In 2010, operating income for the Investment Management segment increased $3.9 million, or 7.4%, as revenue increased more than operating expense.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P202_S1	In contrast, 2009 operating income declined $7.5 million, or 12.4%, as reductions in operating expense were not sufficient enough to outweigh the revenue decline.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S0	In 2010, operating expense in this segment rose $14.1 million, or 35.8%, after declining $11.9 million, or 23.2%, in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S1	Approximately 40% of the segment s operating expense increase reflects recent acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S2	Higher salaries and incentive compensation, including bonuses and sales commissions, contributed approximately two-thirds of the overall operating expense increase in this segment.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S3	Bonus expense rose $4.2 million in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S4	Sales commissions and employee benefits, including employee healthcare benefits and matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, also increased, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S5	Operating expense in 2010 also includes $2.0 million related to a separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P203_S6	A slight reduction in product implementation fees related to our Advice by Ibbotson service partially offset these increases.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S0	In 2009, the operating expense decrease was primarily because of lower bonus and other compensation-related expense, partially offset by additional operating expense related to the Intech acquisition.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S1	Bonus expense declined $10.4 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S2	Most of this reduction reflects the changes we made to our bonus program for 2009 as part of our efforts to better align our cost structure with revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S3	The reduction in bonus expense also reflects a slowdown in our financial performance in 2009 compared with 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S4	Other compensation-related expense was down, primarily because we suspended matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, reducing operating expense by $1.3 million in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P204_S5	A slight reduction in product implementation fees related to our Advice by Ibbotson service also contributed to the decrease.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P205_S0	The segment s operating margin in the segment decreased 5.8 percentage points to 51.5% in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P205_S1	The margin decline mainly reflects higher bonus expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P205_S2	The $2.0 million separation payment reduced the margin by approximately 2.0 percentage points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P205_S3	Salaries and employee benefits also contributed to the margin decline, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P205_S4	In addition, acquisitions had a negative impact on the margin of approximately 1.6 percentage points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P206_S0	Operating margin was 57.3% in 2009, an increase of 3.3 percentage points over 2008.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P206_S1	Lower bonus expense as a percentage of revenue was the main driver of the margin improvement.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P206_S2	The decrease in other compensation-related expense also contributed to the margin improvement, although to a much lesser extent.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P206_S3	These factors were offset by incremental costs from the Intech acquisition and higher compensation expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P207_S0	We do not allocate corporate costs to our business segments.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P207_S1	The corporate items category also includes amortization expense related to intangible assets recorded when we allocate the purchase price of acquisitions.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P207_S2	The table below shows the components of corporate items that impacted our consolidated operating income:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S0	Amortization of intangible assets increased $5.9 million in 2010 and $2.4 million in 2009, mainly reflecting incremental amortization expense related to acquisitions completed in 2010 and 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S1	We paid $281.9 million for acquisitions during the past three years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S2	As of December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, respectively, we had $169.0 million and $135.5 million of net intangible assets.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S3	We amortize these intangible assets over their estimated lives, ranging from one to 25 years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S4	Based on acquisitions completed through December 31, 2010, we estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be approximately $25.7 million in 2011.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P208_S5	Some of the purchase price allocations are preliminary, and the values assigned to intangible assets and the associated amortization expense may change in future periods.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P209_S0	After increasing $3.5 million in 2009, depreciation expense for corporate departments did not change significantly in 2010 from 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P209_S1	We relocated to our new corporate headquarters in the fourth quarter of 2008, resulting in higher depreciation expense in the subsequent years.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P210_S0	In 2010, corporate unallocated expense decreased $8.9 million, as some expenses recorded in 2009 did not recur in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P210_S1	Corporate unallocated expense in 2009 includes $9.5 million of expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options and deposit penalties.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P210_S2	In 2010, expense related to liabilities for vacant office space declined $2.2 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P210_S3	In addition, in 2010 we capitalized approximately $0.8 million of operating expense for software development.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P210_S4	These factors, which favorably impact the year-over-year comparison, were partially offset by incremental expense from acquisitions, higher compensation and bonus expense, and higher professional fees.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P211_S0	Corporate unallocated increased $0.7 million in 2009 as certain expenses recorded in 2009 more than offset the expense reductions implemented in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P211_S1	The increases included the $6.1 million of operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options, as well as an operating expense for the deposit penalty of $3.4 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P211_S2	This category also includes a $3.2 million expense to increase lease vacancy reserves, primarily for the former Ibbotson headquarters.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P212_S0	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities includes our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK) and Morningstar Sweden AB.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P212_S1	In the first six months of 2010, this category also included our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Denmark.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P212_S2	In 2009 and 2008, this category also included our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Denmark and Morningstar Korea.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P212_S3	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities is primarily from our position in MJKK.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P213_S0	In 2010, we acquired an additional 75% ownership interest in Morningstar Denmark, increasing our ownership percentage to 100%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P213_S1	As a result, we no longer account for our investment in Morningstar Denmark using the equity method.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P214_S0	In July 2010, we began consolidating the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of Morningstar Denmark in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P215_S0	In 2009, we acquired an additional 40% ownership interest in Morningstar Korea, increasing our ownership percentage to 80%.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P215_S1	As a result, we no longer account for our investment in Morningstar Korea using the equity method.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P216_S0	In September 2009, we began consolidating the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of Morningstar Korea in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P217_S0	We describe our investments in unconsolidated entities in more detail in Note 8 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P218_S0	The following table presents the components of net non-operating income:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P219_S0	Interest income, net mainly reflects interest from our investment portfolio.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P219_S1	Net interest income decreased $0.6 million in 2010 and $2.7 million during 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P219_S2	The decrease in both years reflects lower returns on our invested balances during the year.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P220_S0	Other income, net primarily represents foreign currency exchange gains and losses arising from the ordinary course of business related to our U.S. and non-U.S. operations.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P220_S1	It also includes royalty income from MJKK and realized gains and losses from our investment portfolio.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P220_S2	In 2010, we recorded a holding gain of approximately $4.6 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P220_S3	This gain represents the difference between the estimated fair value and the book value of our investment in Morningstar Denmark at the date of acquisition.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P220_S4	In 2009, we recorded a holding gain of approximately $0.4 million when we increased our ownership in Morningstar Korea.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P221_S0	The following table summarizes our effective tax rate:
1289419_11_ITEM7_P222_S0	For a reconciliation of the U.S. federal tax rate to our effective income tax rate, refer to Note 15 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P223_S0	In 2010, our effective tax rate was 33.1%, a decrease of 3.2 percentage points compared with 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P223_S1	The lower tax rate in 2010 reflects the positive impact of certain income tax benefits, including the difference between U.S. federal and foreign tax rates, tax credits related to Morningstar s research and development activities, and the use of foreign net operating losses that had previously been subject to a valuation allowance.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P223_S2	These items favorably impacted our effective tax rate by approximately 3.7 percentage points in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P224_S0	Income tax expense in 2010 includes approximately $1.7 million of non-cash expense related to the $4.6 million holding gain we recorded in conjunction with the acquisition of Morningstar Denmark.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P224_S1	This income tax expense did not have a significant impact on our effective tax rate in 2010.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P225_S0	In 2009, our effective tax rate decreased by 1.5 percentage points compared with 2008 despite several items that increased our effective tax rate.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P225_S1	State income taxes represented 2.7 percentage points of our effective tax rate compared with 1.5 percentage points in 2008, due to a favorable impact from reducing accruals for state income taxes in 2008 that did not recur in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P226_S0	Second, in 2009, we recorded an operating expense of $3.4 million for penalties related to the timing of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P226_S1	This penalty is not deductible for income tax purposes and increased our effective tax rate by 1.1 percentage points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P227_S0	The $6.1 million of operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of stock options originally considered incentive stock options increased the effective tax rate by 0.8 percentage points, as these operating expenses are subject to deduction limitations for income tax purposes.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P228_S0	The above items, which increased our effective tax rate, were partially offset by three main factors.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P229_S0	First, research and development and foreign tax credits, some from previous years, reduced the 2009 effective tax rate by 2.5 percentage points.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P229_S1	A reversal of reserves for uncertain tax positions, primarily as a result of a lapse in the statute of limitations, also reduced our effective tax rate by 1.4 percentage points in 2009.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P230_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we had net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards of $49.0 million related to our non-U.S. operations and have recorded a valuation allowance against all but $5.6 million of these NOLs.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P230_S1	Because of the historical operating losses for certain non-U.S. operations, a valuation allowance is required because we do not believe that we will be able to use all of our non-U.S. NOLs.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P231_S0	Certain positions we have taken or intend to take on our U.S. and non-U.S. tax returns may be reviewed by tax authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P231_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we had approximately $9.1 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $8.5 million, if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $6.9 million.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P232_S0	It is not possible to estimate the impact of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P233_S0	We anticipate that our effective income tax rate may continue to fluctuate related to the creation or reversal of valuation allowances for our non-U.S. operations as well as to changes in unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P234_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations, will be sufficient to meet our operating and cash needs for the foreseeable future.
1289419_11_ITEM7_P235_S0	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments, consisting primarily of fixed-income securities.
