1289419_12_ITEM7_P46_S1	To make it easier for investors to compare our results in different periods, we provide information on both organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations, and revenue from acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	We include an acquired operation as part of our revenue from acquisitions for 12 months after we complete the acquisition.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	After that, we include it in organic revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	Consolidated organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P49_S1	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	The table below shows the period in which we included each acquired operation in revenue from acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	In 2011, our consolidated revenue increased 13.7% to $631.4 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	We had $15.3 million in incremental revenue during 2011 from acquisitions completed in 2010, mainly reflecting incremental revenue from Morningstar Credit Ratings (formerly Realpoint LLC) and, to a lesser extent, from the annuity intelligence business of Advanced Sales and Marketing Corporation (ASMC) and Old Broad Street Research Ltd. (OBSR).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P51_S2	Acquisitions contributed about 2.8 percentage points to our consolidated revenue growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P51_S3	Currency movements also had a positive effect, contributing approximately 1.8 percentage points to revenue growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	The Australian dollar, and to a lesser extent, the British pound, the euro, and the Canadian dollar, were the primary contributors to the currency benefit.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	Excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations, our consolidated revenue increased by $50.6 million , or 9.1% , in 2011 , with increases across all major product lines.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	Leading the growth were Morningstar Direct, our institutional research platform, and Investment Consulting, followed by Morningstar Integrated Web Tools, Licensed Data, and Advisor Workstation.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P53_S2	Internet advertising from Morningstar.com, Retirement Solutions, and Structured Credit Ratings also contributed to the organic revenue increase, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	On February 17, 2012, a large Investment Consulting client notified us that it will be moving to in-house management of several fund of funds portfolios in April 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	We received about $12.4 million in revenue from our work on these portfolios in 2011, which represented 2% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	In 2010, our consolidated revenue increased 15.9% to $555.4 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	We had $47.9 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions during the year, mainly reflecting additional revenue from Logical Information Machines (LIM), Structured Credit Ratings, OBSR, and Intech Pty Limited (Intech).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P55_S2	Acquisitions contributed about 10 percentage points to our consolidated revenue growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	While organic revenue and acquisitions had the most significant impact on revenue in 2010, we also enjoyed a benefit of about $4.4 million from foreign currency translations, primarily in the first half of the year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Australian dollar and the Canadian dollar were the primary contributors to the currency benefit, partially offset by the euro and, to a lesser extent, the British pound.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P57_S1	In contrast, currency translations reduced revenue by nearly $9.0 million in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	Excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations, consolidated revenue increased by about $24.1 million, or 5.0% in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	Higher revenue from Morningstar.com advertising sales, Morningstar Direct, and Licensed Data were the main drivers behind the revenue increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P58_S2	These positive factors as well as smaller contributions from advisor software and our Investment Management products helped offset the loss of revenue associated with the Global Analyst Research Settlement (GARS), which ended in July 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P58_S3	We had equity research revenue of $12.5 million related to GARS in 2009 that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations):
1289419_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	Revenue from international operations increased as a percentage of total revenue in 2011 and 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	Our non-U.S. revenue increased to 29.3% of consolidated revenue in 2011, compared with 28.3% in 2010 and 27.0% in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	Several of our 2010 and 2009 acquisitions have operations outside the United States.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	The majority of our international revenue is from Europe, Australia, and Canada.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	Acquisitions contributed $5.6 million to international revenue in 2011 and $17.0 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	Foreign currency translations also had a positive effect on international revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	Foreign currency translations increased revenue by $10.1 million in 2011 and $4.4 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P62_S2	Excluding acquisitions and the effect of foreign currency translations, non-U.S. revenue rose 7.7% in 2011 and 5.2% in 2010, reflecting stronger product sales in Europe.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	In Japan, we have a majority-owned subsidiary, Ibbotson Associates Japan K.K., and hold a minority ownership position in Morningstar Japan K.K.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	Neither of these operations experienced significant disruption as a result of the Great East Japan Earthquake that occurred in March 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	International organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P64_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	The tables below present a reconciliation from international revenue to international organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions and the impact of foreign currency translations):
1289419_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	Our five largest products based on revenue--Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar.com, and Morningstar Direct--made up about 59% of consolidated revenue in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	While the percentage of revenue made up by our top five products has remained relatively consistent over the past three years, the relative size of products within the top five has changed each year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P66_S2	Licensed Data has been our largest product for the last three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	Beginning in 2011, as a part of the new Investment Management organization structure, we reviewed the revenue classification between our Investment Consulting and Retirement Solutions products.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	We reclassified the prior-year information for consistency with the current-year presentation.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	This reclassification changed the order of Advisor Workstation and Investment Consulting in our top five products in 2010, but did not have any effect on the order of our top five products in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business, we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	The following graph illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Licensed Data, Investment Consulting, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average renewal rate was between 90% and 95%, within the same range as 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P69_S1	While aggregate renewal rates were broadly similar for both years, renewal rates for some larger products, including Licensed Data and Morningstar Advisor Workstation, were slightly lower compared with the previous year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P69_S2	These declines were offset by slightly higher renewal rates for institutional software, Investment Consulting, and Retirement Solutions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes and changes to the contract value upon renewal, as well as changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	In 2011, we estimate that our retention rate for subscription-based products, such as Principia, Morningstar.com Premium Membership service, and print and online newsletters, was on the higher end of the range between 65% and 70%, consistent with 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	In 2011 , our consolidated operating expense increased $58.7 million or 13.5% .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	We completed seven acquisitions in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P73_S1	Because of the timing of these acquisitions, our results include operating expense that did not exist in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P73_S2	Incremental operating expense from acquired businesses represented approximately $13.4 million, or 23%, of the increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	Higher salary expense represented approximately 55%, or $32.0 million, of the total operating expense increase in 2011, reflecting additional headcount from hiring in 2011 and the full-year salary impact of 2010 new hires, and, to a lesser extent, additional headcount from acquisitions completed in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P74_S1	Salary adjustments that were effective in July 2011 also contributed to the increase in salary expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	We review employee salaries annually and generally implement salary adjustments in the third quarter.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	We had approximately 3,465 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2011 , compared with 3,225 as of December 31, 2010 and 2,605 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P76_S1	About half of the increase in headcount in 2011 reflects continued hiring for our development centers in China and India, with most of the remainder in the United States.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P76_S2	The headcount growth includes about 30 employees hired in July 2011 in Chicago as part of the Morningstar Development Program, a two-year rotational training program for entry-level college graduates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Incentive compensation and employee benefit costs represented approximately 24%, or $14.1 million, of the overall operating expense increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P77_S1	The increase in incentive compensation included higher bonus expense and an increase in sales commissions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P77_S2	The increase in bonus expense was partially offset because bonuses paid in the first quarter were $0.4 million lower than the amount accrued in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P77_S3	Although the net difference was $0.4 million, there were some greater differences by cost category, which we describe below.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P77_S4	Sales commission expense was up $2.8 million, primarily in the United States and Europe.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	In 2011, we reinstated some of the benefits we temporarily suspended in previous years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P78_S1	This included increasing the matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, representing $2.3 million of additional expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	Higher production expense, travel, and rent expense also contributed to the increase in operating expense, although to a lesser extent than the compensation-related items discussed above.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P79_S1	Higher data purchases for our operations in the U.S. and Europe contributed to the $4.2 million growth in production expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P79_S2	The $1.5 million increase in rent expense primarily reflects higher rent for our new office space in Shenzhen, China, and, to a lesser extent, for our office space in Chicago.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P79_S3	Our 2010 results included an expense of $1.0 million to increase liabilities for vacant office space.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P79_S4	This expense did not recur in 2011, partially offsetting the higher rent expense in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	Intangible amortization expense increased $2.4 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P80_S1	The increase primarily reflects amortization expense from 2010 acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P80_S2	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	Our 2011 results includes $3.2 million of expense for a previously announced separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	Operating expense in 2010 included $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P81_S2	This expense did not recur in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	We capitalized $5.3 million of operating expense in 2011, primarily for software development within the Structured Credit Ratings business, Morningstar Commodity Data, and for Morningstar Direct.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P82_S1	In 2010, we capitalized $0.8 million of operating expense for software development.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue decreased 0.1 percentage points in 2011, as the 13.7% increase in revenue slightly outpaced the 13.5% increase in operating expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	In 2010, our consolidated operating expense increased $80.0 million, or 22.6%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P84_S1	We completed seven acquisitions in 2010 and six in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P84_S2	Because of the timing of these acquisitions, our 2010 results include operating expense that did not exist in the same periods in the previous year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P84_S3	Incremental operating expense from acquired businesses represented more than half of the operating expense increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P84_S4	In 2010, we restored some compensation and employee benefits after reducing them in 2009, contributing to the operating expense increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	Higher salary expense represented slightly more than one-third of the total operating expense increase, reflecting higher headcount from acquisitions and filling open positions, as well as salary increases made in July 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	We had approximately 3,225 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2010, a 23.8% increase from 2,605 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	We added about 125 employees through acquisitions over the 12 months ending December 31, 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	The remainder of the increase in headcount mainly reflects continued hiring for our development centers in China and India.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	Higher incentive compensation and employee benefit costs represented approximately 40% of the overall operating expense increase in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	In early 2010, we began phasing in some of the benefits and other compensation-related expense we reduced in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S2	As a result, bonus expense increased $16.3 million, or 77.6%, in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S3	Sales commissions increased $7.8 million in 2010, reflecting improved sales activity compared with 2009 as well as a change to one of our commission plans.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S4	Matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States increased $3.5 million in 2010 because we partially reinstated this employee benefit in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S5	In addition, healthcare benefit costs rose $2.8 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P87_S6	Operating expense in 2010 also included $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	Intangible amortization expense increased $5.9 million compared with 2009, reflecting additional amortization expense from recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	While operating expense generally increased in 2010, we recorded $9.5 million of operating expense in 2009 related to adjusting the treatment of some incentive stock options and penalties related to the timing of deposits for taxes withheld on stock-option exercises that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	In addition, the recorded expense related to increasing liabilities for vacant office declined by $2.2 million compared with the amount recorded in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue increased 4.2 percentage points in 2010, as the 22.6% increase in operating expense outpaced the 15.9% increase in revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	Cost of goods sold is our largest category of operating expense, representing more than one-third of our total operating expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P91_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and cost of goods sold includes the compensation expense for employees who produce our products and services.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P91_S2	Approximately one-half of our employees are included in this cost category.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	Cost of goods sold rose $25.1 million in 2011 and $28.5 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S1	Approximately 20% of the increase in 2011 was related to 2010 acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S2	Higher salaries contributed approximately 50% of the total increase in 2011, primarily from additional headcount.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S3	Higher production expense of $4.2 million also contributed to the increase, primarily from higher data purchases for our operations in the U.S. and Europe.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S4	Higher bonus expense of $3.8 million for the 2011 annual bonus was offset by a $1.6 million reduction in bonus expense related to the prior year bonus because we paid a smaller portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in this category.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P92_S5	Please refer to the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	Approximately 60% of the increase in 2010 was related to recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	Higher salaries, bonus expense, and other compensation-related expense also contributed to the increase in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	Our gross margin declined by about 0.5 percentage points and 1.4 percentage points in 2011 and 2010, respectively, as expenses in this category increased at a faster rate compared with revenue growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	Development expense increased $3.9 million in 2011 and $10.8 million in 2010 mainly because of higher salaries and compensation-related expense and bonus expense for our development teams.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	We capitalized $5.3 million of operating expense in 2011 and $0.8 million in 2010 for software development, reducing the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P95_S2	Development expense from recent acquisitions also contributed to the increase in 2011 and 2010, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P96_S0	We had approximately 830 employees included in development expense as of December 31, 2011 compared with 760 as of December 31, 2010 and 540 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P97_S0	As a percentage of revenue, development expense was down slightly in 2011 , primarily reflecting the effect of capitalizing operating expense for software development.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P98_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $11.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P98_S1	Approximately 17% of the growth in sales and marketing expense in the year was related to recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P98_S2	Higher salary-related expense represents about 53% of the overall expense increase in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P98_S3	Higher sales commission expense, other compensation-related expenses, and travel expense also contributed to the increase in the year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P98_S4	Lower bonus expense partially offset the increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $23.7 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S1	Higher sales commission expense, which rose $7.8 million in 2010, was the largest factor behind the increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S2	Commission expense rose partly because of improved sales activity.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S3	In addition, we recognized more expense in 2010 because of a change in our U.S. sales commission structure.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S4	Under this new commission plan, we record the entire commission expense in the quarter in which it is incurred.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S5	Under the previous commission structure, we recognized the commission expense over the term of the customer contract.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S6	Other costs in this category, including salaries and bonuses, and, to a lesser extent, advertising, marketing, and travel, also increased.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P99_S7	Approximately one-fourth of the increase in sales and marketing expense was related to recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P100_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense was down in 2011 primarily reflecting lower bonus expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P101_S0	General and administrative expense (G A) rose $15.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P101_S1	Higher compensation-related expense including higher salaries, bonus expense, and other compensation-related expense contributed about 70% of the total increase in G A. Bonus expense included in G A increased $3.6 million in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P101_S2	In the first quarter of 2011, we paid a greater portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $2.6 million of the year-to-date increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P101_S3	Please refer to and the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P102_S0	Higher rent expense, mainly for our office space in China and for our office space in Chicago, also contributed to the growth in G A, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P103_S0	G A in 2011 includes a $0.8 million reduction in sales tax accruals and a $2.0 million business tax rebate for our operations in China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P103_S1	Partially offsetting these two items was $1.4 million of business tax expense related to prior years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P103_S2	G A in 2011 also includes $3.2 million of expense for a previously announced separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P103_S3	Our 2010 results include $1.0 million to increase liabilities for vacant office space and $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P103_S4	These two expenses did not recur in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P104_S0	G A expense increased $9.2 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P104_S1	Bonus expense, salaries, and other compensation-related expense contributed to the increase in 2010, as did incremental expense related to acquisition.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P104_S2	G A expense in 2010 also includes $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P105_S0	While most G A expense rose in 2010, certain G A expense recorded in 2009 did not recur in 2010, including the $6.1 million of operating expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options as well as $1.8 million of operating expense recorded to G A expense for the deposit penalty.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P105_S1	Expenses related to liabilities for vacant office space were $2.2 million lower in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P106_S0	G A as a percentage of revenue increased 0.4 percentage point in 2011 after declining 0.8 percentage points in 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P107_S0	Depreciation expense rose $0.8 million in 2011, primarily related to our new office space in China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P107_S1	Depreciation expense increased $1.8 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P107_S2	The increase in depreciation expense in 2010 reflects incremental expense from acquisitions and accelerated depreciation expense related to our existing office space in China, in advance of moving into new office space.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P108_S0	Amortization expense increased $2.4 million in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P108_S1	The increase in 2011 primarily reflects amortization expense from 2010 acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P108_S2	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P108_S3	Amortization expense increased $5.9 million in 2010, reflecting amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P109_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost for the remaining life of the assets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P109_S1	We estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be $23.8 million in 2012 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P109_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by changes to the preliminary purchase price allocations associated with additional acquisitions and currency translations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P110_S0	As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization expense was down slightly in 2011 and up slightly in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P111_S0	Stock-based compensation expense relates to grants of restricted stock units (RSUs), restricted stock, and stock options.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P112_S0	Our stock-based compensation expense related to RSUs has increased over the past three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P112_S1	We began granting RSUs in May 2006 and have made additional grants each year since then.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P112_S2	We recognize the expense related to RSUs over the vesting period, which is four years for employees and three years for non-employee directors.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P112_S3	We estimate forfeitures for these awards and typically adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience in the second quarter, which is when most of our larger equity grants typically vest.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P112_S4	The expense recorded in 2011 was favorably affected by $0.5 million for restricted stock units that were forfeited in the first quarter.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P113_S0	Restricted Stock: Beginning in 2010, we began recording expense related to restricted stock issued with the acquisition of Realpoint.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P113_S1	In May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares that will vest over five years from the date of grant.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P113_S2	The restricted stock vests ratably over a five-year period from the acquisition date and may be subject to forfeiture if the holder terminates his or her employment during the vesting period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P113_S3	The expense in 2011 includes $0.4 million for accelerated vesting of a portion of these restricted stock grants.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P114_S0	Stock options: In 2011, we granted 92,201 stock options to our executive officers and non-employee directors.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P114_S1	These stock options vest ratably over a four-year period for executive officers and a three-year period for non-employee directors and expire 10 years after the date of grant.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P114_S2	Using a Black-Scholes option pricing model, we estimated the fair value of these grants to be approximately $2.2 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P114_S3	We will amortize this value to stock-based compensation expense ratably over the options' vesting period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P115_S0	We estimate forfeitures of these awards and typically adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience in the second quarter, which is when most of our larger equity grants typically vest.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P115_S1	We describe our stock-based compensation in more detail in Note 10 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P115_S2	Stock-based compensation is included in each of our operating expense categories, as shown below:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P116_S0	Based on grants of RSUs, stock options, and restricted stock made through December 31, 2011 , we anticipate that stock-based compensation expense will be $13.9 million in 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P116_S1	This amount is subject to change based on additional equity grants or changes in our estimated forfeiture rate related to these grants.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P117_S0	The size of our bonus pool varies each year based on a number of items, including changes in full-year operating income relative to the previous year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P117_S1	We review and update our estimates and the bonus pool size quarterly.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P117_S2	We record bonus expense throughout the year and pay annual bonuses to employees in the first quarter of the following year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P118_S0	Bonus expense, which we include in each of our operating expense categories, increased $5.3 million in 2011 and $ 16.3 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P119_S0	We reduced our bonus expense in 2009 as part of our efforts to better align our cost structure with revenue in the challenging business environment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P119_S1	In 2010, we reinstated a portion of the bonus expense that was previously reduced.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P119_S2	Bonus expense for newly acquired operations also contributed to the increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P120_S0	Overall, bonus expense represented about 6.8% and 6.7% of revenue in 2011 and 2010, respectively, after declining to 4.4% in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P120_S1	Prior to 2009, bonus expense represented about 10% to 12% of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P121_S0	The amount of bonus expense is not a fixed cost.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P121_S1	Instead, the size of the bonus pool varies each year based on a number of items, including changes in full-year operating income relative to the previous year and other factors.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P121_S2	We review and update our estimates and the bonus pool size quarterly.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P121_S3	We record bonus expense throughout the year and pay out annual bonuses to employees in the first quarter of the following year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P122_S0	In 2011, the increase in the bonus expense consisted of 1) an increase of $5.7 million in bonus expense and 2) a difference of $0.4 million between the bonus amounts paid in 2011 (related to 2010 performance) compared with the annual bonus expense recorded in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P122_S1	The table below presents the effect of these two factors by cost category and in total:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P123_S0	Although in total the 2010 bonuses paid were $0.4 million lower compared with the amount expensed in 2010, there were some larger differences by cost category.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P123_S1	We paid a greater portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in the G A category compared with our initial estimate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P124_S0	Consolidated operating income increased $17.4 million in 2011 , and our margin was up slightly in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P124_S1	Our revenue growth of $76.0 million outpaced the increase in our costs of $58.7 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P125_S0	Capitalized operating expense for software development contributed 0.7 percentage points to our margin growth in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P125_S1	Higher salaries and other compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue partially offset the benefit of the capitalized operating expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P125_S2	In addition, acquisitions had a slight negative effect on the margin.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P126_S0	Consolidated operating income fell $3.6 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P126_S1	While revenue increased $76.4 million, our cost base rose more, leading to lower operating income.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P126_S2	The decline in operating income reflects higher incentive compensation, including higher bonus expense and sales commissions, modest compensation increases during the second half of 2010, and reinstating some of the employee benefits and other expenses we reduced in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P126_S3	In 2010, costs rose across all of our operating expense categories, with the exception of a $9.5 million operating expense recorded in 2009 that did not recur in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P127_S0	With operating expense increasing more than revenue, our operating margin was 4.2 percentage points lower in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P127_S1	The margin decline mainly reflects higher compensation, bonuses, sales commissions, and employee benefits as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P127_S2	The loss of revenue from the Global Analyst Research Settlement (GARS) also had a negative effect on margins.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P127_S3	Acquisitions represented approximately 2 percentage points of the margin decline for the year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P128_S0	As we mentioned on page 52, on February 17, 2012, a large Investment Consulting client notified us that it will be moving to in-house management of several fund of funds portfolios in April 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P128_S1	We received about $12.4 million in revenue from our work on these portfolios in 2011, which represented 2.0% of our consolidated revenue and a larger percentage of our operating income, as our consulting work generally doesn't involve significant variable costs.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P129_S0	As described in more detail above, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P129_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P129_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P130_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P130_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P131_S0	We generated positive free cash flow in in 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 as our cash provided by operating activities has consistently exceeded our level of capital expenditures, as shown below:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P132_S0	Free cash flow increased $33.0 million in 2011 and $19.8 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P133_S0	Cash provided by operating activities: Cash provided by operating activities increased $41.6 million in 2011 , reflecting the positive cash flow effect of changes in operating assets and liabilities and higher net income (adjusted for non-cash items), partially offset by a $16.1 million increase in bonuses paid in the first quarter of 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P133_S1	We made bonus payments of $37.5 million in the first quarter of 2011, compared with $21.4 million in the first quarter of 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P134_S0	Cash provided by operating activities increased $22.2 million in 2010, mainly because cash paid in 2010 for bonuses was lower than in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P134_S1	We made bonus payments of $21.4 million in the first quarter of 2010, compared with $58.9 million in the first quarter of 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P134_S2	The positive cash flow impact of a lower bonus payment was partially offset by $4.9 million in payments we made to one former and two current executives related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options (ISOs).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P134_S3	We recorded the operating expense related to this matter in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P135_S0	To provide investors with additional insight into our financial results, we provide a comparison between the change in consolidated net income and the change in operating cash flow:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P136_S0	In 2011 , the increase in cash from operations exceeded the change in net income adjusted for non-cash items, primarily because of the positive cash flow effect of accounts receivable, accrued compensation, and income taxes current.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P136_S1	In addition, the cash flow from operations in 2010 includes a $4.9 million payment related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options (ISOs).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P136_S2	This payment did not recur in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P136_S3	These items, which favorably impacted the year-over-year comparison, were partially offset by the increase in bonus payments in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P136_S4	Cash provided by operating activities in 2011 also reflects $4.1 million of payments for previously announced separation agreements with two former executives.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P137_S0	In 2010, cash provided by operating activities increased more than consolidated net income.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P137_S1	The $37.5 million decrease in bonuses paid in 2010 compared with 2009 was the primary driver behind the difference between net income and cash provided by operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P138_S0	FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , requires that we classify excess tax benefits as a financing activity, which contributes to the difference between net income and cash from operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P138_S1	In 2011 and 2010, we classified $9.5 million and $7.5 million , respectively, of excess tax benefits as financing activities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P138_S2	We describe these excess tax benefits in the Liquidity and Capital Resources section.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P139_S0	Capital expenditures: We spent $23.3 million for capital expenditures in 2011 , primarily for computer hardware and software, internally developed capitalized software, and leasehold improvements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P140_S0	We spent $14.8 million for capital expenditures in 2010, primarily for computer hardware and leasehold improvements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P140_S1	A significant portion of the capital expenditures in 2010 are for new office space in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P140_S2	This new office facility was substantially completed in early 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P141_S0	In 2011 , capital expenditures increased $8.6 million , primarily for capitalized software and computer hardware and software for our U.S. operations and for our development center in China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P142_S0	The Investment Information segment includes all of our data, software, and research products and services.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P142_S1	These products are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P143_S0	The largest products in this segment based on revenue are Licensed Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar.com, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Integrated Web Tools (formerly Morningstar Site Builder), and Morningstar Principia.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P144_S0	Licensed Data is a set of investment data spanning all of our investment databases, including real-time pricing data, and is available through electronic data feeds.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P145_S0	Advisor Workstation is a web-based investment planning system for advisors.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P145_S1	Advisor Workstation is available in two editions: Morningstar Office for independent financial advisors and an enterprise edition for financial advisors affiliated with larger firms.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P146_S0	Morningstar.com includes both Premium Memberships and Internet advertising sales.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P147_S0	Morningstar Direct is a web-based institutional research platform.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P147_S1	Morningstar Integrated Web Tools is a set of services that help institutional clients build customized websites or enhance their existing sites with Morningstar s online tools and components.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P148_S0	Principia is our CD-ROM-based investment research and planning software for advisors.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P149_S0	The Investment Information segment also includes Morningstar Equity Research, which we distribute through several channels.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P149_S1	We sell Morningstar Equity Research to companies that purchase our research for their own use or provide our research to their affiliated advisors or individual investor clients.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P150_S0	From June 2004 through July 2009, our equity research was distributed through six major investment banks to meet the requirements for independent research under the Global Analyst Research Settlement (GARS).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P150_S1	The period covered by GARS ended in July 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P151_S0	Although the banks covered by GARS are no longer required to provide independent research to their clients, we entered into equity research contracts with two of the banks that were clients under GARS.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P151_S1	In 2010, we replaced approximately one-third of the lost annual GARS revenue with other equity research business.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P152_S0	The segment also includes Morningstar Credit Research and Morningstar Structured Credit Ratings.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P152_S1	Morningstar Structured Credit Ratings is provided by Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC, a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization specializing in structured finance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P152_S2	It offers securities ratings, research, surveillance services, and data to help institutional investors identify risk in commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P153_S0	We also offer a variety of financial communications and newsletters, real-time data, and investment indexes.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P154_S0	This segment represented approximately 80% of our consolidated revenue in 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S0	In 2011 , Investment Information segment revenue increased $56.0 millions , or 12.6% , to $500.9 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S1	Acquisitions contributed $13.5 million of revenue in 2011 , primarily from Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC and to a lesser extent from ASMC, Denmark, and OBSR.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S2	Revenue from acquisitions represented approximately 3 percentage points of the revenue increase in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S3	Excluding acquisitions, our software, data, and investment research product lines all contributed to the revenue growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S4	Organic revenue for our software product lines was up $26.2 million, driven by Morningstar Direct, and to a lesser extent by Morningstar Integrated Web Tools, Advisor Workstation, and Morningstar.com.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P155_S5	Licensed Data and Morningstar Credit Ratings drove the growth in revenue in our data and investment research product lines, respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P156_S0	Revenue for our Investment Information segment increased $58.3 million , or 15.1% , to $445.0 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P156_S1	Acquisitions contributed $40.4 million of revenue in 2010, primarily from LIM, Realpoint, OBSR, and CPMS.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P157_S0	Revenue from acquisitions represented approximately 10 percentage points of the revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P157_S1	Excluding acquisitions, higher revenue in our software, data, and investment research products and services more than offset the loss of $12.5 million of revenue from GARS, which expired at the end of July 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P157_S2	Organic revenue for our software product lines was up approximately $18.2 million, driven by Morningstar.com, Morningstar Direct, and to a lesser extent from Advisor Workstation and Morningstar Integrated Web Tools.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P158_S0	Excluding acquisitions, Morningstar Direct was the largest contributor to the increase in segment revenue in 2011 and a primary contributor to segment revenue growth in 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P158_S1	Morningstar Direct contributed approximately 39% of the organic revenue growth for the segment in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P158_S2	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to 6,144 worldwide, compared with 4,773 as of December 31, 2010 and 3,524 as of December 31, 2009 , with strong growth in both the U.S. and internationally.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P158_S3	The growth reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients, and, to a lesser extent, from client migrations from both Institutional Workstation and Morningstar EnCorr to Morningstar Direct.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P159_S0	Advisor software revenue increased as higher revenue from Morningstar Integrated Web Tools and Advisor Workstation (mainly Morningstar Office) more than offset slightly lower Principia revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P159_S1	The number of U.S. licenses for Morningstar Advisor Workstation increased to 160,287 as of December 31, 2011 compared with 157,395 as of December 31, 2010 , and 150,473 as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P159_S2	The increase in the number of U.S. licenses compared with December 31, 2009 is partially due to incremental licenses added through our acquisition of ASMC.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P160_S0	Principia subscriptions totaled 31,270 as of December 31, 2011 , down from 32,681 as of December 31, 2010 and 35,844 as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S0	Revenue for Morningstar.com, which includes Internet advertising and Premium Membership subscriptions, also contributed to the growth in the segment's revenue in 2011 and was the primary driver of the segment revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S1	In both years, higher Internet advertising sales for Morningstar.com were partially offset by a continued decline in Premium Membership subscriptions revenue in the United States.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S2	Internet advertising revenue increased 21.8% in 2011 compared with 76.2% in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S3	Premium subscriptions for the U.S. version of Morningstar.com declined to 130,354 as of December 31, 2011 , compared with 138,149 as of December 31, 2010 and 150,473 as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S4	Premium subscriptions have continued declining because of a weak trial pipeline.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P161_S5	However, consistent with the trend over the past few years, we moderately increased subscription prices for U.S. Premium Membership in both January 2011 and 2010 , which partly offset the revenue decline associated with the lower subscription levels.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P162_S0	Licensed Data made positive contributions to segment revenue growth in both 2011 and 2010, reflecting strong renewal rates and new client contracts for managed products data.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P163_S0	Licensed Data gives institutions access to a full range of proprietary investment data spanning numerous investment databases, including real-time pricing data.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P163_S1	The data packages we offer include proprietary statistics, such as the Morningstar Style Box and Morningstar Rating, and a wide range of other data, including information on investment performance, risk, portfolios, operations data, fees and expenses, cash flows, and ownership.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P164_S0	Revenue for our investment research products was up in 2011 mainly because of Structured Credit Ratings and Research.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P164_S1	Within the structured credit ratings business, we had strong revenue growth earlier in the year driven by new issue rating assignments in the CMBS market.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P164_S2	In 2011, we rated 13 new issue CMBS deals, more than double the number in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P164_S3	However, mid-year market volatility and lower levels of investor risk tolerance had a negative effect on the pipeline of potential issues in the CMBS market during the second half of the year based on published industry reports.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P164_S4	Higher revenue for equity research and conferences also contributed to the growth in revenue for our investment research products, but were partially offset by a decline in newsletters revenue, primarily because of lower advertising sales for our trade magazines in Australia.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P165_S0	Investment research revenue declined in 2010 reflecting the loss of $12.5 million of revenue from GARS, which expired at the end of July 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P165_S1	Our post-settlement equity research revenue in 2010 replaced approximately one-third of the annual GARS revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P165_S2	We entered into new equity research contracts with two of the banks that were clients under GARS.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P165_S3	In addition, we're continuing to provide broad equity coverage to individual investors, financial advisors, and institutions through a variety of other channels.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P166_S0	Revenue from other investment research products was essentially flat in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P166_S1	Higher revenue from conferences and corporate credit ratings research helped offset the continuing decline in revenue from newsletters and books.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P167_S0	In 2011 , operating income for the Investment Information segment increased $3.8 million , or 3.0% , as revenue grew more than operating expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S0	Operating expense was up $52.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S1	Additional costs from acquisitions contributed approximately 18% of the increase in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S2	Higher salary-related expense and incentive compensation, including sales commission and bonus expense, contributed about 71% of the overall expense increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S3	Higher salary-related expense is from additional hiring in 2011 and the full-year salary impact of 2010 new hires, and, to a lesser extent, additional headcount from acquisitions completed in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S4	Salary adjustments that were effective in July 2011 also contributed to the increase in salary expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P168_S5	Higher employee benefits expense, including employee health benefits and matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, contributed about 9% of the increase in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P169_S0	The Investment Information segment's operating margin decreased 2.4 percentage points in 2011 , primarily from higher salary expense as a percentage of revenue, and, to a lesser extent, employee benefit expense and bonus expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P169_S1	Higher salary expense contributed 2.0 percentage points to the decline in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P170_S0	Acquisitions had only a minor effect on the segment margin.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P171_S0	In 2010, operating income for the Investment Information segment decreased $10.7 million, or 7.7%, as operating expense increased more than revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P172_S0	Operating expense was up $69.0 million in 2010, with additional costs from acquisitions contributing approximately 45% of the increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P172_S1	Higher salaries (reflecting expanded headcount) and incentive compensation (including bonus and sales commission expense) also contributed to the increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P172_S2	Bonus expense increased $10.9 million in 2010, including incremental bonus expense from recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P172_S3	An increase in employee benefits expense, including employee healthcare benefits and the partial reinstatement of matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, also contributed to the increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P173_S0	Operating margin for the Investment Information segment declined 7.1 percentage points in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P173_S1	Approximately 6.4 percentage points of the margin decline reflects higher compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P174_S0	Acquisitions had a slightly negative impact on the margin.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P175_S0	The Investment Management segment includes all of our asset management operations, which earn the majority of their revenue from asset-based fees.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P176_S0	The key products and services in this segment based on revenue are Investment Consulting, which focuses on investment monitoring and asset allocation for funds of funds, including mutual funds and variable annuities; Retirement Solutions, including the Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson platforms; and Morningstar Managed Portfolios, a fee-based discretionary asset management service that includes a series of mutual fund, ETF, and stock portfolios tailored to meet a range of investment time horizons, risk levels, and investment strategies that financial advisors can use for their clients taxable and tax-deferred accounts.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S0	Our Investment Consulting business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves managing investments or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S4	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S5	The method of calculation varies by client; some contracts include provisions for calculating average assets based on daily data, while others use weekly or monthly data.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P177_S6	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P178_S0	In our Retirement Solutions business, our contracts may include one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P178_S1	Our Retirement Solutions business also includes plan sponsor and custom target date consulting arrangements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P178_S2	Fees for these services may be based on the level of assets under advisement in these arrangements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P179_S0	We do not disclose a fee range for our Investment Consulting and Retirement Solutions businesses because our fee structures vary by client.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P179_S1	In addition, we believe disclosing a fee range would be detrimental to our competitive position.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P179_S2	We disclose changes in the nature of the underlying services we provide or their associated fee structures (for example, a change from flat fees to asset-based fees) in our periodic filings to the extent that they are material to our financial results.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P180_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s account balance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P180_S1	Fees for our mutual fund and ETF portfolios generally range from 30 to 40 basis points.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P180_S2	We charge fees of 55 basis points for our customized stock portfolios.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P181_S0	This segment represented approximately 20% of our consolidated revenue in 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 , respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S0	Investment Management segment revenue increased $20.1 million , or 18.2% , in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S1	Revenue from acquisitions was $1.9 million , primarily from the OBSR and Seeds acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S2	Excluding acquisitions, revenue was up across all three of our key product and service lines in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S3	Investment Consulting was the primary driver of the revenue increase.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S4	Higher revenue in the U.S. and to a lesser extent in Europe was partially offset by a decline in Investment Consulting revenue in Australia.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S5	Retirement Solutions and Managed Portfolios also contributed to the revenue increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S6	On February 17, 2012, a large Investment Consulting client notified us that it will be moving to in-house management of several fund of funds portfolios in April 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P182_S7	We received about $12.4 million in revenue from our work on these portfolios in 2011, which represented 9.5% of Investment Management segment revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P183_S0	Investment Management segment revenue increased $18.0 million, or 19.5%, in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P183_S1	Acquisitions contributed $7.5 million of revenue in 2010, primarily from the Intech and OBSR acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P183_S2	Excluding acquisitions, revenue increased across all product categories in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P184_S0	Retirement Solutions was the main driver of the revenue increase in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P185_S0	We primarily earn license-based fees for the advice and guidance services we provide through our Retirement Solutions platform.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P185_S1	Revenue for these services increased in 2010 primarily because of Advice by Ibbotson, after declining in 2009 because of several smaller client non-renewals.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P185_S2	Managed Portfolios and Investment Consulting also contributed to the revenue increase in 2010, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P185_S3	Higher revenue from Investment Consulting in 2010 was partially offset by a client non-renewal that occurred in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P186_S0	We had $81.7 million in revenue from asset-based fees in 2011, an increase of $14.0 million compared with $67.7 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P186_S1	In 2009, revenue from asset-based fees was $56.0 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P186_S2	Revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 13% of consolidated revenue in 2011, up slightly from 12% in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P186_S3	Within the Investment Management segment, revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 60% of segment revenue over the past three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S0	Total assets under advisement and management were $180.8 billion as of December 31, 2011 , an increase from $149.2 billion as of December 31, 2010 and $100.1 billion as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S1	About $22 billion of the total assets as of December 31, 2011 reflects additional assets for existing clients' fund-of-funds programs for which we now receive asset-based fees.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S2	The increase in assets represents incremental growth for an existing revenue stream.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S3	Similarly, about $39 billion of the total assets as of December 31, 2010 reflected a new fund-of-funds program that began in May 2010 for an existing Morningstar Associates client.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S4	Previously, Morningstar created model portfolios for the same client, so the increase in assets represented incremental growth for an existing revenue stream.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P187_S5	Excluding assets from these fund-of-fund programs, total assets under advisement and management increased in 2011 and 2010, reflecting net client inflows and market performance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P188_S0	The asset totals as of the end of each year don't fully reflect the change in average asset levels during the year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P188_S1	The asset-based fees we earn are primarily based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P188_S2	Average assets under advisement and management (calculated based on available quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $165.3 million in 2011, up 39.3% from $118.7 billion in 2010 and up 75.9% from $94.0 billion in 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P189_S0	We provided Investment Consulting advisory services on $140.4 billion in assets as of December 31, 2011 compared with $111.4 billion in assets as of December 31, 2010 and $64.8 billion in assets as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P190_S0	The asset totals include relationships for which we receive basis-point fees, including consulting arrangements and other agreements where we act as a portfolio construction manager for a mutual fund or variable annuity.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P190_S1	We also provide Investment Consulting services for some assets for which we receive a flat fee; we do not include these assets in the total reported above.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P191_S0	As mentioned above, we manage several fund of funds portfolios for a large Investment Consulting client who recently notified us that it will be moving management of these portfolios in-house in April 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P191_S1	These portfolios represented $12.3 billion, or 8.4%, of our Investment Consulting assets under advisement and management as of December 31, 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P192_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P193_S0	Assets under advisement and management rose $29.0 billion , or 26.0% , compared with December 31, 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P193_S1	Approximately 75% of the increase reflects additional assets for existing clients' fund-of-funds programs for which we now receive asset-based fees.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P193_S2	The remainder of the increase reflects net client inflows and market performance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P194_S0	Total assets under advisement and management for Investment Consulting as of December 31, 2010 increased 71.9% compared with December 31, 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P194_S1	As mentioned above, assets under advisement as of December 31, 2010 includes approximately $39 billion related to a new fund-of-funds program that began in May 2010 for an existing Morningstar Associates client.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P194_S2	Excluding assets from the new fund-of-funds program, assets under advisement for Investment Consulting increased slightly over 2009, mainly reflecting positive market performance partially offset by a client non-renewal that occurred in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P195_S0	We cannot separately quantify cash inflows and outflows for these portfolios because we do not have custody of the assets in the majority of our investment management businesses.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P195_S1	The information we receive from many of our clients does not separately identify the effect of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P195_S2	We also cannot precisely quantify the effect of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P196_S0	Assets under management for managed retirement accounts increased to $19.9 billion as of December 31, 2011 compared with $ 19.6 billion as of December 31, 2010 and $ 15.7 billion as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P196_S1	Assets under advisement for plan sponsor and custom target-date arrangements increased to $17.5 billion as of December 31, 2011 , compared with $ 15.5 billion as of December 31, 2010 and $ 17.5 billion as of December 31, 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P197_S0	We cannot separately quantify the factors affecting assets under management and advisement for our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P197_S1	These factors primarily consist of employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P197_S2	We cannot quantify the impact of these other factors because the information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances caused by market movement.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P198_S0	The table below shows the number of retirement plan participants who had access to the services offered through our Retirement Solutions programs, as well as the number of plan sponsors and plan providers that provide this access.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P199_S2	Assets under management for Morningstar Managed Portfolios were $3.0 billion as of December 31, 2011 , compared with $2.7 billion as of December 31, 2010 and $2.1 billion as of December 31, 2009 , reflecting net inflows.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P200_S0	Operating income for the Investment Management segment increased $12.8 million , or 22.6% , in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P200_S1	In 2010, operating income increased $3.9 million, or 7.4%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P200_S2	In both years, revenue increased more than operating expense.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P201_S2	Excluding acquisitions, higher operating expenses for operations outside of the United States contributed the majority of the operating expense increase.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P201_S6	This expense did not recur in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P202_S0	In 2010, operating expense in this segment rose $14.1 million, or 35.8%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P202_S1	Approximately 40% of the segment's operating expense increase reflects recent acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P202_S2	Higher salaries and incentive compensation, including bonuses and sales commissions, contributed approximately two-thirds of the overall operating expense increase in this segment.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P202_S6	A slight reduction in product implementation fees related to our Advice by Ibbotson service partially offset these increases.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P203_S0	Operating margin increased 1.9 percentage points to 53.4% in 2011 , as revenue growth exceeded the growth in operating expenses.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P203_S1	Lower salary expense and bonus expense as a percentage of revenue contributed to the increase, partially offset by higher expenses outside of the United Stated and higher professional fees as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P203_S2	In addition, acquisitions had a small negative effect on the margin in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P203_S3	The 2010 margin was negatively impacted by the $2.0 million separation agreement.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P203_S4	This separation agreement reduced the 2010 margin by approximately 2.0 percentage points.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P204_S0	The segment's operating margin decreased 5.8 percentage points to 51.5% in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P204_S1	The margin decline mainly reflects higher bonus expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P204_S2	The $2.0 million separation payment reduced the margin by approximately 2.0 percentage points.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P204_S3	Salaries and employee benefits also contributed to the margin decline, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P204_S4	In addition, acquisitions had a negative impact on the margin of approximately 1.6 percentage points.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P205_S0	As previously discussed, a large Investment Consulting client recently notified us that it will be moving to in-house management of several fund of funds portfolios in April 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P205_S1	We received about $12.4 million in revenue from our work on these portfolios in 2011, which represented 9.5% of Investment Management segment revenue and a larger percentage of segment operating income, as our consulting work generally doesn't involve significant variable costs.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P206_S0	This category includes general corporate costs, which we do not allocate to our business segments.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P206_S1	The corporate items category also includes amortization expense related to intangible assets recorded for acquisitions and capitalization of internal product development costs.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P206_S2	The table below shows the components of corporate items that affected our consolidated operating income:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P207_S0	Amortization of intangible assets increased $2.4 million in 2011 and $5.9 million in 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P207_S1	The increase in 2011 primarily reflects amortization expense from 2010 acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P207_S2	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P207_S3	Amortization expense increased $5.9 million in 2010, reflecting amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P208_S0	We paid $176.2 million for acquisitions during the past three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P208_S1	As of December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010 , respectively, we had $139.8 million and $169.0 million of net intangible assets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P208_S2	We amortize these assets over their estimated lives, ranging from one to 20 years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P208_S3	We estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be approximately $23.8 million in 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P209_S0	Depreciation expense for corporate items did not change significantly in 2011 or 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P210_S0	Corporate unallocated expense decreased $3.3 million in 2011 .

1289419_12_ITEM7_P210_S2	Lower professional fees also contributed to the decrease, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P210_S3	In addition, a $1.0 million expense related to vacant office space recorded in 2010 did not recur in 2011 , favorably affecting the comparison with the prior year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P210_S4	Higher salaries partially offset the these favorable items.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P210_S5	In addition, our corporate unallocated expense for 2011 includes $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
