1289419_12_ITEM7_P211_S1	Corporate unallocated expense in 2009 includes $9.5 million of expense related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options and deposit penalties.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P211_S2	In 2010, expense related to liabilities for vacant office space declined $2.2 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P211_S3	In addition, in 2010, we capitalized approximately $0.8 million of operating expense for software development.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P211_S4	These factors, which favorably impact the year-over-year comparison, were partially offset by incremental expense from acquisitions, higher compensation and bonus expense, and higher professional fees.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P212_S0	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities includes our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK), Morningstar Sweden AB, and, beginning in the fourth quarter of 2011, YCharts, Inc. (YCharts).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P212_S1	In the first six months of 2010, this category also included our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Denmark.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P212_S2	In 2009, this category also included our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Denmark and Morningstar Korea.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P212_S3	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities is primarily from our position in MJKK.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P213_S0	In November 2011, we acquired a 20% minority equity stake in YCharts for $2.45 million, paid in cash.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P214_S0	In July 2010, we acquired an additional 75% ownership interest in Morningstar Danmark A/S (Morningstar Denmark), increasing our ownership percentage to 100%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P214_S1	As a result, we no longer account for our investment in Morningstar Denmark using the equity method.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P214_S2	Beginning in the third quarter of 2010, we consolidate the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of Morningstar Denmark in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P215_S0	In 2009, we acquired an additional 40% ownership interest in Morningstar Korea, increasing our ownership percentage to 80%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P215_S1	As a result, we no longer account for our investment in Morningstar Korea using the equity method.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P216_S0	In September 2009, we began consolidating the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of Morningstar Korea in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P217_S0	We describe our investments in unconsolidated entities in more detail in Note 7 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P218_S0	The following table presents the components of net non-operating income (expense):
1289419_12_ITEM7_P219_S0	Interest income mainly reflects interest from our investment portfolio.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P219_S1	Interest income in 2011 increased compared with 2010, primarily due to higher balances of cash equivalents and investments.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P219_S2	The decrease in interest income in 2010 reflects lower returns on our invested balances during the year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P220_S0	In 2011, interest expense includes $0.9 million related to the $1.4 million of business tax expense for prior years recorded in 2011, as discussed above in the section Consolidated Results .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S0	Other income (expense), net primarily represents foreign currency exchange gains and losses arising from the ordinary course of business related to our U.S. and non-U.S. operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S1	It also includes royalty income from MJKK and realized gains and losses from our investment portfolio.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S2	The net other expense in 2011 primarily represents unrealized exchange losses on foreign currency denominated balances.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S3	In 2010, we recorded a holding gain of approximately $4.6 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S4	This gain represented the difference between the estimated fair value and the book value of our investment in Morningstar Denmark at the date of acquisition.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P221_S5	In 2009, we recorded a holding gain of approximately $0.4 million when we increased our ownership in Morningstar Korea.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P222_S0	The following table summarizes the components of our effective tax rate:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P223_S0	For a reconciliation of the U.S. federal tax rate to our effective income tax rate, refer to Note 14 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P224_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2011 was 30.7% , a decrease of 2.4 percentage points compared with 33.1% in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P224_S1	The lower tax rate in 2011 reflects the positive effect of increased tax credits and incentives related to Morningstar's research and development activities and our domestic production activities (Section 199) deduction, some of which relate to prior years, effects of tax audit settlements, and the recognition of certain deferred income tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P224_S2	Additionally, in 2010, the use of foreign net operating losses that had previously been subject to a valuation allowance reduced our effective tax rate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P224_S3	This benefit did not recur in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P225_S0	In 2010, our effective tax rate was 33.1%, a decrease of 3.2 percentage points compared with 2009.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P225_S1	The lower tax rate in 2010 reflects the positive impact of certain income tax benefits, including the difference between U.S. federal and foreign tax rates, tax credits related to Morningstar's research and development activities, and the use of foreign net operating losses that had previously been subject to a valuation allowance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P225_S2	These items favorably impacted our effective tax rate by approximately 3.7 percentage points in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P226_S0	Income tax expense in 2010 includes approximately $1.7 million of non-cash expense related to the $4.6 million holding gain we recorded in conjunction with the acquisition of Morningstar Denmark.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P226_S1	This income tax expense did not have a significant impact on our effective tax rate in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P227_S0	In 2011, we recorded a net increase of $3.1 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, which increased our income tax expense.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P227_S1	The majority of this increase relates to the estimated tax benefits and incentives (discussed above).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P227_S2	As of December 31, 2011 , we had $12.2 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $11.9 million , if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $9.8 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P227_S3	As of December 31, 2010, we had $9.1 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $8.5 million, if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $6.9 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P228_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of approximately $5.3 million and a non-current liability of $6.2 million for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P228_S1	As of December 31, 2010 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of $0.7 million and a non-current liability of $8.2 million for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P228_S2	These amounts include interest and penalties, less any associated tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P229_S0	We have not provided federal and state income taxes on accumulated undistributed earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries, because these earnings have been permanently reinvested.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P229_S1	Approximately 20% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2011 are held by our operations outside of the United States.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P229_S2	As such, we believe that our cash balances and investments in the United States, along with cash generated from our U.S. operations, will be sufficient to meet our U.S. operating and cash needs for the foreseeable future, without requiring us to repatriate earnings from these foreign subsidiaries.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P230_S0	It is not practicable to determine the amount of the unrecognized deferred tax liability related to the undistributed earnings.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P231_S0	We are currently under audit by federal and various state and local tax authorities in the United States, as well as tax authorities in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P231_S1	It is likely that the examination phase of some of these audits will conclude in 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P232_S0	It is not possible to estimate the effect of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P233_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations, will be sufficient to meet our operating and cash needs for at least the next 12 months.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S0	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments, consisting primarily of fixed-income securities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S1	We maintain a conservative investment policy for our investments and invest a portion of these assets in municipal securities with high-quality stand-alone credit ratings.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S2	We also invest a small portion of our investments balance (less than 5% as of December 31, 2011) in proprietary Morningstar portfolios.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S3	These portfolios may consist of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, or exchange-traded funds.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S4	Investments in our portfolio have a maximum maturity of two years; the weighted average maturity is approximately one year.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P234_S5	Approximately 80% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2011 are held by our operations in the United States.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P235_S0	We intend to use our cash, cash equivalents, and investments for general corporate purposes, including working capital and funding future growth.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P235_S1	To date, we have not needed to access any significant commercial credit and have not attempted to borrow or establish any lines of credit.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P236_S1	On December 9, 2011 , our board of directors approved a payment of a regular quarterly dividend of 10 cents per share payable on January 31, 2012 to shareholders of record as of January 13, 2012 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P236_S2	As of December 31, 2011 , we recorded a liability for dividends payable of $5.0 million.

1289419_12_ITEM7_P236_S5	The dividend is payable on April 30, 2012 to shareholders of record as of April 13, 2012 .

1289419_12_ITEM7_P237_S1	The board approval authorized the company to repurchase up to an additional $200 million in shares of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P237_S2	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that we deem appropriate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P237_S3	As of December 31, 2011 , we had repurchased a total of 798,337 shares for $44.5 million under this authorization.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P238_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , we had cash, cash equivalents, and investments of $470.2 million, an increase of $104.8 million compared with $365.4 million as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P238_S1	The increase reflects $165.0 million of cash provided by operating activities and $18.2 million of cash from stock-option proceeds and excess tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P238_S2	These items, which increased our cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance, were partially offset by $40.7 million used to repurchase common stock through our share repurchase program, $23.3 million of capital expenditures, and $10.0 million of dividends paid.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P239_S0	We expect to use a portion of our cash and investments balances in the first quarter of 2012 to make annual bonus payments of approximately $43 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P240_S0	Our main source of capital is cash generated from operating activities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P241_S0	In 2011 , cash provided by operating activities was $165.0 million, driven by $142.6 million of net income, adjusted for non-cash items and changes in our net operating assets and liabilities of $22.4 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P241_S1	Changes in our operating assets and liabilities mainly benefited from an increase in accrued compensation and an increase in income taxes.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P241_S2	The growth in accrued compensation primarily reflects the bonus liability as of year-end, partially offset by the bonus payments made in the first quarter of 2011 of approximately $37.5 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P241_S3	The cash flow benefit of income taxes was partially offset by tax payments of $38.1 million made during 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P241_S4	Cash provided by operating activities in 2011 also reflects $4.1 million of payments for previously announced separation agreements with two former executives.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P242_S0	In 2010, cash provided by operating activities was $123.4 million, driven by $127.0 million of net income, adjusted for non-cash items partially offset by $3.5 million in changes from our net operating assets and liabilities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P242_S1	We paid $21.4 million in annual bonus payments in the first quarter of 2010 and made tax payments of approximately $37.6 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P242_S2	In addition, in 2010, we paid $4.9 million to one former and two current executives to adjust the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P242_S3	The cash flow impact of these items was partially offset by the cash flow benefits of accrued compensation and income taxes payable.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P243_S0	In 2009, cash provided by operating activities was $101.3 million, driven by $115.0 million of net income (adjusted for non-cash items) partially offset by $13.7 million of changes in our net operating assets and liabilities, mainly driven by bonus payments.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P243_S1	We paid $58.9 million for bonuses in 2009, including $10.0 million in deferred payments from 2007.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P243_S2	The cash flow impact of these payments was partially offset by the cash flow benefit from accrued compensation for the 2009 bonuses.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P244_S0	Cash used for investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments less proceeds from the maturity or sale of investments, and cash used for capital expenditures.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P244_S1	The level of investing activities varies from period to period depending on activity in these three categories.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P245_S0	Cash used for investing activities was $110.8 million in 2011 , $87.9 million in 2010 , and $174.7 million in 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S0	In 2011 , purchases of investments exceeded the proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments by $85.3 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S1	In contrast, proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments exceeded the purchases of investments by $28.6 million in 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S2	In 2010, we transferred funds from our investment portfolio to cash and cash equivalents to pay for acquisitions made in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S3	Purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments, were $83.9 million in 2009 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S4	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010 , we had investments, consisting primarily of fixed-income securities, of $269.8 million and $185.2 million, respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P246_S5	As of December 31, 2011 , our investments represented 57% of our total cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance compared with 51% as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P247_S0	Capital expenditures were $23.3 million , $14.8 million , and $12.4 million in 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 , respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P247_S1	The 2011 capital expenditures reflect spending on computer hardware and software and internally developed capitalized software for our U.S. office as well as remaining payments for our development center in China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P247_S2	The 2010 capital expenditures include spending for our office space in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P247_S3	Capital expenditures in 2009 include final payments for the build-out of our new headquarters in Chicago and investment for a couple of our office locations in Europe.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P247_S4	We expect to make total capital expenditures of approximately $25 million in 2012, primarily for computer hardware and software, leasehold improvements for new and existing office locations, and capitalized software.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S0	We did not complete any acquisitions in 2011 , but received cash of approximately $0.6 million as an adjustment to the purchase price of one of our 2010 acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S1	In 2010 , we completed seven acquisitions for $102.3 million , net of cash acquired.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S2	The majority of the cash used for acquisitions was related to our purchase of Realpoint, OBSR, Morningstar Denmark, and the annuity intelligence business of Advanced Sales and Marketing Corp.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S3	In 2009, cash used for acquisitions, net of acquired cash, was $74.2 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S4	We completed six acquisitions in 2009 and increased our investment in Morningstar Korea.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P248_S5	The majority of the cash used for acquisitions was related to our purchase of LIM and our acquisition of the equity research and data business of CPMS.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P249_S0	In 2011, we used cash of approximately $2.5 million to acquire a minority equity stake in YCharts, Inc., a technology company that provides stock research and analysis.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P249_S1	In 2009, we used cash of approximately $4.2 million to acquire minority equity stakes in Pitchbook Data and Bundle Corporation.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P250_S0	Cash provided by financing activities consists primarily of proceeds from stock-option exercises and excess tax benefits related to stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P250_S1	These cash inflows may be offset by dividend payments and cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P251_S0	Excess tax benefits occur at the time a stock option is exercised when the intrinsic value of the option (the difference between the fair value of our stock on the date of exercise and the exercise price of the option) is greater than the fair value of the option at the time of grant.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P251_S1	Similarly, the vesting of restricted stock units generates excess tax benefits when the market value of our common stock on the vesting date exceeds the grant price of the restricted stock units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P251_S2	These excess tax benefits reduce the cash we pay for income taxes in the year they are recognized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P252_S0	It is not possible to predict the timing of stock-option exercises or the intrinsic value that will be achieved at the time options are exercised or upon vesting of restricted stock units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P252_S1	As a result, we expect cash flow from financing activities to vary over time.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P252_S2	Note 10 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements includes additional information concerning stock options and restricted stock units outstanding as of December 31, 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P253_S0	In 2011 , cash used for financing activities was $32.6 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P253_S1	We paid cash of approximately $40.7 million under our share repurchase program in 2011 .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P253_S2	In addition, we made dividend payments of $10.0 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P253_S3	Partially offsetting these cash outflows were proceeds from stock-option exercises of $8.7 million and excess tax benefits related to stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units of $9.5 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P254_S0	In 2011 , we used cash of $32.6 million for financing activities compared with cash provided by financing activities of $12.5 million in 2010.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P254_S1	The net change of $45.1 million , was driven by an increase in cash used to repurchase common shares of $36.9 million and the dividends paid of $10.0 million in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P254_S2	An increase in excess tax benefits of $2.0 million , partially offset the cash outflow.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P255_S0	In 2010 , cash provided by financing activities was $12.5 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P255_S1	Proceeds from stock-option exercises totaled $9.2 million , while excess tax benefits related to stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units totaled $7.5 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P255_S2	Partially offsetting these inflows was $3.8 million of cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P255_S3	In 2010 , cash provided by financing activities decreased by $12.8 million , driven by a decrease in proceeds from stock-option exercises, cash used to repurchase common shares, and (to a lesser extent) from a decline in excess tax benefits.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P256_S0	In 2009, cash provided by financing activities was $25.3 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P256_S1	Proceeds from stock-option exercises totaled $16.4 million and excess tax benefits related to stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units totaled $8.7 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P257_S0	Employees exercised approximately 0.7 million , 0.8 million , and 1.4 million stock options in 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 , respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P257_S1	The total intrinsic value (the difference between the market value of our stock on the date of exercise and the exercise price of the option) of options exercised during 2011 , 2010 , and 2009 , was $29.9 million , $31.4 million , and $37.4 million , respectively.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P258_S0	We did not complete any acquisitions in 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P258_S1	We invested a total of $176.2 million , less cash acquired, related to acquisitions over the past three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P258_S2	We describe these acquisitions, including purchase price and product offerings, in Note 6 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P259_S0	See N ote 17 in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for information on events subsequent to December 31, 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P260_S0	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P260_S1	We discuss our significant accounting policies in Note 2 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P261_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires our management team to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, expense, and related disclosures included in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P262_S0	We evaluate our estimates on an ongoing basis.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P262_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P262_S2	Based on these assumptions and estimates, we make judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P262_S3	Our actual results could vary from these estimates and assumptions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P262_S4	If actual amounts are different from previous estimates, we include revisions in our results of operations for the period in which the actual amounts become known.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P263_S0	We believe the following critical accounting policies reflect the significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our Consolidated Financial Statements:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P264_S0	Much of our revenue comes from the sale of subscriptions or licenses for print publications, software, and Internet-based products and services.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P264_S1	We recognize this revenue in equal amounts over the term of the subscription or license, which generally ranges from one to three years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P264_S2	We also provide analysis, consulting, retirement advice, and other services.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P264_S3	We recognize this revenue when the service is provided or during the service obligation period defined in the contract.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P265_S0	We make significant judgments related to revenue recognition, including whether fees are fixed or determinable and whether the collection of payment is probable.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P266_S0	For contracts that combine multiple products and services, we make judgments regarding the value of each element in the arrangement based on selling prices of the items when sold separately.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P267_S0	Delivery of our products and services is a prerequisite to the recognition of revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P267_S1	If arrangements include an acceptance provision, we begin recognizing revenue upon the receipt of customer acceptance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P268_S0	We make judgments at the beginning of an arrangement regarding whether or not collection is probable.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P268_S1	Probability of collection is assessed on a case-by-case basis.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P268_S2	We typically sell to institutional customers with whom we have a history of successful collections.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S0	Deferred revenue is the amount invoiced or collected in advance for subscriptions, licenses, or services that has not yet been recognized as revenue.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S1	As of December 31, 2011, our deferred revenue was $155.5 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S2	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill our service obligations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S3	The amount of deferred revenue may increase or decrease primarily based on the mix of contracted products and services and the volume of new and renewal subscriptions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S4	The timing of future revenue recognition may change depending on the terms of the license agreements and the timing of fulfilling our service obligations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P269_S5	We believe that the estimate related to revenue recognition is a critical accounting estimate, and to the extent that there are material differences between our determination of deferred revenue and actual results, our financial condition or results of operations may be affected.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P270_S0	Over the past several years, we have acquired several companies that complement our business operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P270_S1	Over the past three years, the total cash paid for acquisitions, less cash acquired, was $176.2 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P270_S2	As of December 31, 2011, we have recorded $318.5 million of goodwill arising from acquisitions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P271_S0	As of December 31, 2011, we allocated $249.4 million of gross value to intangible assets, primarily for customer-related assets, technology-based assets, and intellectual property.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P271_S1	The estimated useful lives of the intangible assets range from one to 25 years.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P272_S0	Management judgment is required in allocating the purchase price to the acquired assets and liabilities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P272_S1	For each acquisition, we allocate the purchase price to the assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and goodwill in accordance with ASC 805, Business Combinations .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P272_S2	Once it has been determined that recognition of an asset or liability in a business combination is appropriate, the asset or liability generally is measured at fair value in accordance with the principles of ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P273_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P274_S0	The determination of the fair values of intangible assets requires significant management judgment in each of the following areas:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P275_S0	Identify the acquired intangible assets: For each acquisition, we identify the intangible assets acquired.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P275_S1	These intangible assets generally consist of customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames, technology-related intangibles including internally developed software and databases, and non-compete agreements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P276_S0	Estimate the fair value of these intangible assets: We consider various approaches to value the intangible assets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P276_S1	These valuation approaches include the cost approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the cost to reproduce it or replace it with another asset of like utility; the market approach, which values the asset through an analysis of sales and offerings of comparable assets; and the income approach, which measures the value of an asset based by measuring the present worth of the economic benefits it is expected to produce.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P277_S0	Estimate the remaining useful life of the assets: For each intangible asset, we use judgment and assumptions to establish the remaining useful life of the asset.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P277_S1	For example, for customer relationships, we determine the estimated useful life with reference to observed customer attrition rates.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P277_S2	For technology-related assets such as databases, we make judgments about the demand for current data and historical metrics in establishing the remaining useful life.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P277_S3	For internally developed software, we estimate an obsolescence factor associated with the software.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P278_S0	Assess the appropriate method for recording amortization expense over the intangible asset's useful life: We use judgment to determine the rate at which the amortization expense should be recognized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P278_S1	In accordance with ASC 350, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other , the method of amortization should reflect the pattern in which the economic benefits of the intangible asset are consumed or otherwise used up.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P278_S2	If that pattern cannot be reliably determined, a straight-line amortization method should be used.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P278_S3	Based on this guidance, we amortize intangible assets over their expected useful life using a straight-line amortization method.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P279_S0	We believe that the accounting estimates related to purchase price allocations are critical accounting estimates because the assumptions impact the amounts and classifications of assets and liabilities presented in our Consolidated Balance Sheets, the amount of amortization and depreciation expense, if any, recorded in our Consolidated Statements of Income, and the impairment testing performed in subsequent periods.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P280_S0	Goodwill recorded on our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2011 was $318.5 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P281_S0	In accordance with ASC 350, Intangibles-Goodwill and Other , we do not amortize goodwill.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P281_S1	Instead, it is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist, based on a discounted cash-flow model.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P282_S0	An impairment would occur if the carrying amount of a reporting unit, including goodwill, exceeded the fair value of that reporting unit.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P282_S1	In 2011, we altered the definition of our reporting units to align with the definition of our operating segments.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P282_S2	This realignment occurred because of our successful efforts to integrate acquired businesses and leverage proprietary content across multiple products.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P282_S3	As a result, the businesses that previously represented components of our operating segments no longer met the criteria for recognition as reporting units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P283_S0	Our reporting units constitute businesses for which discrete financial information, which is regularly reviewed by management, is available.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P283_S1	We performed annual impairment reviews in the fourth quarter of 2011, 2010, and 2009 and did not record any impairment losses in these years, reflecting our assessment that our estimates of fair value substantially exceeded the carrying value of our reporting units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P284_S0	The process of evaluating the potential impairment of goodwill is subjective and requires significant judgment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P285_S0	In estimating the fair value of the reporting units, we make estimates and judgments about the future cash flows of the reporting unit.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P285_S1	These estimates include assumptions about future market growth and trends, forecasted revenue and costs, capital investments, appropriate discount rates, and other variables that can significantly affect the value of the reporting unit.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P286_S0	Although our cash flow forecasts are based on assumptions that are consistent with plans and estimates we use to manage the underlying business, there is significant judgment in determining the cash flows attributable to these businesses over a long-term horizon.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P286_S1	We update these assumptions and cash flow estimates at least annually.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P287_S0	We believe that the accounting estimate related to goodwill impairment is a critical accounting estimate because the assumptions used are highly susceptible to changes in the operating results and cash flows of the reporting units.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P287_S1	If actual results differ from our estimates, future tests may indicate an impairment of goodwill.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P287_S2	This would result in a non-cash charge, adversely affecting our results of operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P288_S0	Our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2011 includes $68.2 million of property, equipment, and capitalized software, net of accumulated depreciation, and $139.8 million of intangible assets, net of accumulated amortization.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P289_S0	In accordance with FASB ASC 360-10-35 , Subsequent Measurement Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets , we review our property, equipment, capitalized software, and intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P289_S1	Such events or changes may include deterioration in the business climate for a specific product or service.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P290_S0	If the total of projected future undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying amount of an asset, we may need to record an impairment loss based on the excess of the carrying amount over the fair value of the assets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P291_S0	Estimates of future cash flows and the estimated useful lives associated with these assets are critical to the assessment of recoverability and fair values.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P291_S1	They are susceptible to change from period to period because of the requirement to make assumptions about future cash flows generated over extended periods of time.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P291_S2	Changes in these estimates could result in a determination of asset impairment, which would result in a reduction to the carrying value and could adversely affect our operating results in the related period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P292_S0	We include stock-based compensation expense in each of our operating expense categories.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P292_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense primarily reflects grants of restricted stock units and restricted stock.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P293_S0	Under FASB ASC 718 , Compensation Stock Compensation , stock-based compensation expense is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award, and the cost is recognized as expense ratably over the award's vesting period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P294_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day prior to grant.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P294_S1	We estimate expected forfeitures of stock-based awards at the grant date and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P294_S2	We ultimately adjust this forfeiture assumption to the actual forfeiture rate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P294_S3	Therefore, changes in the forfeiture assumptions do not impact the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the vesting period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P295_S0	Instead, different forfeiture assumptions would only impact the timing of expense recognition over the vesting period.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P296_S0	Because our largest annual equity grants typically have vesting dates in the second quarter of the year, we adjust the stock-based compensation expense at that time to reflect those awards that ultimately vested.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P296_S1	In addition, we update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P297_S0	We believe that the estimates related to stock-based compensation expense are critical accounting estimates because the assumptions used could significantly impact the timing and amount of stock-based compensation expense recorded in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P298_S0	Our effective tax rate is based on the mix of income and losses in our U.S. and non-U.S. operations, statutory tax rates, and tax-planning opportunities available to us in the various jurisdictions in which we operate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P298_S1	Significant judgment is required to evaluate our tax positions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P299_S0	Tax law requires us to include items in our tax return at different times from when these items are reflected in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P299_S1	As a result, the effective tax rate reflected in our Consolidated Financial Statements is different from the tax rate reported on our tax return (our cash tax rate).
1289419_12_ITEM7_P299_S2	Some of these differences, such as expenses that are not deductible in our tax return, are permanent.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P299_S3	Other differences, such as depreciation expense, reverse over time.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P299_S4	These timing differences create deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P300_S0	We determine our deferred tax assets and liabilities based on temporary differences between the financial reporting and the tax basis of assets and liabilities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P300_S1	The excess tax benefits associated with stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units also create a difference between our cash tax rate and the effective tax rate in our Consolidated Income Statement.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P301_S0	As of December 31, 2011, we had gross deferred tax assets of $38.6 million and gross deferred tax liabilities of $37.4 million .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P301_S1	The deferred tax assets include $13.3 million of deferred tax assets related to $50.1 million of net operating losses (NOLs) of our non-U.S. operations.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P302_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P302_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $5.3 million of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of the NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P303_S0	In assessing the need for a valuation allowance, we consider both positive and negative evidence, including tax-planning strategies, projected future taxable income, and recent financial performance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P303_S1	If we determine a lesser allowance is required at some point in the future, we would record a reduction to our tax expense and valuation allowance.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P303_S2	These adjustments would be made in the same period we determined the change in the valuation allowance was needed.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P303_S3	This would cause our income tax expense, effective tax rate, and net income to fluctuate.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S0	We assess uncertain tax positions in accordance with FASB ASC 740 , Income Taxes.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S1	We use judgment to identify, recognize, and measure the amounts to be recorded in the financial statements related to tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S2	We recognize liabilities to represent our potential future obligations to taxing authorities for the benefits taken in our tax returns.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S3	We adjust these liabilities, including any impact of the related interest and penalties, in light of changing facts and circumstances such as the progress of a tax audit.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S4	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter for which we have established a reserve is audited and finally resolved.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P304_S5	The number of years with open tax audits varies depending on the tax jurisdiction.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P305_S0	We use judgment to classify unrecognized tax benefits as either current or noncurrent liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P305_S1	Settlement of any particular issue would usually require the use of cash.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P306_S0	We generally classify liabilities associated with unrecognized tax benefits as noncurrent liabilities.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P306_S1	It typically takes several years between our initial tax return filing and the final resolution of any uncertain tax positions with the tax authority.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P306_S2	We recognize favorable resolutions of tax matters for which we have previously established reserves as a reduction to our income tax expense when the amounts involved become known.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P307_S0	Assessing the future tax consequences of events that have been recognized in our Consolidated Financial Statements or tax returns requires judgment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P307_S1	Variations in the actual outcome of these future tax consequences could materially impact our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P308_S0	We are subject to various claims and contingencies related to legal proceedings and investigations, which we describe in Note 15 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P308_S1	These legal proceedings involve inherent uncertainties including, but not limited to, court rulings, negotiations between affected parties, and government actions.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P308_S2	Assessing the probability of loss for such contingencies and determining how to accrue the appropriate liabilities requires judgment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P308_S3	If actual results differ from our assessments, our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows would be impacted.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P309_S0	In May 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-04, Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820): Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and IFRSs.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P309_S1	ASU No. 2011-04 clarifies existing fair value measurement and disclosure requirements, amends certain fair value measurement principles and requires additional disclosures about fair value measurements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P309_S2	For Morningstar, ASU No. 2011-04 will be applied prospectively beginning on January 1, 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P309_S3	We do not expect the provisions of ASU No. 2011-04 to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P310_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-08, Intangibles Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Testing Goodwill for Impairment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P310_S1	The objective of this Update is to simplify how entities test goodwill for impairment.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P311_S0	An entity may first assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, as a basis for determining whether it is necessary to perform the two-step goodwill impairment test described in Topic 350.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P312_S0	The more-likely-than-not threshold is defined as having a likelihood of more than 50%.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P312_S1	For Morningstar, t he amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed in 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P313_S0	We do not expect the provisions of ASU No. 2011-08 to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P314_S0	In December 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-12, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Deferral of the Effective Date for Amendments to the Presentation of Reclassifications of Items Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P314_S1	ASU No. 2011-12 defers the effective date of the requirement to present separate line items on the income statement for reclassification adjustments of items out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P314_S2	The deferral is temporary until the Board reconsiders the operational concerns and needs of financial statement users.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P314_S3	The Board has not yet established a timetable for its reconsideration.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P315_S0	The table below shows our known contractual obligations as of December 31, 2011 and the expected timing of cash payments related to these contractual obligations:
1289419_12_ITEM7_P316_S0	(1) The non-cancelable operating lease obligations are mainly for lease commitments for office space.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P317_S0	(2) Represents unrecognized tax benefits (including penalties and interest, less the impact of any associated tax benefits) recorded in accordance with FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes .
1289419_12_ITEM7_P317_S1	The amount included in the table represents items that may be resolved through settlement of tax audits or for which the statues of limitations are expected to lapse during 2012.
1289419_12_ITEM7_P317_S2	The table excludes $6.2 million of unrecognized tax benefits, included as a long-term liability in our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2011, for which we cannot make a reasonably reliable estimate of the period of payment.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our investment portfolio is actively managed and may suffer losses from fluctuating interest rates, market prices, or adverse security selection.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We invest our investment portfolio mainly in high-quality fixed-income securities.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P0_S2	As of December 31, 2011 , our cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance was $470.2 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Based on our estimates, a 100 basis-point change in interest rates would impact the fair value of our investment portfolio by approximately $0.8 million.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	As our non-U.S. revenue increases as a percentage of our consolidated revenue, fluctuations in foreign currencies present a greater potential risk.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Our European operations are subject to currency risk related to the euro.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P1_S2	To date, we have not engaged in currency hedging, and we do not currently have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P1_S3	Our results could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar.
1289419_12_ITEM7A_P1_S4	In addition, because we use the local currency of our subsidiaries as the functional currency, we are affected by the translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries (collectively, the Company) as of December 31, 2011, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P0_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audit.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P0_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_12_ITEM8_P0_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P1_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P1_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P1_S2	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P1_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2011, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P1_S4	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Morningstar, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report dated February 24, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.: We have audited Morningstar, Inc.'s (the Company) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S1	The Company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting, appearing in Item 9A.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P2_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S4	In our opinion, Morningstar, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P3_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheet of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity and cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2011, and our report dated February 24, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P4_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P5_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2010, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.

1289419_12_ITEM8_P5_S2	These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P5_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and schedule based on our audits.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P6_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_12_ITEM8_P6_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P7_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1289419_12_ITEM8_P7_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
