1289419_13_ITEM1_P183_S1	She was president of our Individual segment from 2000 through 2008 and became president of our equity research business in 2009.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P183_S2	She holds a bachelor's degree in American history from The University of Chicago and a master's degree in business administration from The University of Chicago Booth School of Business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P184_S0	Greg Goff has been chief technology officer for Morningstar since 2011 and is responsible for Morningstar's global technology strategy.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P184_S1	Before joining us in 2011, he was senior vice president of global platform technology for The Nielsen Company since 2009.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P185_S0	He joined The Nielsen Company in 2004 as vice president of data warehousing.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P185_S1	He has also worked for Accenture and BlueMeteor, Inc. in Chicago.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P185_S2	He holds a bachelor s degree in electrical engineering from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P186_S0	Thomas Idzorek was named president of Morningstar's Investment Management division in May 2012 and is responsible for our investment advisory, retirement solutions, and investment management operations in North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P186_S1	He also oversees the Investment Policy Committee for the Investment Management division and serves on Morningstar's retirement plan committee.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P187_S0	He joined us in 2006, when we acquired Ibbotson Associates.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P188_S0	From 2006 until May 2012, Thomas was chief investment officer for Morningstar Investment Management.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P188_S1	He holds a bachelor's degree in marketing from Arizona State University, a master's degree in business administration from Thunderbird School of Global Management, and the Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) designation.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S0	Kunal Kapoor Kunal Kapoor has been president of Morningstar's Data division since 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S1	He is responsible for managing our investment databases and related products.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S2	Prior to assuming his current role in 2012, Kunal was president of Equity and Market Data/Software.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S3	In 2009, he became president of Individual Software, and in 2010, his role expanded to include our equity data business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S4	Kunal joined the company as a data analyst in 1997 and became a fund analyst in 1998.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S5	In 2001 he joined Morningstar Investment Services, Inc., a registered investment advisor and wholly owned subsidiary of Morningstar, Inc., as a senior research analyst.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S6	He was named editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds , in 2003, and in 2004 was appointed director of mutual fund analysis, where he led Morningstar's team of mutual fund analysts.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S7	In 2006, Kunal was named director of business strategy for Morningstar's international operations.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P189_S8	He also served as president and chief investment officer of Morningstar Investment Services.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P190_S0	Kunal holds a bachelor's degree in economics and environmental policy from Monmouth College and a master's degree in business administration from The University of Chicago Booth School of Business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P190_S1	He also holds the Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) designation.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S0	Don Phillips has been president of Morningstar's Investment Research division, overseeing our global fund, equity, and credit research, since 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S1	He joined us in 1986 as our first mutual fund analyst.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S2	Don served as our vice president and publisher from 1991 to 1996, as our president from 1996 to 1998, and as our chief executive officer from 1998 to 2000.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S3	He has been a managing director since 2000 and in 2009 took on additional responsibilities as president of fund research.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S4	Don's role expanded in 2012 to include oversight of our global equity and credit research.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P191_S5	He has served on our board of directors since August 1999.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P192_S0	Don holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Texas and a master's degree from The University of Chicago.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P193_S0	Richard Robbins has been our general counsel and corporate secretary since August 2005.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P193_S1	He is responsible for directing Morningstar's legal department and managing our relationships with outside counsel.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P193_S2	He also oversees our compliance and corporate communications departments.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P194_S0	From May 1999 until he joined Morningstar, he was a partner at Sidley Austin Brown Wood LLP (now Sidley Austin LLP), which he joined as an associate in August 1991.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P194_S1	He holds bachelor's and master's degrees in computer science and electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a juris doctor degree from The University of Chicago Law School.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P195_S0	James Tanner joined Morningstar in January 2013 as global head of business development and sales.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P195_S1	Previously he served as vice chairman of business development for Markit On Demand, a company he founded as Wall Street On Demand in 1991.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P195_S2	In addition to his role as CEO, he also served in various roles for firms that have owned Wall Street On Demand, including head of sales for eBridge and head of distribution and vice chairman of business development for Markit, a UK-based global financial information company.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P196_S0	James holds a bachelor s degree in Russian language and literature from Haverford College and a master s degree in business administration from Harvard University.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P197_S0	David W. Williams has been a managing director for Morningstar since 2000.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P197_S1	He is in charge of design and its application to brand identity, products, marketing communications, and the workplace.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P197_S2	He joined us in 1993 and has been instrumental in establishing design as one of our recognized core capabilities.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P197_S3	He holds a bachelor's degree in industrial design from The Ohio State University and a master's degree in fine arts from the Yale University School of Art.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P198_S0	We were incorporated in Illinois on May 16, 1984.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P198_S1	Our corporate headquarters are located at 22 West Washington Street, Chicago, Illinois, 60602.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P199_S0	We maintain a website at http://corporate.morningstar.com .
1289419_13_ITEM1_P199_S1	Our Annual Report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to any of these documents are available free of charge on this site as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports are filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P199_S2	We also post quarterly press releases on our financial results and other documents containing additional information related to our company on this site.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P199_S3	We provide this website and the information contained in or connected to it for informational purposes only.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P199_S4	That information is not part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P200_S0	You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the other information included in this Form 10-K when deciding whether to invest in our common stock or otherwise evaluating our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P200_S1	If any of the following risks materialize, our business, financial condition, or operating results could suffer.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P200_S2	In this case, the trading price of our common stock could decline, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P201_S0	Our investment advisory operations may subject us to liability for any losses that result from a breach of our fiduciary duties.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P202_S0	Three of our subsidiaries, Ibbotson Associates, Inc., Morningstar Associates, LLC, and Morningstar Investment Services, Inc. are registered as investment advisors with the SEC under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, as amended (Advisers Act).
1289419_13_ITEM1_P202_S1	As registered investment advisors, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Advisers Act.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P202_S2	Such requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, and standards of care, as well as general anti-fraud prohibitions.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P203_S0	As registered investment advisors, all three subsidiaries are subject to on-site examination by the SEC.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P204_S0	In addition, because these three subsidiaries provide investment advisory services to retirement plans and their participants, they may be acting as fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_13_ITEM1_P204_S1	As fiduciaries under ERISA, they have obligations to act in the best interest of their clients.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P204_S2	They also have duties of loyalty and prudence, as well as duties to diversify investments and to follow plan documents to comply with the applicable portions of ERISA.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P205_S0	Our subsidiaries outside the United States that have investment advisory operations are subject to similar requirements.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P206_S0	We may face liabilities for actual or claimed breaches of our fiduciary duties, particularly in areas where we provide retirement advice and managed retirement accounts.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P206_S1	We may not be able to prevent clients from taking legal action against us for an actual or claimed breach of a fiduciary duty.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P206_S2	Because we provided investment advisory and management services on about $ 149.5 billion in assets as of December 31, 2012 , we could face substantial liabilities if we breach our fiduciary duties.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P207_S0	In addition, we may face other legal liabilities based on the quality and outcome of our investment advisory recommendations, even in the absence of an actual or claimed breach of fiduciary duty.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P208_S0	An outage of our database and network facilities could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S0	The success of our business depends upon our ability to deliver time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S1	We rely on our computer equipment, database storage facilities, and other network equipment, much of which is geographically concentrated in our Chicago headquarters and other backup locations in the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S2	We also have extensive information systems outside the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S3	Our mission-critical databases and networks are increasingly complex and interdependent.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S4	Many of our client contracts contain service-level agreements that require us to meet certain obligations for delivering time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S5	We may not be able to meet these obligations in the event of failure or downtime in our information systems.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S6	Our operations and those of our suppliers and customers are vulnerable to interruption by fire, earthquake, power loss, telecommunications failure, terrorist attacks, wars, Internet failures or disruptions, computer viruses, and other events beyond our control.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P209_S7	Our database and network facilities may also be vulnerable to external attacks that misappropriate our data, corrupt our databases, or limit access to our information systems.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P210_S0	We maintain off-site back-up facilities for our database and network equipment, but these facilities could be subject to the same interruptions that may affect our headquarters.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P210_S1	We may not be able to fully recover data or information lost during a database or network facility outage.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P210_S2	Any losses, service disruption, or damages incurred by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P211_S0	Our business relies heavily on electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P211_S1	Any failures or disruptions could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P212_S0	Most of our products and services depend heavily on our electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P212_S1	Our ability to deliver information using the Internet may be impaired because of infrastructure failures, service outages at third-party Internet providers, malicious attacks, or other factors.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P212_S2	If disruptions, failures, or slowdowns of our electronic delivery systems or the Internet occur, our ability to distribute our products and services effectively and to serve our customers may be impaired.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P213_S0	We could face liability related to our storage of personal information about our users.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S0	Customers routinely input personal investment and financial information, including portfolio holdings and credit card information, on our websites.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S1	We also handle an increasing volume of personally sensitive information through our Portfolio Management Service, Enterprise Data Management, managed retirement accounts, and other areas of our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S2	Contractual commitments to customers as well as laws and industry regulations related to data protection, system availability, and privacy require us to safeguard critical data.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S3	We are also required to take appropriate steps to safeguard credit card numbers, social security numbers, and other personally identifiable information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S4	We may suffer malicious attacks seeking to penetrate our network and databases to gain access to personal data.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P214_S5	We could be subject to liability if we were to inappropriately disclose any user's personal information or if third parties were able to penetrate our network security or otherwise gain access to any user's name, address, portfolio holdings, or credit card information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P215_S0	Changes in laws applicable to our investment advisory or credit rating operations, compliance failures, or regulatory action could adversely affect our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P216_S0	Our investment advisory operations are a growing part of our overall business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P216_S1	The securities laws and other laws that govern our activities as a registered investment advisor are complex.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P216_S2	The activities of our investment advisory operations are primarily subject to provisions of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 (the Advisers Act) and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_13_ITEM1_P216_S3	In addition, Morningstar Investment Services is a broker-dealer registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the Exchange Act) and is subject to the rules of FINRA.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P216_S4	We also provide investment advisory services in other areas around the world, and our operations are subject to additional regulations in markets outside the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P217_S0	Over the past several years, we have also made significant investments in our credit rating business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P217_S1	We began publishing credit ratings and associated research on corporate debt issuers in 2009.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P218_S0	Although our corporate credit rating business is not currently regulated as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (NRSRO), credit rating and research providers have been under increasing regulatory scrutiny.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P218_S1	We cannot predict the future impact of potential future regulatory changes on our corporate credit rating business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P219_S0	We also expanded our credit rating business operations with our May 2010 acquisition of Realpoint, LLC (now known as Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC), an NRSRO that specializes in structured finance.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P220_S0	As an NRSRO, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to various requirements and regulations under the Exchange Act relating to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, governance, and conflicts of interest.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P221_S0	As part of its NRSRO registration, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to annual examinations by the SEC.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P222_S0	It is difficult to predict the future effect of the broad and expanding legislative and regulatory requirements affecting our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P222_S1	The laws, rules, and regulations applicable to our business may change in the future, and we may not be able to comply with any such changes.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P222_S2	If we fail to comply with any applicable law, rule, or regulation, we could be fined, sanctioned, or barred from providing investment advisory or credit rating services in the future, which could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P223_S0	Downturns in the financial sector, global financial markets, and global economy may adversely impact our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S0	We believe ongoing economic weakness continues to cause uncertainty and pressure on consumer discretionary spending.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S1	The financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, as well as more recent financial and economic uncertainty, has led to spending cutbacks among asset management firms and other financial services companies, which make up a large percentage of our client base.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S2	Some institutional clients also implemented additional review processes for new contracts or began to provide certain services, particularly investment advisory services, in-house rather than hiring external service providers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S3	Some institutional clients have also reduced the scope of their operations.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S4	For example, several large insurers withdrew from the variable annuity market during 2011 and 2012, while others curtailed their new sales efforts.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P224_S5	This has had a negative effect on the services we provide to institutional clients that offer variable annuities.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P225_S0	In 2010 and 2011, rising government debt levels around the world as well as downgrades in sovereign debt issues for some European countries led to market fears about a potential crisis in global sovereign debt.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P225_S1	Some European countries have been unable to successfully refinance their debts, leading European finance officials to take measures during 2010 and 2011 to stabilize financial conditions across Europe.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P226_S0	Although sovereign debt problems have been most severe in countries such as Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, concerns have also grown about the stability of Europe as a whole and the future of the euro currency.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P227_S0	In 2012 , approximately 16.2% of our consolidated revenue was from Europe, including 7.6% in Continental Europe and 8.6% in the United Kingdom.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P227_S1	Our European operations are also subject to currency risk related to the euro, which accounted for approximately 5.8% of our consolidated revenue in 2012 and approximately 10.2% of our cash and cash equivalents balance as of December 31, 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM1_P227_S2	We don't engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P227_S3	Our reported revenue could suffer if the euro declines relative to the U.S. dollar.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P228_S0	In addition, if financial markets around the world experience negative performance and volatility, demand for our products and services may decline, and our revenue, operating income, and other financial results could suffer.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P228_S1	Our business results may also be impacted by negative trends in Internet advertising sales.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P228_S2	The financial markets and many businesses operating in the financial services industry are highly volatile and are affected by factors, such as U.S. and foreign economic conditions and general trends in business and finance, that are beyond our control.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P229_S0	Our revenue from asset-based fees may be adversely affected by market declines as well as the effect of cash outflows from portfolios that we help manage.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P230_S0	In 2012 , revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 12% of our consolidated revenue and a greater percentage of our operating income.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P230_S1	The amount of revenue we earn from asset-based fees depends on the value of assets on which we provide advisory services, and the size of our asset base can increase or decrease along with trends in market performance.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P230_S2	The value of assets under advisement may show substantial declines during periods of significant market volatility.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P230_S3	The size of these portfolios can also be affected if net inflows into the portfolios on which we provide investment advisory services drop or if these portfolios experience redemptions.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P230_S4	If the level of assets on which we provide investment advisory services goes down, we expect our fee-based revenue to show a corresponding decline.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P231_S0	We could face liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as a result of some of our currently pending litigation.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P232_S0	From time to time, we are subject to legal and regulatory proceedings in the ordinary course of our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P232_S1	These include proceedings relating to aspects of our businesses that are specific to us and proceedings that are typical in the asset management and financial information businesses in which we operate.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P233_S0	We are currently defendants in a number of litigation matters as further described in Item 3 Legal Proceedings of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P233_S1	In certain of these matters, the plaintiffs are seeking large and/or indeterminate amounts of damages.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P234_S0	Litigation is inherently unpredictable, and the outcome of any particular proceeding can never be predicted with certainty.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P234_S1	An adverse outcome in a litigation matter could, depending on the facts, have a material financial impact on our company.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P235_S0	In addition to its potential financial impact, litigation can have a significant adverse reputational impact.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P235_S1	We depend to a large extent on our reputation for integrity and high-caliber professional services.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P235_S2	Allegations of improper conduct made by private litigants or regulators, whether the ultimate outcome is favorable or unfavorable to us, as well as negative publicity and press speculation about us, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation, which may be damaging to our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P236_S0	Our results could suffer if the mutual fund industry continues to experience slower growth, or if actively managed equity funds continue to attract less investor attention.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P237_S0	A significant portion of our revenue is generated from products and services related to mutual funds.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P238_S0	The mutual fund industry has experienced substantial growth over the past 30 years, but suffered along with the market downturn in 2008 and early 2009.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P238_S1	Since then, fund assets have increased, but at a slower rate than in previous years.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P238_S2	Based on Morningstar's estimates for U.S. mutual fund asset flows, long-term open-end funds had positive net inflows of approximately $243 billion in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P238_S3	However, assets continued to flow out of actively managed stock funds, with investors heavily favoring fixed-income funds and passively managed vehicles.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P238_S4	While equity funds had net outflows of approximately $104 billion in 2012, fixed-income funds experienced net inflows of more than $300 billion.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P239_S0	A significant portion of our fund research has historically focused on equity-related funds.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P239_S1	In addition, Morningstar is best known for our data and analyst research on actively managed equity funds.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P240_S0	Over the past several years, passively managed index funds have seen strong investor interest.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P240_S1	This trend continued in 2012, as passively managed vehicles (both mutual funds and ETFs) had nearly $200 billion in net inflows, compared with $7 billion of net outflows for active products.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P240_S2	Overall, we estimate that passively managed assets now account for about one-fourth of combined mutual fund and ETF assets.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P241_S0	Continued downturns or volatility in the financial markets, increased investor interest in other investment vehicles, or a lack of investor confidence could continue to reduce investor interest and investment activity.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P241_S1	In addition, a continued lessening of investor interest in actively managed equity funds could decrease demand for our products.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P242_S0	Failing to differentiate our products and continuously create innovative, proprietary research tools may harm our competitive position and business results.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S0	We attribute much of our company's success over the past 29 years to our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools, such as the Morningstar Rating, Morningstar Style Box, Ownership Zone, and Portfolio X-Ray.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S1	We believe these proprietary tools continue to provide us with a competitive advantage, but if tools similar to them become more broadly available through other channels, our competitive position and business results may suffer.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S2	Our competitive position and business results may also suffer if other companies are able to successfully introduce innovative, proprietary research tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S3	Because of lower technology costs and the growth of open software platforms, we believe the barriers to entry for new competitors have declined, making it easier for new players to enter the market.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S4	Smaller companies may also be able to introduce new research tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P243_S5	We cannot guarantee that we will continue to successfully develop new product features and tools that differentiate our product offerings from those of our competitors.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P244_S0	Failing to respond to technological change, keep pace with new technology developments, or adopt a successful technology strategy may negatively affect our competitive position and business results.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S0	We believe the technology landscape has been changing at an accelerating rate over the past several years.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S1	Changes in technology are fundamentally impacting the ways investors access data and content.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S2	Examples include the shift from local network to computing to cloud-based systems, the proliferation of wireless mobile devices, and rapid acceleration in the use of social media platforms.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S3	While some of these changes may offer business opportunities for Morningstar, we cannot guarantee that we will successfully adapt our product offerings to meet the rapidly changing technology landscape.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S4	We believe our history of rapid technological innovation and expertise in technology have historically given us a competitive advantage.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S5	As mentioned above, though, we believe that lower technology costs and growth in open software platforms have lowered barriers to entry for new competitors.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P245_S6	Our competitive position and business results may suffer if we fail to develop new technologies to meet client demands, or if we adopt a technology strategy that doesn't align with changes in the market.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P246_S0	Competition could reduce our share of the investment research market and hurt our financial performance.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P247_S0	We operate in a highly competitive industry, with many investment research providers competing for business from individual investors, financial advisors, and institutional clients.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P247_S1	We compete with many different types of companies that vary in size, product scope, and media focus, including large and well-established distributors of financial information, such as Bloomberg; Standard Poor's, a division of The McGraw-Hill Companies; and Thomson Reuters.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P247_S2	We compete with a variety of other companies in different areas of our business, which we discuss in greater detail in the Business Segments, Products, and Services section in Item 1-Business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P248_S0	Many of our competitors have larger customer bases and significantly greater resources than we do.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P248_S1	This may allow them to respond more quickly to new technologies and changes in demand for products and services, devote greater resources to developing and promoting their services, and make more attractive offers to potential clients, subscribers, and strategic partners.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P248_S2	Industry consolidation may also lead to more intense competition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P248_S3	Increased competition could result in price reductions, reduced margins, or loss of market share, any of which could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P249_S0	The investment information industry is dominated by a few large players, and industry consolidation has increased in the past several years.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P249_S1	If providers of data and investment analysis continue to consolidate, our competitive position may suffer.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P250_S0	Our operations outside of the United States are expanding and involve additional challenges that we may not be able to meet.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P251_S0	Our operations outside of the United States have expanded to $191.3 million in revenue in 2012 from $184.9 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM1_P252_S0	There are risks inherent in doing business outside the United States, including challenges in reaching new markets because of established competitors and limited brand recognition; difficulties in staffing, managing, and integrating non-U.S. operations; difficulties in coordinating and sharing information globally; differences in laws and policies from country to country; exposure to varying legal standards, including intellectual property protection laws; potential tax exposure related to transfer pricing and other issues; heightened risk of fraud and noncompliance; and currency exchange rates and exchange controls.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P252_S1	These risks could hamper our ability to expand around the world, which may hurt our financial performance and ability to grow.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P253_S0	As our non-U.S. revenue increases as a percentage of consolidated revenue, fluctuations in foreign currencies present a greater potential risk.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P253_S1	We don't engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P253_S2	Our reported revenue could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar, although the impact on operating income may be offset by an opposing currency impact on locally based operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P253_S3	In addition, because we use the local currency of our subsidiaries as the functional currency, our financial results are affected by the translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P254_S0	The increasing concentration of data and development work carried out at our offshore facilities may have a negative impact on our business operations, products, and services.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P255_S0	We now have approximately 900 employees working in our data and technology development center in Shenzhen, China, or about one-fourth of our total workforce.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P256_S0	Because China has a restrictive government under centralized control, we cannot predict the level of political and regulatory risk that may affect our operations.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P256_S1	The concentration of development and data work carried out at this facility also involves operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P256_S2	Any difficulties that we face in successfully maintaining our development center in China may harm our business and have a negative impact on the products and services we provide, particularly because of our increasing reliance on this facility.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P257_S0	We have approximately 360 employees who work at our data collection facility in Mumbai, India, which may also be subject to regulatory and political risk (including potential terrorist acts).
1289419_13_ITEM1_P257_S1	Like the Shenzhen operation, these facilities also involve operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P258_S0	We could face liability for the information we publish, including information based on data we obtain from other parties.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P259_S0	We may be subject to claims for securities law violations, defamation (including libel and slander), negligence, or other claims relating to the information we publish, including our research and ratings on corporate credit issuers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P259_S1	For example, investors may take legal action against us if they rely on published information that contains an error, or a company may claim that we have made a defamatory statement about it or its employees.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P259_S2	We could also be subject to claims based on the content that is accessible from our website through links to other websites.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P260_S0	We rely on a variety of outside parties as the original sources for the information we use in our published data.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P260_S1	These sources include securities exchanges, fund companies, hedge funds, transfer agents, and other data providers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P260_S2	Accordingly, in addition to possible exposure for publishing incorrect information that results directly from our own errors, we could face liability based on inaccurate data provided to us by others.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P260_S3	Defending claims based on the information we publish could be expensive and time-consuming and could adversely impact our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P261_S0	Our future success depends on our ability to recruit and retain qualified employees.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P262_S0	We experience competition for analysts and other employees from financial institutions and financial services organizations.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P262_S1	These organizations generally have greater resources than we do and therefore may be able to offer significantly more attractive compensation packages to potential employees.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P262_S2	Competition for these employees is intense, and we may not be able to retain our existing employees or be able to recruit and retain other highly qualified personnel in the future.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P263_S0	Our future success also depends on the continued service of our executive officers, including Joe Mansueto, our chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P263_S1	Joe is heavily involved in our day-to-day operations, business strategy, and overall company direction.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P263_S2	The loss of Joe or other executive officers could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P263_S3	We do not have employment agreements, non-compete agreements, or life insurance policies in place with any of our executive officers.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P263_S4	They may leave us and work for our competitors or start their own competing businesses.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P264_S0	Failure to protect our intellectual property rights could harm our brand and ability to compete effectively.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P265_S0	The steps we have taken to protect our intellectual property may not be adequate to safeguard our proprietary information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P265_S1	Further, effective trademark, copyright, and trade secret protection may not be available in every country in which we offer our services.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P265_S2	Our continued ability to market one or more of our products under their current names could be adversely affected in those jurisdictions where another person registers, or has a pre-existing registration on one or more of them.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P265_S3	Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property could harm our brand, devalue our proprietary content, and affect our ability to compete in the marketplace.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P266_S0	From time to time, we encounter jurisdictions in which one or more third parties have a pre-existing trademark registration in certain relevant international classes that may prevent us from registering our own marks in those jurisdictions.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P266_S1	It is possible that our continued ability to use the Morningstar name or logo, either on a stand-alone basis or in association with certain products or services, could be compromised in those jurisdictions because of these pre-existing registrations.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P266_S2	Similarly, from time to time, we encounter situations in certain jurisdictions where one or more third parties are already using the Morningstar name, either as part of a registered corporate name, a registered domain name or otherwise.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P266_S3	Our ability to effectively market certain products and/or services in those locations could be adversely affected by these pre-existing usages.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P267_S0	Failing to maintain and protect our brand, independence, and reputation may harm our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P267_S1	Our reputation and business may also be harmed by allegations made about possible conflicts of interest.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S0	We believe that independence is at the core of our business, and our reputation is our greatest corporate asset.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S1	We offer products and services to our institutional clients, which include banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies, mutual fund companies, media outlets, and retirement plan providers and sponsors.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S2	Our institutional clients have generated a significant percentage of our consolidated revenue in recent years.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S3	We provide ratings, analyst research, and investment recommendations on mutual funds and other investment products offered and securities issued by our institutional clients.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S4	We also provide investment advisory and investment management services.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P268_S5	The fact that our institutional clients pay us for certain products and services, as well as the fact that in some cases we make investment recommendations within the framework of client constraints, may create the perception that our ratings, research, and recommendations are not impartial.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P269_S0	This perception may undermine the confidence of our customers and potential customers in our reputation as a provider of independent research.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P269_S1	Any such loss of confidence or damage to our reputation could hurt our business.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P270_S0	Any failure to uphold our high ethical standards and ensure that our customers have a consistently positive experience with us (either intentionally or inadvertently) could damage our reputation as an objective, honest, and credible source for investment research and information.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P271_S0	Our reputation may also be harmed by factors outside of our control, such as news reports about our clients or adverse publicity about certain investment products.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P272_S0	Control by a principal shareholder could adversely affect our other shareholders.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P273_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , Joe Mansueto, our chairman and chief executive officer, owned approximately 53% of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P273_S1	As a result, he has the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to our shareholders for approval, including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P273_S2	He also has the ability to control our management and affairs.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P273_S3	This concentration of ownership may delay or prevent a change in control; impede a merger, consolidation, takeover, or other business combination involving Morningstar; discourage a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the company; or result in actions that may be opposed by other shareholders.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P274_S0	Fluctuations in our operating results may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S0	We believe our business has relatively large fixed costs and low variable costs, which magnify the impact of revenue fluctuations on our operating results.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S1	As a result, a decline in our revenue may lead to a larger decline in operating income.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S2	A substantial portion of our operating expense is related to personnel costs, marketing programs, office leases, and other infrastructure spending, which generally cannot be adjusted quickly.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S3	Our operating expense levels are based on our expectations for future revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S4	If actual revenue falls below our expectations, or if our expenses increase before revenues do, our operating results would be materially and adversely affected.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S5	In addition, we do not provide earnings guidance or hold one-on-one meetings with institutional investors and research analysts.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S6	Because of this policy and limited analyst coverage on our stock, our stock price may be volatile.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P275_S7	If our operating results or other operating metrics fail to meet the expectations of outside research analysts and investors, the market price of our common stock may decline.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P276_S0	The future sale of shares of our common stock may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P277_S0	If our shareholders sell substantial amounts of our common stock, the market price of our common stock could fall.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P277_S1	A reduction in ownership by Joe Mansueto or any other large shareholder could cause the market price of our common stock to fall.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P277_S2	In addition, the average daily trading volume in our stock is relatively low.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P277_S3	The lack of trading activity in our stock may lead to greater fluctuations in our stock price.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P277_S4	Low trading volume may also make it difficult for shareholders to make transactions in a timely fashion.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P278_S0	Our shareholders may experience dilution in their ownership positions.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P279_S0	In the past, we've granted options to employees as a significant part of their overall compensation package.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P279_S1	In 2006, we began granting restricted stock units to our employees and non-employee directors.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P279_S2	As of December 31, 2012 , our employees and non-employee directors held options to acquire 674,479 shares of common stock, 620,379 of which were exercisable at a weighted average price of approximately $22.66 per share.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P279_S3	As of December 31, 2012 , there were 745,927 restricted stock units outstanding, which have an average remaining vesting period of 33 months.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P280_S0	Generally speaking, the company issues a share of stock when a restricted stock unit vests.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P280_S1	To the extent that option holders exercise outstanding options to purchase common stock and shares are issued when restricted stock units vest, there will be further dilution.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P280_S2	Future grants of stock options or restricted stock units may also result in dilution.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P281_S0	We may raise additional funds through future sales of our common stock.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P281_S1	Any such financing would result in additional dilution to our shareholders.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P282_S0	Stock option exercises, share repurchases, and other factors may create volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P283_S0	Part of our cash provided by financing activities consists of proceeds from stock option exercises and excess tax benefits related to stock option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P283_S1	Excess tax benefits occur at the time a stock option is exercised if the intrinsic value of the option (the difference between the exercise price of the option and the fair value of our stock on the date of exercise) exceeds the fair value of the option at the time of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P283_S2	Similarly, excess tax benefits are generated upon vesting of restricted stock units when the market value of our common stock at vesting is greater than the grant price of the restricted stock units.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P283_S3	These excess tax benefits reduce the cash we pay for income taxes in the year they are recognized.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P284_S0	It is not possible to predict the timing of stock option exercises or the intrinsic value that will be realized.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P284_S1	Because of this uncertainty, there may be additional volatility in our cash flows from financing activities.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P285_S0	In addition, our board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program allowing for the repurchase of up to $500 million of our outstanding common stock, of which $188.5 million remains available for future repurchases as of February 22, 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P285_S1	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that management deems appropriate.
1289419_13_ITEM1_P285_S2	Changes in the amount of repurchase activity from period to period may also cause volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_13_ITEM1B_P0_S0	We do not have any unresolved comments from the Staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding our periodic or current reports under the Exchange Act.
1289419_13_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , we leased approximately 305,000 square feet of office space for our U.S. operations, primarily for our office located in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_13_ITEM2_P0_S1	We also lease approximately 351,000 square feet of office space in 24 other countries around the world, including 141,000 square feet in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_13_ITEM2_P0_S2	We believe that our existing and planned office facilities are adequate for our needs and that additional or substitute space is available to accommodate growth and expansion.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P0_S0	In September 2011, three individual investors in Life's Good S.T.A.B.L. Mortgage hedge fund (LG), Marta Klass, Gregory Martin, and Richard Roellig, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against LG, its principal Robert Stinson, and several other parties, including Morningstar, Inc. (the Klass Matter).
1289419_13_ITEM3_P0_S1	The plaintiffs claim that Morningstar committed fraud and aided and abetted the other defendants' breach of fiduciary duty through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P1_S0	Hedge fund managers self-report their performance data to Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P2_S0	More than a year before the Klass Matter, in June 2010, the SEC filed suit against LG and other entities claiming they were part of a Ponzi scheme operated by Stinson.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P2_S1	As a result, LG and the other entities were placed in court-appointed receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P2_S2	Morningstar was not part of the SEC suit or receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P2_S3	Since that time, the Receiver, as part of his duties, has been investigating whether to assert claims against third parties.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P3_S0	Morningstar is aware of 14 lawsuits filed by the Receiver seeking to recover money for the fund.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P4_S0	In November 2011, Morningstar filed a motion to dismiss the Klass Matter.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P5_S0	On behalf of the entities in receivership, the Receiver filed a motion to stay the proceedings because the Receivership Order does not permit suits against the entities in receivership without court permission.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P5_S1	The court granted the Receiver's motion and stayed the Klass Matter.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P6_S0	In April 2012, the Receiver filed a complaint against Morningstar, in which the Receiver claims that Morningstar is liable for contribution and aiding and abetting Stinson's breach of fiduciary duty and fraud through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P6_S1	The same day the Receiver filed his complaint, Morningstar sought leave from the court to file a counter suit against Stinson and two of his entities-Keystone State Capital Corporation and LG-for, among other things, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of user agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P6_S2	In June 2012, the court denied Morningstar's motion for leave to file suit.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P6_S3	The court took no position on the merits of Morningstar's claims, and did not preclude Morningstar from renewing its motion to file a complaint at a later time, but deferred to the Receiver's request not to subject the receivership estate to additional litigation at this early point in the receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P6_S4	In August 2012, the court denied Morningstar's motion to dismiss the Receiver's complaint.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P7_S0	Morningstar believes the allegations against it by the Klass plaintiffs and the Receiver have no legal or factual basis and plans to vigorously contest the claims.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P7_S1	Morningstar also intends to refile its affirmative claims against Stinson, Keystone, and LG at a later time consistent with the court's order.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P8_S0	We cannot predict the outcome of the proceedings.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P9_S0	In November 2009, Business Logic Holding Corporation filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois against Ibbotson Associates, Inc. and Morningstar, Inc. relating to Ibbotson's prior commercial relationship with Business Logic.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P9_S1	Business Logic is alleging breach of contract and trade secret misappropriation in connection with Ibbotson's development of a proprietary web-service software and user interface that connects plan participant data with the Ibbotson Wealth Forecasting Engine.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P9_S2	Business Logic seeks, among other things, injunctive relief and unspecified damages.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P9_S3	Ibbotson and Morningstar answered the complaint, and Ibbotson asserted a counterclaim against Business Logic alleging trade secret misappropriation and breach of contract, seeking damages and injunctive relief.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P10_S0	While Morningstar and Ibbotson are vigorously contesting the claims against them, we cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P11_S0	We have not provided an estimate of loss or range of loss in connection with the matters described above because no such estimate can reasonably be made.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P12_S0	In June 2010, Egan-Jones Rating Co. filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania against Realpoint, LLC (now known as Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC) and Morningstar, Inc. in connection with a December 2007 agreement between Egan-Jones and Morningstar Credit Ratings for certain data-sharing and other services.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P12_S1	In addition to damages, Egan-Jones filed a petition seeking an injunction to temporarily prevent Morningstar from offering corporate credit ratings through December 31, 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P12_S2	In September 2010, the court denied Egan-Jones's request for a preliminary injunction against Morningstar's corporate credit ratings business.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P12_S3	In December 2012, Morningstar Credit Ratings, Morningstar, and Egan Jones entered into a settlement agreement resolving the litigation.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P13_S0	In addition to these proceedings, we are involved in legal proceedings and litigation that have arisen in the normal course of our business.
1289419_13_ITEM3_P13_S1	Although the outcome of a particular proceeding can never be predicted, we do not believe that the result of any of these other matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.
1289419_13_ITEM5_P0_S0	Our common stock is listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol MORN .

1289419_13_ITEM5_P3_S1	The first dividend was paid on January 14, 2011 to shareholders of record on December 31, 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM5_P3_S2	We paid a dividend during each quarter of 2011 and 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM5_P3_S3	On December 7, 2012 , our board of directors declared a dividend of 12.5 cents per share, payable on December 28, 2012 to shareholders of record as of December 17, 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM5_P3_S4	This was our fifth dividend payment in 2012 because we opted to pay the dividend in December instead of in January 2013.

1289419_13_ITEM5_P5_S1	Future indebtedness and loan facilities could also prohibit or restrict our ability to pay dividends and make distributions to our shareholders.

1289419_13_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected historical financial data shown below should be read in conjunction with Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. We have derived our Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Other Consolidated Financial Data for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011, and 2010 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P0_S1	The Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Other Consolidated Financial Data for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2010, 2009, and 2008 were derived from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements, as restated, that are not included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) We account for our stock-based compensation expense in accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P1_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, and stock options.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P2_S0	We began granting restricted stock units in May 2006 and have made additional grants each year since then.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P2_S1	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day prior to grant.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P2_S2	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P3_S0	Beginning in 2010, we began recording expense related to restricted stock issued with the acquisition of Realpoint, LLC.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P3_S1	In May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares that will vest over five years from the date of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P3_S2	The restricted stock vests ratably over a five-year period from the acquisition date and may be subject to forfeiture if the holder terminates his or her employment during the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P3_S3	The expense in 2012 and 2011 includes $3.2 million and $0.4 million, respectively, for accelerated vesting of a portion of this restricted stock.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P4_S0	We did not grant any stock options in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P4_S1	In 2011, we granted 92,201 stock options to our executive officers and non-employee directors.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P4_S2	We estimate the fair value of our stock options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P4_S3	We amortize the fair values to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P5_S0	The total expense for stock-based compensation is distributed with other employee compensation costs in the appropriate operating expense categories of our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P5_S1	Refer to Note 12 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for more information on our stock-based compensation.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P6_S0	(2) Cash provided by (used for) investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the sale of investments, capital expenditures, purchases of equity and cost- method investments, and proceeds from the sale of businesses.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P6_S1	The level of investing activities can vary from period to period depending on the level of activity in these categories.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P6_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for investing activities.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P7_S0	(3) Cash provided by (used for) financing activities consists primarily of proceeds from stock-option exercises and excess tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P7_S1	These cash inflows are offset by cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program, which we began in the fourth quarter of 2010 and dividend payments.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P7_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources , for more information concerning cash provided by financing activities.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P8_S0	(4) Free cash flow is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under SEC regulations.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P8_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P8_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P8_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required to be reported under GAAP, nor should this data be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P8_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P9_S0	(5) We frequently invoice or collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_13_ITEM6_P9_S1	These amounts are recorded as deferred revenue on our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P0_S0	The discussion included in this section, as well as other sections of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, contains forward-looking statements as that term is used in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P0_S1	These statements are based on our current expectations about future events or future financial performance.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P0_S2	Forward-looking statements by their nature address matters that are, to different degrees, uncertain, and often contain words such as may, could, expect, intend, plan, seek, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, potential, or continue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P0_S3	These statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause the events we discuss not to occur or to differ significantly from what we expect.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P0_S4	For us, these risks and uncertainties include, among others, general industry conditions and competition, including current global financial uncertainty; the impact of market volatility on revenue from asset-based fees; damage to our reputation resulting from claims made about possible conflicts of interest; liability for any losses that result from an actual or claimed breach of our fiduciary duties; financial services industry consolidation; a prolonged outage of our database and network facilities; challenges faced by our non-U.S. operations; and the availability of free or low-cost investment information.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	A more complete description of these risks and uncertainties can be found in Item 1A - Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P1_S1	If any of these risks and uncertainties materialize, our actual future results may vary significantly from what we expected.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P1_S2	We do not undertake to update our forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	All dollar and percentage comparisons, which are often accompanied by words such as increase, decrease, grew, declined, was up, was down, was flat, or was similar refer to a comparison with the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	Our mission is to create great products that help investors reach their financial goals.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P3_S1	We offer an extensive line of data, software, and research products for individual investors, financial advisors, and institutional clients.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P3_S2	We also offer asset management services for advisors, institutions, and retirement plan participants.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P3_S3	Many of our products are sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P3_S4	As a result, we typically generate recurring revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	Morningstar has two operating segments: Investment Information and Investment Management.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	The Investment Information segment includes all of our data, software, and research products and services.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P4_S2	These products and services are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Investment Management segment includes our asset management operations, which operate as registered investment advisors and earn more than half of their revenue from asset-based fees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P5_S1	We emphasize a decentralized approach to running our business to empower our managers and to create a culture of responsibility and accountability.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	Over our 28-year history, we have focused primarily on organic growth by introducing new products and services and expanding our existing products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P6_S1	From 2006 through 2010, we also completed 24 acquisitions to support our growth strategies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	We generate revenue by selling a variety of investment-related products and services.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S1	We sell most of our products and services, including Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Equity Research, Retirement Solutions, and some of our structured credit research and ratings offerings, through license agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S2	Our license agreements typically range from one to three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S3	We sell some of our other products, such as newsletters, Principia software, and Premium service on Morningstar.com, via subscriptions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S4	These subscriptions are mainly offered for a one-year term, although we also offer terms ranging from one month to three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P7_S5	We also sell advertising on our websites throughout the world.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	For our Investment Advisory services, we generally base our fees on the scope of work and the level of service we provide and calculate them as a percentage of assets under advisement.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	We also earn fees relating to Morningstar Managed Portfolios and the managed retirement accounts offered through Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson that we calculate as a percentage of assets under management.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P8_S2	Overall, revenue tied to asset-based fees accounted for about 12% of our consolidated revenue in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	We frequently invoice our clients and collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	As a result, we use some of this cash to fund our operations and invest in new product development.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P9_S2	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and totaled $146.0 million as of December 31, 2012 and $155.5 million as of December 31, 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P9_S3	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill the service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	Our business requires significant investments to create and maintain proprietary databases and content.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S1	We strive to leverage these costs by selling a wide variety of products and services to multiple investor segments, through multiple media, and in many geographical markets.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S2	In general, our businesses have high fixed costs, and we expect our revenue to increase or decrease more quickly than our expenses.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S3	We believe that while the fixed costs of the investments in our business are relatively high, the variable cost of adding customers is considerably lower, particularly as a significant portion of our products and services focus on Internet-based platforms and assets under management.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S4	At times, we will make investments in building our databases and content that will hurt our short-term operating results.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S5	During other periods, our profitability may improve because we're able to increase revenue without increasing our cost base at the same rate.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P10_S6	When revenue decreases, however, the operating leverage in our business may reduce our profitability.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	We classify our operating expense into separate categories for cost of goods sold, development, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and depreciation and amortization, as described below.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P11_S1	We include stock-based compensation expense, as appropriate, in each of these categories.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	This category includes compensation expense for employees who produce the products and services we deliver to our customers.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	For example, this category covers production teams and analysts who write investment research reports.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P12_S2	Cost of goods sold also includes other expense such as third-party data purchases, data lines, postage, printing, and shareholder servicing fees for Morningstar Managed Portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	This category includes compensation expense for programmers, designers, and other employees who develop new products and enhance existing products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	In some cases, we capitalize the compensation costs associated with certain development projects.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P14_S1	This reduces the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P14_S2	We amortize these capitalized costs over the estimated economic life of the software, which is generally three years, and include this expense in depreciation and amortization.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our sales teams, product managers, and other marketing professionals.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P15_S1	We also include the cost of advertising, direct mail campaigns, and other marketing programs to promote our products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	This category consists mainly of compensation expense for each segment's management team, as well as human resources, finance, and support employees for each segment.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P16_S1	The category also includes compensation expense for senior management and other corporate costs, including corporate systems, finance and accounting, legal, compliance, and facilities expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	Our capital expenditures consist of computers, leasehold improvements, and capitalized product development costs related to certain software development projects.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful life of the asset, which ranges from three to seven years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P17_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P17_S3	We amortize capitalized product development costs over their estimated economic life, which is generally three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P17_S4	We also include amortization related to intangible assets, which is mainly driven by acquisitions, in this category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated economic useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	We have majority-owned operations in 25 countries outside of the United States and include these in our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P19_S1	We account for our minority-owned investments in Japan and Sweden using the equity method.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	When our analysts evaluate a stock, they focus on assessing the company's estimated intrinsic value-the value of the company's future cash flows, discounted to their worth in today's dollars.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P20_S1	Our approach to evaluating our own business works the same way.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	Our goal is to increase the intrinsic value of our business over time, which we believe is the best way to create value for our shareholders.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P21_S1	We do not make public financial forecasts for our business because we want to avoid creating any incentives for our management team to make speculative statements about our financial results that could influence the stock price, or to take actions that help us meet short-term forecasts but may not be in the long-term interest of building shareholder value.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	We provide three specific measures that can help investors generate their own assessment of how our intrinsic value has changed over time:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	Revenue (including organic revenue); Operating income (loss); and Free cash flow, which we define as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	Organic revenue is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulations.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	We define organic revenue as consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	We present organic revenue because we believe it helps investors better compare our period-to-period results, and our management team uses this measure to evaluate the performance of our business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	Free cash flow is also considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P26_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P26_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and should not be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P26_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	To evaluate how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue, we calculate a retention rate.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	We use two different methods for calculating retention.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S2	For subscription-based products (including our print newsletters, Morningstar.com Premium Membership service, and Principia software), we track the number of subscriptions retained during the year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S3	For products sold through contracts and licenses, we use the contract value method, which is based on tracking the dollar value of renewals compared with the total dollar value of contracts up for renewal during the period.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S4	We include changes in the contract value in the renewal amount, unless the change specifically results from adding a new product that we can identify.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S5	We also include variable-fee contracts in this calculation and use the previous quarter's actual revenue as the base rate for calculating the renewal percentage.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P27_S6	The retention rate excludes setup and customization fees, migrations to other Morningstar products, and contract renewals that were pending as of January 31, 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	We monitor developments in the economic and financial information industry on an ongoing basis.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P28_S1	We use these insights to help inform our company strategy, product development plans, and marketing initiatives.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	Despite lingering concerns about the pending fiscal cliff and the strength of the economic recovery, the U.S. stock market finished 2012 with double-digit returns for the year, following only a slight positive return in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P29_S1	Morningstar's U.S. Market Index, a broad market benchmark, ended the year up 16.3%.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P29_S2	Global markets closed out the year with similarly strong results.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	Total U.S. mutual fund assets rose to $13.0 trillion as of December 31, 2012, compared with $11.6 trillion as of December 31, 2011, based on data from the Investment Company Institute (ICI).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	Although aggregate cash flows to mutual funds were positive for the year, investors continued to heavily favor fixed-income funds rather than equity funds.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	Based on Morningstar's analysis of fund flow trends, fixed-income funds experienced net inflows of more than $300 billion in 2012, but equity funds had net outflows of approximately $100 billion.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P30_S3	Global mutual fund assets showed a similar trend, with total assets increasing but asset flows favoring fixed-income funds.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	Investors have also continued to favor passively managed index funds rather than actively managed portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P31_S1	This trend continued in 2012, as passively managed vehicles had more than $260 billion in net inflows, compared with about $190 billion of net inflows for active products (both mutual funds and ETFs).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	The number of mutual funds in the United States was essentially unchanged (excluding multiple share classes), with about 7,600 funds in both 2012 and 2011 based on ICI data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	The number of global mutual funds rose to about 73,500 as of September 30, 2012, compared with about 72,000 as of September 30, 2011, based on ICI data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	ETFs continued to increase in popularity relative to traditional mutual funds.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P33_S1	The U.S. ETF industry closed out 2012 with more than $1.3 trillion in assets under management based on ICI data, up from about $1 trillion at the end of 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	Based on data from ComScore, aggregate page views to financial and investment sites declined by about 9% in 2012, while the number of pages viewed per visit and time spent per visit were each down roughly 20%.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P34_S1	The number of unique visitors, meanwhile, fell about 4%.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P34_S2	We believe these trends reflect individual investors' continuing lower level of interest in financial- and investment-related content in the wake of the market downturn.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P34_S3	For Morningstar.com, metrics such as pages viewed per visit, time spent per visit, and unique visitors also declined, although unique visitors rose slightly during the fourth quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	Amid these trends, we believe online advertising spending by financial services companies was weaker in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P35_S1	Although Magna Global, a division of Interpublic Group, estimates that global online advertising revenue rose about 14% across all industries in 2012, financial services companies have been cautious about spending.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P36_S0	In the wake of the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, regulators have continued to implement new rules for financial services companies globally.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P36_S1	Many of these relate to financial advisor compensation, fees and expenses, investor disclosure, and the use of hedge funds and alternative investments.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P36_S2	In the United Kingdom, for example, the Retail Distribution Review (RDR), which emphasizes increased regulation of advisory fees, higher professional standards for financial advisors, and an emphasis on "whole of market" investment solutions, became effective in December 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P36_S3	Advisors are now required to give clients a choice of all investment vehicles (including funds, ETFs, and other products) and demonstrate that they consider different investment options without bias.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P36_S4	We believe this requirement may increase the business need for investment information on multiple investment types, which we offer through products such as Morningstar Direct and Morningstar Advisor Workstation.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P37_S0	In the European Union, Undertakings for Collective Investments in Transferable Securities (UCITS) is a set of EU directives designed to enable funds to operate across the EU based upon authorization from one state regulator.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P37_S1	UCITS IV, which came into effect in July 2011, included requirements for a new Key Investor Information Document (KIID), an easy-to-read annual factsheet that replaces the Simplified Prospectus.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P37_S2	Every UCITS fund that is promoted to retail investors is now required to produce a KIID and issue an updated copy each year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P37_S3	We've started using our data and production capabilities to help fund companies produce and distribute these documents.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P38_S0	In Australia, the government has introduced a series of Future of Financial Advice reforms, with implementation voluntary beginning in July 2012 and mandatory beginning in July 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P38_S1	Many of these related to fiduciary standards and compensation structures for financial advisors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P39_S0	In the United States, President Obama signed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank) into law in July 2010.
