1289419_13_ITEM7_P39_S1	Dodd-Frank creates a number of new regulatory, supervisory, and advisory bodies and touches on the regulation of virtually every aspect of U.S. financial markets and activities.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P39_S2	Dodd-Frank also left numerous matters to be addressed through rulemaking and other regulatory action, giving the regulators significant discretion in many areas.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P39_S3	As a result, the final shape and effect of the legislation are continuing to emerge.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P40_S0	Dodd-Frank included a number of corporate governance and disclosure requirements that apply to publicly traded companies generally.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P40_S1	It also included changes to the regulatory framework for credit rating agencies granting the SEC more oversight over Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organizations (NRSROs), including our Morningstar Credit Ratings subsidiary.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P40_S2	While we believe Dodd-Frank and related regulations will not have a significant effect on Morningstar (other than Morningstar Credit Ratings), we continue to monitor the potential impact on our clients.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P41_S0	We are also monitoring a pending amendment to the Department of Labor's ERISA underwriting exemptions that would expand the number of approved rating agencies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P42_S0	In many cases, market issuers favor ratings from ERISA-approved agencies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P42_S1	Morningstar Credit Ratings doesn't currently qualify as an ERISA-eligible agency under existing Department of Labor requirements, but would qualify under the proposed amendment.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P43_S0	As noted in How We Evaluate Our Business, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P43_S1	Please refer to the discussion on page 45 for more detail.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P44_S0	Because we ve made several acquisitions in recent years and had two divestitures in 2012, comparing our financial results from year to year is complex.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P44_S1	To make it easier for investors to compare our results in different periods, we provide information on both organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations, and revenue from acquisitions and divestitures.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P44_S2	We include an acquired operation as part of our revenue from acquisitions for 12 months after we complete the acquisition.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P44_S3	After that, we include it in organic revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P44_S4	We include a divested operation as part of revenue from divestitures for 12 months after we complete the divestiture.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P45_S0	Consolidated organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P46_S0	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P46_S1	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P47_S0	The table below shows the period in which we included each acquired operation in revenue from acquisitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P48_S0	In 2012, our consolidated revenue increased 4.3% to $658.3 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P48_S1	We had no incremental revenue during 2012 from acquisitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P48_S2	Our 2011 results included revenue of $1.1 million from businesses that we sold in 2012 and that did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P48_S3	Currency movements had a negative effect, lowering revenue growth by $4.6 million.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P48_S4	The euro, and to a lesser extent, the British pound, were the primary contributors to the negative currency impact.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P49_S0	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations, our consolidated revenue rose by $32.6 million , or 5.2% , in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P49_S1	Leading the growth was Morningstar Direct, followed by Morningstar Data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P49_S2	Morningstar Advisor Workstation and Integrated Web Tools also contributed to the organic revenue increase, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P49_S3	These factors helped offset the loss of business from the largest client in our Investment Management segment.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P49_S4	We recognized $3.8 million in associated revenue in 2012 compared with $12.4 million in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P50_S0	In 2011, our consolidated revenue increased 13.7% to $631.4 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P50_S1	We had $15.3 million in incremental revenue during 2011 from acquisitions completed in 2010, mainly reflecting incremental revenue from Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC (formerly Realpoint, LLC) and, to a lesser extent, the annuity intelligence business of Advanced Sales and Marketing Corporation and Old Broad Street Research Ltd. (OBSR).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P50_S2	Acquisitions contributed about 2.8 percentage points to our consolidated revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P50_S3	Currency movements also had a positive effect, contributing approximately 1.8 percentage points to revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P51_S0	The Australian dollar, and to a lesser extent, the British pound, the euro, and the Canadian dollar were the primary contributors to the currency benefit.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P52_S0	Excluding acquisitions and the effect of foreign currency translations, our consolidated revenue rose $50.6 million , or 9.1% , in 2011 , with increases across all major product lines.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P52_S1	Leading the growth were Morningstar Direct and Investment Advisory Services, followed by Morningstar Integrated Web Tools, Morningstar Data, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P52_S2	Internet advertising sales from Morningstar.com, Retirement Solutions, and Structured Credit Ratings also contributed to the organic revenue increase, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P53_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations):
1289419_13_ITEM7_P54_S0	Revenue from international operations was down slightly as a percentage of total revenue in 2012 compared with 2011 and up slightly compared with 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P54_S1	Our non-U.S. revenue was 29.1% of consolidated revenue in 2012 , compared with 29.3% in 2011 and 28.3% in 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P54_S2	More than half of our international revenue came from Europe, with most of the remainder from Australia and Canada.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P54_S3	Divested businesses contributed $1.0 million to 2011 revenue that did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P55_S0	Foreign currency translations had a negative effect on international revenue in 2012, but a positive effect in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P55_S1	Foreign currency translations decreased revenue by $4.6 million in 2012 , but increased revenue by $10.1 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P55_S2	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations, non-U.S. revenue rose 6.5% in 2012 and 7.7% in 2011 , primarily reflecting stronger product sales in Europe and Canada, partially offset by lower revenue in Australia.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P56_S0	International organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P56_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P56_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P57_S0	The tables below present a reconciliation from international revenue to international organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the impact of foreign currency translations):
1289419_13_ITEM7_P58_S0	Our five largest products based on revenue Morningstar Data (previously Licensed Data), Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Direct, Investment Advisory Services (previously Investment Consulting), and Morningstar.com made up 63.9% of consolidated revenue in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P58_S1	While the percentage of revenue made up by our top five products has remained relatively consistent over the past three years, the relative size of products within the top five has changed each year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P58_S2	Morningstar Data has been our largest product for the last three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S0	Beginning in 2012, we reviewed the revenue classification for our Morningstar Data product.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S1	The Morningstar Data product now includes Morningstar Commodity Data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S2	In addition, as part of our global product structure, we reviewed the revenue classification for our Investment Advisory Services (previously Investment Consulting) revenue to better align our non-U.S. operations with our U.S. product definitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S3	Subsequent to the first quarter, we made some additional, minor reclassifications for Morningstar Advisor Workstation and Morningstar.com.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S4	We reclassified the prior-year information for consistency with the current-year presentation.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P59_S5	As presented in the tables below, these reclassifications changed the order of Advisor Workstation and Investment Advisory Services in our top five products in 2011, but did not have any effect on the order of our top five products in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P60_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business, we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P60_S1	The following graph illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P61_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Morningstar Data, Investment Advisory Services, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average renewal rate was between 90% and 95%, within the same range as 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P61_S1	While the loss of business from our largest client had a negative effect on the renewal rate for Investment Advisory Services, renewals for other major products were slightly higher, on average, than in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P61_S2	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes and changes to the contract value upon renewal, as well as changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P62_S0	In 2012, we estimate that our retention rate for subscription-based products, such as Principia, Morningstar.com's Premium Membership service, and print and online newsletters, was between 65% and 70%, within the same range as 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P63_S0	In 2012 , our consolidated operating expense increased $14.6 million or 3.0% .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P64_S0	Higher salary expense of $14.0 million was the primary driver of the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P64_S1	The majority of the increase in salary expense reflects the full-year effect of regular pay raises and market adjustments made in July 2011, as well as regular pay raises made in July 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P64_S2	The rest of the increase represents the full-year salary impact of 2011 new hires and incremental expense for new hires in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P65_S0	We review employee salaries annually and implemented salary adjustments in the third quarter of 2012 and 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P65_S1	We had approximately 3,495 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2012 , compared with 3,465 as of December 31, 2011 and 3,225 as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P66_S0	Higher professional fees, production expense, company-sponsored benefits, including matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, and stock-based compensation expense also contributed to the increase in operating expense, although to a lesser extent than the salary expense discussed above.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P66_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense in 2012 includes $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of restricted stock issued to a former executive in the structured credit research unit when we acquired the business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P66_S2	Additional data purchases contributed to the $3.8 million growth in production expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P67_S0	Partially offsetting these increases was lower bonus expense of approximately $6.4 million in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P67_S1	Lower discretionary spending, including advertising and marketing and travel expense also offset the increases.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P67_S2	In addition, we capitalized $8.5 million of operating expense in 2012, primarily for software development.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P67_S3	In comparison, we capitalized $5.3 million of operating expense in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P68_S0	General and administrative expense (G A) in 2012 included about $1.6 million for a litigation settlement and an impairment charge for one of our smaller products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P68_S1	However, our results included a benefit of approximately $1.0 million for the resolution of a prior-year business tax expense matter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P68_S2	Conversely, our results in 2011 included $1.4 million of expense related to this business tax.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P68_S3	Our G A results for 2011 also included $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P68_S4	This expense did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P69_S0	Intangible amortization expense decreased $3.3 million , primarily because certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P69_S1	In addition, our 2011 results included $1.6 million of expense for the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P69_S2	Offsetting the decrease in amortization expense was higher depreciation expense of $3.5 million.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P70_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue decreased 1.0 percentage point in 2012, as the 4.3% increase in revenue slightly outpaced the 3.0% increase in operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P71_S0	In 2011 , our consolidated operating expense increased $58.7 million or 13.5% .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P72_S0	We completed seven acquisitions in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P72_S1	Because of the timing of these acquisitions, our results include operating expense that did not exist in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P72_S2	Incremental operating expense from acquired businesses represented approximately $13.4 million, or 23%, of the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P73_S0	Higher salary expense represented approximately 55%, or $32.0 million, of the total operating expense increase in 2011, reflecting additional hiring in 2011 and the full-year salary effect of 2010 new hires, and, to a lesser extent, additional headcount from acquisitions completed in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P73_S1	Salary adjustments that were effective in July 2011 also contributed to the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P74_S0	We review employee salaries annually and have generally implemented salary adjustments in the third quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P75_S0	We had approximately 3,465 employees worldwide as of December 31, 2011 , compared with 3,225 as of December 31, 2010 and 2,605 as of December 31, 2009.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P75_S1	About half of the headcount growth in 2011 reflects continued hiring for our development centers in China and India, with most of the remainder in the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P75_S2	The latter includes about 30 employees hired in July 2011 in Chicago as part of the Morningstar Development Program, a two-year rotational training program for entry-level employees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P76_S0	Incentive compensation and employee benefit costs represented approximately 24%, or $14.1 million, of the overall operating expense increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P76_S1	Higher bonus expense and sales commissions both contributed to the growth in incentive compensation.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P76_S2	Bonus expense rose $5.7 million, which was slightly offset by a $0.4 million gap between bonuses paid in the first quarter and the amount accrued in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P76_S3	Although total bonuses paid were $0.4 million lower than the amount accrued, there were some greater differences by cost category, which we describe below.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P76_S4	Sales commission expense was up $2.8 million, primarily in the United States and Europe.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P77_S0	In 2011, we reinstated some of the benefits we temporarily suspended in previous years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P77_S1	This included increasing the matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, representing $2.3 million of additional expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	Higher production expense, travel, and rent expense also contributed to operating expense growth, although to a lesser extent than the compensation-related items discussed above.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P78_S1	Higher data purchases for our operations in the U.S. and Europe contributed to the $4.2 million growth in production expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P78_S2	The $1.5 million increase in rent expense primarily reflects higher rent for our new office space in Shenzhen, China, and, to a lesser extent, for our office space in Chicago.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P78_S3	Our 2010 results included an expense of $1.0 million to increase liabilities for vacant office space.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P78_S4	This expense did not recur in 2011, partially offsetting the higher rent expense in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	Intangible amortization expense increased $2.4 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P79_S1	The increase primarily reflects amortization expense from 2010 acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P79_S2	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	Our 2011 results include $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P80_S1	Operating expense in 2010 included $2.0 million related to the separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P80_S2	This expense did not recur in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	We capitalized $5.3 million of operating expense in 2011, primarily for software development within the Structured Credit Ratings business, Morningstar Commodity Data, and for Morningstar Direct.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P81_S1	In 2010, we capitalized $0.8 million of operating expense for software development.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue decreased 0.1 percentage points in 2011, as the 13.7% increase in revenue slightly outpaced the 13.5% increase in operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	Cost of goods sold is our largest category of operating expense, representing more than one-third of our total operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P83_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and cost of goods sold includes the compensation expense for employees who produce our products and services.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P83_S2	Approximately one-half of our employees are included in this cost category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	Cost of goods sold rose $13.2 million in 2012 and $25.1 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P84_S1	Higher salaries contributed approximately 55% and 50% of the total increase in 2012 and 2011, respectively, primarily from additional headcount.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P84_S2	Higher production expense of $3.8 million and $4.2 million also contributed to the increase in both years, primarily from additional data purchases for our operations in the U.S. and Europe.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P84_S3	Other compensation-related expense, primarily employee benefit costs, also contributed to the increase in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	In 2011, higher bonus expense of $3.8 million for the 2011 annual bonus was offset by a $1.6 million reduction in bonus expense related to the prior-year bonus because we paid a smaller portion of the 2011 bonus to employees in this category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	Please refer to the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	Approximately 20% of the increase in 2011 was related to acquisitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	Our gross margin declined by about 0.9 percentage points and 0.5 percentage points in 2012 and 2011 , respectively, as expenses in this category increased at a faster rate compared with revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	Development expense decreased $1.7 million in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P88_S1	We capitalized $8.5 million of operating expense in 2012 compared with $5.3 million in 2011 for software development, reducing the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P88_S2	Lower bonus expense of $1.8 million also contributed to the decline.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P88_S3	Higher salaries and other compensation-related expense for our development teams partially offset the favorable effect of the capitalized operating expense in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	Development expense increased $3.9 million in 2011 mainly because of higher salaries, benefits, and bonus expense for our development teams.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P89_S1	We capitalized $5.3 million of operating expense in 2011 and $0.8 million in 2010 for software development, reducing the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P89_S2	Development expense from acquisitions also contributed to the increase in 2011, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	We had approximately 820 employees included in development expense as of December 31, 2012 compared with 830 as of December 31, 2011 and 760 as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	As a percentage of revenue, development expense was down slightly in 2012 and 2011, primarily reflecting the effect of capitalizing operating expense for software development.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $2.2 million in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	Higher salary expense of $4.1 million and higher bonus expense of $1.5 million were partially offset by lower advertising and marketing expense and lower commissions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	Full-year bonus expense was flat in 2012; however, in the first quarter of 2012, we paid a greater portion of the 2011 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $1.0 million to the bonus expense recorded in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P92_S3	Please refer to the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $11.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P93_S1	Approximately 17% of the growth in sales and marketing expense in the year was related to acquisitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P93_S2	Higher salary-related expense represents about 53% of the overall expense increase in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P93_S3	Higher sales commission expense, other compensation-related expenses, and travel expense also contributed to the increase in the year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P93_S4	Lower bonus expense partially offset the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense was down in 2012 primarily reflecting lower advertising and marketing expense and commissions as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P94_S1	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense was down in 2011, primarily reflecting lower bonus expense as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S0	General and Administrative (G A) expense rose $0.8 million in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	Higher professional fees and higher stock-based compensation expense contributed to the total increase in G A. Our stock-based compensation expense in 2012 includes $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of restricted stock issued to a former executive in the structured credit research unit when we acquired the business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S2	Lower bonus expense of $5.7 million in 2012 partially offset the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S3	Current-year bonus expense was down $2.8 million.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S4	In addition, in the first quarter of 2011, we paid a greater portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $2.6 million to the bonus expense recorded in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P95_S5	Please refer to the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P96_S0	G A expense in 2012 included about $1.6 million of expense for a litigation settlement and an impairment charge for one of our smaller products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P96_S1	However, as mentioned above, our 2012 results included a benefit of approximately $1.0 million from the resolution of a prior-year business tax expense matter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P96_S2	Conversely, our results for 2011 included $1.4 million of expense related to this business tax.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P96_S3	G A in 2011 also included $3.2 million for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P96_S4	This expense did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P97_S0	G A rose $15.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	Higher compensation-related expense including salaries, bonus expense, and other compensation-related costs contributed about 70% of the total increase in G A expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P97_S2	Bonus expense included in G A expense increased $3.6 million in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P97_S3	In the first quarter of 2011, we paid a greater portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $2.6 million of the full-year increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P97_S4	Please refer to the section, Bonus Expense, for additional information.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P98_S0	Higher rent expense, mainly for our office space in China and additional office space in Chicago, also contributed to the growth in G A expense, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P99_S0	G A expense in 2011 included a $0.8 million reduction in sales tax accruals and a $2.0 million business tax rebate for our operations in China.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P99_S1	Partially offsetting these two items was $1.4 million of business tax expense related to prior years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P99_S2	G A expense in 2011 also includes $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P99_S3	Our 2010 results include $1.0 million to increase liabilities for vacant office space and $2.0 million related to a previously announced separation agreement between Morningstar and the former head of Morningstar Associates.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P99_S4	These two expenses did not recur in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P100_S0	G A expense as a percentage of revenue was down 0.6 percentage points in 2012 after increasing 0.4 percentage points in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P101_S0	Depreciation expense rose $3.5 million in 2012 , primarily related to increased capital expenditures for our operations in the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P101_S1	Depreciation expense increased $0.8 million in 2011 , primarily related to our new office space in China.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P102_S0	Amortization expense decreased $3.3 million in 2012 , primarily because certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P102_S1	In addition, our 2011 results included $1.6 million of expense for the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P102_S2	Amortization expense increased $2.4 million in 2011 , reflecting amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P102_S3	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P103_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost for the remaining life of the assets.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P103_S1	We estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be $21.2 million in 2013 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P103_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by additional acquisitions, divestitures, changes in the estimated average useful lives, and currency translations.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P104_S0	As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization expense was down slightly in 2012 and 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P105_S0	Stock-based compensation expense relates to grants of restricted stock units (RSUs), restricted stock, and stock options.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P106_S0	Our stock-based compensation expense related to RSUs has increased over the past three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P106_S1	We began granting RSUs in May 2006 and have made additional grants each year since then.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P106_S2	We recognize the expense related to RSUs over the vesting period, which is four years for employees and three years for non-employee directors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P106_S3	We estimate forfeitures for these awards and typically adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience in the third quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P106_S4	The expense recorded in 2011 was favorably affected by $0.5 million for restricted stock units that were forfeited in the first quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P107_S0	Restricted Stock: Beginning in 2010, we began recording expense related to restricted stock issued with the acquisition of Realpoint.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P107_S1	In May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares that will vest over five years from the date of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P107_S2	The restricted stock vests ratably over a five-year period from the acquisition date and may be subject to forfeiture if the holder terminates his or her employment during the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P107_S3	The expense in 2012 and 2011 includes $3.2 million and $0.4 million, respectively, for accelerated vesting of a portion of this restricted stock.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P108_S0	Stock Options: We did not grant any stock options in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P108_S1	In 2011, we granted 92,201 stock options to our executive officers and non-employee directors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P108_S2	These stock options vest ratably over a four-year period for executive officers and a three-year period for non-employee directors and expire 10 years after the date of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P108_S3	Using a Black-Scholes option pricing model, we estimated the fair value of these grants.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P108_S4	We amortize this value to stock-based compensation expense ratably over the options' vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P109_S0	We estimate forfeitures of these awards and adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience in the third quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P109_S1	We describe our stock-based compensation in more detail in Note 12 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P110_S0	Stock-based compensation is included in each of our operating expense categories, as shown below:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P111_S0	Based on grants of RSUs, stock options, and restricted stock made through December 31, 2012 , we anticipate that stock-based compensation expense will be $13.5 million in 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P111_S1	This amount is subject to change based on additional equity grants or changes in our estimated forfeiture rate related to these grants.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P112_S0	The amount of bonus expense is not a fixed cost.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P112_S1	Instead, the size of the bonus pool varies each year based on a number of items, including changes in full-year operating income relative to the previous year and other factors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P112_S2	We review and update our estimates and the bonus pool size quarterly, primarily based on our expectations for full-year operating income relative to budget.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P112_S3	We record bonus expense throughout the year and pay annual bonuses to employees in the first quarter of the following year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P113_S0	Bonus expense, which we include in each of our operating expense categories, decreased $6.4 million in 2012 and increased $ 5.3 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P114_S0	Overall, bonus expense represented about 5.5% , 6.8% , and 6.7% of revenue in 2012 , 2011 , and 2010 , respectively.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P115_S0	Bonus expense consisted of both the current-year bonus expense and the true-up related to the prior-year bonus accrual.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P115_S1	We adjust the prior-year bonus estimate to the actual bonus payout during the first quarter, which is when the payout occurs.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P115_S2	This true-up had a favorable effect of $0.1 million on total bonus expense in 2012 and $0.4 million in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P116_S0	While total bonuses paid out in 2012 and 2011 were only slightly lower compared with the amounts expensed in 2011 and 2010, respectively, there were some differences by cost category.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P116_S1	The table below presents the effect of these two factors by cost category and in total for 2012 and 2011:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P117_S0	Consolidated operating income increased $12.3 million in 2012 , and our margin was up 1.0 percentage point in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P117_S1	Our revenue growth of $26.9 million outpaced the increase in our costs of $14.6 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P118_S0	Lower bonus expense contributed 1.3 percentage points to our margin growth in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P118_S1	In addition, capitalized operating expense for software development contributed 0.5 percentage points to our margin growth in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P118_S2	Higher salaries and other compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue partially offset these increases.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P119_S0	Consolidated operating income increased $17.4 million , and our margin was up slightly in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P119_S1	We had revenue growth of $76.0 million , which outpaced expense growth of $58.7 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P120_S0	Capitalized operating expense for software development contributed 0.7 percentage points to our margin growth in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P120_S1	Higher salaries and other compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue partially offset the benefit of the capitalized operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P120_S2	In addition, acquisitions had a slight negative effect on the margin.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P121_S0	As described in more detail above, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P121_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P121_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P122_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P122_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P123_S0	We generated positive free cash flow in 2012 , 2011 , and 2010 as our cash provided by operating activities has consistently exceeded capital expenditures, as shown below:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P124_S0	Free cash flow decreased $25.7 million in 2012 and increased $33.0 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P125_S0	Cash provided by operating activities: Cash provided by operating activities decreased $19.0 million in 2012 , reflecting the negative cash flow effect of changes in operating assets and liabilities, a $9.3 million increase in cash paid for taxes, and a $5.3 million increase in bonuses paid in the first quarter of 2012 , partially offset by higher net income (adjusted for non-cash items).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P125_S1	We made cash payments of $47.4 million for income taxes in 2012, compared with $38.1 million in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P125_S2	We made bonus payments of $42.8 million in the first quarter of 2012 , compared with $37.5 million in the first quarter of 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P126_S0	Cash provided by operating activities increased $41.6 million in 2011 , reflecting the positive cash flow effect of changes in operating assets and liabilities and higher net income (adjusted for non-cash items), partially offset by a $16.1 million increase in bonuses paid in the first quarter of 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P126_S1	We made bonus payments of $37.5 million in the first quarter of 2011 , compared with $21.4 million in the first quarter of 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P127_S0	To provide investors with additional insight into our financial results, we provide a comparison between the change in consolidated net income and the change in operating cash flow:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P128_S0	In 2012 , the decrease in cash from operations more than offset the positive change in net income adjusted for non-cash items, primarily because of the negative cash flow effect of accounts receivable and accrued compensation.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P128_S1	An increase in cash paid for income taxes and cash paid for bonuses also contributed to the decrease.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P129_S0	In 2011 , the increase in cash from operations exceeded the change in net income adjusted for non-cash items, primarily because of the positive cash flow effect of accounts receivable, accrued compensation, and income taxes current.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P129_S1	In addition, the cash flow from operations in 2010 includes a $4.9 million payment related to adjusting the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options (ISOs).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P129_S2	This payment did not recur in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P129_S3	These items, which favorably affected the year-over-year comparison, were partially offset by the increase in bonus payments in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P129_S4	Cash provided by operating activities in 2011 also reflects $4.1 million of payments for separation agreements with two former executives.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P130_S0	FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , requires that we classify excess tax benefits as a financing activity, which contributes to the difference between net income and cash from operations.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P130_S1	In 2012 and 2011 , we classified $7.2 million and $9.5 million , respectively, of excess tax benefits as financing activities.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P130_S2	We describe these excess tax benefits in the Liquidity and Capital Resources section.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P131_S0	Capital expenditures: We spent $30.0 million for capital expenditures in 2012 , primarily for computer hardware and software, internally developed capitalized software, and spending for an expansion of office space in Chicago.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P132_S0	We spent $23.3 million for capital expenditures in 2011 , primarily for computer hardware and software, internally developed capitalized software, and leasehold improvements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P133_S0	In 2012 , capital expenditures increased $6.7 million , primarily for capitalized software and computer hardware and software for our U.S. operations and internally developed capitalized software.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P134_S0	The Investment Information segment includes all of our data, software, and research products and services.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P134_S1	These products are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P135_S0	The largest products in this segment based on revenue are Morningstar Data (formerly Licensed Data), Morningstar Advisor Workstation (including Morningstar Office), Morningstar Direct, Morningstar.com, Morningstar Integrated Web Tools, and Morningstar Principia.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P136_S0	Morningstar Data is a set of investment data spanning all of our investment databases, including real-time pricing and commodity data, and is available through electronic data feeds.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P137_S0	Advisor Workstation is a web-based investment planning system for advisors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P137_S1	Advisor Workstation is available in two editions: Morningstar Office for independent financial advisors and an enterprise edition for financial advisors affiliated with larger firms.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P138_S0	Morningstar Direct is a web-based institutional research platform.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P139_S0	Morningstar.com includes both Premium Memberships and Internet advertising sales.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P140_S0	Morningstar Integrated Web Tools is a set of services that help institutional clients build customized websites or enhance their existing sites with our online tools and components.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P140_S1	Principia is our CD-ROM-based investment research and planning software for advisors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P141_S0	The Investment Information segment also includes Morningstar Equity Research, which we distribute through several channels.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P141_S1	We sell Morningstar Equity Research to companies that purchase our research for their own use or provide our research to their affiliated advisors or individual investor clients.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P141_S2	The segment also includes Morningstar Credit Research and Morningstar Structured Credit Ratings.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P141_S3	The latter is provided by Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC, a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization specializing in structured finance.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P141_S4	It offers securities ratings, research, surveillance services, and data to help institutional investors identify risk in commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS).
1289419_13_ITEM7_P142_S0	We also offer a variety of financial communications and newsletters, other institutional and advisor software, and investment indexes.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P143_S0	This segment represented approximately 80% of our consolidated revenue in 2012 , 2011 , and 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P144_S0	In 2012 , Investment Information segment revenue increased $29.1 million , or 5.8% , to $530.0 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P144_S1	Our software, data, and investment research product lines all contributed to the revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P144_S2	Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Data, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation were the main contributors to revenue growth in 2012, partially offset by lower revenue for Morningstar.com.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P144_S3	In addition, our 2011 results included revenue of about $1.1 million from businesses that we sold in 2012 that did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S0	Investment Information segment revenue increased $56.0 million , or 12.6% , to $500.9 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S1	Acquisitions contributed $13.5 million of revenue in 2011 , primarily from Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC and to a lesser extent from the annuity intelligence business of Advanced Sales and Marketing Corporation (ASMC), Morningstar Denmark, and OBSR.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S2	Revenue from acquisitions represented approximately 3 percentage points of the revenue increase in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S3	Excluding acquisitions, our software, data, and investment research product lines all contributed to the revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S4	Organic revenue for our software product lines was up $26.2 million, driven by Morningstar Direct, and to a lesser extent by Morningstar Integrated Web Tools, Advisor Workstation, and Morningstar.com.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P145_S5	Morningstar Data and Morningstar Credit Ratings drove revenue growth in our data and investment research product lines, respectively.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P146_S0	Morningstar Direct was the largest contributor to the increase in segment revenue in both 2012 and 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P146_S1	Morningstar Direct contributed approximately 43% and 39% of the organic revenue growth for the segment in 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P146_S2	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to 7,435 worldwide, compared with 6,144 as of December 31, 2011 and 4,773 as of December 31, 2010 , with strong growth in both the United States and internationally.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P146_S3	The growth reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients, and, to a lesser extent, client migrations from both Institutional Workstation and Morningstar EnCorr to Morningstar Direct.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P147_S0	Morningstar Data was the second-largest contributor to segment revenue growth in both 2012 and 2011 , reflecting strong renewal rates and new client contracts for managed products data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P148_S0	Morningstar Data gives institutions access to a full range of proprietary investment data spanning numerous investment databases, including real-time pricing data and commodity data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P148_S1	The data packages we offer include proprietary statistics, such as the Morningstar Style Box and Morningstar Rating, and a wide range of other data, including information on investment performance, risk, portfolios, operations data, fees and expenses, cash flows, and ownership.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P149_S0	Higher revenue from Morningstar Integrated Web Tools and Advisor Workstation (mainly Morningstar Office) also contributed to revenue growth in 2012 and 2011, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P149_S1	The number of U.S. licenses for Morningstar Advisor Workstation increased to 162,904 as of December 31, 2012 compared with 160,287 as of December 31, 2011 , and 157,395 as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P149_S2	The increase in the number of U.S. licenses compared with December 31, 2010 was partially due to incremental licenses added through our acquisition of ASMC.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P149_S3	Lower revenue for Principia partially offset the higher revenue from these two products.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P150_S0	Principia subscriptions totaled 26,807 as of December 31, 2012 , down from 31,270 as of December 31, 2011 and 32,681 as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S0	Revenue for Morningstar.com, which includes Internet advertising sales and Premium Membership subscriptions, decreased in 2012, but contributed to the growth in the segment's revenue in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S1	Revenue was down in 2012 because of declining paid Premium subscriptions, primarily in the United States, and a difficult advertising sales market.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S2	The increase in 2011 Morningstar.com revenue was driven entirely by higher Internet advertising sales.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S3	Internet advertising revenue decreased 4.2% in 2012 compared with an increase of 18.8% in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S4	Premium subscriptions for the U.S. version of Morningstar.com declined to 123,899 as of December 31, 2012 , compared with 130,354 as of December 31, 2011 and 138,149 as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P151_S5	However, consistent with the trend over the past few years, we moderately increased subscription prices for U.S. Premium Membership in both January 2012 and 2011 , which partly offset the revenue decline associated with the lower subscription levels.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P152_S0	Newsletter revenue declined in both 2012 and 2011, primarily because of lower advertising sales for our trade magazines in Australia.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P153_S0	Revenue for our investment research products was up in 2012 and 2011, mainly reflecting higher revenue for equity and fund research.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P153_S1	Structured Credit Ratings also contributed to the increase in 2011, but was up only slightly in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P154_S0	Revenue growth was slow in 2012 because of competitive pricing pressure.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P154_S1	Within the structured credit ratings business in 2011, we had strong revenue growth earlier in the year driven by new issue rating assignments in the CMBS market.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P154_S2	In 2011, we rated 13 new issue CMBS deals, more than double the number in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P155_S0	In 2012 , operating income for the Investment Information segment increased $19.2 million , or 14.6% , as revenue rose more than operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P156_S0	Operating expense was up $9.9 million in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P156_S1	Higher salary-related expense, which increased $11.3 million compared with 2011, was the primary contributor to the increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P156_S2	Company-sponsored benefits, including matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, stock-based compensation expense, and production expense also contributed to the increase in operating expense, although to a lesser extent than salary expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P156_S3	Our stock-based compensation expense in 2012 includes $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of a portion of a restricted stock grant.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P156_S4	Additional data purchases for our operations in the United States and Europe contributed to the growth in production expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P157_S0	Lower incentive compensation, including bonus expense and commissions, and discretionary costs, including advertising, marketing, and travel, partially offset the higher expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P157_S1	Bonus expense decreased $4.6 million in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P158_S0	The Investment Information segment's operating margin increased 2.1 percentage points in 2012 , primarily reflecting lower bonus expense as a percentage of revenue, and, to a lesser extent, lower commission expense and discretionary spending as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P158_S1	Lower bonus expense contributed 1.2 percentage points to the margin improvement in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P159_S0	In 2011 , operating income for the Investment Information segment increased $3.8 million , or 3.0% , as revenue grew more than operating expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S0	Operating expense was up $52.2 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S1	Additional costs from acquisitions contributed approximately 18% of this increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S2	Higher salary-related expense and incentive compensation, including sales commission and bonus expense, contributed about 71% of the overall expense increase.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S3	Higher salary-related expense reflects additional hiring in 2011 and the full-year salary impact of 2010 new hires, and, to a lesser extent, additional headcount from acquisitions completed in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S4	Salary adjustments that were effective in July 2011 also contributed to the growth in salary expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P160_S5	Costs for employee benefits, including health care and matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States, contributed about 9% of the increase in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P161_S0	The Investment Information segment's operating margin decreased 2.4 percentage points in 2011 , primarily because of higher salary expense as a percentage of revenue, and, to a lesser extent, employee benefit and bonus costs as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P161_S1	Higher salary expense contributed 2.0 percentage points to the decline in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P162_S0	Acquisitions had only a minor effect on the segment margin.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P163_S0	The Investment Management segment includes all of our asset management operations, which earn more than half of their revenue from asset-based fees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P164_S0	The key products and services in this segment based on revenue are Investment Advisory Services (formerly Investment Consulting), which focuses on investment monitoring and asset allocation for multimanager portfolios, including mutual funds and variable annuities; Retirement Solutions, including the Morningstar Retirement Manager and Advice by Ibbotson platforms; and Morningstar Managed Portfolios, a fee-based discretionary asset management service that includes a series of mutual fund, ETF, and stock portfolios tailored to meet a range of investment time horizons, risk levels, and investment strategies that financial advisors can use for their clients taxable and tax-deferred accounts.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S0	Our Investment Advisory Services business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves managing investments or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S4	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S5	The method of calculation varies by client; some contracts include provisions for calculating average assets based on daily data, while others use weekly or monthly data.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P165_S6	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P166_S0	In our Retirement Solutions business, our contracts may include one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P166_S1	Our Retirement Solutions business also includes plan sponsor and custom target-date consulting arrangements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P166_S2	Fees for these services may be based on the level of assets under advisement in these arrangements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P167_S0	We do not disclose a fee range for our Investment Advisory Services and Retirement Solutions businesses because our fee structures are customized by client.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P167_S1	In addition, we believe disclosing a fee range would be detrimental to our competitive position.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P167_S2	We disclose changes in the nature of the underlying services we provide or their associated fee structures (for example, a change from flat fees to asset-based fees) in our SEC filings to the extent that they are material to our financial results.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P168_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s account balance.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P168_S1	Fees for our mutual fund and ETF portfolios generally range from 30 to 40 basis points.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P168_S2	We charge fees of 55 basis points for our customized stock portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P169_S0	In addition, we offer Managed Portfolios through our subsidiary Ibbotson Associates Australia, which provides asset management services primarily to institutional clients and individual investors.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P170_S0	This segment represented approximately 20% of our consolidated revenue in 2012 , 2011 , and 2010 , respectively.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P171_S0	Investment Management segment revenue decreased $2.2 million , or 1.7% , in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P172_S0	Our largest client in the Investment Management segment began managing several fund-of-funds portfolios in-house in April 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P172_S1	We recognized $3.8 million in associated revenue in 2012 compared with $12.4 million in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P172_S2	Excluding the loss of this business, Investment Advisory Services revenue was up $3.4 million in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P172_S3	Revenue for Morningstar Managed Portfolios, and to a lesser extent, Retirement Solutions, also rose in 2012, partially offsetting the loss of business discussed above.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S0	Investment Management segment revenue increased $20.1 million , or 18.2% , in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S1	Revenue from acquisitions was $1.9 million , primarily from the OBSR and Seeds acquisitions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S2	Excluding acquisitions, revenue was up across all three of our key product and service lines in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S3	Investment Advisory Services was the primary driver of the revenue increase and was driven by higher revenue in the United States and, to a lesser extent, in Europe.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S4	Retirement Solutions and Managed Portfolios also contributed to the revenue increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P173_S5	Managed Portfolios for Ibbotson Associates Australia was down, partially offsetting the revenue growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P174_S0	The variable annuity industry, which accounted for approximately 15% of Investment Management segment revenue in 2012, continues to face challenges.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P174_S1	Accordingly, we expect there will be further pressure on revenue from clients in the variable annuity industry.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P175_S0	We had $81.4 million in revenue from asset-based fees in 2012 , a slight decrease of $0.3 million compared with $81.7 million in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P175_S1	In 2010 , revenue from asset-based fees was $67.7 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P175_S2	Revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 12.4% of consolidated revenue in 2012 , down slightly from 12.9% in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P175_S3	Within the Investment Management segment, revenue from asset-based fees made up slightly more than 60% of segment revenue over the past three years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P176_S0	Total assets under advisement and management were $149.5 billion as of December 31, 2012 , a decrease from $180.9 billion as of December 31, 2011 and up slightly from $149.2 billion as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P177_S0	As mentioned above, our largest Investment Management client began managing several fund-of-fund portfolios in-house in April 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P177_S1	These portfolios represented $11.8 billion of our assets as of December 31, 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P177_S2	In addition, a change in the scope of services we provide to an existing client during the fourth quarter of 2012 lowered our assets by about $42.9 billion.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P177_S3	About $22 billion of the total assets as of December 31, 2011 compared with December 31, 2010 reflects additional assets for existing clients' fund-of-funds programs for which we now receive asset-based fees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P177_S4	The increase in assets represents incremental growth for an existing revenue stream.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P178_S0	The asset totals as of the end of each year don't fully reflect the change in average asset levels during the year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P178_S1	The asset-based fees we earn are primarily based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P178_S2	Average assets under advisement and management (calculated based on available quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $180.6 million in 2012 , up 9.3% from $165.3 billion in 2011 , and up 52.1% from $118.7 billion in 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P179_S0	We provided Investment Advisory Services on $94.3 billion in assets as of December 31, 2012 compared with $137.5 billion in assets as of December 31, 2011 and $108.0 billion in assets as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P180_S0	The asset totals include relationships for which we receive basis-point fees, including consulting arrangements and other agreements where we act as a portfolio construction manager for a mutual fund or variable annuity.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P180_S1	We also provide Investment Advisory services for some assets for which we receive a flat fee; we do not include these assets in the total reported above.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P181_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P182_S0	Assets under advisement and management decreased $43.2 billion , or 31.4% , compared with December 31, 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P183_S0	As mentioned above, our largest Investment Management client began managing several fund-of-funds portfolios in-house in April 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P183_S1	These portfolios represented $11.8 billion, or 8.6% of our Investment Advisory Services assets under advisement and management as of December 31, 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P183_S2	In addition, a change in the scope of services we provide to an existing client lowered our assets by about $42.9 billion.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P183_S3	Excluding these effects, assets under advisement and management rose 8.3%, primarily reflecting asset inflows and market performance.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P184_S0	Total assets under advisement and management for Investment Advisory Services as of December 31, 2011 increased 27.3% compared with December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P184_S1	Approximately 75% of the increase reflects additional assets for existing clients' fund-of-funds programs for which we now receive asset-based fees.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P184_S2	The remainder of the increase reflects net client inflows and market performance.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P185_S0	We cannot separately quantify cash inflows and outflows for these portfolios because we do not have custody of the assets in the majority of our investment management businesses.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P185_S1	The information we receive from many of our clients does not separately identify the effect of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P185_S2	We also cannot precisely quantify the effect of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P186_S0	Assets under management for managed retirement accounts increased to $25.1 billion as of December 31, 2012 compared with $ 19.9 billion as of December 31, 2011 and $ 19.6 billion as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P186_S1	Assets under advisement for plan sponsor and custom target-date arrangements increased to $22.1 billion as of December 31, 2012 , compared with $ 17.5 billion as of December 31, 2011 and $ 15.5 billion as of December 31, 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P187_S0	We cannot separately quantify the factors affecting assets under management and advisement for our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P187_S1	These factors primarily consist of employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P187_S2	We cannot quantify the impact of these other factors because the information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances caused by market movement.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P188_S0	The table below shows the number of retirement plan participants who had access to the services offered through our Retirement Solutions programs, as well as the number of plan sponsors and plan providers that provide this access.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P189_S1	The growth mainly reflects higher average asset levels during 2012 compared with 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P189_S2	Assets under management for Morningstar Managed Portfolios were $4.7 billion as of December 31, 2012 , compared with $3.1 billion as of December 31, 2011 , reflecting positive market performance and strong net inflows.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P189_S4	Assets under management for Morningstar Managed Portfolios were $3.1 billion as of December 31, 2011 compared with $2.7 billion as of December 31, 2010 , reflecting strong net inflows.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P191_S0	Operating income for the Investment Management segment decreased $8.5 million , or 12.2% , in 2012 .

1289419_13_ITEM7_P191_S2	In 2012, revenue increased less than operating expense.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P195_S2	Lower bonus expense as a percentage of revenue partially offset these increases.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P196_S0	The segment's operating margin increased 1.9 percentage points to 53.4% in 2011 , as revenue growth exceeded the change in operating expenses.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P196_S1	Lower salary expense and bonus expense as a percentage of revenue contributed to the increase, partially offset by higher expenses outside of the United Stated and higher professional fees as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P196_S2	In addition, acquisitions had a slight negative effect on the margin in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P196_S3	The 2010 margin was negatively affected by the $2.0 million separation agreement, which reduced the 2010 margin by approximately 2.0 percentage points.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P197_S0	This category includes general corporate costs, which we do not allocate to our business segments.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P197_S1	The corporate items category also includes amortization expense related to intangible assets recorded for acquisitions and capitalization of internal product development costs.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P197_S2	The table below shows the components of corporate items that affected our consolidated operating income:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P198_S0	Amortization of intangible assets decreased $3.3 million in 2012 primarily because certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P198_S1	In addition, our 2011 results included $1.6 million of expense for the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P198_S2	Amortization expense increased $2.4 million in 2011 , reflecting amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions, and to a lesser extent, the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P198_S3	The increase was partially offset by the runoff of amortization expense for certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P199_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011 , respectively, we had $116.7 million and $139.8 million of net intangible assets.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P199_S1	We amortize these assets over their estimated lives, ranging from one to 20 years.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P199_S2	We estimate that aggregate amortization expense for intangible assets will be approximately $21.2 million in 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P200_S0	Depreciation expense for corporate items increased $2.3 million in 2012 primarily related to increased capital expenditures for our operations in the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P200_S1	Depreciation expense did not change significantly in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P201_S0	Corporate unallocated expense decreased $0.6 million in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P201_S1	In 2012 , we capitalized $8.5 million of expense for software development, compared with $5.3 million in 2011 , favorably affecting the year-over-year comparison.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P201_S2	In addition, our corporate unallocated expense for 2011 included $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P201_S3	This expense did not recur in 2012.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P201_S4	Higher professional fees, salaries, and production expense partially offset these favorable items.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P202_S1	In 2011 , we capitalized $5.3 million of expense for software development, compared with $0.8 million in 2010 , favorably affecting the year-over-year comparison.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P202_S2	Lower professional fees also contributed to the decrease, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P202_S3	In addition, a $1.0 million expense related to vacant office space recorded in 2010 did not recur in 2011, favorably affecting the comparison with the previous year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P202_S4	Higher salaries partially offset these favorable items.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P202_S5	In addition, our corporate unallocated expense for 2011 includes $3.2 million of expense for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P203_S0	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities includes our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK), Morningstar Sweden AB, and beginning in the fourth quarters of 2011 and 2012, YCharts, Inc. (YCharts) and Inquiry Financial Europe AB, respectively.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P203_S1	In the first six months of 2010, this category also included our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Denmark.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P204_S0	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities is primarily from our position in MJKK.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P205_S0	In September 2012, we acquired a 34% minority equity stake in Inquiry Financial Europe AB for $3.6 million, paid in cash.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P205_S1	In November 2011, we acquired a 22% minority equity stake in YCharts for $2.5 million, paid in cash.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P206_S0	In July 2010, we acquired an additional 75% ownership interest in Morningstar Danmark A/S (Morningstar Denmark), increasing our ownership percentage to 100%.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P206_S1	As a result, we no longer account for our investment in Morningstar Denmark using the equity method.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P206_S2	Beginning in the third quarter of 2010, we consolidate the assets, liabilities, and results of operations of Morningstar Denmark in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P207_S0	We describe our investments in unconsolidated entities in more detail in Note 9 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P208_S0	The following table presents the components of net non-operating income (expense):
1289419_13_ITEM7_P209_S0	Interest income mainly reflects interest from our investment portfolio.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P209_S1	Interest income in 2012 also includes approximately $0.7 million of interest income related to the $1.0 million of business tax refund for prior years recorded in 2012, as discussed above in the section, Consolidated Results .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P209_S2	The increase in interest income in 2011 reflects higher balances of cash equivalents and investments.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P211_S1	We previously accounted for this investment using the cost method.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P212_S1	The net other expense in 2011 primarily represented unrealized exchange losses on foreign currency denominated balances.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P213_S0	The following table summarizes the components of our effective tax rate:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P214_S0	For a reconciliation of the U.S. federal tax rate to our effective income tax rate, refer to Note 15 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P215_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2012 was 33.9% , an increase of 3.2 percentage points compared with 30.7% in 2011 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P215_S1	The higher tax rate in 2012 reflects lower tax credits and incentives in the current year, as well as certain deferred income tax benefits recorded in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P216_S0	In 2011 , our effective tax rate was 30.7% , a decrease of 2.4 percentage points compared with 33.1% in 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P216_S1	The lower tax rate in 2011 reflects:
1289419_13_ITEM7_P217_S0	the recognition of certain deferred income tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P218_S0	Additionally, in 2010, the use of foreign net operating losses that had previously been subject to a valuation allowance reduced our effective tax rate.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P218_S1	This benefit did not recur in 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P219_S0	In 2012 , we recorded a net increase of $0.5 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, which increased our income tax expense.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P219_S1	As of December 31, 2012 , we had $12.7 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $12.7 million , if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $10.4 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P219_S2	As of December 31, 2011 , we had $12.2 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $11.9 million, if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $9.8 million.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P220_S1	As of December 31, 2011 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of $5.3 million and a non-current liability of $6.2 million for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P220_S2	These amounts include interest and penalties, less any associated tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P221_S0	We have not provided federal and state income taxes on accumulated undistributed earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries, because these earnings have been permanently reinvested.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P221_S1	Approximately 42% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2012 is held by our operations outside of the United States.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P221_S2	As such, we believe that our cash balances and investments in the United States, along with cash generated from our U.S. operations, will be sufficient to meet our U.S. operating and cash needs for the foreseeable future, without requiring us to repatriate earnings from these foreign subsidiaries.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P222_S0	It is not practicable to determine the amount of the unrecognized deferred tax liability related to the undistributed earnings.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P223_S0	We are currently under audit by federal and various state and local tax authorities in the United States, as well as tax authorities in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P223_S1	It is likely that the examination phase of some of these audits will conclude in 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P224_S0	It is not possible to estimate the effect of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P225_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations, will be sufficient to meet our operating and cash needs for at least the next 12 months.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S0	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments, consisting primarily of fixed-income securities.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S1	We maintain a conservative investment policy for our investments and invest a portion of these assets in municipal securities with high-quality stand-alone credit ratings.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S2	We also invest a portion of our investments balance (approximately 25% as of December 31, 2012 ) in proprietary Morningstar portfolios.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S3	These portfolios may consist of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, or ETFs.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S4	Investments in our portfolio have a maximum maturity of two years; the weighted average maturity is approximately one year.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S5	Approximately 58% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2012 was held by our operations in the United States, down from about 80% as of December 31, 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P226_S6	We used cash generated from our operations in the United States to fund our share repurchase program and dividends to shareholders.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P227_S0	We intend to use our cash, cash equivalents, and investments for general corporate purposes, including working capital and funding future growth.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P227_S1	To date, we have not needed to access any significant commercial credit and have not attempted to borrow or establish any lines of credit.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P235_S1	Changes in our operating assets and liabilities mainly benefited from increases in accrued compensation and income taxes.

1289419_13_ITEM7_P236_S1	We paid $21.4 million in annual bonus payments in the first quarter of 2010 and made tax payments of approximately $37.6 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P236_S2	In addition, in 2010 , we paid $4.9 million to one former and two then current executives to adjust the tax treatment of certain stock options originally considered incentive stock options.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P236_S3	The cash flow impact of these items was partially offset by the cash flow benefits of accrued compensation and income taxes payable.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P237_S0	Cash provided by (used for) investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments less proceeds from the maturity or sale of investments, cash used for capital expenditures, purchases of equity and cost-method investments, and proceeds from the sale of businesses.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P237_S1	The level of investing activities varies from period to period depending on activity in these categories.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P238_S0	Cash provided by investing activities was $80.2 million in 2012 , compared with cash used for investing activities of $110.8 million in 2011 and $87.9 million in 2010 .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P239_S0	In 2012 , proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments exceeded the purchases of investments by $114.8 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P239_S1	In contrast, in 2011 , purchases of investments exceeded the proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments by $85.3 million .
1289419_13_ITEM7_P239_S2	In 2010, proceeds from the maturity and sale of investments exceeded the purchases of investments by $28.6 million .

1289419_13_ITEM7_P239_S6	As of December 31, 2012 , our investments represented 49% of our total cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance down from 57% as of December 31, 2011 .

1289419_13_ITEM7_P241_S0	We did not complete any acquisitions in 2012 or 2011.
1289419_13_ITEM7_P241_S1	In 2011, we received cash of approximately $0.6 million as an adjustment to the purchase price of one of our 2010 acquisitions.
