1289419_13_ITEM8_P186_S0	In accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , we estimate forfeitures of employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P186_S1	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense during the third quarter to reflect those awards that ultimately vested and update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P187_S0	Restricted stock units represent the right to receive a share of Morningstar common stock when that unit vests.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P187_S1	Restricted stock units granted to employees vest ratably over a four-year period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P187_S2	Restricted stock units granted to non-employee directors vest ratably over a three-year period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P187_S3	For restricted stock units granted through December 31, 2008, employees could elect to defer receipt of the Morningstar common stock issued upon vesting of the restricted stock unit.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P188_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the closing market price of the underlying common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P188_S1	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P189_S0	The following table summarizes restricted stock unit activity during the past three years:
1289419_13_ITEM8_P190_S0	In conjunction with the Realpoint acquisition in May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares of restricted stock to the selling employee-shareholders under the 2004 Stock Incentive Plan.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P190_S1	The restricted stock vests ratably over a five-year period from the acquisition date and may be subject to forfeiture if the holder terminates his or her employment during the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P191_S0	Because of the terms of the restricted share agreements prepared in conjunction with the Realpoint acquisition, we account for the grant of restricted shares as stock-based compensation expense and not as part of the acquisition consideration.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P191_S1	See Note 7 , in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements, for additional information concerning the Realpoint acquisition.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P192_S0	We measured the fair value of the restricted stock on the date of grant based on the closing market price of our common stock on the day prior to the grant.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P192_S1	We amortize the fair value of $9,363,000 to stock-based compensation expense over the vesting period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P192_S2	The stock-based compensation expense recorded in 2012 and 2011 includes approximately $3,238,000 and $396,000 , respectively, of expense recognized upon the accelerated vesting of restricted stock.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P192_S3	We have assumed that all of the remaining restricted stock will ultimately vest, and therefore we have not incorporated a forfeiture rate for purposes of determining the stock-based compensation expense.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P193_S0	Stock options granted to employees vest ratably over a four-year period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P193_S1	Grants to our non-employee directors vest ratably over a three-year period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P193_S2	All grants expire 10 years after the date of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P194_S0	Almost all of the outstanding options granted under the 2004 Stock Incentive Plan have a premium price feature in which the exercise price increases over the term of the option at a rate equal to the 10-year Treasury bond yield as of the date of grant.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P194_S1	Options granted under the 2011 Plan have an exercise price equal to the fair market value on the grant date.

1289419_13_ITEM8_P200_S0	FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation, requires that we classify the cash flows that result from excess tax benefits as financing cash flows.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P200_S1	Excess tax benefits correspond to the portion of the tax deduction taken on our income tax return that exceeds the amount of tax benefit related to the compensation cost recognized in our Statement of Income.

1289419_13_ITEM8_P201_S0	We sponsor a defined contribution 401(k) plan, which allows our U.S.-based employees to voluntarily contribute pre-tax dollars up to a maximum amount allowable by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P201_S1	In 2012 and 2011, we made matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States in an amount equal to 75 cents for every dollar of an employee's contribution, up to a maximum of 7% of the employee's compensation in the pay period.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P201_S2	In 2010, we made matching contributions to our 401(k) plan in the United States in an amount equal to 50 cents for every dollar of an employee's contribution, up to a maximum of 7% of the employee's compensation in the pay period.

1289419_13_ITEM8_P219_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P219_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $4,031,000 of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of these NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P220_S0	We conduct business globally and as a result, we file income tax returns in U.S. federal, state, local, and foreign jurisdictions.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P220_S1	In the normal course of business we are subject to examination by tax authorities throughout the world.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P220_S2	The open tax years for our U.S. Federal tax returns and most state tax returns include the years 2008 to the present.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P220_S3	In non-U.S. jurisdictions, the statute of limitations generally extends to years prior to 2005.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P221_S0	We are currently under audit by federal, state and local tax authorities in the United States as well as tax authorities in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P221_S1	It is likely that the examination phase of some of these U.S. federal, state, local, and non-U.S. audits will conclude in 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P222_S0	It is not possible to estimate the impact of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P223_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of $6,568,000 and a non-current liability of $5,659,000 for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P223_S1	These amounts include interest and penalties, less any associated tax benefits.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P224_S0	The table below reconciles the beginning and ending amount of the gross unrecognized tax benefits as follows:
1289419_13_ITEM8_P225_S0	In 2012 , we recorded a net increase of $1,299,000 of gross unrecognized tax benefits before settlements and lapses of statutes of limitations, of which $875,000 increased our income tax expense by $702,000 .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P225_S1	In addition, we reduced our unrecognized tax benefits by $790,000 for settlements and lapses of statutes of limitations, of which $207,000 decreased our income tax expense by $207,000 .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P226_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , we had $12,699,000 of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $12,699,000 , if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $10,446,000 .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P227_S0	We record interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions as part of our income tax expense.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P227_S1	The following table summarizes our gross liability for interest and penalties:
1289419_13_ITEM8_P228_S0	We recorded the increase in the liability, net of any tax benefits, to income tax expense in our Consolidated Statement of Income in 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P229_S0	In September 2011, three individual investors in Life's Good S.T.A.B.L. Mortgage hedge fund (LG), Marta Klass, Gregory Martin, and Richard Roellig, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against LG, its principal Robert Stinson, and several other parties, including Morningstar, Inc. (the Klass Matter).
1289419_13_ITEM8_P229_S1	The plaintiffs claim that Morningstar committed fraud and aided and abetted the other defendants' breach of fiduciary duty through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P230_S0	Hedge fund managers self-report their performance data to Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P231_S0	More than a year before the Klass Matter, in June 2010, the SEC filed suit against LG and other entities claiming they were part of a Ponzi scheme operated by Stinson.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P231_S1	As a result, LG and the other entities were placed in court-appointed receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P231_S2	Morningstar was not part of the SEC suit or receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P231_S3	Since that time, the Receiver, as part of his duties, has been investigating whether to assert claims against third parties.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P232_S0	Morningstar is aware of 14 lawsuits filed by the Receiver seeking to recover money for the fund.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P233_S0	In November 2011, Morningstar filed a motion to dismiss the Klass Matter.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P234_S0	On behalf of the entities in receivership, the Receiver filed a motion to stay the proceedings because the Receivership Order does not permit suits against the entities in receivership without court permission.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P234_S1	The court granted the Receiver's motion and stayed the Klass Matter.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P235_S0	In April 2012, the Receiver filed a complaint against Morningstar, in which the Receiver claims that Morningstar is liable for contribution and aiding and abetting Stinson's breach of fiduciary duty and fraud through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P235_S1	The same day the Receiver filed his complaint, Morningstar sought leave from the court to file a counter suit against Stinson and two of his entities-Keystone State Capital Corporation and LG-for, among other things, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of user agreements.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P235_S2	In June 2012, the court denied Morningstar's motion for leave to file suit.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P235_S3	The court took no position on the merits of Morningstar's claims, and did not preclude Morningstar from renewing its motion to file a complaint at a later time, but deferred to the Receiver's request not to subject the receivership estate to additional litigation at this early point in the receivership.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P235_S4	In August 2012, the court denied Morningstar's motion to dismiss the Receiver's complaint.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P236_S0	Morningstar believes the allegations against it by the Klass plaintiffs and the Receiver have no legal or factual basis and plans to vigorously contest the claims.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P236_S1	Morningstar also intends to refile its affirmative claims against Stinson, Keystone, and LG at a later time consistent with the court's order.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P237_S0	We cannot predict the outcome of the proceedings.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P238_S0	In November 2009, Business Logic Holding Corporation filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois against Ibbotson Associates, Inc. and Morningstar, Inc. relating to Ibbotson's prior commercial relationship with Business Logic.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P238_S1	Business Logic is alleging breach of contract and trade secret misappropriation in connection with Ibbotson's development of a proprietary web-service software and user interface that connects plan participant data with the Ibbotson Wealth Forecasting Engine.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P238_S2	Business Logic seeks, among other things, injunctive relief and unspecified damages.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P238_S3	Ibbotson and Morningstar answered the complaint, and Ibbotson asserted a counterclaim against Business Logic alleging trade secret misappropriation and breach of contract, seeking damages and injunctive relief.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P239_S0	While Morningstar and Ibbotson are vigorously contesting the claims against them, we cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P240_S0	We have not provided an estimate of loss or range of loss in connection with the matters described above because no such estimate can reasonably be made.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P241_S0	In June 2010, Egan-Jones Rating Co. filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania against Realpoint, LLC (now known as Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC) and Morningstar, Inc. in connection with a December 2007 agreement between Egan-Jones and Morningstar Credit Ratings for certain data-sharing and other services.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P241_S1	In addition to damages, Egan-Jones filed a petition seeking an injunction to temporarily prevent Morningstar from offering corporate credit ratings through December 31, 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P241_S2	In September 2010, the court denied Egan-Jones's request for a preliminary injunction against Morningstar's corporate credit ratings business.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P241_S3	In December 2012, Morningstar Credit Ratings, Morningstar, and Egan Jones entered into a settlement agreement resolving the litigation.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P242_S0	In addition to these proceedings, we are involved in legal proceedings and litigation that have arisen in the normal course of our business.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P242_S1	Although the outcome of a particular proceeding can never be predicted, we do not believe that the result of any of these other matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S0	In September 2010, the board of directors approved a share repurchase program that authorizes the repurchase of up to $100 million in shares of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S1	In December 2011, the board approved an increase to the $100 million share repurchase program it announced in 2010.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S2	The board approval authorized the company to repurchase up to an additional $200 million in shares of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S3	In December 2012, the board approval authorized the company to repurchase an additional $200 million , increasing the repurchase program from $300 million to $500 million .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S4	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that we deem appropriate.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P243_S5	As of December 31, 2012 , we had repurchased a total of 5,056,595 shares for $300,936,000 under this authorization.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P244_S0	In February 2013 , our board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 12.5 cents per share.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P244_S1	The dividend is payable on April 30, 2013 to shareholders of record as of April 12, 2013 .
1289419_13_ITEM8_P245_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-2, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220).
1289419_13_ITEM8_P245_S1	The amended guidance requires us to show the effects of items reclassified out of each component of accumulated other comprehensive income to net income on the face of the financial statement where net income is presented.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P245_S2	For Morningstar, the ASU No. 2013-2 is effective on January 1, 2013.
1289419_13_ITEM8_P246_S0	We do not expect the provisions of ASU No. 2013-2 to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Disclosure controls and procedures are designed to reasonably assure that information required to be disclosed in the reports filed or submitted under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC's rules and forms.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Disclosure controls and procedures include, without limitation, controls and procedures designed to reasonably assure that information required to be disclosed in the reports filed under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to management, including the chief executive officer and chief financial officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P1_S0	We carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as of December 31, 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Based on that evaluation, our chief executive officer and chief financial officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in the reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported as and when required and is accumulated and communicated to management, including the chief executive officer and chief financial officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P3_S0	We carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework set forth in Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Based on that evaluation, our management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2012 .
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P4_S1	KPMG LLP, our independent registered public accounting firm, has issued its report on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting, which is included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K under the caption Financial Statements and Supplementary Data and incorporated herein by reference.
1289419_13_ITEM9A_P5_S0	There were no changes in our internal controls over financial reporting during our fiscal quarter ended December 31, 2012 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_13_ITEM9B_P0_S0	There is no information that was required to be disclosed in a report on Form 8-K during the fourth quarter of the year covered by this Annual Report on Form 10-K that was not reported.
