1289419_14_ITEM1_P173_S1	He joined us in January 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P173_S2	Previously he served as vice chairman of business development for Markit On Demand, an Internet technology company he founded as Wall Street On Demand in 1991.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P173_S3	In addition to his role as CEO, he also served in various roles for firms that have owned Wall Street On Demand, including head of sales for eBridge and head of distribution and vice chairman of business development for Markit, a UK-based global financial information company.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P174_S0	Jim holds a bachelor s degree in Russian language and literature from Haverford College and a master s degree in business administration from Harvard University.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P175_S0	David W. Williams is head of design and marketing for Morningstar.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P175_S1	He is responsible for corporate design and its application to brand identity, products, communications, and the workplace.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P175_S2	He joined us in 1993 and has been instrumental in establishing design as one of our recognized core capabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P176_S0	David holds a bachelor's degree in industrial design from The Ohio State University and a master's degree in fine arts from the Yale University School of Art.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P177_S0	We were incorporated in Illinois on May 16, 1984.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P177_S1	Our corporate headquarters are located at 22 West Washington Street, Chicago, Illinois, 60602.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P178_S0	We maintain a website at http://corporate.morningstar.com .
1289419_14_ITEM1_P178_S1	Our Annual Report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to any of these documents are available free of charge on this site as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports are filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P178_S2	We also post quarterly press releases on our financial results and other documents containing additional information related to our company on this site.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P178_S3	We provide this website and the information contained in or connected to it for informational purposes only.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P178_S4	That information is not part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P179_S0	You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the other information included in this Form 10-K when deciding whether to invest in our common stock or otherwise evaluating our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P179_S1	If any of the following risks materialize, our business, financial condition, or operating results could suffer.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P179_S2	In this case, the trading price of our common stock could decline, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P180_S0	Our investment advisory operations may subject us to liability for any losses that result from a breach of our fiduciary duties.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P181_S0	Three of our subsidiaries, Ibbotson Associates, Inc., Morningstar Associates, LLC, and Morningstar Investment Services, Inc. are registered as investment advisors with the SEC under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, as amended (Advisers Act).
1289419_14_ITEM1_P181_S1	As registered investment advisors, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Advisers Act.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P181_S2	Such requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, and standards of care, as well as general anti-fraud prohibitions.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P182_S0	As registered investment advisors, all three subsidiaries are subject to on-site examination by the SEC.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P183_S0	In addition, because these three subsidiaries provide investment advisory services to retirement plans and their participants, they may be acting as fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_14_ITEM1_P183_S1	As fiduciaries under ERISA, they have obligations to act in the best interest of their clients.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P183_S2	They also have duties of loyalty and prudence, as well as duties to diversify investments and to follow plan documents to comply with the applicable portions of ERISA.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P184_S0	Our subsidiaries outside the United States that have investment advisory operations are subject to similar requirements.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P185_S0	We may face liabilities for actual or claimed breaches of our fiduciary duties, particularly in areas where we provide retirement advice and managed retirement accounts.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P185_S1	In some of our retirement contracts, we act as an ERISA fiduciary by, for example, selecting and monitoring a broad range of diversified plan options.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P185_S2	As part of this service, we can construct and monitor the investment lineup, document our investment process, create an Investment Policy Statement, and furnish the plan with detailed quarterly investment and performance reports.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P185_S3	We also provide a managed account service for retirement plan participants who elect to have their accounts managed by our programs.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P185_S4	As of December 31, 2013, we had $31.7 billion in assets under management in our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P186_S0	We rely on automated investment technology for our retirement advice and managed retirement accounts services.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P187_S0	The Wealth Forecasting Engine is our core advice and managed accounts engine that determines appropriate asset allocations for retirement plan participants and assigns individuals to portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P187_S1	We also rely on automated portfolio construction tools.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P187_S2	Problems could arise if these programs assigned retirement plan participants to the wrong portfolios, particularly if we failed to detect program errors over an extended period.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P188_S0	We may not be able to prevent clients from taking legal action against us for an actual or claimed breach of a fiduciary duty.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P188_S1	If we make an error, we may be subject to potentially large liabilities for make-whole payments and/or litigation.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P188_S2	We cannot quantify the potential size of these liabilities with any level of precision.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P189_S0	In addition, we may face other legal liabilities based on the quality and outcome of our investment advisory recommendations, even in the absence of an actual or claimed breach of fiduciary duty.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P189_S1	In total, we provided investment advisory and management services on nearly $160 billion in assets as of December 31, 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P189_S2	We could face substantial liabilities related to our work on these assets.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P190_S0	Failing to differentiate our products and continuously create innovative, proprietary research tools may harm our competitive position and business results.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S0	We attribute much of our company's success over the past 29 years to our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools, such as the Morningstar Rating, Morningstar Style Box, Ownership Zone, and Portfolio X-Ray.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S1	We believe these proprietary tools continue to provide us with a competitive advantage, but if tools similar to them become available through other channels, our competitive position and business results may suffer.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S2	Our competitive position and business results may also suffer if other companies are able to successfully introduce innovative, proprietary research tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S3	We believe lower technology costs and the growth of open software platforms have lowered the barriers to entry for new competitors, making it easier for new players to enter the market.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S4	Smaller companies may be able to introduce new research tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S5	If we fail to introduce innovative, proprietary research tools at the same rate as in the past, we may not generate enough enthusiasm with potential clients to win new business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P191_S6	We cannot guarantee that we will continue to successfully develop new product features and tools that differentiate our product offerings from those of our competitors.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P192_S0	Failing to respond to technological change, keep pace with new technology developments, or adopt a successful technology strategy may negatively affect our competitive position and business results.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S0	We believe the technology landscape has been changing at an accelerating rate over the past several years.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S1	Changes in technology are fundamentally changing the ways investors access data and content.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S2	Examples include the shift from local network to computing to cloud-based systems, the proliferation of wireless mobile devices, and rapid acceleration in the use of social media platforms.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S3	We are in the process of building the next-generation software architecture that will eventually underlie of our investment research platforms, but we have not yet incorporated this software in our products.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S4	While some changes in technology may offer opportunities for Morningstar, we cannot guarantee that we will successfully adapt our product offerings to meet evolving customer needs.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S5	We believe our history of rapid technological innovation and expertise in technology have historically given us a competitive advantage.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S6	As mentioned above, though, we believe that lower technology costs and growth in open software platforms have lowered barriers to entry for new competitors.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S7	Our competitors may also be able to introduce new technology more rapidly than we are to meet changing market needs.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P193_S8	Our competitive position and business results may suffer if we fail to develop new technologies to meet client demands, or if we adopt a technology strategy that doesn't align with changes in the market.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P194_S0	An outage of our database and network facilities could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S0	The success of our business depends upon our ability to deliver time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S1	We rely on our computer equipment, database storage facilities, and other network equipment, much of which is geographically concentrated in our Chicago headquarters and other backup locations in the United States.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S2	We also have extensive information systems outside the United States.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S3	Our mission-critical databases and networks are increasingly complex and interdependent.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S4	Many of our client contracts contain service-level agreements that require us to meet certain obligations for delivering time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S5	We may not be able to meet these obligations in the event of failure or downtime in our information systems.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S6	Our operations and those of our suppliers and customers are vulnerable to interruption by fire, earthquake, power loss, telecommunications failure, terrorist attacks, wars, Internet failures or disruptions, computer viruses, and other events beyond our control.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P195_S7	Our database and network facilities may also be vulnerable to external attacks that misappropriate our data, corrupt our databases, or limit access to our information systems.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P196_S0	We maintain off-site back-up facilities for our database and network equipment, but we cannot guarantee that these facilities will operate as expected during an interruption that affects our headquarters.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P196_S1	There may be single points of failure that affect our core databases, data transfer interfaces, or storage area networks.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P196_S2	We may not be able to fully recover data or information lost during a database or network facility outage.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P196_S3	Any losses, service disruption, or damages incurred by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P197_S0	Our business relies heavily on electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P197_S1	Any failures or disruptions could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P198_S0	Most of our products and services depend heavily on our electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P198_S1	Our ability to deliver information using the Internet may be impaired because of infrastructure failures, service outages at third-party Internet providers, malicious attacks, or other factors.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P198_S2	If disruptions, failures, or slowdowns of our electronic delivery systems or the Internet occur, our ability to distribute our products and services effectively and to serve our customers may be impaired.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P199_S0	We could face liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as a result of some of our currently pending litigation.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P200_S0	From time to time, we are subject to legal or regulatory proceedings in the ordinary course of our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P200_S1	These include proceedings relating to aspects of our businesses that are specific to us and proceedings that are typical in the asset management and financial information businesses in which we operate.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P201_S0	We are currently defendants in two cases that we describe in Item 3 Legal Proceedings of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P201_S1	The plaintiffs are seeking large and/or indeterminate amounts of damages.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P202_S0	Litigation is inherently unpredictable, and the outcome of any particular proceeding can never be predicted with certainty.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P202_S1	An adverse litigation outcome could have a materially adverse effect on our financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P203_S0	In addition to its potential financial impact, litigation can have a significant adverse reputational impact.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P203_S1	We depend to a large extent on our reputation for integrity and high-caliber professional services.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P203_S2	Allegations of improper conduct made by private litigants or regulators, whether the ultimate outcome is favorable or unfavorable to us, as well as negative publicity and press speculation about us, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation, which may be damaging to our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P204_S0	We could face liability related to our storage of personal information about our users.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S0	Customers routinely enter personal investment and financial information, including portfolio holdings and credit card information, on our websites.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S1	We also handle an increasing volume of personally sensitive information through our Portfolio Management Service, Enterprise Data Management, managed retirement accounts, and other areas of our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S2	Contractual commitments to customers as well as laws and industry regulations related to data protection, system availability, and privacy require us to safeguard critical data.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S3	We are also required to take appropriate steps to safeguard credit card numbers, social security numbers, and other personally identifiable information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S4	We may suffer malicious attacks seeking to penetrate our network and databases to gain access to personal data.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P205_S5	We could be subject to liability if we were to inappropriately disclose any user's personal information or if third parties were able to penetrate our network security or otherwise gain access to any user's name, address, portfolio holdings, or credit card information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P206_S0	Downturns in the financial sector, global financial markets, and global economy may adversely impact our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S0	We believe ongoing economic weakness continues to cause uncertainty and pressure on consumer discretionary spending.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S1	The financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, as well as more recent financial and economic uncertainty, has led to spending cutbacks among asset management firms and other financial services companies, which make up a large percentage of our client base.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S2	Some institutional clients have also implemented additional review processes for new contracts or began to provide certain services, particularly investment advisory services, in-house rather than hiring outside service providers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S3	Some institutional clients have also reduced the scope of their operations.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S4	For example, several large insurers withdrew from the variable annuity market in recent years, while others curtailed their new sales efforts.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P207_S5	This has had a negative effect on the services we provide to institutional clients that offer variable annuities.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P208_S0	In 2010 and 2011, rising government debt levels around the world as well as downgrades in sovereign debt issues for some European countries led to market fears about a potential crisis in global sovereign debt.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P208_S1	Some European countries have been unable to successfully refinance their debts, leading European finance officials to take measures during 2010 and 2011 to stabilize financial conditions across Europe.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P208_S2	While conditions in Europe have improved, many European countries have continued to experience weak economic growth.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P208_S3	In addition, many companies in the financial services industry have been subject to increasing government regulation, which may increase their operating costs and cause them to reduce spending in other areas.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P209_S0	In addition, if financial markets around the world experience negative performance and volatility, demand for our products and services may decline, and our revenue, operating income, and other financial results could suffer.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P209_S1	Our business results may also be hurt by negative trends in Internet advertising sales.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P209_S2	Our structured credit rating business is subject to volatility from trends in new issuance of commercial mortgage-backed securities and other structured credits.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P209_S3	The financial markets and many businesses operating in the financial services industry are highly volatile and are affected by factors, such as U.S. and foreign economic conditions and general trends in business and finance, that are beyond our control.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P210_S0	Our revenue from asset-based fees may be adversely affected by market declines as well as the effect of cash outflows from portfolios that we help manage.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P211_S0	In 2013, revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 13% of our consolidated revenue and a greater percentage of our operating income.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P211_S1	The amount of revenue we earn from asset-based fees depends on the value of assets on which we provide advisory services, and the size of our asset base can increase or decrease along with trends in market performance.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P211_S2	The value of assets under advisement may show substantial declines during periods of significant market volatility.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P211_S3	The size of these portfolios can also be affected if net inflows into the portfolios on which we provide investment advisory services drop or if these portfolios experience redemptions.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P211_S4	If the level of assets on which we provide investment advisory services goes down, we expect our fee-based revenue to show a corresponding decline.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P212_S0	Failing to maintain and protect our brand, independence, and reputation may harm our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P212_S1	Our reputation and business may also be harmed by allegations made about possible conflicts of interest.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S0	We believe that independence is at the core of our business, and our reputation is our greatest corporate asset.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S1	We offer products and services to our institutional clients, which include banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies, mutual fund companies, media outlets, and retirement plan providers and sponsors.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S2	Our institutional clients have generated a significant percentage of our consolidated revenue in recent years.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S3	We provide ratings, analyst research, and investment recommendations on mutual funds and other investment products offered and securities issued by our institutional clients.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S4	We also provide investment advisory and investment management services.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P213_S5	The fact that our institutional clients pay us for certain products and services, as well as the fact that in some cases we make investment recommendations within the framework of client constraints, may create the perception that our ratings, research, and recommendations are not impartial.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P214_S0	This perception may undermine the confidence of our customers and potential customers in our reputation as a provider of independent research.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P214_S1	Any such loss of confidence or damage to our reputation could hurt our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P215_S0	Any failure to uphold our high ethical standards and ensure that our customers have a consistently positive experience with us (either intentionally or inadvertently) could damage our reputation as an objective, honest, and credible source for investment research and information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P216_S0	Our reputation may also be harmed by factors outside of our control, such as news reports about our clients or adverse publicity about certain investment products.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P217_S0	Changes in laws applicable to our investment advisory or credit rating operations, compliance failures, or regulatory action could adversely affect our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S0	Our investment advisory operations are a growing part of our overall business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S1	The securities laws and other laws that govern our activities as a registered investment advisor are complex.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S2	The activities of our investment advisory operations are primarily subject to provisions of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 (the Advisers Act) and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA).
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S3	In addition, Morningstar Investment Services is a broker-dealer registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the Exchange Act) and is subject to the rules of FINRA.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S4	We also provide investment advisory services in other areas around the world, and our operations are subject to additional regulations in markets outside the United States.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P218_S5	If we fail to establish required licenses or regulatory approvals for our investment advisory operations, we may be subject to fines or other events that could have a negative effect on our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P219_S0	Over the past several years, we have also made significant investments in our credit rating business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P219_S1	We began publishing credit ratings and associated research on corporate debt issuers in 2009.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P220_S0	Although our corporate credit rating business is not currently regulated as a Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organization (NRSRO), credit rating and research providers have been under increasing regulatory scrutiny.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P220_S1	We cannot predict the future impact of potential future regulatory changes on our corporate credit rating business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P221_S0	We also expanded our credit rating business operations with our May 2010 acquisition of Realpoint, LLC (now known as Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC), an NRSRO that specializes in structured finance.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P222_S0	As an NRSRO, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to various requirements and regulations under the Exchange Act relating to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, governance, and conflicts of interest.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P223_S0	As part of its NRSRO registration, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to annual examination by the SEC.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P224_S0	It is difficult to predict the future effect of the broad and expanding legislative and regulatory requirements affecting our business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P224_S1	The laws, rules, and regulations applicable to our business may change in the future, and we may not be able to comply with any such changes.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P224_S2	If we fail to comply with any applicable law, rule, or regulation, we could be fined, sanctioned, or barred from providing investment advisory or credit rating services in the future, which could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P225_S0	Competition could reduce our share of the investment research market and hurt our financial performance.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P226_S0	We operate in a highly competitive industry, with many investment research providers competing for business from individual investors, financial advisors, and institutional clients.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P226_S1	We compete with many different types of companies that vary in size, product scope, and media focus, including large and well-established distributors of financial information, such as Bloomberg; Standard Poor's, a division of McGraw Hill Financial; and Thomson Reuters.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P226_S2	We compete with a variety of other companies in different areas of our business, which we discuss in greater detail in the Major Products and Services section in Item 1 Business.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P227_S0	Many of our competitors have larger customer bases and significantly greater resources than we do.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P227_S1	This may allow them to respond more quickly to new technologies and changes in demand for products and services, devote greater resources to developing and promoting their services, and make more attractive offers to potential clients, subscribers, and strategic partners.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P227_S2	They may also be able to offer better customer service and support.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P227_S3	Industry consolidation may also lead to more intense competition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P227_S4	Increased competition could result in price reductions, reduced margins, or loss of market share, any of which could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P228_S0	The investment information industry is dominated by a few large players, and industry consolidation has increased in the past several years.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P228_S1	If providers of data and investment analysis continue to consolidate, our competitive position may suffer.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P229_S0	Our results could suffer if the mutual fund industry continues to experience slower growth, or if actively managed equity funds continue to attract less investor attention.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P230_S0	We generate a significant portion of our revenue from products and services related to mutual funds.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P231_S0	The mutual fund industry has experienced substantial growth over the past 30 years, but suffered along with the market downturn in 2008 and early 2009.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P231_S1	Since then, fund assets have increased, but at a slower rate than in previous years.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P231_S2	Based on Morningstar's estimates for U.S. mutual fund asset flows, long-term open-end funds had positive net inflows of approximately $270 billion in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P232_S0	A significant portion of our fund research has historically focused on equity-related funds.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P232_S1	In addition, we are best-known for our data and analyst research on actively managed equity funds.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P233_S0	Over the past several years, passively managed index funds have seen greater investor interest.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P233_S1	This trend continued in 2013, as passively managed vehicles (both mutual funds and ETFs) had about $300 billion in net inflows, compared with $150 billion of net inflows for active products.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P233_S2	Overall, we estimate that passively managed assets now account for more than one-fourth of combined mutual fund and ETF assets.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P234_S0	Continued downturns or volatility in the financial markets, increased investor interest in other investment vehicles, or a lack of investor confidence could continue to reduce investor interest and investment activity.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P234_S1	In addition, a continued lessening of investor interest in actively managed equity funds could decrease demand for our products.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P235_S0	Our operations outside of the United States are expanding and involve additional challenges that we may not be able to meet.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P236_S0	Our operations outside of the United States generated $197.5 million in revenue in 2013, or about 28% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P236_S1	There are risks inherent in doing business outside the United States, including challenges in reaching new markets because of established competitors and limited brand recognition; difficulties in staffing, managing, and integrating non-U.S. operations; difficulties in coordinating and sharing information globally; differences in laws and policies from country to country; exposure to varying legal standards, including intellectual property protection laws; potential tax exposure related to transfer pricing and other issues; heightened risk of fraud and noncompliance; and currency exchange rates and exchange controls.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P236_S2	These risks could hamper our ability to expand around the world, which may hurt our financial performance and ability to grow.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P237_S0	As our non-U.S. revenue increases as a percentage of consolidated revenue, fluctuations in foreign currencies present a greater potential risk.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P237_S1	We don't engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P237_S2	Our reported revenue could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar, although the impact on operating income may be offset by an opposing currency impact on locally based operating expense.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P237_S3	In addition, because we use the local currency of our subsidiaries as the functional currency, our financial results are affected by the translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P238_S0	The concentration of data and development work carried out at our offshore facilities may have a negative effect on our business operations, products, and services.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P239_S0	We now have approximately 900 employees working in our data and technology development center in Shenzhen, China, or about one-fourth of our total workforce.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P240_S0	Because China has a restrictive government under centralized control, we cannot predict the level of political and regulatory risk that may affect our operations.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P240_S1	The concentration of development and data work carried out at this facility also involves operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P240_S2	Any difficulties that we face in successfully maintaining our development center in China may harm our business and have a negative impact on the products and services we provide, particularly because we rely on employees in this facility to maintain and update our mutual fund database.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P241_S0	We have approximately 360 employees who work at our data collection facility in Mumbai, India, which may also be subject to regulatory and political risk (including potential terrorist acts).
1289419_14_ITEM1_P241_S1	Like the Shenzhen operation, these facilities also involve operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P242_S0	We could face liability for the information we publish, including information based on data we obtain from other parties.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P243_S0	We may be subject to claims for securities law violations, defamation (including libel and slander), negligence, or other claims relating to the information we publish, including our research and ratings on corporate credit issuers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P243_S1	For example, investors may take legal action against us if they rely on published information that contains an error, or a company may claim that we have made a defamatory statement about it or its employees.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P243_S2	We could also be subject to claims based on the content that is accessible from our website through links to other websites.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P244_S0	We rely on a variety of outside parties as the original sources for the information we use in our published data.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P244_S1	These sources include securities exchanges, fund companies, hedge funds, transfer agents, and other data providers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P244_S2	Accordingly, in addition to possible exposure for publishing incorrect information that results directly from our own errors, we could face liability based on inaccurate data provided to us by others.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P244_S3	Defending claims based on the information we publish could be expensive and time-consuming and could adversely impact our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P245_S0	Our future success depends on our ability to recruit and retain qualified employees.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P246_S0	We experience competition for analysts and other employees from financial institutions and financial services organizations.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P246_S1	These organizations generally have greater resources than we do and therefore may be able to offer significantly more attractive compensation packages to potential employees.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P246_S2	Competition for these employees is intense, and we may not be able to retain our existing employees or be able to recruit and retain other highly qualified personnel in the future.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P247_S0	Our future success also depends on the continued service of our executive officers, including Joe Mansueto, our chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P247_S1	Joe is heavily involved in our day-to-day operations, business strategy, and overall company direction.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P247_S2	The loss of Joe or other executive officers could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P247_S3	We do not have employment agreements, non-compete agreements, or life insurance policies in place with any of our executive officers.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P247_S4	They may leave us and work for our competitors or start their own competing businesses.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P248_S0	Failure to protect our intellectual property rights could harm our brand and ability to compete effectively.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P249_S0	The steps we have taken to protect our intellectual property may not be adequate to safeguard our proprietary information.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P249_S1	Further, effective trademark, copyright, and trade secret protection may not be available in every country in which we offer our services.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P249_S2	Our continued ability to market one or more of our products under their current names could be adversely affected in those jurisdictions where another person registers, or has a pre-existing registration on one or more of them.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P249_S3	Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property could harm our brand, devalue our proprietary content, and affect our ability to compete in the marketplace.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P250_S0	From time to time, we encounter jurisdictions in which one or more third parties have a pre-existing trademark registration in certain relevant international classes that may prevent us from registering our own marks in those jurisdictions.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P250_S1	It is possible that our continued ability to use the Morningstar name or logo, either on a stand-alone basis or in association with certain products or services, could be compromised in those jurisdictions because of these pre-existing registrations.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P250_S2	Similarly, from time to time, we encounter situations in certain jurisdictions where one or more third parties are already using the Morningstar name, either as part of a registered corporate name, a registered domain name or otherwise.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P250_S3	Our ability to effectively market certain products and/or services in those locations could be adversely affected by these pre-existing usages.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P251_S0	Control by a principal shareholder could adversely affect our other shareholders.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P252_S0	As of December 31, 2013, Joe Mansueto, our chairman and chief executive officer, owned approximately 55% of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P252_S1	As a result, he has the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to our shareholders for approval, including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P252_S2	He also has the ability to control our management and affairs.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P252_S3	This concentration of ownership may delay or prevent a change in control; impede a merger, consolidation, takeover, or other business combination involving Morningstar; discourage a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the company; or result in actions that may be opposed by other shareholders.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P253_S0	Fluctuations in our operating results may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S0	We believe our business has relatively large fixed costs and low variable costs, which magnify the impact of revenue fluctuations on our operating results.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S1	As a result, a decline in our revenue may lead to a larger decline in operating income.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S2	A substantial portion of our operating expense is related to personnel costs, marketing programs, office leases, and other infrastructure spending, which generally cannot be adjusted quickly.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S3	Our operating expense levels are based on our expectations for future revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S4	If actual revenue falls below our expectations, or if our expenses increase before revenues do, our operating results would be materially and adversely affected.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S5	In addition, we do not provide earnings guidance or hold one-on-one meetings with institutional investors and research analysts.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S6	Because of this policy and limited analyst coverage on our stock, our stock price may be volatile.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P254_S7	If our operating results or other operating metrics fail to meet the expectations of outside research analysts and investors, the market price of our common stock may decline.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P255_S0	The future sale of shares of our common stock may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P256_S0	If our shareholders sell substantial amounts of our common stock, the market price of our common stock could fall.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P256_S1	A reduction in ownership by Joe Mansueto or any other large shareholder could cause the market price of our common stock to fall.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P256_S2	In addition, the average daily trading volume in our stock is relatively low.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P256_S3	The lack of trading activity in our stock may lead to greater fluctuations in our stock price.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P256_S4	Low trading volume may also make it difficult for shareholders to make transactions in a timely fashion.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P257_S0	Our shareholders may experience dilution in their ownership positions.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P258_S0	In the past, we've granted options to employees as a significant part of their overall compensation package.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P258_S1	In 2006, we began granting restricted stock units to our employees and non-employee directors.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P258_S2	As of December 31, 2013, our employees and non-employee directors held options to acquire 433,531 shares of common stock, 399,008 of which were exercisable at a weighted average price of approximately $27.91 per share.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P258_S3	As of December 31, 2013, there were 696,684 restricted stock units outstanding, which have an average remaining vesting period of 33 months.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P259_S0	Generally speaking, the company issues a share of stock when a restricted stock unit vests.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P259_S1	To the extent that option holders exercise outstanding options to purchase common stock and we issue shares with the vesting of restricted stock units vest, there will be further dilution.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P259_S2	Future grants of stock options or restricted stock units may also result in dilution.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P260_S0	We may raise additional funds through future sales of our common stock.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P260_S1	Any such financing would result in additional dilution to our shareholders.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P261_S0	Stock option exercises, share repurchases, and other factors may create volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P262_S0	Part of our cash provided by financing activities consists of proceeds from stock option exercises and excess tax benefits related to stock option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P262_S1	Excess tax benefits occur at the time a stock option is exercised if the intrinsic value of the option (the difference between the exercise price of the option and the fair value of our stock on the date of exercise) exceeds the fair value of the option at the time of grant.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P262_S2	Similarly, excess tax benefits are generated upon vesting of restricted stock units when the market value of our common stock at vesting is greater than the grant price of the restricted stock units.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P262_S3	These excess tax benefits reduce the cash we pay for income taxes in the year they are recognized.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P263_S0	It is not possible to predict the timing of stock option exercises or the intrinsic value that will be realized.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P263_S1	Because of this uncertainty, there may be additional volatility in our cash flows from financing activities.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P264_S0	In addition, our board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program allowing for the repurchase of up to $700 million of our outstanding common stock, of which approximately $230 million remains available for future repurchases as of February 21, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P264_S1	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that management deems appropriate.
1289419_14_ITEM1_P264_S2	Changes in the amount of repurchase activity from period to period may also cause volatility in our cash flows.
1289419_14_ITEM1B_P0_S0	We do not have any unresolved comments from the Staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding our periodic or current reports under the Exchange Act.
1289419_14_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , we leased approximately 334,000 square feet of office space for our U.S. operations, primarily for our office located in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_14_ITEM2_P0_S1	We also lease approximately 357,000 square feet of office space in 26 other countries around the world, including 141,000 square feet in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_14_ITEM2_P0_S2	We believe that our existing and planned office facilities are adequate for our needs and that additional or substitute space is available to accommodate growth and expansion.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P0_S0	In September 2011, three individual investors in Life's Good S.T.A.B.L. Mortgage hedge fund (LG), Marta Klass, Gregory Martin, and Richard Roellig, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against LG, its principal Robert Stinson, and several other parties, including Morningstar, Inc. (the Klass Matter).
1289419_14_ITEM3_P0_S1	The plaintiffs claim that Morningstar committed fraud and aided and abetted the other defendants' breach of fiduciary duty through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P1_S0	Hedge fund managers self-report their performance data to Morningstar.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P2_S0	More than a year before the Klass Matter, in June 2010, the SEC filed suit against LG and other entities claiming they were part of a Ponzi scheme operated by Stinson.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P2_S1	As a result, LG and the other entities were placed in court-appointed receivership.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P2_S2	Morningstar was not part of the SEC suit or receivership.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P2_S3	Since that time, the Receiver, as part of his duties, has been investigating whether to assert claims against third parties.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P3_S0	Morningstar is aware of 14 lawsuits filed by the Receiver seeking to recover money for the fund.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P4_S0	In November 2011, Morningstar filed a motion to dismiss the Klass Matter.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P5_S0	On behalf of the entities in receivership, the Receiver filed a motion to stay the proceedings because the Receivership Order does not permit suits against the entities in receivership without court permission.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P5_S1	The court granted the Receiver's motion and stayed the Klass Matter.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P6_S0	In April 2012, the Receiver filed a complaint against Morningstar, in which the Receiver claims that Morningstar is liable for contribution and aiding and abetting Stinson's breach of fiduciary duty and fraud through the 5-star rating LG obtained from Morningstar.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P6_S1	The same day the Receiver filed his complaint, Morningstar sought leave from the court to file a counter suit against Stinson and two of his entities-Keystone State Capital Corporation and LG for, among other things, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of user agreements.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P6_S2	In June 2012, the court denied Morningstar's motion for leave to file suit.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P6_S3	The court took no position on the merits of Morningstar's claims, and did not preclude us from renewing our motion to file a complaint at a later time, but deferred to the Receiver's request not to subject the receivership estate to additional litigation at this early point in the receivership.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P7_S0	A bench trial related to the Receiver s claims against Morningstar was held between January 13 and January 28, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P8_S0	At trial, the Receiver claimed that Morningstar is liable under a contribution theory for all or part of a $14.5 million disgorgement judgment that the SEC obtained against the entities and individuals in receivership.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P8_S1	Morningstar contested liability and damages at trial and believes it is not liable for any amount.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P8_S2	The parties will file post-trial proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law in early March 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P8_S3	It is not known when the court will issue its decision.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P9_S0	We believe the allegations against Morningstar by the Klass plaintiffs and the Receiver have no legal or factual basis and we plan to continue to vigorously contest the claims.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P9_S1	We also intend to refile our affirmative claims against Stinson, Keystone, and LG at a later time consistent with the court's order.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P10_S0	We cannot predict the outcome of the proceedings.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P11_S0	We have not provided an estimate of loss or range of loss in connection with this matter because no such estimate can reasonably be made.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P12_S0	In November 2009, Business Logic Holding Corporation filed a complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois against Ibbotson Associates, Inc. and Morningstar, Inc. relating to Ibbotson's prior commercial relationship with Business Logic.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P12_S1	Business Logic is alleging breach of contract and trade secret misappropriation in connection with Ibbotson's development of a proprietary web-service software and user interface that connects plan participant data with the Ibbotson Wealth Forecasting Engine.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P12_S2	Ibbotson and Morningstar answered the complaint, and Ibbotson asserted a counterclaim against Business Logic alleging trade secret misappropriation and breach of contract, also seeking damages and injunctive relief.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P12_S3	Business Logic filed a motion for summary judgment on its breach of contract claim, which was denied on October 1, 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P13_S0	Business Logic's complaint seeks, among other things, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and injunctive relief.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P13_S1	With regard to compensatory damages, based on the analysis of Ibbotson's retained damages expert (who has assumed, solely for purposes of his analysis, that Business Logic will prevail with regard to the issue of liability), and recognizing the uncertainty inherent in litigation and our intention to continue to vigorously defend the claims made by Business Logic, our best estimate of the range of possible loss is between $0 and $5.4 million, excluding punitive damages or attorneys' fees, both of which are recoverable in certain circumstances under the Illinois Trade Secrets Act.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P13_S2	Business Logic's retained damages expert (who has also assumed for purposes of her estimate that Business Logic will prevail with regard to the issue of liability) has, however, estimated compensatory damages of $84 million, excluding punitive damages or attorneys' fees.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P14_S0	We dispute the conclusions reached and the methods employed by Business Logic's expert.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P15_S0	With regard to Business Logic's claim for injunctive relief, no reasonable estimate of loss or range of loss is possible.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P16_S0	Morningstar and Ibbotson continue to vigorously contest all the claims against them in this matter.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P16_S1	We cannot, however, predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P17_S0	In addition to these proceedings, we are involved in legal proceedings and litigation that have arisen in the normal course of our business.
1289419_14_ITEM3_P17_S1	Although the outcome of a particular proceeding can never be predicted, we do not believe that the result of any of these other matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.

1289419_14_ITEM5_P5_S0	Any determination to pay dividends in the future will be at the discretion of our board of directors and will be dependent upon our results of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions, restrictions imposed by applicable law, and other factors deemed relevant by the board of directors.
