1289419_14_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected historical financial data shown below should be read in conjunction with Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. We have derived our Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012, and 2011 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2013 and 2012 from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P0_S1	The Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2011, 2010, and 2009 were derived from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements that are not included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) We account for our stock-based compensation expense in accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P1_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, and stock options.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P1_S2	Please see Note 11 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for more information on our stock-based compensation.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P2_S0	(2) Cash provided by (used for) investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the sale of investments, capital expenditures, purchases of equity and cost- method investments, and proceeds from the sale of businesses.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P2_S1	The level of investing activities can vary from period to period depending on the level of activity in these categories.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P2_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for investing activities.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P3_S0	(3) Cash provided by (used for) financing activities consists primarily of cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program and dividend payments.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P3_S1	These cash outflows are offset by proceeds from stock-option exercises and excess tax benefits.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P3_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources , for more information concerning cash provided by financing activities.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P4_S0	(4) Free cash flow is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under SEC regulations.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P4_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P4_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P4_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required to be reported under GAAP, nor should this data be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P4_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P5_S0	(5) We frequently invoice or collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_14_ITEM6_P5_S1	These amounts are recorded as deferred revenue on our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	The discussion included in this section, as well as other sections of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, contains forward-looking statements as that term is used in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P0_S1	These statements are based on our current expectations about future events or future financial performance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P0_S2	Forward-looking statements by their nature address matters that are, to different degrees, uncertain, and often contain words such as may, could, expect, intend, plan, seek, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, potential, or continue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P0_S3	These statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause the events we discuss not to occur or to differ significantly from what we expect.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P0_S4	For us, these risks and uncertainties include, among others:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	challenges faced by our non-U.S. operations, including the concentration of development work at our offshore facilities in China and India.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	A more complete description of these risks and uncertainties can be found in Item 1A Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	If any of these risks and uncertainties materialize, our actual future results may vary significantly from what we expected.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P2_S2	We do not undertake to update our forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	All dollar and percentage comparisons, which are often accompanied by words such as increase, decrease, grew, declined, was up, was down, was flat, or was similar refer to a comparison with the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our mission is to create great products that help investors reach their financial goals.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for financial advisors, asset managers, retirement plan providers and sponsors, and individual investors.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	Many of our products are sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P4_S3	As a result, we typically generate recurring revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	In the third quarter of 2013, we revised our segment structure to reflect our shift to a more centralized organizational structure.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	We now report our results in a single segment, which is consistent with how management allocates resources and evaluates our financial results.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	We generate revenue by selling a variety of investment-related products and services.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	We sell most of our investment information products and services, including Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Equity Research, Retirement Solutions, and some of our structured credit research and ratings offerings, through license agreements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	Our license agreements typically range from one to three years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S3	We sell some of our other products, such as Premium Membership service on Morningstar.com, Principia software, and newsletters, via subscriptions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S4	These subscriptions are mainly offered for a one-year term, although we also offer terms ranging from one month to three years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S5	We also sell advertising on our websites throughout the world.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P6_S6	In our structured credit research and rating business, we generate transaction-based revenue for our ratings on new issues of commercial mortgage-backed securities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	Our investment management business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves managing investments or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S4	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S5	The method of calculation varies by client; some contracts include provisions for calculating average assets based on daily data, while others use weekly or monthly data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P7_S6	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	In our Retirement Solutions business, our contracts may include one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	Our Retirement Solutions business also includes plan sponsor and custom target-date consulting arrangements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	Fees for these services may be based on the level of assets under advisement.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	We do not disclose a fee range for our Investment Advisory Services and Retirement Solutions businesses because our fee structures vary by client.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	In addition, we believe disclosing a fee range would be detrimental to our competitive position.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	We disclose changes in the nature of the underlying services we provide or their associated fee structures (for example, a change from flat fees to asset-based fees) in our SEC filings to the extent that they are material to our financial results.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s account balance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	Fees for our mutual fund and ETF portfolios generally range from 20 to 40 basis points.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	We charge fees of 55 basis points for our customized stock portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	We frequently invoice our clients and collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	As a result, we use some of this cash to fund our operations and invest in new product development.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and totaled $149.2 million at the end of 2013 and $146.0 million at the end of 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill the service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	Our business requires significant investments to create and maintain proprietary databases and content.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	We strive to leverage these costs by selling a wide variety of products and services to multiple customer groups, through multiple media, and in many geographical markets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	In general, our businesses have high fixed costs, and we expect our revenue to increase or decrease more quickly than our operating expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	We believe that while the fixed costs of the investments in our business are relatively high, the variable cost of adding customers is considerably lower, particularly as a significant portion of our products and services focus on Internet-based platforms and assets under management.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S4	At times, we may make investments in building our databases and content that will hurt our short-term operating results.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S5	During other periods, our profitability may improve because we are able to increase revenue without increasing our cost base at the same rate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P12_S6	When revenue decreases, however, the operating leverage in our business may reduce our profitability.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	We classify our operating expense into separate categories for cost of revenue, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and depreciation and amortization, as described below.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	We include stock-based compensation expense, as appropriate, in each of these categories.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	This category includes compensation expense for employees who produce the products and services we deliver to our customers.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	For example, this category covers production teams and analysts who write investment research reports.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	It also includes compensation expense for programmers, designers, and other employees who develop new products and enhance existing products.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	In some cases, we capitalize the compensation costs associated with certain software development projects.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	This reduces the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	Cost of revenue also includes other expense such as third-party data purchases and data lines.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P15_S3	We now include development expense in the cost of revenue category, which we previously referred to as cost of goods sold.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P15_S4	We have reclassified development expense to include it in cost of revenue for all periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our sales teams, product managers, and other marketing professionals.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	We also include the cost of advertising, direct mail campaigns, and other marketing programs to promote our products in this category.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	This category consists mainly of compensation expense for our management team, as well as corporate functions (including employees in our human resources, finance, and legal departments).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	The category also includes compensation expense for senior management and other corporate costs, including corporate systems, finance and accounting, legal, compliance, and facilities expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	Our capital expenditures primarily consist of information technology equipment, leasehold improvements, and capitalized software development costs.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful lives of the assets, which range from three to seven years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P18_S3	We amortize capitalized software development costs over their estimated economic life, which is generally three years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P18_S4	We also include amortization related to intangible assets, which is mainly driven by acquisitions, in this category.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated economic useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	As of December 31, 2013, we had majority-owned operations in 26 countries outside of the United States and included their results of operations and financial condition in our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	We account for our minority-owned investments in Japan and Sweden using the equity method.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	When our analysts evaluate a stock, they focus on assessing the company's estimated intrinsic value, which represents the company's future cash flows, discounted to their value in today's dollars.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	Our approach to evaluating our own business works the same way.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	Our goal is to increase the intrinsic value of our business over time, which we believe is the best way to create value for our shareholders.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	We do not make public financial forecasts for our business because we want to avoid creating any incentives for our management team to make speculative statements about our financial results that could influence our stock price, or to take actions that help us meet short-term forecasts but may not be in the long-term interest of building shareholder value.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	We provide three specific measures that can help investors generate their own assessment of how our intrinsic value has changed over time:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	Revenue (including organic revenue); Operating income (loss); and Free cash flow, which we define as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	Organic revenue is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	We define organic revenue as consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	We present organic revenue because we believe it helps investors better compare our period-to-period results, and our management team uses this measure to evaluate the performance of our business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	Free cash flow is also considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P27_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and should not be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P27_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	To evaluate how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue, we calculate a retention rate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	We use two different methods for calculating retention.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S2	For subscription-based products (including our print newsletters, Morningstar.com Premium Membership service, and Principia software), we track the number of subscriptions retained during the year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S3	For products sold through contracts and licenses, we use the contract value method, which is based on tracking the dollar value of renewals compared with the total dollar value of contracts up for renewal during the period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S4	We include changes in the contract value in the renewal amount, unless the change specifically results from adding a new product that we can identify.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S5	We also include variable-fee contracts in this calculation and use the previous quarter's actual revenue as the base rate for calculating the renewal percentage.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P28_S6	The retention rate excludes setup and customization fees, migrations to other Morningstar products, and contract renewals that were pending as of January 31, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	We monitor developments in the economic and financial information industry on an ongoing basis.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P29_S1	We use these insights to help inform our company strategy, product development plans, and marketing initiatives.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	Despite a temporary government shutdown and periodic concerns about the Federal Reserve tapering off its efforts to stimulate the economy, the U.S. stock market showed unusually strong gains in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	Morningstar's U.S. Market Index, a broad market benchmark, ended the year up 33.1%.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	Global markets also closed out the year with strong returns; Morningstar s Global Markets ex-U.S. Index posted a 16.1% gain for the year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	The fund industry enjoyed healthy growth in 2013 as a slowly improving global economy help lead to more positive investor sentiment.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	Total U.S. mutual fund assets rose to $15.0 trillion as of December 31, 2013, compared with $13.0 trillion as of December 31, 2012, based on data from the Investment Company Institute (ICI).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P31_S2	Based on Morningstar s analysis of fund flow trends, equity mutual funds had estimated net inflows of about $220 billion in 2013, up from about $100 billion in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P31_S3	In contrast to the past several years, when investors heavily favored bond funds, some fixed-income fund categories experienced net outflows as rising interest rates led to negative total returns.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P31_S4	Global mutual fund assets showed a similar trend.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	Investors have also continued to favor passively managed index funds rather than actively managed portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P32_S1	In 2013, passively managed vehicles had more than $300 billion in net inflows, compared with about $150 billion of net inflows for active products (both mutual funds and ETFs).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	The number of mutual funds in the United States rose slightly to about 7,700 in 2013 (excluding multiple share classes), compared with about 7,600 in 2012 based on ICI data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	The number of global mutual funds rose to about 75,300 as of September 30, 2013, up from about 73,500 as of September 30, 2012, based on ICI data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	ETFs continued to increase in popularity relative to traditional mutual funds.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	The U.S. ETF industry closed out 2013 with about $1.7 trillion in assets under management based on ICI data, up from about $1.3 trillion at the end of 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	Based on data from ComScore, aggregate page views to financial and investment sites rose about 9% in 2013, while the number of unique users was up about 11%.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	The number of pages viewed per visit and time spent per visit increased by about 17% and 21%, respectively.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	We believe these trends reflect a higher level of interest in financial- and investment-related content among individual investors as the market rose during 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	For Morningstar.com, metrics such as unique users and aggregate page views were up slightly for the year, while pages viewed per visit and time spent per visit showed a more significant increase.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	Amid these trends, we believe online advertising spending by financial services companies rose moderately in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	Although Magna Global, a division of Interpublic Group, estimates that global online advertising revenue rose about 16% across all industries in 2013, we believe spending in the financial services industry rose at a more moderate pace.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	In the wake of the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, regulators have continued to implement new rules for financial services companies globally.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	Many of these relate to financial advisor compensation, fees and expenses, investor disclosure, and the use of hedge funds and alternative investments.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	In the United Kingdom, for example, the Retail Distribution Review (RDR), which emphasizes increased regulation of advisory fees, higher professional standards for financial advisors, and an emphasis on "whole of market" investment solutions, became effective in January 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S3	Advisors are now required to give clients a choice of all investment vehicles (including funds, ETFs, and other products) and demonstrate that they consider different investment options without bias.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S4	Financial advisors are also required to fully disclose and have clients agree on fees for advice and charge separately for any funds or investments.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P37_S5	Beginning in April 2014, online investment platforms will also be required to charge separate fees for investors who make transactions through them and provide additional disclosures about the fees they charge.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	In the European Union, Undertakings for Collective Investments in Transferable Securities (UCITS) is a set of directives designed to enable funds to operate across the region based upon authorization from one state regulator.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	UCITS IV, which came into effect in July 2011, included requirements for a new Key Investor Information Document (KIID), an easy-to-read annual factsheet that replaces the Simplified Prospectus.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P38_S2	Every UCITS fund that is promoted to retail investors is now required to produce a KIID and issue an updated copy each year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P38_S3	We use our data and production capabilities to help fund companies produce and distribute these documents.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	In Australia, the government has introduced a series of Future of Financial Advice reforms.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	Mandatory implementation of these reforms began in July 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	Many of these related to fiduciary standards and compensation structures for financial advisors.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	In the United States, President Obama signed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank) into law in July 2010.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	Dodd-Frank creates a number of new regulatory, supervisory, and advisory bodies and touches on the regulation of virtually every aspect of U.S. financial markets and activities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	Dodd-Frank also left numerous matters to be addressed through rulemaking and other regulatory action, giving the regulators significant discretion in many areas.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	As a result, the final shape and effect of the legislation are continuing to emerge.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	In 2013, various regulatory agencies approved provisions of the "Volcker Rule," which would prevent banks from engaging in some types of proprietary trading and more speculative investments.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P41_S1	The Volcker Rule is scheduled to go into effect in April 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	Dodd-Frank included a number of corporate governance and disclosure requirements that apply to publicly traded companies generally.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	It also included changes to the regulatory framework for credit rating agencies granting the SEC more oversight over Nationally Recognized Statistical Rating Organizations (NRSROs), including our Morningstar Credit Ratings subsidiary.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	While we believe Dodd-Frank and related regulations will not have a significant effect on other areas of Morningstar, we continue to monitor the potential impact on our clients.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has been considering rules that would impose a fiduciary standard for financial advisors, which would require them to act in the best interest of clients when making investment recommendations instead of the looser suitability standards currently in place.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	The Department of Labor has proposed a similar plan that would only apply to advisors working with defined contribution plans and individual retirement accounts.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	We believe the increase regulatory scrutiny of advisors may lead to an expanding need for independent advice, tools, and solutions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	In July 2013, the United States Department of Labor (DOL) revised the definition of "Rating Agency" in its amended requirements for the Exemption From Certain Prohibited Transaction Restrictions of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to eliminate any specific reference to a particular credit rating agency.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	The amended exemption increases the ability of employee benefit plans to invest in structured credit securities that carry ratings issued by Morningstar Credit Ratings.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	Despite generally positive market trends, we believe the business environment for the financial services industry remains challenging.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	Asset management firms have been facing increasing regulatory burdens, which are leading to higher costs and more cautious spending in other areas.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P46_S2	Further, the historically low interest rate environment has put significant pressure on the margins of many firms, most notably those in the variable annuity space.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P46_S3	As a result, we expect there will be further pressure on revenue from clients in this area.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	The tables below summarize our key product metrics and other supplemental data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	(1) The decline in assets under advisement in 2012 and 2013 reflects difficult market conditions for companies that offer variable annuities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	Some of our clients have been managing their funds-of-funds portfolios in-house instead of using outside subadvisors.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P48_S2	Because of this trend, assets under advisement were down $10.8 billion in 2013 and $43.2 billion in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P48_S3	The asset change in 2012 reflects both the loss of business from a large client and a change in the scope of services provided to another client.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	The asset totals include relationships for which we receive basis-point fees, including consulting arrangements and other agreements where we act as a portfolio construction manager for a mutual fund or variable annuity.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	We also provide Investment Advisory services for some assets for which we receive a flat fee; we do not include these assets in the total reported above.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	We cannot separately quantify cash inflows and outflows for these portfolios because we do not have custody of the assets in the majority of our investment management businesses.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	The information we receive from many of our clients does not separately identify the effect of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P51_S2	We also cannot precisely quantify the effect of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	(2) We cannot separately quantify the factors affecting assets under management and advisement for our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P52_S1	These factors primarily consist of employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P52_S2	We cannot quantify the impact of these other factors because the information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances caused by market movement.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	(3) Beginning with the third quarter of 2013, we revised our segment structure to reflect our shift to a more centralized organizational structure.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P53_S1	In addition, we took this opportunity to revise our revenue by product structure to better represent how management internally reviews and evaluates product revenue and performance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P53_S2	The most significant revision is that Morningstar Data now excludes Morningstar Commodity Data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P53_S3	We have reclassified the prior-year information to reflect these changes.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P53_S4	We also made minor corrections to the total number of licenses for Morningstar Direct in 2012 and 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	We define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	Please refer to the discussion in How We Evaluate our Business for more detail.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	In 2013, our consolidated revenue rose 6.1% compared with the previous year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	Although our Investment Advisory revenue was down about $7.2 million compared with 2012, most of our other major products performed well.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P55_S2	Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Data, Morningstar Managed Portfolios, and Morningstar Retirement Solutions were some of our major growth drivers in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	In 2012, our consolidated revenue increased 4.3% .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	Morningstar Direct was the main contributor to revenue growth, followed by Morningstar Data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	Morningstar Advisor Workstation and Integrated Web Tools also made positive contributions, although to a lesser extent.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	These factors helped offset the loss of business from a large variable annuity client in our Investment Advisory business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P56_S4	Because this client began managing several fund-of-funds portfolios in-house in April 2012, we recognized $3.8 million in associated revenue in 2012, down from $12.4 million in 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Investment information products, which make up about 80% of our consolidated revenue, rose $29.5 million , or 5.6% , in 2013 and $27.9 million , or 5.6% , in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	Morningstar Direct was the biggest contributor to growth in this product group in both 2013 and 2012, with revenue increasing by $14.1 million in 2013 and $13.1 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to about 8,500 worldwide in 2013, compared with about 7,400 at the end of 2012 and 6,100 at the end of 2011, with strong growth in both the United States and internationally.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P57_S3	Growth in Morningstar Direct reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients, and, to a lesser extent, client migrations from both Institutional Workstation and Morningstar EnCorr to Morningstar Direct.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	Morningstar Data was the second-biggest contributor to growth in this product group in both 2013 and 2012, reflecting strong renewal rates and new client contracts for managed products data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	Morningstar Data gives institutions access to a full range of proprietary investment data spanning numerous investment databases, including real-time pricing data, fundamental equity data, and managed investment product data.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	The data packages we offer include proprietary statistics, such as the Morningstar Style Box and Morningstar Rating, and a wide range of other data, including information on investment performance, risk, portfolios, operations data, fees and expenses, cash flows, and ownership.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	Morningstar Advisor Workstation (mainly Morningstar Office) had moderately positive revenue growth in both 2013 and 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P60_S1	The number of U.S. licenses for Morningstar Advisor Workstation increased to about 170,000 in 2013, compared with 163,000 at the end of 2012 and 160,000 at the end of 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P60_S2	These positive growth trends were partially offset by lower revenue for Principia, which was down $4.8 million in 2013 and $1.8 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P60_S3	During the first quarter of 2013, we announced that we are no longer selling new subscriptions to Principia, and we ve begun migrating Principia clients to Morningstar Advisor Workstation and other Morningstar products that meet their needs.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P60_S4	We expect to continue supporting clients on Principia until the end of 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	Morningstar.com was up slightly in 2013, but declined by $2.7 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	Revenue was down in 2012 because of declining paid Premium Membership subscriptions (mainly in the United States) and a difficult advertising sales market.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	Investment management revenue, which represents about 20% of consolidated revenue, was up $10.5 million , or 7.9% , in 2013, as positive trends in assets under management for Retirement Solutions and Morningstar Managed Portfolios more than offset lower revenue for Investment Advisory services.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	Companies that offer variable annuities have continued to face difficult market conditions, which has prompted some of our clients to begin managing their fund-of-funds portfolios in-house instead of using outside subadvisors.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P63_S1	Because of this trend, our Investment Advisory revenue was about $7.2 million lower in 2013 versus 2012, and assets under advisement for these services were down $10.8 billion over the same period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	Investment management revenue decreased $1.0 million , or 0.7% , in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	The loss of some business from a large client in the variable annuity industry was the main reason for this decline.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	Excluding the loss of this business, Investment Advisory revenue was up $3.4 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P64_S3	Revenue for Morningstar Managed Portfolios, and to a lesser extent, Retirement Solutions, also rose in 2012, partially offsetting negative trends in Investment Advisory.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	The asset-based fees we earn are primarily based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	Average assets under advisement and management (calculated based on available average quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $161.6 million in 2013, compared with $181.0 million in 2012 and $165.3 million in 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P65_S2	We had $88.6 million in revenue from asset-based fees in 2013 , an increase of $7.2 million compared with $81.4 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P65_S3	In 2011 , revenue from asset-based fees was $81.7 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P65_S4	Revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 12.7% of consolidated revenue in 2013 , up slightly from 12.4% in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	The variable annuity industry, which accounted for approximately 2% and 3% of consolidated revenue in 2013 and 2012, respectively, continues to face challenges.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P66_S1	Accordingly, we expect there will be further pressure on revenue from variable annuity clients.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	To allow for more meaningful comparisons of our results in different periods, we provide information about organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P67_S1	During the second quarter of 2013, we acquired an additional 76% interest in Morningstar Sweden AB to become the sole owner.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P68_S0	We divested several smaller business lines during 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P69_S0	We exclude revenue from businesses acquired or divested from organic revenue for a period of 12 months after we complete the acquisition or divestiture.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P70_S0	In 2013, the net effect of acquisitions and divestitures was essentially neutral, as we had $3.7 million in incremental revenue from our acquisition of the remaining ownership interest in Morningstar Sweden, which was offset by the loss of $4.1 million in revenue from business lines we divested in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P70_S1	In addition, currency translations reduced revenue by about $3.6 million in 2013, mainly because of the weaker Australian dollar.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P70_S2	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 6.7% in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P71_S0	In 2012, currency translations reduced revenue by about $4.6 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P72_S0	The euro, and to a lesser extent, the British pound, were the primary reasons for the negative currency effect.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P73_S0	Divestitures reduced revenue by an additional $1.1 million in 2012, and we had no incremental revenue from acquisitions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P73_S1	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 5.2% in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations):
1289419_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	Organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non- GAAP financial measure.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P75_S1	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P75_S2	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	International revenue made up about 28% of our consolidated revenue in 2013, 2012, and 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	About 60% of our international revenue is from Continental Europe and the United Kingdom.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P76_S2	We also have a fairly large revenue base in Australia and Canada.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P77_S0	Revenue from international operations rose 3.2% in 2013, as our operations in Continental Europe enjoyed stronger product sales, but this growth was partly offset by the negative effect of foreign currency translations (mainly the weaker Australian dollar).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P78_S0	In 2012, international revenue was up 3.5% , mainly because of stronger product sales in Europe and Canada, partially offset by lower revenue in Australia.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P78_S1	Divestitures had a slight negative effect on international revenue in 2012, while foreign currency translations decreased revenue by $4.6 million , mainly because of the euro, and to a lesser extent, the British pound.

1289419_14_ITEM7_P80_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P80_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business, we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P81_S1	The following graph illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P82_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Morningstar Data, Investment Advisory services, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average annual renewal rate was between 90% and 95% in 2013, within the same range as 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P82_S1	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes and changes to the contract value upon renewal, as well as changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P83_S0	In 2013, we estimate that our annual retention rate for subscription-based products, such as Principia, Morningstar.com's Premium Membership service, and print and online newsletters, was between 65% and 70%, within the same range as 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P84_S0	(1) We now include development expense in the cost of revenue category, which we previously referred to as cost of goods sold.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P84_S1	We have reclassified development expense to include it in cost of revenue for all periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P84_S2	We previously reported development expense as a separate operating expense category.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P85_S0	Separately, as a result of our recent reorganization (including new positions created, changes in focus for some existing roles, and the refinement of employee cost categorizations as we moved to a more centralized structure), approximately 180 net positions shifted from the general and administrative and sales and marketing categories to cost of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P85_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2013 as compared with 2012 and 2011, changes related to our more centralized organizational structure added approximately $14 million of compensation expense to cost of revenue, and reduced the compensation expense in our sales and marketing and general and administrative expense categories by approximately $8 million and $6 million, respectively.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P85_S2	These changes did not affect our total operating expense or operating income for any of the periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P86_S0	(2) Includes stock-based compensation expense of:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P87_S0	In 2013, our operating expense was up $20.0 million , or 3.9% , mainly because of higher salary expense, depreciation expense, professional fees, and bonus expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P87_S1	Salary expense rose $6.3 million for the year, primarily because of pay raises made in July 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P87_S2	In addition, while headcount was down in the first nine months of the year, we hired about 75 net new employees during the fourth quarter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P87_S3	By the end of 2013, we had about 3,565 employees worldwide, compared with 3,495 at the end of 2012 and 3,465 at the end of 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P88_S0	Depreciation increased $5.1 million, mainly reflecting additional capitalized software development and computer software purchases for our U.S. operations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P89_S0	Professional fees were up $5.0 million in 2013, mainly reflecting higher legal expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P90_S0	Bonus expense rose $4.6 million in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P90_S1	We review our estimates for the size of the bonus pool quarterly and make adjustments based on our expectations for full-year revenue and operating income relative to internal targets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P91_S0	In 2012, operating expense rose $14.6 million or 3.0% , mainly because of a $14.0 million increase in salary expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P91_S1	Salary expense was up because of the full-year effect of regular pay raises and market adjustments made in July 2011, as well as regular pay raises made in July 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P91_S2	New hires in 2011 and 2012 also contributed to the growth in salary expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P92_S0	Higher professional fees, production expense, company-sponsored benefits (including matching contributions to our 401(k) plan for U.S. employees), and stock-based compensation expense also added to our expense base in 2012, although to a lesser extent than the salary costs discussed above.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P92_S1	Stock-based compensation expense in 2012 included $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of restricted stock issued to a former executive in our structured credit research unit when we acquired the business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P92_S2	Additional data purchases contributed to the $3.8 million growth in production expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P93_S0	Operating expense as a percentage of revenue was down 1.5 percentage points in 2013 and 1.0 percentage point in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P94_S0	Cost of revenue (which we previously referred to as cost of goods sold) is our largest category of operating expense, representing about one-half of our total operating expense.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P94_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and we include compensation costs for the employees who produce our products and services in cost of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P94_S2	We now include development expense in this category and have reclassified development expense to include it in cost of revenue for all periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P95_S0	Cost of revenue was up $24.7 million , or 10.0% , in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P95_S1	Higher compensation expense of $14.0 million (mainly because of the shift in expense categories discussed above) was the main contributor to the increase.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P95_S2	We included compensation expense in this category for approximately 2,880 employees as of December 31, 2013 (about 80% of our total employees), compared with approximately 2,585 as of December 31, 2012 (about 75% of our total employees).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P96_S0	We capitalized $8.1 million of compensation expense related to software development activities in 2013, reducing cost of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P96_S1	For comparison, we capitalized $8.5 million of expense in this category in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P97_S0	Cost of revenue rose $11.5 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P97_S1	Higher salary expense contributed about $10.4 million of this increase, mainly because of additional headcount.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P97_S2	We also had higher production expense of $3.8 million because of additional data purchases for our operations in the United States and Europe.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P97_S3	Other compensation-related expense (mainly for employee benefits) was another factor behind higher cost of revenue in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P97_S4	We capitalized $8.5 million of operating expense in 2012 compared with $5.3 million in 2011 for software development, reducing the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P98_S0	Our gross margin declined by about 1.4 percentage points and 0.2 percentage points in 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P98_S1	In 2013, about 2 percentage points of the decline resulted from the shift in expense categories discussed above.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P99_S0	Sales and marketing expense was down $5.3 million in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P99_S1	Lower salary-related and bonus expense of $6.4 million (including approximately $8 million from the shift in expense categories as a result of our recent reorganization), was the main reason for the decline.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P99_S2	We included compensation expense in this category for approximately 290 employees as of December 31, 2013 compared with approximately 350 as of December 31, 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P99_S3	Higher sales commissions of $2.6 million partly offset this decrease.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P100_S0	Sales and marketing expense rose $2.2 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P100_S1	Salary expense increased $4.1 million and bonus expense was up $1.5 million, but these were partially offset by lower costs for advertising, marketing, and commissions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P100_S2	Full-year bonus expense included in this category was flat in 2012; however, in the first quarter of 2012, we paid a greater portion of the 2011 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $1.0 million to the bonus expense recorded in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P101_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense was down 1.7 percentage points in 2013 and 0.4 percentage points in 2012, mainly because of lower salary expense as a percentage of revenue in both years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P101_S1	In 2012, advertising and marketing and commissions also declined as a percentage of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P101_S2	In 2013, 1.1 percentage points of the decline was driven by the shift in expense categories discussed above.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P102_S0	General and administrative (G A) expense was down $2.0 million in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P103_S0	There were three main items that contributed to the decline in G A expense in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S0	First, G A expense in 2012 included $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of restricted stock issued to a former executive in the structured credit research unit when we acquired the business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S1	This expense did not recur in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S2	Second, we had an additional $1.6 million of combined expense in 2012 for an impairment charge for one of our smaller products and a litigation settlement.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S3	This expense did not recur in 2013, either.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S4	Third, salary expense was down about $0.9 million (including a reduction of approximately $6 million from the shift in expense categories as a result of our recent reorganization).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P104_S5	We included compensation expense in this category for approximately 395 employees as of December 31, 2013, compared with approximately 560 as of December 31, 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P105_S0	Higher professional fees of $3.6 million partially offset the decline in G A expense in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P105_S1	In addition, our 2012 results included a benefit of approximately $1.0 million for the resolution of a prior-year business tax expense matter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P105_S2	This benefit did not recur in 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P106_S0	G A expense rose $0.8 million in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P106_S1	Higher professional fees and higher stock-based compensation expense contributed to the total increase in G A. As mentioned above, stock-based compensation expense in 2012 included $3.2 million for accelerated vesting of restricted stock.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P106_S2	Lower bonus expense of $5.7 million in 2012 partially offset the increase.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P106_S3	Current-year bonus expense was down $2.8 million.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P106_S4	In addition, in the first quarter of 2011, we paid a greater portion of the 2010 bonus to employees in this category compared with our initial estimate, contributing $2.6 million to the bonus expense recorded in 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P107_S0	G A expense in 2012 included about $1.6 million of expense for a litigation settlement and an impairment charge for one of our smaller products.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P107_S1	However, as mentioned above, our 2012 results included a benefit of approximately$1.0 million from the resolution of a prior-year business tax expense matter.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P107_S2	Conversely, our results for 2011 included $1.4 million of expense related to this business tax.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P107_S3	G A expense in 2011 also included $3.2 million for the separation agreement with our former chief operating officer.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P107_S4	This expense did not recur in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P108_S0	G A expense as a percentage of revenue was down 1.2 percentage points in 2013 and 0.6 percentage points in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P108_S1	In 2013, 0.9 percentage points of the decline was driven by the shift in expense categories discussed above.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P109_S0	Intangible amortization expense decreased $2.5 million in 2013 and $3.3 million in 2012, mainly because some of the intangible assets from some of our previous acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P109_S1	Amortization expense was also down in 2012 because of a favorable comparison with 2011, when our results included $1.6 million of expense for the accelerated amortization of certain trade names and the impairment of one trade name.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P109_S2	However, depreciation expense rose $5.1 million in 2013, mainly because of additions to capitalized software development and purchases of computer software for our U.S. operations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P109_S3	Depreciation expense rose $3.5 million in 2012, mainly driven by an increase in capital spending for our U.S. operations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P110_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost for the remaining lives of the assets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P110_S1	We estimate that total amortization expense for intangible assets will be approximately $20.5 million in 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P110_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by additional acquisitions, dispositions, changes in the estimated average useful lives, and currency translations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P111_S0	Overall, depreciation and amortization was unchanged in 2013 and decreased slightly as a percentage of revenue in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P112_S0	Consolidated operating income increased $20.0 million in 2013 as our revenue increased $40.0 million and operating expense rose by $20.0 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P112_S1	Operating margin was 24.4% , an increase of 1.5 percentage points compared with 2012, mainly reflecting higher operating margins for the first three quarters of the year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P113_S0	Lower salary expense as a percentage of revenue contributed approximately 1.0 percentage points to the margin improvement in 2013; lower stock-based compensation expense and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue also had favorable effects of 0.7 percentage points and 0.5 percentage points, respectively.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P113_S1	On the negative side, professional fees and depreciation expense as a percentage of revenue were both up 0.6 percentage points, and bonus expense as a percentage of revenue rose 0.4 percentage points.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P114_S0	In 2012, consolidated operating income rose $12.3 million , and our margin was up 1.0 percentage points.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P114_S1	Our revenue growth of $26.9 million outpaced the increase in our costs of $14.6 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P115_S0	Lower bonus expense contributed 1.3 percentage points to our margin growth in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P115_S1	In addition, capitalized operating expense for software development contributed 0.5 percentage points to our margin growth in 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P115_S2	Higher salaries and other compensation-related expense as a percentage of revenue partially offset these increases, and acquisitions also had a slight negative effect on the margin.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P116_S0	Equity in net income of unconsolidated entities mainly consists of our portion of the net income (loss) of Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P116_S1	Beginning in the fourth quarters of 2011 and 2012, it also includes our portion of the net income (loss) of YCharts, Inc. (YCharts) and Inquiry Financial Europe AB, respectively.

1289419_14_ITEM7_P117_S1	In May 2013, we acquired the remaining 76% interest in Morningstar Sweden for $14.6 million in cash, increasing our ownership interest to become the sole owner.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P117_S2	Because Morningstar Sweden is now a wholly owned subsidiary, we no longer account for our investment using the equity method.

1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations and outside sources, will be sufficient to meet our operating and other cash needs for at least the next 12 months.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S1	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments, consisting primarily of fixed-income securities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S2	We maintain a conservative investment policy for our investments and invest a portion of these assets in municipal securities with high-quality stand-alone credit ratings.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S3	Investments in our portfolio have a maximum maturity of two years; the weighted average maturity is approximately one year.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S4	We also invest a portion of our investments balance (approximately $19.7 million, or 15%, of our total investment balance as of December 31, 2013 ) in proprietary Morningstar portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P126_S5	These portfolios may consist of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, or ETFs.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P127_S0	Approximately 51% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2013 was held by our operations in the United States, down from about 58% as of December 31, 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P127_S1	Given our strong liquidity in the United States, we do not expect to repatriate earnings from our foreign subsidiaries in the foreseeable future.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P127_S2	We have not recognized deferred tax liabilities for the portion of the outside basis differences (including unremitted earnings) relating to foreign subsidiaries because the investment in these subsidiaries is considered to be permanent in duration.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P127_S3	Quantification of the deferred tax liability associated with these outside basis differences is not practicable.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P128_S0	We intend to use our cash, cash equivalents, and investments for general corporate purposes, including working capital and funding future growth.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P128_S1	To date, we have not needed to access any significant commercial credit and have not borrowed under any lines of credit.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P129_S0	In 2013 , we paid dividends of $17.4 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P129_S1	We made only three dividend payments in 2013 because we opted to pay the dividend originally scheduled for January 2013 in December 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P129_S2	In February 2014, our board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 17 cents per share.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P129_S3	The dividend is payable on April 30, 2014 to shareholders of record as of April 11, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P129_S4	We expect to make regular quarterly dividend payments of 17 cents per share in 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P130_S0	In December 2013, our board of directors approved a $200 million increase to our share repurchase program, bringing the total amount authorized under the program to $700 million.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P130_S1	We may repurchase shares of our outstanding common stock from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that we deem appropriate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P130_S2	In 2013, we repurchased a total of approximately 2.0 million shares for $153.5 million.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P130_S3	As of December 31, 2013 , we had repurchased a total of approximately 7.1 million shares for $449.8 million under this program since we originally announced it in October 2010.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P131_S0	Cash provided by operating activities is our main source of cash.

1289419_14_ITEM7_P132_S0	As of December 31, 2013, we had cash, cash equivalents, and investments of $298.6 million , a decrease of $22.9 million compared with $321.4 million as of December 31, 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P132_S1	The change reflects cash provided by operating activities partially offset by $153.5 million used to repurchase common stock, bonus payments of $36.6 million made during the first quarter of 2013 related to the 2012 bonus, and $33.6 million of capital expenditures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P132_S2	In addition, we used approximately $14.6 million in cash to acquire the remaining 76% of Morningstar Sweden to become sole owner.

1289419_14_ITEM7_P134_S0	We also expect to use a portion of our cash and investments balances in the first quarter of 2014 to make annual bonus payments of approximately $40 million related to the 2013 bonus.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P135_S0	As described in more detail above, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P135_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P135_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P136_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P136_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P137_S0	We generated positive free cash flow in 2013 , 2012 , and 2011 as our cash provided by operating activities has consistently exceeded capital expenditures, as shown below:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P138_S0	We generated positive free cash flow of $153.1 million in 2013, an increase of $37.1 million versus 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P138_S1	In 2012, free cash flow was down $25.7 million from 2011, reflecting lower cash provided by operating activities and higher capital expenditures compared with 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P139_S0	In May 2013, we acquired an additional 76% interest in Morningstar Sweden AB (Morningstar Sweden), increasing our ownership to 100% from 24%.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P139_S1	We did not complete any acquisitions in 2012 or 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P139_S2	We invested a total of $10.8 million , less cash acquired, related to acquisitions over the past three years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P139_S3	We describe these acquisitions, including purchase price and product offerings, in Note 6 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
