1289419_14_ITEM7_P142_S0	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P142_S1	We discuss our significant accounting policies in Note 2 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P143_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires our management team to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, expense, and related disclosures included in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P144_S0	We evaluate our estimates on an ongoing basis.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P144_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P144_S2	Based on these assumptions and estimates, we make judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P144_S3	Our actual results could vary from these estimates and assumptions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P144_S4	If actual amounts are different from previous estimates, we include revisions in our results of operations for the period in which the actual amounts become known.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P145_S0	We believe the following critical accounting policies reflect the significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our Consolidated Financial Statements:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P146_S0	Much of our revenue comes from the sale of subscriptions or licenses for print publications, software, and Internet-based products and services.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P146_S1	We recognize this revenue in equal amounts over the term of the subscription or license, which generally ranges from one to three years.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P146_S2	We also provide analysis, consulting, retirement advice, and other services.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P146_S3	We recognize this revenue when the service is provided or during the service obligation period defined in the contract.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P147_S0	We make significant judgments related to revenue recognition, including whether fees are fixed or determinable and whether the collection of payment is probable.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P148_S0	For contracts that combine multiple products and services, we make judgments regarding the value of each element in the arrangement based on selling prices of the items when sold separately.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P149_S0	Delivery of our products and services is a prerequisite to the recognition of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P149_S1	If arrangements include an acceptance provision, we begin recognizing revenue upon the receipt of customer acceptance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P150_S0	We make judgments at the beginning of an arrangement regarding whether or not collection is probable.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P150_S1	Probability of collection is assessed on a case-by-case basis.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P150_S2	We typically sell to institutional customers with whom we have a history of successful collections.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S0	Deferred revenue is the amount invoiced or collected in advance for subscriptions, licenses, or services that has not yet been recognized as revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , our deferred revenue was $149.2 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S2	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill our service obligations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S3	The amount of deferred revenue may increase or decrease primarily based on the mix of contracted products and services and the volume of new and renewal subscriptions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S4	The timing of future revenue recognition may change depending on the terms of the license agreements and the timing of fulfilling our service obligations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P151_S5	We believe that the estimate related to revenue recognition is a critical accounting estimate, and to the extent that there are material differences between our determination of deferred revenue and actual results, our financial condition or results of operations may be affected.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P152_S0	Acquisitions, Goodwill, and Other Intangible Assets Our financial statements reflect the operations of an acquired business starting from the completion of the transaction.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P152_S1	In addition, the assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at the date of acquisition at their respective estimated fair values.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P153_S0	Allocating the purchase price to the acquired assets and liabilities involves management judgment.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P153_S1	Accordingly, we typically obtain the assistance of third-party valuation experts for significant assets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P154_S0	The fair value estimates are based on available historical information and on future expectations and assumptions deemed reasonable by management, but are inherently uncertain.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P155_S0	The determination of the fair values of intangible assets requires significant management judgment in each of the following areas:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P156_S0	Identify the acquired intangible assets: For each acquisition, we identify the intangible assets acquired.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P156_S1	These intangible assets generally consist of customer relationships, trademarks and trade names, technology-related intangibles including internally developed software and databases, and non-compete agreements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P157_S0	Estimate the fair value of these intangible assets: We consider various approaches to value the intangible assets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P157_S1	These valuation approaches include the cost approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the cost to reproduce it or replace it with another asset of like utility; the market approach, which values the asset through an analysis of sales and offerings of comparable assets; and the income approach, which measures the value of an asset based by measuring the present worth of the economic benefits it is expected to produce.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P158_S0	Estimate the remaining useful life of the assets: For each intangible asset, we use judgment and assumptions to establish the remaining useful life of the asset.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P158_S1	For example, for customer relationships, we determine the estimated useful life with reference to observed customer attrition rates.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P158_S2	For technology-related assets such as databases, we make judgments about the demand for current data and historical metrics in establishing the remaining useful life.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P158_S3	For internally developed software, we estimate an obsolescence factor associated with the software.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P159_S0	Any excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the net assets acquired is recorded as Goodwill which is not amortized.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P159_S1	Instead, it is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist, based on a discounted cash-flow model.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P159_S2	We review the carrying value of goodwill for impairment at least annually based upon the estimated fair value of our reporting units.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P159_S3	Should the review indicate that goodwill is impaired, the goodwill balance would be reduced by the difference between the carrying value of goodwill and its fair value.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P160_S0	For purposes of performing the impairment test, fair values are determined using a discounted cash flow methodology.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P160_S1	This requires significant judgments including estimation of future cash flows, which, among other factors, is dependent on internal forecasts, estimation of the long-term rate of growth for businesses and determination of weighted average cost of capital.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P160_S2	We believe that the accounting estimates related to purchase price allocations in connection with acquisitions and subsequent goodwill impairment testing are critical accounting estimates because changes in these assumptions could materially affect the amounts and classifications of assets and liabilities presented in our Consolidated Balance Sheets, as well as the amount of amortization and depreciation expense, if any, recorded in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P161_S0	We include stock-based compensation expense in each of our operating expense categories.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P161_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense primarily reflects grants of restricted stock units and restricted stock.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S0	Under FASB ASC 718 , Compensation Stock Compensation , we measure stock-based compensation expense at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and recognize the cost as expense ratably over the award's vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S1	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day before the grant.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S2	We estimate expected forfeitures of stock-based awards at the grant date and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S3	We ultimately adjust this forfeiture assumption to the actual forfeiture rate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S4	Therefore, changes in the forfeiture assumptions do not change the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P162_S5	Instead, different forfeiture assumptions would only affect the timing of expense recognition over the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P163_S0	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense during the third quarter to reflect those awards that ultimately vested.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P163_S1	In addition, we update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P164_S0	We believe that the estimates related to stock-based compensation expense are critical accounting estimates because the assumptions used could significantly impact the timing and amount of stock-based compensation expense recorded in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P165_S0	Our effective tax rate is based on the mix of income and losses in our U.S. and non-U.S. operations, statutory tax rates, and tax-planning opportunities available to us in the various jurisdictions in which we operate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P165_S1	Significant judgment is required to evaluate our tax positions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P166_S0	Tax law requires us to include items in our tax return at different times from when these items are reflected in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P166_S1	As a result, the effective tax rate reflected in our Consolidated Financial Statements is different from the tax rate reported on our tax return (our cash tax rate).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P166_S2	Some of these differences, such as expenses that are not deductible in our tax return, are permanent.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P166_S3	Other differences, such as depreciation expense, reverse over time.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P166_S4	These timing differences create deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P167_S0	We determine our deferred tax assets and liabilities based on temporary differences between the financial reporting and the tax basis of assets and liabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P167_S1	The excess tax benefits associated with stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units also create a difference between our cash tax rate and the effective tax rate in our Consolidated Income Statement.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P168_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , we had gross deferred tax assets of $33.2 million and gross deferred tax liabilities of $45.6 million .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P168_S1	The deferred tax assets include $9.2 million of deferred tax assets related to $45.4 million of net operating losses (NOLs) of our non-U.S. operations.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P169_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P169_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $8.8 million of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of the NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P170_S0	In assessing the need for a valuation allowance, we consider both positive and negative evidence, including tax-planning strategies, projected future taxable income, and recent financial performance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P170_S1	If we determine a lesser allowance is required at some point in the future, we would record a reduction to our tax expense and valuation allowance.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P170_S2	These adjustments would be made in the same period we determined the change in the valuation allowance was needed.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P170_S3	This would cause our income tax expense, effective tax rate, and net income to fluctuate.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S0	We assess uncertain tax positions in accordance with FASB ASC 740 , Income Taxes.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S1	We use judgment to identify, recognize, and measure the amounts to be recorded in the financial statements related to tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S2	We recognize liabilities to represent our potential future obligations to taxing authorities for the benefits taken in our tax returns.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S3	We adjust these liabilities, including any impact of the related interest and penalties, in light of changing facts and circumstances such as the progress of a tax audit.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S4	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter for which we have established a reserve is audited and finally resolved.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P171_S5	The number of years with open tax audits varies depending on the tax jurisdiction.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P172_S0	We use judgment to classify unrecognized tax benefits as either current or noncurrent liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P172_S1	Settlement of any particular issue would usually require the use of cash.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P173_S0	We generally classify liabilities associated with unrecognized tax benefits as noncurrent liabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P173_S1	It typically takes several years between our initial tax return filing and the final resolution of any uncertain tax positions with the tax authority.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P173_S2	We recognize favorable resolutions of tax matters for which we have previously established reserves as a reduction to our income tax expense when the amounts involved become known.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P174_S0	Assessing the future tax consequences of events that have been recognized in our Consolidated Financial Statements or tax returns requires judgment.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P174_S1	Variations in the actual outcome of these future tax consequences could materially impact our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P175_S0	We are subject to various claims and contingencies related to legal proceedings and investigations, which we describe in Note 15 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P175_S1	These legal proceedings involve inherent uncertainties including, but not limited to, court rulings, negotiations between affected parties, and government actions.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P175_S2	Assessing the probability of loss for such contingencies and determining how to accrue the appropriate liabilities requires judgment.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P175_S3	If actual results differ from our assessments, our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows would be affected.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S0	In March 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-05, Foreign Currency Matters (Topic 830): Parent's Accounting for the Cumulative Translation Adjustment upon Derecognition of Certain Subsidiaries or Groups of Assets within a Foreign Entity or an Investment in a Foreign Entity.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S1	ASU No. 2013-05 specifies that when a reporting entity (parent) ceases to have a controlling financial interest in a subsidiary or group of assets that is a business within a foreign entity, the parent is required to apply the guidance in Subtopic 830-30 to release any related cumulative translation adjustment into net income.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S2	Accordingly, the cumulative translation adjustment should be released into net income only if the sale or transfer results in the complete or substantially complete liquidation of the foreign entity in which the subsidiary or group of assets had resided.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S3	Additionally, the amendments in this update clarify that the sale of an investment in a foreign entity includes both (1) events that result in the loss of a controlling financial interest in a foreign entity and (2) events that results in an acquirer obtaining control of an acquiree in which it held an equity interest immediately before the acquisition date (sometimes referred to as a step acquisition).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S4	The currency translation adjustment should be released into net income upon the occurrence of those events.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P176_S5	For Morningstar, ASU No. 2013-05 is effective prospectively for events occurring on or after January 1, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P177_S0	In July 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-11, Presentation of an Unrecognized Tax Benefit When a Net Operating Loss Carryforward, a Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists (a consensus of the FASB Emerging Issues Task Force).
1289419_14_ITEM7_P177_S1	This update requires an entity to present an unrecognized tax benefit as a reduction of a deferred tax asset for a net operating loss (NOL) carryforward, or similar tax loss or tax credit carryforward, rather than as a liability when (1) the uncertain tax position would reduce the NOL or other carryforward under the tax law of the applicable jurisdiction and (2) the entity intends to use the deferred tax asset for that purpose.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P177_S2	The update does not require new recurring disclosures.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P177_S3	For Morningstar, ASU No. 2013-11 is effective prospectively as of January 1, 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P178_S0	We do not expect the provisions of ASU No. 2013-05 and ASU No. 2013-11 to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P179_S0	The table below shows our known contractual obligations as of December 31, 2013 and the expected timing of cash payments related to these contractual obligations:
1289419_14_ITEM7_P180_S0	(1) The non-cancelable operating lease obligations are mainly for lease commitments for office space.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P181_S0	(2) Represents unrecognized tax benefits (including penalties and interest, less the impact of any associated tax benefits) recorded in accordance with FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes .
1289419_14_ITEM7_P181_S1	The amount included in the table represents items that may be resolved through settlement of tax audits or for which the statutes of limitations are expected to lapse during 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM7_P181_S2	The table excludes $6.0 million of unrecognized tax benefits, included as a long-term liability in our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2013 , for which we cannot make a reasonably reliable estimate of the period of payment.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our investment portfolio is actively managed and may suffer losses from fluctuating interest rates, market prices, or adverse security selection.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We invest our investment portfolio mainly in high-quality fixed-income securities.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	As of December 31, 2013 , our cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance was $298.6 million.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Based on our estimates, a 100 basis-point change in interest rates would change the fair value of our investment portfolio by approximately $0.5 million.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	As our non-U.S. revenue increases as a percentage of our consolidated revenue, fluctuations in foreign currencies present a greater potential risk.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Our operations are subject to currency risk related to the British pound, the euro, and the Australian and Canadian dollars, among other currencies.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P1_S2	To date, we have not engaged in currency hedging, and we do not currently have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P1_S3	Our results could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar.
1289419_14_ITEM7A_P1_S4	In addition, because we use the local currency of our subsidiaries as the functional currency, we are affected by the translation of foreign currencies into U.S. dollars.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company's) as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P0_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P0_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_14_ITEM8_P0_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P1_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P1_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2013, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P1_S4	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Morningstar Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report dated February 28, 2014 expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.: We have audited Morningstar Inc. s (the Company) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S1	Morningstar, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P2_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S4	In our opinion, Morningstar, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1289419_14_ITEM8_P3_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2013, and our report dated February 28, 2014 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	Morningstar, Inc. and its subsidiaries (Morningstar, we, our), is a provider of independent investment research to investors around the world.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for individual investors, financial advisors, asset managers, and retirement plan providers and sponsors.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P9_S2	We have operations in 27 countries.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	We conduct our business operations through wholly owned or majority-owned operating subsidiaries.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Morningstar, Inc. and our subsidiaries.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	The assets, liabilities, and results of operations of subsidiaries in which we have a controlling interest have been consolidated.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P10_S3	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	We account and report the noncontrolling (minority) interest in our Consolidated Financial Statements in accordance with FASB ASC 810, Consolidation .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	A noncontrolling interest is the portion of equity (net assets) in a subsidiary not attributable, directly or indirectly, to the parent company.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	We report the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Balance Sheet within equity separate from the shareholders' equity attributable to Morningstar, Inc.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P12_S2	In addition, we present the net income (loss) and comprehensive income (loss) attributable to Morningstar, Inc.'s shareholders and the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Statements of Income, Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income, and Consolidated Statements of Equity.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	We account for investments in entities in which we exercise significant influence, but do not control, using the equity method.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	As part of our investment management operations, we manage certain funds outside of the United States that are considered variable interest entities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	For the majority of these variable interest entities, we do not have a variable interest in them.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P14_S2	In cases where we do have a variable interest, we are not the primary beneficiary.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P14_S3	Accordingly, we do not consolidate any of these variable interest entities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	In accordance with ASU No. 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income, we present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income (OCI) in two separate but consecutive statements, our Consolidated Statements of Income and separately, our Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P15_S1	In addition, effective January 1, 2013, we adopted FASB ASU No. 2013-2, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220) .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P15_S2	We show the effects of items reclassified out of each component of accumulated other comprehensive income to net income on the face of the financial statement where net income is presented.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses during the reporting period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P16_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	Certain amounts reported in previous years have been reclassified to conform to the 2013 presentation.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	We now include development expense in the cost of revenue category, which we previously referred to as cost of goods sold.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	We previously reported development expense as a separate operating expense category.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P18_S2	We have reclassified development expense to include it in cost of revenue for all periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	Separately, as a result of our recent reorganization (including new positions created, changes in focus for some existing roles, and the refinement of employee cost categorizations as we moved to a more centralized structure), approximately 180 net positions shifted from the general and administrative and sales and marketing categories to cost of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	For 2013 as compared with both 2012 and 2011, changes related to our more centralized organizational structure added approximately $14 million of compensation expense to cost of revenue, and reduced the compensation expense in our sales and marketing and general and administrative expense categories by approximately $8 million and $6 million, respectively.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P19_S2	These changes did not affect our total operating expense or operating income for any of the periods presented.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash and investments with original maturities of three months or less.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P20_S1	We state them at cost, which approximates fair value.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P20_S2	We state at fair value the portion of our cash equivalents that are invested in money market funds, which are actively traded and have quoted market prices.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	We account for our investments in accordance with FASB ASC 320, Investments Debt and Equity Securities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P21_S1	We classify our investments into three categories: held-to-maturity, trading, and available-for-sale.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Held-to-maturity: We classify certain investments, primarily certificates of deposit, as held-to-maturity securities, based on our intent and ability to hold these securities to maturity.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	We record held-to-maturity investments at amortized cost in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	Trading: We classify certain other investments, primarily equity securities, as trading securities, primarily to satisfy the requirements of one of our wholly owned subsidiaries, which is a registered broker-dealer.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P23_S1	We include realized and unrealized gains and losses associated with these investments as a component of our operating income in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P23_S2	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	Available-for-sale: Investments not considered held-to-maturity or trading securities are classified as available-for-sale securities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	Available-for-sale securities primarily consist of fixed-income securities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P24_S2	We report unrealized gains and losses for available-for-sale securities as other comprehensive income (loss), net of related income taxes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P24_S3	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	We follow FASB ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	FASB ASC 820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	Under FASB ASC 820, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	The standard applies whenever other standards require (or permit) assets or liabilities to be measured at fair value.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	The standard does not expand the use of fair value in any new circumstances and does not require any new fair value measurements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Effective January 1, 2012, we adopted FASB ASU No. 2011-04, Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820): Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and IFRS .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	ASU No. 2011-04 clarifies existing fair value measurement and disclosure requirements, amends certain fair value measurement principles, and requires additional disclosures about fair value measurements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	The adoption of ASU No. 2011-04 did not have a material impact on our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	FASB ASC 820 uses a fair value hierarchy based on three broad levels of valuation inputs as described below:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	Level 1: Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the company has the ability to access.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	Level 2: Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	Level 3: Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	We provide additional information about our cash equivalents and investments that are subject to valuation under FASB ASC 820 in Note 5 in these Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	FASB ASC 825, Financial Instruments , permits entities the option to measure many financial instruments and certain other items at fair value with changes in fair value recognized in earnings each period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	FASB ASC 825 allows the fair value option to be elected on an instrument-by-instrument basis when the asset or liability is initially recognized or when there's an event that gives rise to a new basis of accounting for that instrument.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P34_S3	We do not apply this fair value option to any of our eligible assets.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	No single customer is large enough to pose a significant credit risk to our operations or financial condition.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012, and 2011, no single customer represented 5% or more of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	If receivables from our customers become delinquent, we begin a collections process.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	We maintain an allowance for doubtful accounts based on our estimate of the probable losses of accounts receivable.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	We state property and equipment at historical cost, net of accumulated depreciation.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful life of the asset, which ranges from three to seven years.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P37_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	Computer Software and Internal Product Development Costs.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	We capitalize certain costs in accordance with FASB ASC 350-40, Internal-Use Software , FASB ASC 350-50, Website Development Costs, and FASB ASC 985, Software .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	Internal product development costs mainly consist of employee costs for developing new web-based products and certain major enhancements of existing products.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P39_S1	We amortize these costs on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic life, which is generally three years.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P39_S2	Capitalized software development costs related to projects that have not been placed into service yet are included in our construction in progress balance.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	The table below summarizes our capitalized software development costs for the past three years:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	Over the past several years, we have acquired companies that complement our business operations.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	For each acquisition, we allocate the purchase price to the assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and goodwill.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S2	We follow FASB ASC 805, Business Combinations .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S3	We recognize and measure the fair value of the acquired operation as a whole, and the assets acquired and liabilities assumed at their full fair values as of the date control is obtained, regardless of the percentage ownership in the acquired operation or how the acquisition was achieved.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S4	We expense direct costs related to the business combination, such as advisory, accounting, legal, valuation, and other professional fees, as incurred.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P41_S5	We recognize restructuring costs, including severance and relocation for employees of the acquired entity, as post-combination expenses unless the target entity meets the criteria of FASB ASC 420, Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations on the acquisition date.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	As part of the purchase price allocation, we follow the requirements of FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P42_S1	This includes establishing deferred tax assets or liabilities reflecting the difference between the values assigned for financial statement purposes and values applicable for income tax purposes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P42_S2	In certain acquisitions, the goodwill resulting from the purchase price allocation may not be deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P42_S3	FASB ASC 740 prohibits recognition of a deferred tax asset or liability for temporary differences in goodwill if goodwill is not amortizable and deductible for tax purposes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	Changes in the carrying amount of our recorded goodwill are mainly the result of business acquisitions and divestitures.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P43_S1	In accordance with FASB ASC 350, Intangibles Goodwill and Other , we do not amortize goodwill; instead, goodwill is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	An impairment would occur if the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeded the fair value of that reporting unit.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P44_S1	We performed annual impairment reviews in the fourth quarter of 2013, 2012, and 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P44_S2	We did not record any significant impairment losses in 2013, 2012, and 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	We have no intangible assets with indefinite useful lives.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S2	In accordance with FASB ASC 360-10-35, Subsequent Measurement Impairment or Disposal of Long Lived Assets , we review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S3	If the value of future undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying amount of an asset group, we record an impairment loss based on the excess of the carrying amount over the fair value of the asset group.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S4	We recorded an impairment loss of approximately $800,000 in 2011.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S5	We did not record any impairment losses in 2013 or 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P45_S6	The impairment charge is included in our amortization expense on our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	We recognize revenue in accordance with SEC SAB Topic 13, Revenue Recognition , ASC 605-25, Revenue Recognition: Multiple Element Arrangements , and ASC 985-605, Software: Revenue Recognition .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	We recognize revenue when all of the following conditions are met:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	Delivery of our products and services is a prerequisite for recognition of revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	The collectibility of the fees is reasonably assured.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	We generate revenue through sales of Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation (including Morningstar Office), Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Equity Research, Premium Membership fees for Morningstar.com, our structured credit research and ratings offerings, and a variety of other investment-related products and services.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	We generally structure the revenue agreements for these offerings as licenses or subscriptions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	We recognize revenue from licenses and subscription sales ratably as we deliver the product or service and over the service obligation period defined by the terms of the customer contract.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P50_S3	For new-issue ratings and analysis for CMBS, we charge asset-based fees that are paid by the issuer on the rated balance of the transaction and recognize the revenue immediately upon issuance of the transaction.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	We also generate revenue from Internet advertising, primarily from impression-based contracts.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P51_S1	For advertisers who use our cost-per-impression pricing, we charge fees each time we display their ads on our site.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Our Investment Advisory business includes a broad range of services.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P52_S1	Pricing for consulting services is based on the scope of work and the level of service provided, and includes asset-based fees for work we perform that involves investment management or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P52_S2	In arrangements that involve asset-based fees, we generally invoice clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P52_S3	We recognize asset-based fees once the fees are fixed and determinable assuming all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	Our Retirement Solutions offerings help retirement plan participants plan and invest for retirement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	We offer these services both through retirement plan providers (typically third-party asset management companies that offer proprietary mutual funds) and directly to plan sponsors (employers that offer retirement plans to their employees).
1289419_14_ITEM8_P53_S2	For our Retirement Solutions offerings, we provide both a hosted solution as well as proprietary installed software advice solution.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P53_S3	Clients can integrate the installed customized software into their existing systems to help investors accumulate wealth, transition into retirement, and manage income during retirement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	The revenue arrangements for Retirement Solutions generally extend over multiple years.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	Our contracts may include one-time setup fees, implementation fees, technology licensing and maintenance fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	Upon customer acceptance, we recognize revenue ratably over the term of the agreement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P55_S1	We recognize asset-based fees and variable fees in excess of any minimum once the value is fixed and determinable.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	Some of our revenue arrangements with our customers combine multiple products and services.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P56_S1	These products and services may be provided at different points in time or over different time periods within the same arrangement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	We allocate fees to the separate deliverables based on the deliverables relative selling price, which is generally based on the price we charge when the same deliverable is sold separately.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	We record taxes imposed on revenue-producing transactions (such as sales, use, value-added, and some excise taxes) on a net basis; therefore, we exclude such taxes from revenue in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	Deferred revenue represents the portion of licenses or subscriptions billed or collected in advance of the service being provided, which we expect to recognize as revenue in future periods.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P59_S1	Certain arrangements may have cancellation or refund provisions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	If we make a refund, it typically reflects the amount collected from a customer for which we have not yet provided services.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P60_S1	The refund therefore results in a reduction of deferred revenue.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	Advertising costs include expenses incurred for various print and Internet ads, search engine fees, and direct mail campaigns.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P61_S1	We expense advertising costs as incurred.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P61_S2	The table below summarizes our advertising expense for the past three years:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	We account for our stock-based compensation expense in accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P62_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, and stock options.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P62_S2	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units and restricted stock on the date of grant based on the closing market price of Morningstar's common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P62_S3	For stock options granted in 2011, we estimated the fair value of our stock options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P62_S4	We amortize the fair values to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	We estimate expected forfeitures of all employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P63_S1	We determine forfeiture rates based on historical experience and adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience as needed.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	In certain of our operations, we offer employees a sabbatical leave.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P64_S1	Although the sabbatical policy varies by region, in general, Morningstar's full-time employees are eligible for six weeks of paid time off after four years of continuous service.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P64_S2	We account for our sabbatical liability in accordance with FASB ASC 710-10-25 , Compensated Absences .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P64_S3	We record a liability for employees' sabbatical benefits over the period employees earn the right for sabbatical leave which is included in Accrued Compensation in our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	We record deferred income taxes for the temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities for financial statement purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes in accordance with FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P65_S1	FASB ASC 740 prescribes the minimum recognition threshold a tax position is required to meet before being recognized in the financial statements, and also provides guidance on derecognition, measurement, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, and disclosure for uncertain tax positions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P66_S0	We recognize interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of income tax expense in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P66_S1	We classify liabilities related to unrecognized tax benefits as either current or long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheet, depending on when we expect to make payment.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	We compute and present income per share in accordance with FASB ASC 260, Earnings Per Share .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	The difference between weighted average shares outstanding and diluted shares outstanding primarily reflects the dilutive effect associated with our stock-based compensation plans.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	We further compute income per share in accordance with FASB ASC 260-10-45-59A, Participating Securities and the Two Class Method .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P70_S0	Under the two-class method, we allocate earnings between common stock and participating securities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P70_S1	The two-class method includes an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for each class of common stock according to dividends declared and undistributed earnings for the period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P70_S2	For purposes of calculating earnings per share, we reduce our reported net earnings by the amount allocated to participating securities to arrive at the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P71_S0	ASC 260-10-45-59A requires the dilutive effect of participating securities to be calculated using the more dilutive of the treasury stock or the two-class method.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P71_S1	We have determined the two-class method to be the more dilutive.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P71_S2	As such, we adjusted the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders in the basic earnings per share calculation for the reallocation of undistributed earnings to participating securities to calculate diluted earnings per share.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	We translate the financial statements of non-U.S. subsidiaries to U.S. dollars using the period-end exchange rate for assets and liabilities and an average exchange rate for revenue and expense.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P72_S1	We use the local currency as the functional currency for all of our non-U.S. subsidiaries.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P72_S2	We record translation adjustments for non-U.S. subsidiaries as a component of Other comprehensive income (loss) in our Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P72_S3	We include exchange gains and losses arising from transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency in Other income (expense), net in our Consolidated Statements of Income.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	The following table shows the number of weighted average stock options, restricted stock units, and restricted stock excluded from our calculation of diluted earnings per share from both continuing operations and net earnings because their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	These stock options and restricted stock units could be included in the calculation in the future.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	In the third quarter of 2013, we revised our segment structure to reflect our shift to a more centralized organizational structure.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P76_S1	We now report our results in a single reportable segment, which reflects how our chief operating decision maker allocates resources and evaluates our financial results.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P76_S2	We have revised our historical financial results to reflect this change.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P77_S0	Because we have a single reportable segment, all required financial segment information can be found directly in the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	The accounting policies for our reportable segment are the same as those described in Note 2 .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	Summary of Significant Accounting Policies .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P79_S1	We evaluate the performance of our reporting segment based on revenue and operating income.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	We derive revenue from two product groups.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P81_S0	The investment information product group includes all of our data, software, and research products and services.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P81_S1	These products are typically sold through subscriptions or license agreements.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P93_S0	The fair value of our assets subject to fair value measurements and that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis using the fair value hierarchy and the necessary disclosures under FASB ASC 820, Fair Value Measurement , are as follows:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P94_S0	Level 1: Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that we have the ability to access.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P95_S0	Level 2: Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P95_S1	Level 3: Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P96_S0	Based on our analysis of the nature and risks of our investments in equity securities and mutual funds, we have determined that presenting these investment categories each in the aggregate is appropriate.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P97_S0	There were no transfers between levels one and two during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P98_S0	We measure the fair value of money market funds, equity securities, and ETFs based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P98_S1	All other financial instruments were valued either based on recent trades of securities in inactive markets or based on quoted market prices of similar instruments and other significant inputs derived from observable market data.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P99_S0	We did not hold any securities categorized as Level 3 as of December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P100_S0	In May 2013, we acquired an additional 76% interest in Morningstar Sweden AB (Morningstar Sweden), increasing our ownership to 100% from 24% .
1289419_14_ITEM8_P101_S0	Morningstar s main offerings in Sweden include Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Data, Integrated Web Tools, and Morningstar.se, a website for individual investors that provides fund and ETF data, portfolio tools, and market analysis.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P101_S1	We began consolidating the financial results of this acquisition in our Consolidated Financial Statements on May 2, 2013.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P102_S0	Morningstar Sweden's total estimated fair value of $18,513,000 included $14,554,000 in cash paid to acquire the remaining 76% interest in Morningstar Sweden and $3,959,000 related to the 24% of Morningstar Sweden we previously held.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P102_S1	We determined the fair value of the previously held 24% investment independent of the acquired controlling interest by applying a minority interest discount based on analysis of comparable transactions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P102_S2	Accordingly, we recorded a non-cash holding gain of $3,635,000 , which is classified as "Holding gain upon acquisition of additional ownership of equity-method investments" in our Consolidated Statement of Income for the year ended December 31, 2013.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P105_S0	We recognized a deferred tax liability of $2,272,000 mainly because the amortization expense related to certain intangible assets is not deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P106_S0	Goodwill of $8,911,000 represents the premium over the fair value of the net tangible and intangible assets acquired with this acquisition.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P106_S1	We paid this premium for a number of reasons, including the opportunity to offer Morningstar's full suite of products and services to investors in Sweden and further leverage Morningstar's global reach, investment databases, and technology expertise.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P116_S0	In October 2012, we sold Morningstar Investor Relations Services to UK-based Investis, a leading specialist in digital corporate communications for public companies.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P143_S0	In accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , we estimate forfeitures of employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P143_S1	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense during the third quarter to reflect those awards that ultimately vested and update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P144_S0	Restricted stock units represent the right to receive a share of Morningstar common stock when that unit vests.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P144_S1	Restricted stock units granted to employees generally vest ratably over a four-year period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P144_S2	Restricted stock units granted to non-employee directors vest ratably over a three-year period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P144_S3	For restricted stock units granted through December 31, 2008, employees could elect to defer receipt of the Morningstar common stock issued upon vesting of the restricted stock unit.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P145_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the closing market price of the underlying common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P145_S1	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P146_S0	The following table summarizes restricted stock unit activity during the past three years:
1289419_14_ITEM8_P147_S0	In conjunction with the Realpoint acquisition in May 2010, we issued 199,174 shares of restricted stock to the selling employee-shareholders under the 2004 Stock Incentive Plan.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P147_S1	The restricted stock vests ratably over a five-year period from the acquisition date and may be subject to forfeiture if the holder terminates his or her employment during the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P148_S0	Because of the terms of the restricted share agreements prepared in conjunction with the Realpoint acquisition, we account for the grant of restricted shares as stock-based compensation expense and not as part of the acquisition consideration.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P149_S0	We measured the fair value of the restricted stock on the date of grant based on the closing market price of our common stock on the day prior to the grant.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P149_S1	We amortize the fair value of $9,363,000 to stock-based compensation expense over the vesting period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P149_S2	The stock-based compensation expense recorded in 2012 and 2011 includes approximately $3,238,000 and $396,000 , respectively, of expense recognized upon the accelerated vesting of restricted stock.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P149_S3	We have assumed that all of the remaining restricted stock will ultimately vest, and therefore we have not incorporated a forfeiture rate for purposes of determining the stock-based compensation expense.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P150_S0	Stock options granted to employees vest ratably over a four-year period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P150_S1	Grants to our non-employee directors vest ratably over a three-year period.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P150_S2	All grants expire 10 years after the date of grant.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P151_S0	Almost all of the outstanding options granted under the 2004 Stock Incentive Plan have a premium price feature in which the exercise price increases over the term of the option at a rate equal to the 10-year Treasury bond yield as of the date of grant.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P151_S1	Options granted under the 2011 Plan have an exercise price equal to the fair market value on the grant date.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P157_S1	Excess tax benefits correspond to the portion of the tax deduction taken on our income tax return that exceeds the amount of tax benefit related to the compensation cost recognized in our Statement of Income.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P174_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P174_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $8,759,000 of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of these NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P175_S0	We conduct business globally and as a result, we file income tax returns in U.S. federal, state, local, and foreign jurisdictions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P175_S1	In the normal course of business we are subject to examination by tax authorities throughout the world.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P175_S2	The open tax years for our U.S. Federal tax returns and most state tax returns include the years 2008 to the present.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P175_S3	In non-U.S. jurisdictions, the statute of limitations generally extends to years prior to 2005.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P176_S0	We are currently under audit by federal, state and local tax authorities in the United States as well as tax authorities in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P176_S1	It is likely that the examination phase of some of these U.S. federal, state, local, and non-U.S. audits will conclude in 2014.
1289419_14_ITEM8_P177_S0	It is not possible to estimate the effect of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P178_S1	These amounts include interest and penalties, less any associated tax benefits.

1289419_14_ITEM8_P181_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , we had $12,958,000 of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $10,557,000 , if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $9,262,000 .
