1289419_16_ITEM1_P158_S1	Before taking on his current role in January 2014, he was head of equity and credit research since 2009 and took on additional responsibility for equity data in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P158_S2	He holds a bachelor s degree in economics from The University of Chicago, where he graduated as a member of Phi Beta Kappa.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P158_S3	He also holds the CFA designation.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P159_S0	Daniel E. Needham Daniel Needham is president and chief investment officer (CIO) of Morningstar Investment Management and is responsible for building world-class investment management solutions based on our proprietary research.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P159_S1	Before taking on his current role in February 2015, he served as CIO for Morningstar Investment Management, and was previously managing director and CIO for Morningstar Investment Management s Asia-Pacific Operations.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P160_S0	He joined our company when Morningstar acquired Intech Pty Ltd (now Ibbotson Associates Australia) in 2009, where he served as chief investment officer.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P160_S1	Before joining Intech in 2002, Daniel worked for Zurich Financial Services in Sydney.

1289419_16_ITEM1_P160_S3	He also holds the CFA designation.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P161_S0	Rob Pinkerton is our chief marketing officer and is responsible for overseeing our global marketing organization and corporate communications.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P161_S1	He joined Morningstar through our June 2014 acquisition of HelloWallet, where he served as chief marketing officer.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P161_S2	Before joining HelloWallet in 2012, Rob was a senior director for Adobe Systems, a computer software company, beginning in 2007.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P161_S3	He previously served in executive marketing and product roles with LexisNexis and Siebel Systems (which was acquired by Oracle).
1289419_16_ITEM1_P162_S0	He holds a bachelor s degree in economics, political science, and history from the University of Richmond, a juris doctor degree from the University of Baltimore School of Law, and a master s degree in business administration with concentrations in information technology management, marketing, and strategy from Carnegie Mellon University.

1289419_16_ITEM1_P165_S0	James holds a bachelor s degree in Russian language and literature from Haverford College and a master s degree in business administration from Harvard University.

1289419_16_ITEM1_P167_S0	David holds a bachelor's degree in industrial design from The Ohio State University and a master's degree in fine arts from the Yale University School of Art.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P168_S0	We were incorporated in Illinois on May 16, 1984.

1289419_16_ITEM1_P169_S0	We maintain a website at http://corporate.morningstar.com .
1289419_16_ITEM1_P169_S1	Our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to any of these documents are available free of charge on this site as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports are filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P169_S2	We also post quarterly press releases on our financial results and other documents containing additional information related to our company on this site.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P169_S3	We provide this website and the information contained in or connected to it for informational purposes only.
1289419_16_ITEM1_P169_S4	That information is not part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the other information included in this Form 10-K when deciding whether to invest in our common stock or otherwise evaluating our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks materialize, our business, financial condition, or operating results could suffer.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P0_S2	In this case, the trading price of our common stock could decline, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our investment management operations may subject us to liability for any losses that result from a breach of our fiduciary duties.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Two of our subsidiaries, Morningstar Investment Management LLC and Morningstar Investment Services LLC, are registered as investment advisors with the SEC under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, as amended.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P1_S2	As registered investment advisors, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Advisers Act.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P1_S3	These requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, and standards of care, as well as general anti-fraud prohibitions.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	As registered investment advisors, both subsidiaries are subject to on-site examination by the SEC.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	In addition, because these subsidiaries provide investment advisory services to retirement plans and their participants, they may be acting as fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	As fiduciaries under ERISA, they have obligations to act in the best interest of their clients.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	They also have duties of loyalty and prudence, as well as duties to diversify investments and to follow plan documents to comply with the applicable portions of ERISA.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our subsidiaries outside the United States that have investment advisory operations are subject to similar requirements.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We may face liabilities for actual or claimed breaches of our fiduciary duties, particularly in areas where we provide retirement advice and managed retirement accounts.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In some of our retirement contracts, we act as an ERISA fiduciary by, for example, selecting and monitoring a broad range of diversified plan options.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We also provide a managed account service for retirement plan participants who elect to have their accounts managed by our programs.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P6_S3	As of December 31, 2015, we had $40.3 billion in assets under management in our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We rely on automated investment technology for our retirement advice and managed retirement accounts services.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Wealth Forecasting Engine is our core advice and managed accounts engine that determines appropriate asset allocations for retirement plan participants and assigns individuals to portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	We also rely on automated portfolio construction tools.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Problems could arise if these programs assigned retirement plan participants to the wrong portfolios, particularly if we failed to detect program errors over an extended period.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Clients may take legal action against us for an actual or claimed breach of a fiduciary duty.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S4	If we make an error, we may be subject to potentially large liabilities for make-whole payments and/or litigation.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P8_S5	We cannot quantify the potential size of these liabilities with any level of precision.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	In addition, we may face other legal liabilities based on the quality and outcome of our investment advisory recommendations, even in the absence of an actual or claimed breach of fiduciary duty, or based on our investment management fees and expenses.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P9_S1	In total, we provided investment advisory and management services on approximately $180 billion in assets as of December 31, 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P9_S2	We could face substantial liabilities related to our work on these assets.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Failing to maintain and protect our brand, independence, and reputation may harm our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Our reputation and business may also be harmed by allegations made about possible conflicts of interest.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We believe independence is at the core of our business, and our reputation is our greatest corporate asset.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	We depend to a large extent on our reputation for integrity and high-caliber products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Any failure to uphold our high ethical standards and ensure that our customers have a consistently positive experience with us could damage our reputation as an objective, honest, and credible source for investment research and information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Allegations of improper conduct, whether the ultimate outcome is favorable or unfavorable to us, as well as any negative publicity or media reports about Morningstar, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation and damage our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We offer products and services to institutional clients, which include banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies, mutual fund companies, media outlets, and retirement plan providers and sponsors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Our institutional clients generate a significant portion of our overall revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P12_S2	We provide ratings, analyst research, and investment recommendations on mutual funds and other investment products offered and securities issued by our institutional clients.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P12_S3	We also provide investment advisory and investment management services.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P12_S4	In some cases, we make investment recommendations (such as Select Lists) within the framework of client constraints.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	While we don t charge asset management firms for their products to be rated, we do charge licensing fees for the use of our ratings.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We also receive payments from issuers for our new-issue ratings on commercial mortgage-backed securities.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	These payments may create the perception that our ratings, research, and recommendations are not impartial.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	This perception may undermine the confidence of our customers and potential customers in our reputation as a provider of independent research.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Any such loss of confidence or damage to our reputation could hurt our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our reputation may also be harmed by factors outside of our control, such as news reports about our clients or adverse publicity about certain investment products.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Our reputation could also suffer if we fail to produce competitive performance in our investment management offerings.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Failing to differentiate our products and continuously create innovative, proprietary research tools may harm our competitive position and business results.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We attribute much of our company's success over the past 30 years to our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools, such as the Morningstar Rating, Morningstar Style Box, Ownership Zone, and Portfolio X-Ray.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P17_S1	More recently, we ve developed unique concepts and tools such as the Wealth Forecasting Engine, Gamma, and Total Wealth Approach.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P17_S2	We believe these innovations set us apart because most of our competitors focus on providing data or software rather than creating their own proprietary research frameworks.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P17_S3	We also believe our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools is at the core of what drives Morningstar s value for all of our customer groups.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	If we fail to continuously fuel our innovation engine and develop new tools to meet the needs of our customers, our competitive position and business results may suffer.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P18_S1	In addition, our reputation could be harmed if we re perceived as not moving quickly enough to meet the changing needs of investors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our competitive position and business results may also suffer if other companies are able to successfully introduce innovative, proprietary research tools that gain attention from our clients.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P19_S1	We believe lower technology costs and the growth of open software platforms have lowered the barriers to entry for new competitors, making it easier for new players to enter the market.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Smaller companies, including startup firms funded by private equity and venture capital, may be able to move more quickly to develop research and tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	If we fail to introduce innovative, proprietary research tools and frameworks, we may not generate enough interest from potential clients to win new business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P20_S1	We cannot guarantee that we will successfully develop new product features and tools that differentiate our product offerings from those of our competitors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Failing to respond to technological change, keep pace with new technology developments, or adopt a successful technology strategy may negatively affect our competitive position and business results.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We believe the technology landscape has been changing at an accelerating rate over the past several years.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P22_S1	Changes in technology are fundamentally changing the ways investors access data and content.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Examples include the shift from local network computing to cloud-based systems, the proliferation of wireless mobile devices, and rapid acceleration in the use of social media platforms.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	While some changes in technology may offer opportunities for Morningstar, we cannot guarantee that we will successfully adapt our product offerings to meet evolving customer needs.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	We believe our ability to develop innovative technology has historically given us a competitive advantage.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S2	As mentioned above, though, we believe lower technology costs and growth in open software platforms have lowered barriers to entry for new competitors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Our competitors may also be able to introduce new technology more rapidly than we are to meet changing market needs.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S4	If we fail to develop and implement new technology rapidly enough, we may sacrifice new business opportunities or renewals from existing customers.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S5	We may also incur additional operating expense if major software projects take longer than anticipated.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P23_S6	Our competitive position and business results may suffer if we fail to develop new technologies to meet client demands, if our execution speed is too slow, or if we adopt a technology strategy that doesn't align with changes in the market.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We could face liability related to our storage of personal information about individuals as well as portfolio and account-level information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Customers routinely enter personal investment and financial information, including portfolio holdings, account numbers, and credit card information, on our websites.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S1	In addition, we handle increasing amounts of personally identifiable information in areas such as Morningstar Retirement Manager, HelloWallet, Morningstar Managed Portfolios, ByAllAccounts, Morningstar Office, Enterprise Data Management, and Morningstar.com.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S2	In 2014, we acquired HelloWallet, which provides personalized financial guidance to individuals through their employer benefit plans.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S3	Through HelloWallet's website and mobile applications, employees enter their goals and priorities and add their financial information, including income, bank accounts, credit cards, retirement plans, insurance, and investments.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S4	We also acquired ByAllAccounts, which uses technology to collect, consolidate, and transform financial account data and deliver it to any platform.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P25_S5	Both HelloWallet and ByAllAccounts handle a large volume of personally identifiable information as part of their normal business operations.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Any failure to safeguard this information could damage our reputation and business results.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We must continuously invest in systems, processes, and controls to guard against the risk of improper access to this information, which could be disclosed through employee errors, other inadvertent release, failure to restrict access, or failure to properly purge and protect data.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We may suffer malicious attacks by individuals or groups seeking to penetrate our network and databases to gain access to personal data.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P27_S1	These attacks have become increasingly frequent, sophisticated, and difficult to detect.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Contractual commitments to customers as well as laws and industry regulations related to data protection, system availability, and privacy require us to safeguard critical data.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P28_S1	We are also required to take appropriate steps to safeguard credit card numbers, Social Security numbers, and other information about individuals or their accounts.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Given the growing concern over data privacy and identity theft, we have been and expect to continue to be subject to increased scrutiny by clients and regulators.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P28_S3	We could be subject to liability if we were to inappropriately disclose any user's personal information or if third parties were able to penetrate our network security or otherwise gain access to any user's name, address, Social Security number, account numbers, portfolio holdings, credit card information, or other personal information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Compliance failures, regulatory action, or changes in laws applicable to our investment advisory or credit rating operations could adversely affect our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Our investment management operations are a growing part of our overall business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S1	The securities laws and other laws that govern our investment advisory activities are complex.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S2	The activities of our investment advisory operations are subject to provisions of the Advisers Act and ERISA.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S3	In addition, Morningstar Investment Services is a broker-dealer registered under the Exchange Act and is subject to the rules of FINRA.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S4	We also provide investment advisory services in other areas around the world, and our operations are subject to additional regulations in markets outside the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P30_S5	If we fail to comply with securities laws and other regulatory requirements, we may be subject to fines or other events that could have a negative effect on our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Over the past several years, we have also made significant investments in our credit rating business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Our Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC subsidiary is an NRSRO that specializes in structured finance.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P31_S2	As an NRSRO, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to various requirements and regulations under the Exchange Act relating to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, governance, and conflicts of interest.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P32_S0	As part of its NRSRO registration, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to annual examination by the SEC.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We also publish credit ratings and research on corporate debt issuers and have completed a preliminary application to expand our NRSRO license to include ratings for corporate credits and financial institutions.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Credit rating and research providers have been under increasing regulatory scrutiny.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The laws, rules, and regulations applicable to our business may change in the future, and we may not be able to comply with these changes.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P35_S1	In addition, the broad scope of our business operations makes it more difficult to monitor areas that may be subject to regulatory and compliance risk.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P35_S2	If we fail to comply with any applicable law, rule, or regulation, we could be fined, sanctioned, or barred from providing investment advisory or credit rating services in the future, which could adversely affect our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P36_S0	An outage of our database, technology-based products and services, or network facilities could result in reduced revenue and the loss of customers.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The success of our business depends upon our ability to deliver time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P37_S1	We rely on our computer equipment, database storage facilities, and other network equipment, much of which is geographically concentrated in our Chicago headquarters and other backup locations in the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P37_S2	We also have extensive information systems outside the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P37_S3	Our mission-critical databases and networks are increasingly complex and interdependent, which increases the risk of failure.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P37_S4	Problems in our network systems may lead to cascading effects involving product downtime, overloading of third-party data centers, and other issues that may affect our clients.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Many of our client contracts contain service-level agreements that require us to meet certain obligations for delivering time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P38_S1	We may not be able to meet these obligations in the event of failure or downtime in our information systems.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Our operations and those of our suppliers and customers are vulnerable to interruption by fire, earthquake, power loss, telecommunications failure, terrorist attacks, wars, computer viruses, and other events beyond our control.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Our database and network facilities may also be vulnerable to external attacks that misappropriate our data, corrupt our databases, or limit access to our information systems.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P39_S2	To defend against these threats, we implement a series of controls focusing on both prevention and detection, including firewalls, intrusion detection systems, automated scanning and testing, server hardening, anti-virus software, and patch management.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P39_S3	We make significant investments in servers, storage, and other network infrastructure to prevent incidents of network failure and downtime, but we cannot guarantee that these efforts will work as planned.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Most of our products and services depend heavily on our electronic delivery systems and the Internet.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Our ability to deliver information using the Internet may be impaired because of infrastructure failures, service outages at third-party Internet providers, malicious attacks, or other factors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P40_S2	If disruptions, failures, or slowdowns of our electronic delivery systems or the Internet occur, our ability to distribute our products and services effectively and to serve our customers may be impaired.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We maintain off-site back-up facilities for our data, but we cannot guarantee that these facilities will operate as expected during an interruption that affects our headquarters.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P41_S1	There may be single points of failure that affect our core databases, data transfer interfaces, or storage area networks.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P41_S2	We may not be able to fully recover data or information lost during a database or network facility outage.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P41_S3	Any losses, service disruption, or damages incurred by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The concentration of data and development work carried out at our offshore facilities may have a negative effect on our business operations, products, and services.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We now have approximately 850 employees working in our data and technology development center in Shenzhen, China, or about one-fifth of our total workforce.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P43_S1	We rely on these employees to maintain and update our mutual fund database and work on other projects.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Because China has a restrictive government under centralized control, our operations are subject to political and regulatory risk, which is inherently unpredictable.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Recent news reports have heightened concerns about problems related to data privacy, security, and protection of intellectual property rights in China, as well.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P45_S0	The concentration of development and data work carried out at this facility also involves operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P45_S1	While we have short-term backup plans in place, it would be difficult for us to maintain and update our mutual fund database if we were unable to access our Shenzhen operations for an extended period of time.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P45_S2	Any difficulties that we face in continuing to operate our development center in China may harm our business and have a negative impact on the products and services we provide.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P46_S0	We have approximately 500 employees who work at our data collection facility in Mumbai, India, which may also be subject to regulatory and political risk (including potential terrorist acts).
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Like the Shenzhen operation, these facilities also involve operational risks for our network infrastructure.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our results could suffer if the mutual fund industry continues to experience slower growth, or if actively managed equity funds continue to attract less investor attention.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We generate a significant portion of our revenue from products and services related to mutual funds, and part of our growth since 1984 can be attributed to favorable industry trends.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P49_S0	The mutual fund industry has experienced substantial growth over the past 30 to 40 years, but suffered along with the market downturn in 2008 and early 2009.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Since then, fund assets have increased, but at a slower rate than in previous years.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P50_S0	A significant portion of our fund research has historically focused on equity-related funds.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P50_S1	In addition, we are best-known for our data and analyst research on actively managed equity funds.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Over the past 15 years, passively managed index funds have seen greater investor interest, and this trend has been more dramatic in recent years.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P51_S1	In 2015, actively managed mutual funds suffered more than $200 billion of net outflows, compared with net inflows of more than $400 billion for passively managed funds.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P51_S2	Overall, we estimate that passively managed portfolios now account for nearly one-third of combined mutual fund and ETF assets.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Continued downturns or volatility in the financial markets, increased investor interest in other investment vehicles, or a lack of investor confidence could continue to reduce investor interest and investment activity.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P52_S1	In addition, a continued lessening of investor interest in actively managed equity funds could decrease demand for our products, including our software, data, and analyst research.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Downturns in the financial sector, global financial markets, and global economy may hurt our results, resulting in lower revenue from asset-based fees, transaction-based revenue, or other parts of our business.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Our business results are partly driven by factors outside of our control, including general economic and financial market trends.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P54_S1	Any unfavorable changes in the environment we operate in could cause a corresponding negative effect on our business results.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P54_S2	As a result, we may experience lower revenue, operating income, and other financial results in the event of a market downturn.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Many of our customers are asset management firms and other financial services companies, which are also subject to external trends and changes.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S1	For example, the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009 led to spending cutbacks among many of the companies we sell to.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S2	Some institutional clients have implemented additional review processes for new contracts or started providing certain services, such as investment management, in-house rather than hiring outside service providers.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S3	Some institutional clients have also reduced the scope of their operations.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S4	For example, several large insurers withdrew from the variable annuity market in recent years, while others curtailed their new sales efforts.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P55_S5	This has had a negative effect on the services we provide to institutional clients that offer variable annuities.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Many companies in the financial services industry have also been subject to increasing government regulation and pressure to reduce fees, which may increase their operating costs and cause them to reduce spending.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P57_S0	In addition, our revenue from asset-based fees may be adversely affected by market declines as well as the level of cash outflows from portfolios that we help manage.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P58_S0	In 2015, revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 15% of our consolidated revenue and a greater percentage of our operating income.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P58_S1	The amount of revenue we earn from asset-based fees depends on the value of assets on which we provide advisory services, and the size of our asset base can increase or decrease along with trends in market performance.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P58_S2	The value of assets under advisement may show substantial declines during periods of significant market volatility.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P58_S3	Asset levels can also be affected if net inflows into the portfolios on which we provide investment advisory services drop or if these portfolios experience redemptions.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P58_S4	If the level of assets on which we provide investment advisory or investment management services goes down, we expect our fee-based revenue to show a corresponding decline.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Our business results may also be hurt by negative trends in Internet advertising sales, which made up about 4% of consolidated revenue in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P59_S1	Our structured credit rating business, which made up about 5% of consolidated revenue in 2015, is subject to volatility from trends in new issuance of commercial mortgage-backed securities and other structured credits.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P59_S2	If industry-wide issuance for commercial mortgage-backed securities declines, our revenue associated with this line of business may also go down.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P60_S0	Our future success depends on our ability to recruit, develop, and retain qualified employees.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P61_S0	We experience competition for analysts, technology experts, and other employees from other companies and organizations.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P61_S1	These organizations often have greater resources than we do and are often able to offer significantly more attractive compensation packages to potential employees.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P61_S2	Competition for these employees is intense, and we may not be able to retain our existing employees or be able to recruit and retain other highly qualified personnel in the future.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P62_S0	Our future success also depends on the continued service of our executive officers, including Joe Mansueto, our chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P62_S1	Joe is heavily involved in our day-to-day operations, business strategy, and overall company direction.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P62_S2	The loss of Joe or other executive officers could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P62_S3	We do not have employment agreements, non-compete agreements, or life insurance policies in place with any of our executive officers.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P62_S4	They may leave us and work for our competitors or start their own competing businesses.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P63_S0	Our operations outside of the United States involve additional challenges that we may not be able to meet.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Our operations outside of the United States generated $203.7 million in revenue in 2015, or about 26% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P64_S1	There are risks inherent in doing business outside the United States, including challenges in reaching new markets because of established competitors and limited brand recognition; difficulties in staffing, managing, and integrating non-U.S. operations; difficulties in coordinating and sharing information globally; differences in laws and policies from country to country; exposure to varying legal standards, including intellectual property protection laws; potential tax exposure related to transfer pricing and other issues; heightened risk of fraud and noncompliance; and currency exchange rates and exchange controls.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P64_S2	These risks could hamper our ability to expand around the world, which may hurt our financial performance and ability to grow.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P65_S0	We don't engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P65_S1	Our reported revenue could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar, although the impact on operating income may be offset by an opposing currency impact on locally based operating expense.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P66_S0	We could face liability for the information we publish, including information based on data we obtain from other parties.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P67_S0	We may be subject to claims for securities law violations, defamation (including libel and slander), negligence, or other claims relating to the information we publish, including our research and ratings on issuers of structured credits and corporate credits.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P67_S1	For example, investors may take legal action against us if they rely on published information that contains an error, or a company may claim that we have made a defamatory statement about it or its employees.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P67_S2	We could also be subject to claims based on the content that is accessible from our website through links to other websites.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P68_S0	We rely on a variety of outside parties as the original sources for the information we use in our published data.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P68_S1	These sources include securities exchanges, fund companies, hedge funds, transfer agents, and other data providers.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P68_S2	Accordingly, in addition to possible exposure for publishing incorrect information that results directly from our own errors, we could face liability based on inaccurate data provided to us by others.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P68_S3	Defending claims based on the information we publish could be expensive and time-consuming and could adversely impact our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P69_S0	Failure to protect our intellectual property rights could harm our brand and ability to compete effectively.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P70_S0	The steps we have taken to protect our intellectual property may not be adequate to safeguard our proprietary information.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P70_S1	Further, effective trademark, copyright, and trade secret protection may not be available in every country in which we offer our services.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P70_S2	Our continued ability to market one or more of our products under their current names could be adversely affected in those jurisdictions where another person registers or has a pre-existing registration on one or more of them.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P70_S3	Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property could harm our brand, devalue our proprietary content, and affect our ability to compete in the marketplace.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P71_S0	From time to time, we encounter jurisdictions in which one or more third parties have a pre-existing trademark registration in certain relevant international classes that may prevent us from registering our own marks in those jurisdictions.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P71_S1	Our continued ability to use the Morningstar name or logo, either on a stand-alone basis or in association with certain products or services, could be compromised in those jurisdictions because of these pre-existing registrations.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P71_S2	Similarly, from time to time, we encounter situations in certain jurisdictions where one or more third parties are already using the Morningstar name, either as part of a registered corporate name, a registered domain name or otherwise.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P71_S3	Our ability to effectively market certain products and/or services in those locations could be adversely affected by these pre-existing usages.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P72_S0	Control by a principal shareholder could adversely affect our other shareholders.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P73_S0	As of December 31, 2015, Joe Mansueto, our chairman and chief executive officer, owned approximately 56% of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P73_S1	As a result, he has the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to our shareholders for approval, including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P73_S2	He also has the ability to control our management and affairs.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P73_S3	This concentration of ownership may delay or prevent a change in control; impede a merger, consolidation, takeover, or other business combination involving Morningstar; discourage a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the company; or result in actions that may be opposed by other shareholders.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P74_S0	Fluctuations in our operating results may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S0	We believe our business has relatively large fixed costs and low variable costs, which magnify the impact of revenue fluctuations on our operating results.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S1	As a result, a decline in our revenue may lead to a larger decline in operating income.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S2	In addition, because we manage our business with a long-term perspective, we generally don t make significant adjustments to our strategy or cost structure in response to short-term factors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S3	As a result, our operating results may suffer in the short term.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S4	In addition, we do not provide earnings guidance or hold one-on-one meetings with institutional investors and research analysts.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S5	Because of this policy and limited analyst coverage on our stock, our stock price may be volatile.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P75_S6	If our operating results or other operating metrics fail to meet the expectations of outside research analysts and investors, the market price of our common stock may decline.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P76_S0	The future sale of shares of our common stock may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P77_S0	If our shareholders sell substantial amounts of our common stock, the market price of our common stock could fall.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P77_S1	A reduction in ownership by Joe Mansueto or any other large shareholder could cause the market price of our common stock to fall.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P77_S2	In addition, the average daily trading volume in our stock is relatively low.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P77_S3	The lack of trading activity in our stock may lead to greater fluctuations in our stock price.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P77_S4	Low trading volume may also make it difficult for shareholders to make transactions in a timely fashion.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Our shareholders may experience dilution in their ownership positions.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P79_S0	In the past, we granted stock options to employees as a significant part of their overall compensation package.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P79_S1	In 2006, we began granting restricted stock units to our employees and non-employee directors.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P79_S2	As of December 31, 2015, our employees and non-employee directors held options to acquire 52,096 shares of common stock, all of which were exercisable at a weighted average price of approximately $57.52 per share.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P79_S3	As of December 31, 2015, there were 587,450 restricted stock units outstanding, which have an average remaining vesting period of 31 months.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P80_S0	Generally speaking, the company issues a share of stock when a restricted stock unit vests.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P80_S1	To the extent that option holders exercise outstanding options to purchase common stock and we issue shares when restricted stock units vest, there will be further dilution.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P80_S2	Future grants of stock options or restricted stock units may also result in dilution.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P81_S0	We may raise additional funds through future sales of our common stock.
1289419_16_ITEM1A_P81_S1	Any such financing would result in additional dilution to our shareholders.
1289419_16_ITEM1B_P0_S0	We do not have any unresolved comments from the Staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding our periodic or current reports under the Exchange Act.
1289419_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we leased approximately 377,000 square feet of office space for our U.S. operations, primarily for our corporate headquarters located in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	We also lease approximately 375,000 square feet of office space in 26 other countries around the world, including 141,000 square feet in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_16_ITEM2_P0_S2	We believe that our existing and planned office facilities are adequate for our needs and that additional or substitute space is available to accommodate growth and expansion.
1289419_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	We are involved in legal proceedings and litigation that arise in the normal course of our business.
1289419_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	Although we may not be able to predict the outcome of a particular proceeding, we do not believe that the result of any of these matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.

1289419_16_ITEM5_P5_S0	Any determination to pay dividends in the future will be at the discretion of our board of directors and will be dependent upon our results of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions, restrictions imposed by applicable law, and other factors deemed relevant by the board of directors.
1289419_16_ITEM5_P5_S1	Future indebtedness and loan facilities could also prohibit or restrict our ability to pay dividends and make distributions to our shareholders.

1289419_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected historical financial data shown below should be read in conjunction with Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. We have derived our Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014, and 2013 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P0_S1	The Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2013, 2012, and 2011 were derived from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements that are not included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Operating income and free cash flow for 2014 included a $61.0 million litigation settlement expense and corresponding cash outflow.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	(2) Cash provided by (used for) investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the sale of investments, capital expenditures, purchases of equity and cost- method investments, and proceeds from the sale of businesses.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P2_S1	The level of investing activities can vary from period to period depending on the level of activity in these categories.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P2_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for investing activities.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	(3) Cash used for financing activities consists primarily of cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program and dividend payments.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P3_S1	These cash outflows are partially offset by proceeds from our revolving credit facility, stock option exercises, and excess tax benefits.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P3_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for financing activities.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P4_S0	(4) Free cash flow is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under SEC regulations.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P4_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P4_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P4_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required to be reported under GAAP, nor should this data be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P4_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P5_S0	(5) We frequently invoice or collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_16_ITEM6_P5_S1	These amounts are recorded as deferred revenue on our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The discussion included in this section, as well as other sections of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, contains forward-looking statements as that term is used in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	These statements are based on our current expectations about future events or future financial performance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	Forward-looking statements by their nature address matters that are, to different degrees, uncertain, and often contain words such as may, could, expect, intend, plan, seek, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, potential, or continue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P0_S3	These statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause the events we discuss not to occur or to differ significantly from what we expect.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P0_S4	For us, these risks and uncertainties include, among others:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	trends in the mutual fund industry, including the increasing popularity of passively managed investment vehicles.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	A more complete description of these risks and uncertainties can be found in Item 1A Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	If any of these risks and uncertainties materialize, our actual future results may vary significantly from what we expected.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	We do not undertake to update our forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	All dollar and percentage comparisons, which are often accompanied by words such as increase, decrease, grew, declined, was up, was down, was flat, or was similar refer to a comparison with the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our mission is to create great products that help investors reach their financial goals.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for financial advisors, asset managers, retirement plan providers and sponsors, and individual investors.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	Many of our products are sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P4_S3	As a result, we typically generate recurring revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	We generate revenue by selling a variety of investment-related products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	We sell many of our products and services, including Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Research, through license agreements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	Our license agreements typically range from one to three years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S3	We sell some of our other products, such as Premium Membership service on Morningstar.com, via subscriptions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S4	These subscriptions are mainly offered for a one-year term, although we offer terms ranging from one month to three years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S5	We also sell advertising on our websites throughout the world.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P5_S6	In our credit research and rating business, we generate transaction-based revenue for our ratings on new issues of commercial mortgage-backed securities and other structured credits.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	Our investment management business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves managing investments or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S4	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P6_S5	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	In our Workplace Solutions area, our contracts may include one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	We also offer plan sponsor advice and custom target-date consulting arrangements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	Fees for these services may be based on the level of assets under advisement.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	We do not disclose a fee range for our Investment Advisory services and Workplace Solutions businesses because our fee structures vary by client.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	In addition, we believe disclosing a fee range could be detrimental to our competitive position.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	We disclose changes in the services we provide or their associated fee structures (for example, a change from flat fees to asset-based fees) in our SEC filings to the extent that they are material to our consolidated financial results.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s account balance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	We invoice some of our clients and collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	We use some of this cash to fund our operations and invest in new product development.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and, at the end of 2015, totaled $152.0 million (of which $140.7 million was classified as a current liability with an additional $11.3 million included in other long-term liabilities).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P10_S3	At the end of 2014, the amount of deferred revenue was $146.0 million , all of which was classified as a current liability.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P10_S4	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill the service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	In recent years, our deferred revenue balance has increased at a more moderate rate, partly because we've been issuing more quarterly and monthly invoices versus up-front, annual invoices.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P11_S1	In addition, as we ve migrated Principia subscribers to Morningstar Advisor Workstation and other products that meet their needs, we have less subscription-based revenue contributing to the deferred revenue balance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Our business requires significant investments to create and maintain proprietary software, databases, and content.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	While the fixed costs of the investments we make in our business are relatively high, the variable cost of adding customers is relatively low, partly because our business focuses on Internet-based platforms and assets under management.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	At times, we may make investments in building our databases and content that cause weaker short-term operating results.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	During other periods, our profitability may improve because we're able to increase revenue without increasing our cost base at the same rate.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P12_S4	When revenue decreases, however, we may not be able to adjust our cost base at a corresponding rate.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	We classify our operating expense into separate categories for cost of revenue, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and depreciation and amortization, as described below.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	We include stock-based compensation expense, as appropriate, in each of these categories.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	This category includes compensation expense for employees who produce the products and services we deliver to our customers.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	For example, this category covers production teams and analysts who write investment research reports.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	It also includes compensation expense for programmers, designers, and other employees who develop new products and enhance existing products.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	In some cases, we capitalize the compensation costs associated with certain software development projects.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	This reduces the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	Cost of revenue also includes other expense such as third-party data purchases and data lines.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our sales teams, product managers, and other marketing professionals.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	We also include the cost of advertising, direct mail campaigns, and other marketing and promotion efforts in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our management team and other corporate functions, including employees in our compliance, finance, human resources, and legal departments.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	It also includes costs for corporate systems and facilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Our capital expenditures are mainly for information technology equipment, leasehold improvements, and capitalized software development costs.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful lives of the assets, which range from three to seven years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P18_S3	We amortize capitalized software development costs over their estimated economic life, which range from three to seven years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P18_S4	We also include amortization related to intangible assets, which is mainly driven by acquisitions, in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated economic useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	As of December 31, 2015, we had majority-owned operations in 26 countries outside of the United States and included their results of operations and financial condition in our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	We account for our minority-owned investment in Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK) using the equity method.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	When our analysts evaluate a stock, they focus on assessing the company's estimated intrinsic value, which is based on estimated future cash flows, discounted to their value in today's dollars.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P21_S1	Our approach to evaluating our own business works the same way.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	Our goal is to increase the intrinsic value of our business over time, which we believe is the best way to create value for our shareholders.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	We do not make public financial forecasts for our business because we want to avoid creating any incentives for our management team to make speculative statements about our financial results that could influence our stock price or take actions that help us meet short-term forecasts but may not build long-term shareholder value.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	We provide three specific measures that can help investors generate their own assessment of how our intrinsic value has changed over time:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	Revenue (including organic revenue); Operating income (loss); and Free cash flow, which we define as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Organic revenue and free cash flow are not measures of performance set forth under GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	We define organic revenue as consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	We present organic revenue because we believe it helps investors better compare our period-to-period results, and our management team uses this measure to evaluate the performance of our business.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	We present free cash flow as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required under GAAP and should not be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	To evaluate how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue, we calculate retention and renewal rates using two different methods.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	For subscription-based products, we track the number of subscriptions retained during the year.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	For products sold through contracts and licenses, we use the contract value method, which is based on tracking the dollar value of renewals compared with the total dollar value of contracts up for renewal during the period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	We include changes in the contract value in the renewal amount, unless the change specifically results from adding a new product that we can identify.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P29_S3	We also include variable-fee contracts in this calculation and use the previous quarter's actual revenue as the base rate for calculating the renewal percentage.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P29_S4	The renewal rate excludes setup and customization fees, migrations to other Morningstar products, and contract renewals that were pending as of January 31, 2016.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	We monitor developments in the economic and financial information industry on an ongoing basis.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	We use these insights to help inform our company strategy, product development plans, and marketing initiatives.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	After posting double-digit gains for each of the three previous years, the U.S. stock market finished 2015 barely in positive territory.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	Morningstar's U.S. Market Index, a broad market benchmark, ended the year with a 0.7% gain.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P31_S2	Morningstar s Global Markets ex-U.S. Index finished the year down 0.6%.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	With a less favorable market as a backdrop, the fund industry was relatively flat in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	Total U.S. mutual fund assets were down slightly to $15.7 trillion as of December 31, 2015, compared with $15.9 trillion as of December 31, 2014, based on data from the Investment Company Institute (ICI).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P32_S2	Based on Morningstar s analysis of fund flow trends, long-term mutual funds had aggregate net inflows of about $200 billion in 2015, down from about $460 billion in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Investors have also continued to favor passively managed index funds rather than actively managed portfolios a trend that continued accelerating in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	In 2015, actively managed mutual funds suffered more than $200 billion of net outflows, compared with net inflows of more than $400 billion for passively managed funds.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	ETFs continued to increase in popularity relative to traditional mutual funds.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	The U.S. ETF industry closed out 2015 with $2.1 trillion in assets under management based on ICI data, up from about $2.0 trillion as of December 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	Based on data from ComScore, aggregate monthly average page views to financial and investment sites were down about 7% in 2015, while the number of unique users decreased by about 12%.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	The number of pages viewed per visit was up about 5%, though, and time spent per visit increased by about 8%.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P35_S2	We believe these results indicate that while fewer investors visited financial and investment sites during 2015, the remaining users were more engaged.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P35_S3	Results for Morningstar.com generally showed similar trends, with the exception of monthly average page views.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P35_S4	Monthly average page views for Morningstar.com increased by approximately 25% in 2015 based on ComScore data, driven by a large increase in pages viewed per visit.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	Amid these trends, we believe online advertising spending by financial services companies was generally positive in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	A report published by eMarketer in September 2015 estimated that global online advertising spending would increase by about 18% across all industries in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P36_S2	We believe advertising spending in the financial services industry also increased versus 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	In addition to industry developments in 2015, there are several longer-term trends we consider relevant to our business, as outlined below.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	In the wake of the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, regulators have continued to implement new frameworks for financial services companies globally.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P38_S1	Many of these rules relate to financial advisor compensation, fees and expenses, investor disclosure, and the use of hedge funds and alternative investments.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	In the United Kingdom, for example, the Retail Distribution Review (RDR), which emphasizes increased regulation of advisory fees, higher professional standards for financial advisors, and "whole of market" investment solutions, became effective in January 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	Advisors are now required to give clients a choice of all investment vehicles (including funds, ETFs, and other products) and demonstrate that they consider different investment options without bias.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P39_S2	Financial advisors are also required to fully disclose and have clients agree on fees for advice and charge separately for any funds or investments.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P39_S3	The RDR also restricted the use of commission payments for products sold to individual investors, although UK regulators are reportedly considering changes to this restriction.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	In September 2015, the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) published a final draft of an updated version of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive, also known as MiFID II.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	The new regulatory framework is scheduled to go into effect in January 2017 and aims to ensure that secondary markets are fair, transparent, and safe.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	It also seeks to ensure that investors interests are safeguarded when being sold investment products.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	The main provisions include, among other things, limits on portfolio managers' use of third-party research, quality and organizational rules regarding the provision of advice, additional governance requirements for the manufacturing and distribution of financial instruments and structured deposits, requirements for firms to provide clients with details of all costs and charges related to their investments, and new rules for disclosing the cumulative effect of costs on investor returns.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	In Australia, the government has continued to implement the series of Future of Financial Advice reforms that began in July 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	Some of these reforms include requirements relating to annual fee disclosure and compensation structures for financial advisors.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	In response, we believe financial advisors have become more focused on client engagement to demonstrate the value of the services they provide.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	In December 2015, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority published a series of new reporting standards for superannuation funds (a type of pension plan for employees to use in saving for retirement) with additional reporting requirements regarding assets held.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	We've expanded our data collection and distribution services to help asset management firms and superannuation funds meet these standards.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	In the United States, the Department of Labor (DOL) has proposed a rule that would impose a fiduciary standard for financial advisors working with defined contribution plans and individual retirement accounts.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	The new standard would require them to act in the best interest of clients when making investment recommendations instead of the looser suitability standards currently in place.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	President Obama has endorsed the proposed rule for a fiduciary standard for financial advisors providing retirement advice.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	We believe the increased regulatory scrutiny of advisors could have a broad impact on the financial services sector, including a greater need for independent advice, tools, and solutions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	Overall, we believe the business environment for the financial services industry remains challenging.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	Asset management firms are facing increasing regulatory burdens, which are leading to higher costs and more cautious spending.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	Further, the historically low interest rate environment continues to put pressure on margins for some firms, most notably those in the variable annuity space.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P44_S3	As a result, we expect there will be further pressure on revenue from clients in this area.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	Beginning in the second half of 2015, the global financial markets began showing significantly higher levels of volatility, and equity market returns have generally turned negative.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P45_S1	For the year to date through February 25, 2016, Morningstar's U.S. Market Index was down 4.8%.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	The recent market downturn has significantly increased the level of uncertainty for individual investors, financial advisors, and asset management firms.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	In addition, new issuance volume for commercial mortgage-backed securities began declining in the second half of 2015 and has remained weak during the first two months of 2016.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P47_S0	A downturn in the financial markets directly impacts several of our businesses in an adverse fashion, including revenue from asset-based fees and Morningstar Credit Ratings.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P47_S1	It also may have other negative effects on our clients, including increased caution, longer sales cycles, and reduced spending.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	The tables below summarize our key product metrics and other supplemental data.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P49_S0	(1) Beginning in the second quarter of 2014, we changed our reporting to show the number of enterprise clients for Morningstar Advisor Workstation instead of individual licenses.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P49_S1	We believe this is a better way to capture underlying business trends because per-user pricing varies significantly depending on the scope of the license.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P49_S2	We also began disclosing the number of licenses for Morningstar Office as a separate line item.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P50_S0	(2) The asset totals include relationships for which we receive basis-point fees, including consulting arrangements and other agreements where we act as a portfolio construction manager for a mutual fund or variable annuity.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P50_S1	We also provide Investment Advisory services for some assets for which we receive a flat fee; we do not include these assets in the total reported above.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	Because we don't have custody of the underlying assets, it's difficult for us to quantify cash inflows and outflows for these portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P52_S1	The information we receive from most of our clients does not separately identify the effect of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P52_S2	We also cannot specify the effect of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	(3) Many factors can cause changes in assets under management and advisement for our managed retirement accounts, including employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	The information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances caused by market movement.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	(4) Revised to include Ibbotson Australia and a minor classification change.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	(6) Key product revenue includes the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	(7) Revised to include a minor classification change.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	(1) Operating income and free cash flow for 2014 include a $61.0 million litigation settlement expense and corresponding cash outflow.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	We define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	Please refer to the discussion in How We Evaluate our Business for more detail.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	In 2015 , our consolidated revenue rose 3.8% .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P59_S1	Currency movements were a major factor in our 2015 results, as continued strength in the U.S. dollar reduced revenue from our international operations when translated into U.S. dollars.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P59_S2	This has been an ongoing trend for several quarters and reduced revenue by $26.9 million in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	Some of the main contributors to the 2015 revenue increase were Morningstar Direct, Workplace Solutions, Morningstar Credit Ratings, Morningstar Data, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation (including Morningstar Office).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P60_S1	Positive results for these products were partially offset by decreases in Morningstar Enterprise Components and Principia.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	Morningstar Direct was the biggest contributor to growth in both 2015 and 2014, with revenue increasing by $9.9 million in 2015 and $12.5 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P61_S1	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to about 11,400 worldwide at the end of 2015, compared with about 10,000 at the end of 2014 and 8,500 at the end of 2013, with strong growth in both the United States and internationally.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P61_S2	Growth in Morningstar Direct reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	Revenue for Workplace Solutions increased by $9.3 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	Assets under management and advisement for Workplace Solutions rose 16.8% year over year, mainly reflecting growth in custom models.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	Revenue for Morningstar Credit Ratings rose $5.8 million, reflecting both higher new issuance volume for the year overall and a significant increase in the asset value of new-issue ratings.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Revenue for Morningstar Data increased $5.0 million, mainly reflecting new contracts and renewals for managed products data.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	In addition, several larger contracts renewed during 2015 with additional revenue added upon renewal.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	Morningstar Advisor Workstation's revenue increased an additional $4.7 million, mainly driven by clients migrating from legacy software products.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	Revenue from Morningstar Principia and a few other legacy software products declined $10.0 million because we've been migrating subscribers to newer workflow solutions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	The asset-based fees we earn are generally based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	Average assets under management and advisement (calculated based on available average quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $176.8 billion in 2015, compared with $166.3 billion in 2014 and $161.6 billion in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P67_S2	We had $116.9 million in revenue from asset-based fees in 2015 , an increase of $22.8 million compared with $94.1 million in 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P67_S3	In 2013 , revenue from asset-based fees was $88.6 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P67_S4	Revenue from asset-based fees made up approximately 14.8% of consolidated revenue in 2015 , an increase of 2.4 percentage points compared with 12.4% in 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	In 2014 , our consolidated revenue increased 8.9% .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	Some of the main contributors to the increase were Morningstar Direct, Workplace Solutions, Morningstar Managed Portfolios, and Morningstar Credit Ratings.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P68_S2	Positive results for these products were partially offset by a $9.1 million decline in Principia.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P68_S3	Revenue for Investment Advisory services was down $2.3 million, reflecting the ongoing effect of clients moving to in-house management for fund-of-funds portfolios in the variable annuity industry.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	To make it easier to compare our results in different periods, we provide information about organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	In November 2015, we acquired Total Rebalance Expert (tRx).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	In April 2014, we acquired ByAllAccounts, Inc. (ByAllAccounts) and in June 2014, we acquired an additional 81.3% interest in HelloWallet Holdings, Inc. (HelloWallet) to become the sole owner.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	We exclude revenue from businesses acquired or divested from organic revenue for a period of 12 months after we complete the acquisition or divestiture.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	In 2015 , we had $4.1 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions, primarily from ByAllAccounts and HelloWallet.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	In addition, currency translations reduced revenue by about $26.9 million in 2015 , mainly because of the weaker Euro, Australian dollar, British pound, and Canadian dollar.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P72_S2	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 6.8% in 2015 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	In 2014 , we had $11.4 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions, primarily from ByAllAccounts and HelloWallet.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	In addition, currency translations reduced revenue by about $2.5 million in 2014, mainly because of the weaker Australian dollar and Canadian dollar, partially offset by the stronger British pound.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 7.6% in 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations):
1289419_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	Organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P75_S2	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	International revenue made up about 26% of our consolidated revenue in 2015 , compared to 28% in both 2014 and 2013 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	About 60% of our international revenue is from Continental Europe and the United Kingdom.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P76_S2	We also have a fairly large revenue base in Australia and Canada.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	Revenue from international operations decreased 2.7% in 2015 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	Excluding acquisitions and foreign currency translations, revenue from international operations increased 10.2% .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P77_S2	Our operations in the United Kingdom were the main contributors to the organic increase, followed by Continental Europe and Japan.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	In 2014 , revenue from international operations rose 6.0% , as our operations in Continental Europe enjoyed stronger product sales, and revenue growth was also relatively strong in United Kingdom and Australia.
