1289419_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P80_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business, we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P81_S1	The graph below illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Morningstar Data, Investment Advisory services, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average annual renewal rate was approximately 99% in 2015 , compared with 95% in 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	The increase partly reflects some larger renewals for Morningstar Data, Enterprise Components, and Morningstar Research that included additional business upon renewal.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	These positive trends were partly offset by slightly lower renewal rates for Morningstar Direct and Morningstar Advisor Workstation.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes and changes to the contract value upon renewal, as well as changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	In 2015 , we estimate that our annual retention rate for subscription-based products, including Morningstar.com's Premium Membership service, Morningstar Office, and newsletter products, was approximately 67% in 2015 , compared with 69% in 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P84_S1	The decline was mainly driven by a lower retention rate for Morningstar.com Premium Memberships, partly offset by positive retention trends for Morningstar Office and our international operations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	Note: Following our change to a more centralized structure during 2013, we refined the classification of employees within operating expense categories.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P85_S1	As a result, approximately 180 net positions shifted from the general and administrative and sales and marketing categories to cost of revenue starting in the second half of 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P85_S2	These changes added approximately $14 million of compensation expense to cost of revenue in 2014 versus 2013, and reduced the compensation expense included in the sales and marketing and general and administrative categories by approximately $8 million and $6 million, respectively, in the same period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P85_S3	These changes did not affect total operating expense or operating income for any of the periods presented.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	In 2015 , our operating expense was down $56.3 million , or 8.6% .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	We settled a dispute with Business Logic for $61.0 million in 2014, which did not recur in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P86_S2	In addition, as a result of the continued strength in the U.S. dollar, foreign currency translations had a favorable effect of $23.9 million on operating expense during 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Commission expense decreased $14.7 million in 2015 , mainly because we changed to a new sales commission structure that requires a different accounting treatment.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	In the first quarter of 2014, we started expensing sales commissions as incurred instead of amortizing them over the term of the underlying contracts.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P87_S2	However, we continued to amortize the prepaid commission balance from the previous commission plan.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P87_S3	This amortization triggered an additional $3.5 million and $9.8 million of sales commission cost in 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	Legal and other professional fees were down $4.2 million in 2015, mainly reflecting litigation-related legal fees in 2014 that did not recur in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	Also reducing operating expense was an increase in capitalized software development.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	In 2015, we capitalized $21.8 million of software development expense for ongoing enhancements of key platforms and new development of upgraded software platforms.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	In comparison, we capitalized a total of $18.8 million of software development expense in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	Compensation expense (including salaries, bonus, and other company-sponsored benefits) increased $6.3 million in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	While headcount remained relatively flat during the first nine months of the year, net headcount increased by about 100 employees during the fourth quarter as we continued to invest in our key growth initiatives.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P90_S2	The new hires mainly reflect technology, client support, and credit analyst roles in the United States and India.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P90_S3	Overall, we had 3,930 employees worldwide at the end of 2015, compared with 3,760 at the end of 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	Depreciation expense was up $9.8 million in 2015, mainly reflecting additional capitalized software development and computer software purchases for our U.S. operations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	Advertising and marketing, computer and software supplies, rent, and production expense were also higher during 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	In 2014, our operating expense was up $126.9 million, or 24.0%.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	The $61.0 million litigation settlement expense incurred in 2014 contributed approximately half of this increase.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P92_S2	Higher compensation expense (including salaries, bonus, and other company-sponsored benefits) also contributed to the change.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	We had approximately 3,760 employees worldwide at the end of 2014, compared with 3,565 at the end of 2013 an increase of approximately 200 employees.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P93_S1	The ByAllAccounts and HelloWallet acquisitions added approximately 100 employees on a combined basis.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P93_S2	We also added product and technology roles in the United States as well as equity data analysts in India.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	Depreciation expense was up $8.4 million in 2014, mainly reflecting additional capitalized software development and computer software purchases for our U.S. operations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	Production expense was up $6.7 million in 2014, mainly reflecting higher costs for information technology maintenance agreements and infrastructure, as well as an unrealized loss on some of our model portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	This expense growth was partially offset by an increase in capitalized software development, which reduced operating expense.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P96_S1	In 2014, we capitalized $18.8 million of software development costs for ongoing enhancements as well as new development of upgraded software platforms, compared with $8.1 million in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	Total operating expense also includes bonus expense and stock-based compensation expense, which we include in each of the cost categories shown in the table above.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P97_S1	Bonus expense was $50.7 million in 2015, compared with $48.1 million in 2014 and $40.9 million in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P97_S2	Stock-based compensation expense was $17.4 million in 2015, compared with $17.6 million in 2014 and $15.0 million in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	Cost of revenue is our largest category of operating expense, representing about one-half of our total operating expense.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P98_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and cost of revenue includes the compensation expense for employees who produce our products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P98_S2	We include compensation expense for approximately 80% of our employees in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	In 2015, cost of revenue was up $11.5 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	Higher salary expense of $7.9 million was the main reason for the increase, reflecting new hires we made to support the growth of our business as well as annual merit increases.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P99_S2	Higher expense for bonus, professional fees, and production expense also contributed to the change in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	Partially offsetting these increases was a higher level of capitalized software development, which reduced cost of revenue during 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	We capitalized $21.8 million associated with software development activities in 2015 versus $18.8 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	Cost of revenue rose $47.2 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P101_S1	The $14.0 million of additional expense from the shift in employee cost categories discussed above was a major factor behind the growth in cost of revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P101_S2	In 2014, other increases in salary expense, bonus, and other compensation costs which totaled about $44.4 million also contributed to growth in this category.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P101_S3	Production expense was up $6.7 million in 2014, mainly reflecting higher costs for information technology maintenance agreements and infrastructure, as well as an unrealized loss on some of our model portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	These increases were partially offset by a higher level of capitalized software development in 2014, which reduced cost of revenue during 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P102_S1	We capitalized $18.8 million of software development in 2014, compared with $8.1 million in 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	As a percentage of revenue, cost of revenue decreased by about 0.1 percentage points in 2015 and increased 3.0 percentage points in 2014, with approximately 2 percentage points of the change in 2014 driven by the shift in employee cost categories.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	Sales and marketing expense decreased $14.5 million in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P104_S1	Lower sales commission expense of $13.9 million (mainly reflecting the change in sales commission structure discussed above) as well as lower salary expense of $2.1 million were the primary contributors to the decrease.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P104_S2	Partly offsetting these decreases was an increase in advertising and marketing expense of $3.0 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	In 2014, the shift in employee cost categories reduced sales and marketing expense by approximately $8.0 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	Despite this reduction, total sales and marketing expense was still up $7.5 million in 2014, mainly because of higher sales commission costs following the change in commission plan discussed above.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P105_S2	Additional costs for advertising and marketing also contributed to this increase, but to a lesser extent.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P105_S3	This expense growth was partly offset by lower costs for travel, training, and conferences.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense was down 2.4 percentage points in 2015 and 0.2 percentage points in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	General and administrative expense decreased $1.8 million in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P107_S1	Legal fees decreased $3.5 million as a result of litigation-related legal fees in 2014 that did not recur in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P107_S2	Salary expense also decreased $0.9 million in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P107_S3	These decreases were partially offset by an increase of $3.1 million in rent and utilities expense, mainly because of new and expanded office space in New York and London.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P108_S0	In 2014, the shift in employee cost categories discussed above reduced general and administrative (G A) expense by approximately $6.0 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P108_S1	Despite this reduction, total G A expense still increased by $2.0 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P108_S2	Rent and facilities costs were up $2.8 million versus 2013, mainly because we expanded our office space in the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P108_S3	This additional expense was partially offset by a $1.5 million credit we recorded for damages received in connection with a legal matter in the first quarter of 2014, which partially offset growth in legal and other professional fees.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P109_S0	G A expense as a percentage of revenue was down 0.7 percentage points in 2015 and 1.0 percentage points in 2014, mainly because of the shift in employee cost categories.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P110_S0	Depreciation expense rose $9.8 million in 2015 and $8.4 million in 2014, mainly because of higher capital expenditures for computer software and incremental capitalized software development costs for our operations in the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P110_S1	Intangible amortization expense decreased $0.3 million in 2015 as certain intangible assets from some of our earlier acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P110_S2	Intangible amortization expense increased $0.8 million in 2014, as additional amortization expense for the intangible assets of HelloWallet and ByAllAccounts was largely offset by the completed amortization of intangible assets from some previous acquisitions .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P111_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost for the remaining lives of the assets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P111_S1	We estimate that this expense will total approximately $17.7 million in 2016 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P111_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by additional acquisitions, dispositions, changes in the estimated average useful lives, and currency translations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P112_S0	Overall, depreciation and amortization increased $9.5 million in 2015 and $9.2 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P113_S0	We recorded a $61.0 million litigation settlement expense in the second quarter of 2014 that did not recur in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P113_S1	This expense is included in our results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 and contributed nearly half of the increase in operating expense in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P114_S0	Consolidated operating income increased $85.0 million in 2015 as our revenue increased $28.7 million and operating expense decreased by $56.3 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P114_S1	Operating margin was 24.2% , an increase of 10.3 percentage points compared with 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P114_S2	The decrease in operating expense in 2015 mainly reflects the $61.0 million litigation settlement expense incurred in the second quarter of 2014 that did not recur in 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P115_S0	In 2014, the $61.0 million settlement was the biggest contributor to the decline in operating income and operating margin compared with 2013.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P115_S1	We also had higher salary and other compensation-related expense from additional headcount, reflecting both new hires and employees added with the ByAllAccounts and HelloWallet acquisitions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P116_S0	We reported adjusted operating income, which excludes the settlement, of $166.6 million in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P117_S0	Adjusted operating income is a non-GAAP measure; the table above shows a reconciliation to the comparable GAAP measure.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P118_S0	We present adjusted operating income (operating income excluding the settlement) to show the effect of this charge, better reflect period-over-period comparisons, and improve overall understanding of our current and future financial performance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P119_S0	We reported an adjusted operating margin, which excludes the settlement, of 21.9% in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P119_S1	Adjusted operating margin is a non-GAAP measure; the table above shows a reconciliation to the comparable GAAP measure.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P120_S0	We present adjusted operating margin (operating margin excluding the settlement) for the same reasons mentioned above.

1289419_16_ITEM7_P122_S0	Interest income mainly reflects interest from our investment portfolio.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P122_S1	Interest expense mainly relates to the outstanding principal balance on the credit facility we established in 2014.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P123_S0	Non-operating income in 2014 includes the $5.2 million gain we recorded with our purchase of the remaining ownership interest in HelloWallet, which was previously a minority investment.

1289419_16_ITEM7_P127_S0	The following table summarizes the components of our effective tax rate:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P128_S0	For a reconciliation of the U.S. federal tax rate to our effective income tax rate, refer to Note 13 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P129_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2015 was 32.1% , an increase of 0.8 percentage points compared with 31.3% in 2014, primarily reflecting higher state taxes.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P130_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2014 was 31.3% , almost exactly at par with 2013 , when we provided for income taxes at an effective tax rate of 31.2% .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P131_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations and our line of credit, will be sufficient to meet our operating and cash needs for at least the next 12 months.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P131_S1	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P131_S2	We maintain a conservative investment policy for our investments.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P131_S3	We invest a portion of our investments balance (approximately $26.1 million, or 63% of our total investments balance as of December 31, 2015 ) in stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, money market funds, or exchange-traded products that replicate the model portfolios and strategies created by Morningstar.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P131_S4	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P132_S0	Approximately 26% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2015 was held by our operations in the United States, down from about 28% as of December 31, 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P132_S1	We do not expect to repatriate earnings from our foreign subsidiaries in the foreseeable future.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P132_S2	We have not recognized deferred tax liabilities for the portion of the outside basis differences (including unremitted earnings) relating to foreign subsidiaries because the investment in these subsidiaries is considered to be permanent in duration.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P132_S3	It is not practical to quantify the deferred tax liability associated with these outside basis differences.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P133_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had cash, cash equivalents, and investments of $248.6 million , an increase of $24.0 million compared with $224.6 million as of December 31, 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P133_S1	The increase reflects net income, adjusted for non-cash items, and the net effect of changes in our operating assets and liabilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P133_S2	These items were partially offset by $97.0 million used to repurchase common stock through our share repurchase program, $57.3 million of capital expenditures, bonus payments of $47.8 million, and dividend payments of $33.7 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P134_S0	We intend to use our cash, cash equivalents, and investments for general corporate purposes, including working capital and funding future growth.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P135_S0	Cash provided by operating activities is our main source of cash.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P135_S1	In 2015 , cash provided by operating activities was $238.9 million , driven by $212.5 million of net income, adjusted for non-cash items and $26.4 million in positive changes from our net operating assets and liabilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P136_S0	In December 2015, our board of directors approved a $300.0 million increase to our share repurchase program, bringing the total amount authorized under the program to $1.0 billion .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P136_S1	In 2015 , we repurchased a total of approximately 1.2 million shares for $97.0 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P136_S2	As of December 31, 2015 , we had repurchased a total of 9.4 million shares for $623.5 million since we announced the share repurchase program in September 2010.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P137_S0	In 2015 , we also paid dividends of $33.7 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P137_S1	In February 2016 , our board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 22 cents per share.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P137_S2	The dividend is payable on April 29, 2016 to shareholders of record as of April 8, 2016 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P137_S3	We expect to make regular quarterly dividend payments of 22 cents per share in 2016 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P138_S0	We expect to continue making capital expenditures in 2016 , primarily for computer hardware and software, internally developed software, and leasehold improvements for new and existing office locations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P139_S0	We also expect to use a portion of our cash and investments balances in the first quarter of 2016 to make annual bonus payments of approximately $50.0 million related to the 2015 bonus.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P140_S0	In July 2015, we renewed our $75.0 million single-bank revolving credit facility in the United States, which we intend to use for general corporate purposes.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P140_S1	We had an outstanding principal balance of $35.0 million as of December 31, 2015 at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 100 basis points, leaving borrowing availability of $40.0 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P141_S0	As described in more detail above, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P141_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P141_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P142_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P142_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P143_S0	We generated free cash flow of $181.6 million in 2015 , an increase of $107.7 million versus 2014 .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P143_S1	The change reflects a $106.7 million increase in cash provided by operating activities as well as a $1.0 million decrease in capital expenditures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P143_S2	Free cash flow for 2014 included a $61.0 million cash outflow in connection with the litigation settlement.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P144_S0	In 2014 , free cash flow was down $79.2 million from 2013 , largely because of the $61.0 million litigation settlement payment, as well as growth in capital expenditures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P145_S0	We invested a total of $86.6 million , less cash acquired, related to acquisitions over the past three years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P145_S1	We describe these acquisitions, including purchase price and product offerings, in Note 7 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P146_S0	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P146_S1	We discuss our significant accounting policies in Note 2 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P147_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires our management team to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, expense, and related disclosures included in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P148_S0	We evaluate our estimates on an ongoing basis.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P148_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P148_S2	Based on these assumptions and estimates, we make judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P148_S3	Our actual results could vary from these estimates and assumptions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P148_S4	If actual amounts are different from previous estimates, we include revisions in our results of operations for the period in which the actual amounts become known.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P149_S0	We believe the following critical accounting policies reflect the significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our Consolidated Financial Statements:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P150_S0	Much of our revenue comes from the sale of subscriptions or licenses for data, software, and Internet-based products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P150_S1	We recognize this revenue in equal amounts over the term of the subscription or license, which generally ranges from one to three years.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P150_S2	We also provide research, investment advisory, retirement advice, and other services.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P150_S3	We recognize this revenue when the service is provided or during the service obligation period defined in the contract.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P151_S0	We make significant judgments related to revenue recognition, including whether fees are fixed or determinable and whether the collection of payment is probable.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P152_S0	For contracts that combine multiple products and services, we make judgments regarding the value of each element in the arrangement based on selling prices of the items when sold separately.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P153_S0	Delivery of our products and services is a prerequisite to the recognition of revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P153_S1	If arrangements include an acceptance provision, we begin recognizing revenue upon the receipt of customer acceptance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P154_S0	We make judgments at the beginning of an arrangement regarding whether or not collection is probable.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P154_S1	We typically sell to institutional customers with whom we have a history of successful collections and assess the probability of collection on a case-by-case basis.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P155_S0	Deferred revenue is the amount invoiced or collected in advance for subscriptions, licenses, or services that has not yet been recognized as revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P155_S1	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and, at the end of 2015 , totaled $152.0 million (of which $140.7 million was classified as a current liability with an additional $11.3 million included in other long-term liabilities).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P155_S2	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill our service obligations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P156_S0	The amount of deferred revenue may increase or decrease based on the mix of contracted products and services and the volume of new and renewal subscriptions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P156_S1	The timing of future revenue recognition may change depending on the terms of the license agreements and the timing of fulfilling our service obligations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P156_S2	We believe that the estimate related to revenue recognition is a critical accounting estimate, and to the extent that there are material differences between our determination of deferred revenue and actual results, our financial condition or results of operations may be affected.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P157_S0	Acquisitions, Goodwill, and Other Intangible Assets Our financial statements reflect the operations of an acquired business starting from the completion of the transaction.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P157_S1	We record the estimated fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the date of acquisition.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P157_S2	Allocating the purchase price to the acquired assets and liabilities involves management judgment.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P157_S3	On occasion we may obtain the assistance of third-party valuation experts for significant assets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P158_S0	We base the fair value estimates on available historical information and on future expectations and assumptions that we believe are reasonable, but these estimates are inherently uncertain.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P158_S1	Determining the fair value of intangible assets requires significant management judgment in each of the following areas:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P159_S0	Identify the acquired intangible assets: For each acquisition, we identify the intangible assets acquired.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P159_S1	These intangible assets generally consist of customer relationships, trademarks and trade names, technology-related intangibles (including internally developed software and databases), and non-compete agreements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P160_S0	Estimate the fair value of these intangible assets: We consider various approaches to value the intangible assets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P160_S1	These include the cost approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the cost to reproduce it or replace it with another asset of like utility; the market approach, which values the asset through an analysis of sales and offerings of comparable assets; and the income approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the present value of the economic benefits it is expected to produce.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S0	Estimate the remaining useful life of the assets: For each intangible asset, we use judgment and assumptions to establish the remaining useful life of the asset.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S1	For example, for customer relationships, we determine the estimated useful life with reference to observed customer attrition rates.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S2	For technology-related assets such as databases, we make judgments about the demand for current data and historical metrics in establishing the remaining useful life.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S3	For internally developed software, we estimate an obsolescence factor associated with the software.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S4	We record any excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the net assets acquired as goodwill, which is not amortized.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S5	Instead, it is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist, based on a discounted cash-flow model.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S6	We review the carrying value of goodwill for impairment at least annually based on the estimated fair value of our reporting unit.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P161_S7	If we determine that goodwill is impaired, we reduce the goodwill balance to reflect the revised fair value.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P162_S0	For purposes of performing the impairment test, fair values are determined using a discounted cash-flow methodology.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P162_S1	This requires significant judgments including estimation of future cash flows, which, among other factors, is dependent on internal forecasts, estimation of the long-term rate of growth for businesses and determination of weighted average cost of capital.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P162_S2	We believe the accounting estimates related to purchase price allocations in connection with acquisitions and subsequent goodwill impairment testing are critical accounting estimates because changes in these assumptions could materially affect the amounts and classifications of assets and liabilities presented in our Consolidated Balance Sheets, as well as the amount of amortization and depreciation expense, if any, recorded in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P163_S0	We include stock-based compensation expense in each of our operating expense categories.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P163_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense primarily reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, and performance share awards.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S0	We measure stock-based compensation expense at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and recognize the expense ratably over the award's vesting period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S1	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day before the grant.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S2	We estimate expected forfeitures of stock-based awards at the grant date and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S3	We later adjust this forfeiture assumption to the actual forfeiture rate.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S4	Therefore, changes in the forfeiture assumptions do not change the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the vesting period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P164_S5	Instead, different forfeiture assumptions would only affect the timing of expense recognition over the vesting period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P165_S0	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense to reflect those awards that ultimately vested and update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P166_S0	We believe the estimates related to stock-based compensation expense are critical accounting estimates because the assumptions used could significantly impact the timing and amount of stock-based compensation expense recorded in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P167_S0	Our effective tax rate is based on the mix of income and losses in our U.S. and non-U.S. operations, statutory tax rates, and tax-planning opportunities available to us in the various jurisdictions in which we operate.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P167_S1	Significant judgment is required to evaluate our tax positions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P168_S0	Tax law requires us to include items in our tax return at different times from when these items are reflected in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P168_S1	As a result, the effective tax rate reflected in our Consolidated Financial Statements is different from the tax rate reported on our tax return (our cash tax rate).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P168_S2	Some of these differences, such as expenses that are not deductible in our tax return, are permanent.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P168_S3	Other differences, such as depreciation expense, reverse over time.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P168_S4	These timing differences create deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P169_S0	We determine our deferred tax assets and liabilities based on temporary differences between the financial reporting and the tax basis of assets and liabilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P169_S1	The excess tax benefits associated with stock-option exercises and vesting of restricted stock units also create a difference between our cash tax rate and the effective tax rate in our Consolidated Income Statement.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P170_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had gross deferred tax assets of $40.8 million and gross deferred tax liabilities of $59.4 million .
1289419_16_ITEM7_P170_S1	The deferred tax assets include $3.7 million of deferred tax assets related to $18.4 million of net operating losses (NOLs) of our non-U.S. operations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P171_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P171_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $12.1 million of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of the NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P172_S0	In assessing the need for a valuation allowance, we consider both positive and negative evidence, including tax-planning strategies, projected future taxable income, and recent financial performance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P172_S1	If we determine a lesser allowance is required at some point in the future, we would record a reduction to our tax expense and valuation allowance.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P172_S2	These adjustments would be made in the same period we determined the change in the valuation allowance was needed.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P172_S3	This would cause our income tax expense, effective tax rate, and net income to fluctuate.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P173_S0	We use judgment to identify, recognize, and measure the amounts of uncertain tax positions to be recorded in the financial statements related to tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P173_S1	We recognize liabilities to represent our potential future obligations to taxing authorities for the benefits taken in our tax returns.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P173_S2	We adjust these liabilities, including any impact of the related interest and penalties, in light of changing facts and circumstances such as the progress of a tax audit.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P173_S3	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter for which we have established a reserve is audited and finally resolved.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P173_S4	The number of years with open tax audits varies depending on the tax jurisdiction.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P174_S0	We use judgment to classify unrecognized tax benefits as either current or noncurrent liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P174_S1	Settlement of any particular issue would usually require the use of cash.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P175_S0	We generally classify liabilities associated with unrecognized tax benefits as noncurrent liabilities.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P175_S1	It typically takes several years between our initial tax return filing and the final resolution of any uncertain tax positions with the tax authority.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P175_S2	We recognize favorable resolutions of tax matters for which we have previously established reserves as a reduction to our income tax expense when the amounts involved become known.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P176_S0	Assessing the future tax consequences of events that have been recognized in our Consolidated Financial Statements or tax returns requires judgment.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P176_S1	Variations in the actual outcome of these future tax consequences could materially impact our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P177_S0	We are subject to various claims and contingencies related to legal proceedings and investigations.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P177_S1	These legal proceedings involve inherent uncertainties including, but not limited to, court rulings, negotiations between affected parties, and government actions.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P177_S2	Assessing the probability of loss for such contingencies and determining how to accrue the appropriate liabilities requires judgment.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P177_S3	If actual results differ from our assessments, our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows would be affected.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S0	On May 28, 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , which requires an entity to recognize the amount of revenue to which it expects to be entitled for the transfer of promised goods or services to customers.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S1	The ASU will replace most existing revenue recognition guidance in U.S. GAAP when it becomes effective.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S2	The original effective date for ASU 2014-09 would have required the Company to adopt beginning on January 1, 2017.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers - Deferral of the Effective Date , which defers the effective date of ASU 2014-09 for one year and permits early adoption as early as the original effective date of ASU 2014-09.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S4	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P178_S5	The standard permits the use of either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P179_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2014-09 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P179_S1	We have not yet selected a transition method nor have we determined the effect of the standard on our ongoing financial reporting.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P180_S0	On September 28, 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-16, Simplifying the Accounting for Measurement Period Adjustments , which eliminates the requirement to restate prior period financial statements for adjustments made during the measurement period.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P180_S1	The new standard requires that the cumulative impact of a measurement period adjustment (including the impact on prior periods) be recognized in the reporting period in which the adjustment is identified.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P180_S2	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2016.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P180_S3	We elected to early adopt ASU No. 2015-16 in the quarter ended December 31, 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P181_S0	The adoption of ASU No. 2015-16 did not have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P182_S0	On November 20, 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes, which requires that deferred tax liabilities and assets be classified as noncurrent in a classified statement of financial position and apply to all entities that present a classified statement of financial position.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P182_S1	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2017.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P183_S0	The standard permits the use of either the prospective or retrospective method.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P183_S1	We elected to early adopt ASU No. 2015-17 retrospectively in the quarter ended December 31, 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P184_S0	The adoption of ASU No. 2015-17 did not have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P185_S0	The table below shows our known contractual obligations as of December 31, 2015 and the expected timing of cash payments related to these contractual obligations:
1289419_16_ITEM7_P186_S0	(1) The non-cancelable operating lease obligations are mainly for lease commitments for office space.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P187_S0	(2) The 2016 minimum payments on the credit facility reflect the current outstanding principal balance of $35.0 million and an estimate for interest and commitment fees.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P187_S1	Only the interest and commitment fees are mandatory payments during 2016, as we anticipate renewing the one-year revolving credit facility in July 2016 and any outstanding principal balance at that time.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P188_S0	(3) Represents unrecognized tax benefits (including penalties and interest, less the impact of any associated tax benefits).
1289419_16_ITEM7_P188_S1	The amount included in the table represents items that may be resolved through settlement of tax audits or for which the statutes of limitations are expected to lapse during 2016.
1289419_16_ITEM7_P188_S2	The table excludes $6.0 million of unrecognized tax benefits, included as a long-term liability in our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2015 , for which we cannot make a reasonably reliable estimate of the period of payment.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our investment portfolio is actively managed and may suffer losses from fluctuating interest rates, market prices, or adverse security selection.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	These accounts may consist of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, money market funds, or exchange-traded products that replicate the model portfolios and strategies created by Morningstar.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	As of December 31, 2015 , our cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance was $248.6 million.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P0_S4	Based on our estimates, a 100 basis-point change in interest rates would not have a material effect on the fair value of our investment portfolio.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We are subject to risk from fluctuations in foreign currencies from our operations outside of the United States.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	To date, we have not engaged in currency hedging, and we do not currently have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The table below shows our exposure to foreign currency denominated revenue and operating income for the year ended December 31, 2015 :
1289419_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The table below shows our net investment exposure in foreign currencies as of December 31, 2015 :
1289419_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2015.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	In connection with our audits of the consolidated financial statements, we also have audited the financial statement Schedule II - Valuation and Qualifying Accounts.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P1_S2	These consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our audits.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2015, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Morningstar, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) , issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) , and our report dated February 26, 2016, expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of Morningstar Inc. s internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited Morningstar, Inc. s (the Company) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) , issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1289419_16_ITEM8_P7_S1	Morningstar, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1289419_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P8_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P8_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	In our opinion, Morningstar, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) , issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1289419_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015, and the financial statement schedule, and our report dated February 26, 2016, expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements and accompanying schedule.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Morningstar, Inc. and its subsidiaries (Morningstar, we, our), provides independent investment research for investors around the world.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for financial advisors, asset managers, retirement plan providers and sponsors, and individual investors.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P18_S2	We have operations in 27 countries.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	We conduct our business operations through wholly owned or majority-owned operating subsidiaries.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Morningstar, Inc. and our subsidiaries.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	We consolidate assets, liabilities, and results of operations of subsidiaries in which we have a controlling interest and eliminate all significant intercompany accounts and transactions.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	We account and report the noncontrolling (minority) interest in our Consolidated Financial Statements in accordance with FASB ASC 810, Consolidation .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	A noncontrolling interest is the portion of equity (net assets) in a subsidiary not attributable, directly or indirectly, to the parent company.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P21_S1	We report the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Balance Sheet within equity separate from the shareholders' equity attributable to Morningstar, Inc.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P21_S2	In addition, we present the net income (loss) and comprehensive income (loss) attributable to Morningstar, Inc.'s shareholders and the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Statements of Income, Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income, and Consolidated Statements of Equity.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	We account for investments in entities in which we exercise significant influence, but do not control, using the equity method.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	As part of our investment management operations, we manage certain funds outside of the United States that are considered variable interest entities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P23_S1	For the majority of these variable interest entities, we do not have a variable interest in them.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P23_S2	In cases where we do have a variable interest, we are not the primary beneficiary.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P23_S3	Accordingly, we do not consolidate any of these variable interest entities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	In accordance with ASU No. 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income, we present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income (OCI) in two separate but consecutive statements, our Consolidated Statements of Income and separately, our Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	In addition, effective January 1, 2013, we adopted FASB ASU No. 2013-02, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220) .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P24_S2	We show the effects of items reclassified out of each component of accumulated other comprehensive income to net income on the face of the financial statement along with net income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses during the reporting period.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	Certain amounts reported in prior years have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P27_S0	Separately, as a result of our move to a more centralized structure in 2013 (including new positions created, changes in focus for some existing roles, and the refinement of employee cost categorizations as we moved to a more centralized structure), approximately 180 net positions shifted from the general and administrative and sales and marketing categories to cost of revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P27_S1	These changes added approximately $14 million of compensation expense to cost of revenue in 2014 versus 2013, and reduced the compensation expense included in the sales and marketing and general and administrative categories by approximately $8 million and $6 million , respectively, in the same period.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P27_S2	These changes did not affect total operating expense or operating income for any of the periods presented.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P28_S0	Cash and cash equivalents consists of cash and investments with original maturities of three months or less.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P28_S1	We state them at cost, which approximates fair value.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P28_S2	We state the portion of our cash equivalents that are invested in money market funds at fair value, as these funds are actively traded and have quoted market prices.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P29_S0	We account for our investments in accordance with FASB ASC 320, Investments Debt and Equity Securities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P29_S1	We classify our investments into three categories: held-to-maturity, trading, and available-for-sale.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P30_S0	Held-to-maturity: We classify certain investments, primarily certificates of deposit, as held-to-maturity securities, based on our intent and ability to hold these securities to maturity.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P30_S1	We record held-to-maturity investments at amortized cost in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P31_S0	Trading: We classify certain other investments, primarily equity securities, as trading securities, primarily to satisfy the requirements of one of our wholly owned subsidiaries, which is a registered broker-dealer.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	We include realized and unrealized gains and losses associated with these investments as a component of our operating income in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P31_S2	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	Available-for-sale: Investments not considered held-to-maturity or trading securities are classified as available-for-sale securities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	Available-for-sale securities primarily consist of equity securities, exchange-traded funds, and mutual funds.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P32_S2	We report unrealized gains and losses for available-for-sale securities as other comprehensive income (loss), net of related income taxes.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P32_S3	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	We follow FASB ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	FASB ASC 820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	Under FASB ASC 820, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants as of the measurement date.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P34_S1	The standard applies whenever other standards require (or permit) assets or liabilities to be measured at fair value.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P34_S2	The standard does not expand the use of fair value in any new circumstances and does not require any new fair value measurements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	FASB ASC 820 uses a fair value hierarchy based on three broad levels of valuation inputs:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	Level 1: Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the company has the ability to access.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	Level 2: Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	Level 3: Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	We provide additional information about our cash equivalents and investments that are subject to valuation under FASB ASC 820 in Note 6 .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	No single customer is large enough to pose a significant credit risk to our operations or financial condition.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 , and 2013 , no single customer represented 5% or more of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	If receivables from our customers become delinquent, we begin a collections process.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	We maintain an allowance for doubtful accounts based on our estimate of the probable losses of accounts receivable.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	We state property and equipment at historical cost, net of accumulated depreciation.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P42_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful life of the asset, which ranges from three to seven years.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P42_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	Computer Software and Internal Product Development Costs.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P43_S1	We capitalize certain costs in accordance with FASB ASC 350-40, Internal-Use Software , FASB ASC 350-50, Website Development Costs, and FASB ASC 985, Software .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	Internal product development costs mainly consist of employee costs for developing new web-based products and certain major enhancements of existing products.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	We amortize these costs on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic life, which is generally three to five years.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P44_S2	We include capitalized software development costs related to projects that have not been placed into service in our construction in progress balance.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	The table below summarizes our capitalized software development costs for the past three years:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	Over the past several years, we have acquired companies that complement our business operations.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S1	For each acquisition, we allocate the purchase price to the assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and goodwill.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S2	We follow FASB ASC 805, Business Combinations .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S3	We recognize and measure the fair value of the acquired operation as a whole, as well as the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, at their full fair values as of the date we obtain control, regardless of the percentage ownership in the acquired operation or how the acquisition was achieved.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S4	We expense direct costs related to the business combination, such as advisory, accounting, legal, valuation, and other professional fees, as incurred.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P46_S5	We recognize restructuring costs, including severance and relocation for employees of the acquired entity, as post-combination expenses unless the target entity meets the criteria of FASB ASC 420, Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations , on the acquisition date.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	As part of the purchase price allocation, we follow the requirements of FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	This includes establishing deferred tax assets or liabilities reflecting the difference between the values assigned for financial statement purposes and income tax purposes.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P47_S2	In certain acquisitions, the goodwill resulting from the purchase price allocation may not be deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P47_S3	FASB ASC 740 prohibits recognition of a deferred tax asset or liability for temporary differences in goodwill if goodwill is not amortizable and deductible for tax purposes.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	Changes in the carrying amount of our recorded goodwill are mainly the result of business acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	In accordance with FASB ASC 350, Intangibles Goodwill and Other , we do not amortize goodwill; instead, goodwill is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	An impairment would occur if the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeded the fair value of that reporting unit.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P49_S1	We performed annual impairment reviews in the fourth quarter of 2015 , 2014 , and 2013 .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P49_S2	We did not record any impairment losses in 2015 , 2014 , or 2013 .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P50_S1	We have no intangible assets with indefinite useful lives.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P50_S2	In accordance with FASB ASC 360-10-35, Subsequent Measurement Impairment or Disposal of Long Lived Assets , we review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P50_S3	If the value of future undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying amount of an asset group, we record an impairment loss based on the excess of the carrying amount over the fair value of the asset group.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P50_S4	We did not record any impairment losses in 2015 , 2014 , or 2013 .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	We recognize revenue in accordance with SEC SAB Topic 13, Revenue Recognition , ASC 605-25, Revenue Recognition: Multiple Element Arrangements , and ASC 985-605, Software: Revenue Recognition .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	We recognize revenue when all of the following conditions are met:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	Delivery of our products and services has taken place.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	The collectibility of the fees is reasonably assured.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	We generate revenue through sales of Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation (including Morningstar Office), Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Research, Premium Membership subscriptions for Morningstar.com, our structured credit research and ratings offerings, and a variety of other investment-related products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	We generally structure the revenue agreements for these offerings as licenses or subscriptions.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	We recognize revenue from licenses and subscription sales ratably as we deliver the product or service and over the service obligation period defined by the terms of the customer contract.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P56_S0	For new-issue ratings and analysis for commercial mortgage- backed securities (CMBS), we charge asset-based fees that are paid by the issuer on the rated balance of the transaction and recognize the revenue immediately upon issuance.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	We also generate revenue from Internet advertising, primarily from impression-based contracts.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P57_S1	For advertisers who use our cost-per-impression pricing, we charge fees each time we display their ads on our site.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P58_S0	Our Investment Advisory business includes a broad range of services.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P58_S1	Pricing for consulting services is based on the scope of work and the level of service provided, and includes asset-based fees for work we perform that involves investment management or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P58_S2	In arrangements that involve asset-based fees, we generally invoice clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P58_S3	We recognize asset-based fees once the fees are fixed and determinable assuming all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	Our Workplace Solutions offerings help retirement plan participants plan and invest for retirement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P59_S1	We offer these services both through retirement plan providers (typically third-party asset management companies that offer proprietary mutual funds) and directly to plan sponsors (employers that offer retirement plans to their employees).
1289419_16_ITEM8_P59_S2	For our Workplace Solutions offerings, we provide both a hosted solution as well as proprietary installed software advice solution.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P59_S3	Clients can integrate the installed customized software into their existing systems to help investors accumulate wealth, transition into retirement, and manage income during retirement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P60_S0	The revenue arrangements for Workplace Solutions generally extend over multiple years.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	Our contracts may include one-time setup fees, implementation fees, technology licensing and maintenance fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	Upon customer acceptance, we recognize revenue ratably over the term of the agreement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P61_S1	We recognize asset-based fees and variable fees in excess of any minimum once the value is fixed and determinable.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	Some of our revenue arrangements combine multiple products and services.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P62_S1	These products and services may be provided at different points in time or over different time periods within the same arrangement.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	We allocate fees to the separate deliverables based on the deliverables relative selling price, which is generally based on the price we charge when the same deliverable is sold separately.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	We record taxes imposed on revenue-producing transactions (such as sales, use, value-added, and some excise taxes) on a net basis; therefore, we exclude such taxes from revenue in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P65_S0	Deferred revenue represents the portion of licenses or subscriptions billed or collected in advance of the service being provided which we expect to recognize as revenue in future periods.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	Certain arrangements may have cancellation or refund provisions.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P66_S0	If we make a refund, it typically reflects the amount collected from a customer for which we have not yet provided services.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P66_S1	The refund therefore results in a reduction of deferred revenue.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	Through December 31, 2013, we paid sales commissions based on a formula driven by the total contract value of sales opportunities closed, with any subsequent adjustments (such as clawbacks for contract cancellations) reflected in future commission payouts.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	We considered the corresponding commission expense an incremental direct acquisition cost and treated it as a deferred charge, which we expensed over the term of the underlying sales contracts.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P68_S0	In the first quarter of 2014, we modified our sales incentive plan.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P68_S1	The revised plan is based on a combination of net new sales and specific business objectives not solely tied to revenue growth.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P68_S2	Because of this new structure and the discretion involved in determining the related incentives, we started expensing sales commissions as incurred instead of amortizing them over the contract terms.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P68_S3	However, we continued to amortize the deferred charge capitalized in connection with sales commissions paid in 2013 and previous periods as part of the previous incentive plan.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P68_S4	This amortization added $3.5 million and $9.8 million of sales commission cost in 2015 and 2014, respectively.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	Advertising costs include expenses incurred for various print and Internet ads, search engine fees, and direct mail campaigns.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P69_S1	We expense advertising costs as incurred.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P69_S2	The table below summarizes our advertising expense for the past three years:
1289419_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	We account for our stock-based compensation expense in accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, performance share awards, and stock options.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units, restricted stock, and performance share awards on the date of grant based on the closing market price of Morningstar's common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P71_S1	For stock options, we estimate the fair value of our stock options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P71_S2	We amortize the fair values to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	We estimate expected forfeitures of all employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P72_S1	We determine forfeiture rates based on historical experience and adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience as needed.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	In certain of our operations, we offer employees a sabbatical leave.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P73_S1	Although the sabbatical policy varies by region, Morningstar's full-time employees are generally eligible for six weeks of paid time off after four years of continuous service.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P73_S2	We account for our sabbatical liability in accordance with FASB ASC 710-10-25 , Compensated Absences .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P73_S3	We record a liability for employees' sabbatical benefits over the period employees earn the right for sabbatical leave and include this liability in Accrued Compensation in our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	We record deferred income taxes for the temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities for financial statement purposes and tax purposes in accordance with FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	FASB ASC 740 prescribes the minimum recognition threshold a tax position is required to meet before being recognized in the financial statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P74_S2	It also provides guidance on derecognition, measurement, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, and disclosure for uncertain tax positions.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	We recognize interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of income tax expense in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P75_S1	We classify liabilities related to unrecognized tax benefits as either current or long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheet, depending on when we expect to make payment.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	We compute and present income per share in accordance with FASB ASC 260, Earnings Per Share .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	The difference between weighted average shares outstanding and diluted shares outstanding mainly reflects the dilutive effect associated with our stock-based compensation plans.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	We further compute income per share in accordance with FASB ASC 260-10-45-59A, Participating Securities and the Two-Class Method .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	Under the two-class method, we allocate earnings between common stock and participating securities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P79_S1	The two-class method includes an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for each class of common stock according to dividends declared and undistributed earnings for the period.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P79_S2	For purposes of calculating earnings per share, we reduce our reported net earnings by the amount allocated to participating securities to arrive at the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	ASC 260-10-45-59A requires the dilutive effect of participating securities to be calculated using the more dilutive of the treasury stock or the two-class method.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P80_S1	We have determined the two-class method to be the more dilutive.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P80_S2	As such, we adjusted the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders in the basic earnings per share calculation for the reallocation of undistributed earnings to participating securities to calculate diluted earnings per share.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P81_S0	We translate the financial statements of non-U.S. subsidiaries to U.S. dollars using the period-end exchange rate for assets and liabilities and an average exchange rate for revenue and expense.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P81_S1	We use the local currency as the functional currency for all of our non-U.S. subsidiaries.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P81_S2	We record translation adjustments for non-U.S. subsidiaries as a component of Other comprehensive income (loss) in our Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P81_S3	We include exchange gains and losses arising from transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency in Other income (expense), net in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P82_S0	In July 2015, we renewed our $75.0 million , single-bank revolving credit facility.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P82_S1	We drew on the credit facility during the fourth quarter of 2015 and had an outstanding principal balance of $35.0 million at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 100 basis points as of December 31, 2015 , leaving borrowing availability of $40.0 million .

1289419_16_ITEM8_P91_S0	We report our results in a single reportable segment, which reflects how our chief operating decision maker allocates resources and evaluates our financial results.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P92_S0	Because we have a single reportable segment, all required financial segment information can be found directly in the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P93_S0	The accounting policies for our reportable segment are the same as those described in Note 2 .
1289419_16_ITEM8_P94_S0	We evaluate the performance of our reporting segment based on revenue and operating income.

1289419_16_ITEM8_P96_S0	We account for our investments in accordance with FASB ASC 320, Investments Debt and Equity Securities.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P96_S1	We classify our investments into three categories: available-for-sale, held-to-maturity, and trading.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P96_S2	Our investment portfolio consists of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, money market funds, or exchange-traded products that replicate the model portfolios and strategies created by Morningstar.
1289419_16_ITEM8_P96_S3	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.

1289419_16_ITEM8_P101_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , held-to-maturity investments included a $1.5 million certificate of deposit, held as collateral against bank guarantees for our office leases, primarily in Australia.
