1289419_18_ITEM1_P180_S0	We were incorporated in Illinois on May 16, 1984.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P180_S1	Our corporate headquarters are located at 22 West Washington Street, Chicago, Illinois, 60602.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P181_S0	We maintain a website at http://www.morningstar.com/company.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P181_S1	Our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, and amendments to any of these documents are available free of charge on this site as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports are filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P181_S2	We also post quarterly press releases on our financial results and other documents containing additional information related to our company on this site.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P181_S3	We provide this website and the information contained in or connected to it for informational purposes only.
1289419_18_ITEM1_P181_S4	That information is not part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the other information included in this Form 10-K when deciding whether to invest in our common stock or otherwise evaluating our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks materialize, our business, financial condition, or operating results could suffer.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	In this case, the trading price of our common stock could decline, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our investment management operations may subject us to liability for any losses that result from a breach of our fiduciary duties.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Three of our subsidiaries, Morningstar Investment Management LLC, Morningstar Investment Services LLC, and Morningstar Research Services LLC, are registered as investment advisors with the SEC under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, as amended.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P1_S2	As registered investment advisors, these companies are subject to the requirements and regulations of the Advisers Act.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P1_S3	These requirements relate to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, and standards of care, as well as general anti-fraud prohibitions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	As registered investment advisors, these subsidiaries are subject to on-site examination by the SEC.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	In addition, in cases where these subsidiaries provide investment advisory services to retirement plans and their participants, they may be acting as fiduciaries under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	As fiduciaries under ERISA, they have obligations to act in the best interest of their clients.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	They also have duties of loyalty and prudence, as well as duties to diversify investments and to follow plan documents to comply with the applicable portions of ERISA.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our subsidiaries outside the United States that have investment advisory operations are subject to similar requirements.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We may face liabilities for actual or claimed breaches of our fiduciary duties, particularly in areas where we provide retirement advice and managed retirement accounts.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In some of our retirement contracts, we act as an ERISA fiduciary by, for example, selecting and monitoring a broad range of diversified plan options.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We also provide a managed account service for retirement plan participants who elect to have their accounts managed by our programs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Such activities have been the subject of increasing class action litigation in recent years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S4	For example, in 2017, a participant in a pension plan filed a putative class action proceeding against us alleging that we, together with other defendant parties, violated the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act by allegedly engaging in actions to steer plan participants into high-cost investments that pay unwarranted fees to the defendants.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P6_S5	We are vigorously contesting this proceeding, which is described in more detail in Item 3 of this Form 10-K under Legal Proceedings.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	As of December 31, 2017, we had $57.6 billion in assets under management in our managed retirement accounts.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We could face substantial liabilities related to our management of these assets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We rely on automated investment technology for our retirement advice and managed retirement accounts services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The Wealth Forecasting Engine is our core advice and managed accounts engine that determines appropriate asset allocations for retirement plan participants and assigns individuals to portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S1	We also rely on automated portfolio construction tools.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Problems could arise if these programs assigned retirement plan participants to the wrong portfolios, particularly if we failed to detect program errors over an extended period.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Clients may take legal action against us for an actual or claimed breach of a fiduciary duty.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S4	If we make an error, we may be subject to potentially large liabilities for make-whole payments and/or litigation.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P9_S5	We cannot quantify the potential size of these liabilities with any level of precision.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	In addition, we may face other legal liabilities based on the quality and outcome of our investment advisory recommendations, even in the absence of an actual or claimed breach of fiduciary duty, or based on our investment management fees and expenses.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	In total, we provided investment advisory and management services on approximately $195 billion in assets as of December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	We could face substantial liabilities related to our work on these assets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Failing to maintain and protect our brand, independence, and reputation may harm our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Our reputation and business may also be harmed by allegations made about possible conflicts of interest or by other negative publicity or media reports.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We believe independence is at the core of our business, and our reputation is our greatest corporate asset.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We rely on our reputation for integrity and high-caliber products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Any failure to uphold our high ethical standards and ensure that our customers have a consistently positive experience with us could damage our reputation as an objective, honest, and credible source for investment research and information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Allegations of improper conduct, whether the ultimate outcome is favorable or unfavorable to us, as well as any negative publicity or media reports about Morningstar, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation and damage our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S4	For instance, in October 2017, The Wall Street Journal ran an article critical of our fund star and analyst ratings.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P12_S5	We publicly and comprehensively disputed the assertions made in the article, but the publication of such an article illustrates the risks of negative publicity to our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We provide ratings, analyst research, and investment recommendations on mutual funds and other investment products offered by our institutional clients.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We also provide investment advisory and investment management services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	In some cases, we make investment recommendations (such as Select Lists) within the framework of client constraints.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	While we don t charge asset management firms for their products to be rated, we do charge licensing fees for the use of our ratings.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We also receive payments from issuers for our new-issue ratings on various types of asset-backed securities and corporate bond issues.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	These payments may create the perception that our ratings, research, and recommendations are not impartial.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	This perception may undermine the confidence of our customers and potential customers in our reputation as a provider of independent research.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Any such loss of confidence or damage to our reputation could hurt our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Our reputation may also be harmed by factors outside of our control, such as news reports about our clients or adverse publicity about certain investment products.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P15_S3	Our reputation could also suffer if we fail to produce competitive performance in our investment management offerings.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Failing to differentiate our products and continuously create innovative, proprietary research tools may harm our competitive position and business results.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We attribute much of our company's success over the past 34 years to our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools, such as the Morningstar Rating, Morningstar Style Box, Ownership Zone, and Portfolio X-Ray.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	More recently, we ve developed unique concepts and tools such as the Wealth Forecasting Engine, Gamma, Total Wealth Approach, and Best Interest Scorecard.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	We believe these innovations set us apart because most of our competitors focus on providing data or software rather than creating their own proprietary research frameworks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	We also believe our ability to develop innovative, proprietary research tools is at the core of what drives Morningstar s value for all of our customer groups.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	If we fail to continuously innovate and develop new tools to meet the needs of our customers, our competitive position and business results may suffer.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S1	In addition, our reputation could be harmed if we re perceived as not moving quickly enough to meet the changing needs of investors.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Clients may also delay purchases of our currently offered research tools in anticipation of us offering new products or enhanced versions of existing products.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S3	Our competitive position and business results may also suffer if other companies are able to successfully introduce innovative, proprietary research tools that gain attention from our clients.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S4	We believe lower technology costs, the growth of open software platforms, and cloud computing technologies have lowered the barriers to entry for new competitors, making it easier for new players to enter the market.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Smaller companies, including startup firms funded by private equity and venture capital, may be able to move more quickly to develop research and tools that gain a wide following.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	In addition, the value of our data, research and software tools may be negatively affected by the increasing amount of information and tools that are available for free, or at low cost, through internet sources or other low-cost delivery systems.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Although we believe our products and services contain value-added features and functionality that deeply embed them in our customers workflows, such developments may over time reduce the demand for, or customers willingness to pay for, certain of our products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	If we fail to introduce innovative, proprietary research tools and frameworks, we may not generate enough interest from potential clients to win new business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	We cannot guarantee that we will successfully develop new product features and tools that differentiate our product offerings from those of our competitors.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	In addition, we must make long-term investments and commit significant resources often before knowing whether such investments will result in products or services that satisfy our clients needs or generate revenues sufficient to justify such investments.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	In addition, from time to time, we also incur costs to transition clients to new or enhanced products or services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Such transitions can involve material execution risks and challenges.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P21_S3	If we are unable to manage these investments and transitions successfully, our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Failing to respond to technological change, keep pace with new technology developments, or adopt a successful technology strategy may negatively affect our competitive position and business results.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We believe the technology landscape has been changing at an accelerating rate over the past several years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Changes in technology are fundamentally changing the ways investors access data and content.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Examples include the shift from local network computing to cloud-based systems, the proliferation of wireless mobile devices, and rapid acceleration in the use of social media platforms.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Our software development process is based on frequently rolling out new features so that we can quickly incorporate user feedback.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	While some changes in technology may offer opportunities for Morningstar, we cannot guarantee that we will successfully adapt our product offerings to meet evolving customer needs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	If we fail to develop and implement new technology rapidly enough, we may sacrifice new business opportunities or renewals from existing customers.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	We may also incur additional operating expense if major software projects take longer than anticipated.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P24_S4	Our competitive position and business results may suffer if we fail to develop new technologies to meet client demands, if our execution speed is too slow, or if we adopt a technology strategy that doesn't align with changes in the market.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Our results could suffer if the mutual fund industry continues to experience slower growth, if actively managed equity funds continue to attract less investor attention, or if the industry continues to meaningfully consolidate.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We generate a significant portion of our revenue from products and services related to mutual funds, and part of our growth since 1984 can be attributed to favorable industry trends.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The mutual fund industry has experienced substantial growth over the past 30 to 40 years, but suffered during the market downturn of 2008 and 2009.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Since then, fund assets have increased, but at a slower rate than in previous years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Some of that slower growth is attributable to the growth of ETFs as a mutual fund alternative, and we have accordingly expanded our research coverage and analyst ratings to include ETFs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P27_S3	However, ETFs generally track passive investing strategies and charge lower management fees than active strategies, which may affect both the profitability of asset managers, on whose success we in part depend, and the perceived value of our research regarding ETFs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P28_S0	A significant portion of our fund research has historically focused on equity-related funds.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P28_S1	In addition, we are best-known for our data and analyst research on actively managed equity funds.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Over the past 15 years, passively managed index funds have seen greater investor interest, and this trend has accelerated in recent years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P29_S1	In 2017, actively managed mutual funds suffered about $7 billion in net outflows, compared with net inflows of more than $690 billion for passively managed funds.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P29_S2	Overall, we estimate that passively managed portfolios now account for more than one-third of combined mutual fund and ETF assets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P29_S3	The growth of online wealth management tools that provide automated, algorithm-based portfolio management advice, sometimes called robo-advice, may further accelerate the adoption of passively managed portfolios and reduce demand for our data and analyst research.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The growth of the mutual fund industry is also being affected by increasing merger and acquisition activity within the asset management industry, which is reducing the number of asset managers offering mutual funds and ETFs, the pruning by some mutual fund and ETF platforms of the number of funds available for purchase, and the continuing impacts of regulation, such as MiFID II s requirement that asset managers pay banks and brokers for investment research, which may be a competitive advantage for larger asset managers better able to absorb such costs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Prolonged downturns or volatility in the financial markets, increased investor interest in other investment vehicles, or a lack of investor confidence could continue to reduce investor interest and investment activity.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P30_S2	In addition, a continued lessening of investor interest in actively managed equity funds could decrease demand for our products, including our software, data, and analyst research.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our business continuity program may not be adequate in the event of a material emergency affecting one or more of our United States or offshore business centers or adverse political or regulatory developments in countries in which we have significant data and development operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We have approximately 1,360 employees working at our corporate headquarters in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P32_S1	These include most of our executive leadership team as well as substantial numbers of employees involved in the delivery of most of our major products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P32_S2	If our headquarters were to become unusable due to a natural disaster, a violent incident or another dangerous emergency, we might not be able to continue business operations at an acceptable level that would meet all our legal and contractual commitments.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P32_S3	Our failure to successfully implement and deploy a business continuity plan, either at an enterprise level or with respect to particular business centers, could materially affect our business operations and have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We now have approximately 950 employees working in our data and technology development center in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We rely on these employees to maintain and update our mutual fund database and work on other projects.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Because China has a restrictive government under centralized control and the relationship between the United States and China is experiencing a period of increased political, military, and commercial tensions, our operations are subject to political and regulatory risk, which is inherently unpredictable.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Laws and regulations relating to data privacy, security, and protection of intellectual property rights in China, as well as the enforcement environment for such laws and regulations, are in certain cases uncertain and evolving.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P35_S1	In addition, this facility is subject from time to time to extreme weather events.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P36_S0	The concentration of certain types of development and data work carried out at this facility also involves operational risks for parts of our network infrastructure.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P36_S1	While we have short-term backup plans in place, it would be difficult for us to maintain and update our mutual fund database if we were unable to access our Shenzhen operations for an extended period of time.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P36_S2	Any difficulties that we face in continuing to operate our development center in China may harm our business and have a negative impact on the products and services we provide.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We have approximately 935 employees who work at our data collection, technology and operational center in Mumbai, India.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S1	These employees maintain and update our equity database and provide shared services to many of our operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S2	This location is subject to extreme weather events and political unrest, including public protests which can disrupt transportation and make it difficult for employees to commute to and from work.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S3	The electrical infrastructure of Mumbai is also subject to more frequent interruptions than are experienced at our other major facilities.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S4	In addition, Mumbai has experienced and may in the future experience terrorist attacks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P37_S5	While we have short-term backup plans in place to address such business continuity issues, it would be challenging for us to maintain and update our equity database or continue to provide certain shared services to our worldwide operations if we were unable to access our Mumbai operations for an extended period of time.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P38_S0	PitchBook, which we acquired in December 2016, has approximately 230 contract employees based in Calcutta and Pune, India who support its data and research operations and approximately 100 contract employees based in Ukraine who work on software development.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Ukraine has been subject to significant political unrest and military incursions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Any disruption to PitchBook's contract operations in these locations would make it difficult for PitchBook to meet its operating goals.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P40_S0	We could face liability related to our storage of personal information about individuals as well as portfolio and account-level information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Customers routinely enter personal investment and financial information, including portfolio holdings, account numbers, and credit card information, on our websites.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P41_S1	In addition, we handle increasing amounts of personally identifiable information in areas such as Morningstar Retirement Manager, Morningstar Managed Portfolios, ByAllAccounts, Morningstar Office, Enterprise Data Management, and Morningstar.com.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P42_S0	ByAllAccounts uses technology to collect, consolidate, and transform financial account data and deliver it to any platform, and accordingly handles a large volume of personally identifiable information as part of its normal business operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Any failure to safeguard this information could damage our reputation and business results.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P43_S1	We must continuously invest in systems, processes, and controls to guard against the risk of improper access to this information, which could be disclosed through employee errors, other inadvertent release, social engineering, failure to restrict access, or failure to properly purge and protect data.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P43_S2	We may suffer malicious attacks by individuals or groups seeking to attack our products and services or penetrate our network and databases to gain access to personal data or to launch or coordinate distributed denial of service attacks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P43_S3	These attacks have become increasingly frequent, sophisticated, and difficult to detect.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Contractual commitments to customers as well as laws and industry regulations related to data protection, system availability, and privacy require us to safeguard critical data.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S1	We are also required to take appropriate steps to safeguard credit card numbers, Social Security numbers, and other information about individuals or their accounts.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S2	In the European Union, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which will become effective in May 2018, will among other things impose stringent additional requirements regarding the information to be provided to, and the consents required from, individuals to justify a business using their personal data, as well as new rights of data subjects to be forgotten, data portability rights and the right to object to certain automated decision-making processes.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S3	Given the growing concern over data privacy and identity theft, we have been and expect to continue to be subject to increased scrutiny by clients and regulators.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S4	We could be subject to liability if we were to inappropriately collect, retain, or disclose any user's personal information or if third parties were able to penetrate our network security or otherwise gain access to any user's name, address, Social Security number, account numbers, portfolio holdings, credit card information, or other personal information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P44_S5	We could also be subject to liability if we fail to meet the requirements of laws and regulations such as the GDPR, which contemplate substantial enterprise-level penalties for non-compliance, in a timely or thorough manner.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Compliance failures, regulatory action, or changes in laws applicable to our investment advisory or credit rating operations could adversely affect our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S0	Our investment management operations are a growing part of our overall business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The securities laws and other laws that govern our investment advisory activities are complex.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S2	The activities of our investment advisory operations are subject to provisions of the Advisers Act and ERISA.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S3	In addition, Morningstar Investment Services is a broker-dealer registered under the Exchange Act and is subject to the rules of FINRA.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S4	We also provide investment advisory services in other areas around the world, and our operations are subject to additional regulations in markets outside the United States.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P46_S5	If we fail to comply with securities laws and other regulatory requirements, we may be subject to fines or other events that could have a negative effect on our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Over the past several years, we have also made significant investments in our credit rating business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S1	Our Morningstar Credit Ratings, LLC subsidiary is an NRSRO that specializes in structured finance, corporate credit issuers, and financial institutions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Credit rating and research providers continue to be subject to intensive regulatory scrutiny.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S3	As an NRSRO, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to various requirements and regulations under the Exchange Act relating to, among other things, record-keeping, reporting, governance, and conflicts of interest.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S4	As part of its NRSRO registration, Morningstar Credit Ratings is subject to annual examination by the SEC, as well as periodic investigations by the SEC and other governmental authorities relating to matters of regulatory interest such as industry practices and personnel matters.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P47_S5	The cost and management distraction resulting from such examinations and investigations may have a negative effect on our credit rating business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our index business could be negatively affected by increased regulation of benchmarks generally, which could increase the costs and risks of producing and administering indexes.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Such regulations may discourage market participants from continuing to use, administer or contribute to indexes, trigger changes in the rules or methodologies relating indexes, and/or lead to declining demand for indexes.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P49_S0	The laws, rules, and regulations, and their interpretations, applicable to our business may change in the future, and we may not be able to comply with these changes without extensive changes to our business practices.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P49_S1	In addition, the broad scope of our business operations makes it more difficult to monitor areas that may be subject to regulatory and compliance risk.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P49_S2	If we fail to comply with any applicable law, rule, or regulation, we could be fined, sanctioned, or barred from providing investment advisory, credit rating or index services in the future, which could adversely affect our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P50_S0	The success of our business depends upon our ability to deliver time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P50_S1	We rely primarily on our computer equipment, database storage facilities, and other network equipment, which is located across multiple facilities in the United States.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P50_S2	We also have extensive information systems outside the United States.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P50_S3	Our mission-critical databases and networks are complex and interdependent, which increases the risk of failure.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P50_S4	Problems in our network systems may lead to cascading effects involving product downtime, overloading of third-party data centers, and other issues that may affect our clients.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Many of our client contracts contain service-level agreements that require us to meet certain obligations for delivering time-sensitive, up-to-date data and information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P51_S1	We may not be able to meet these obligations in the event of failure or downtime in our information systems.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Our operations and those of our suppliers and customers are vulnerable to interruption by fire, earthquake, power loss, telecommunications failure, terrorist attacks, wars, computer viruses, and other events beyond our control.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Our database and network facilities may also be vulnerable to external attacks that misappropriate our data, corrupt our databases, or limit access to our information systems.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P52_S2	To defend against these threats, we implement a series of controls focusing on both prevention and detection, including firewalls, intrusion detection systems, automated scanning and testing, server hardening, anti-virus software, training, and patch management.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P52_S3	We make significant investments in servers, storage, and other network infrastructure to prevent incidents of network failure and downtime, but we cannot guarantee that these efforts will work as planned.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Most of our products and services currently depend heavily on our electronic delivery systems and the Internet, although we are shifting the delivery of several of our products and services to cloud-based delivery systems.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Our ability to deliver information using the Internet may be impaired because of infrastructure failures, service outages at third-party Internet providers, malicious attacks, or other factors.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P53_S2	If disruptions, failures, or slowdowns of our electronic delivery systems or the Internet occur, our ability to distribute our products and services effectively and to serve our customers may be impaired.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P54_S0	We maintain off-site back-up facilities for our data, but we cannot guarantee that these facilities will operate as expected during an interruption that affects our headquarters.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P54_S1	There may be single points of failure that affect our core databases, data transfer interfaces, or storage area networks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P54_S2	We may not be able to fully recover data or information lost during a database or network facility outage.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P54_S3	Any losses, service disruption, or damages incurred by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Our gradual movement of parts of our technological infrastructure to the public cloud and software as a service (SaaS) solutions presents a variety of additional risks, including risks relating to sharing the same computing resources with other users, the use by cloud and SaaS providers of virtualization products and various security issues relating thereto, reliance on cloud and SaaS providers authentication, authorization and access control mechanisms, a lack of control over cloud and SaaS providers redundancy systems and fault tolerances, and a reduced ability to directly address client concerns over data security and privacy.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P55_S1	Any disruption of or interference with our use of the public cloud or SaaS solutions, or any information security breach at any cloud or SaaS provider, could materially impact our operations and have an adverse effect on our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P55_S2	Over time, a growing dependence of our technology infrastructure on the public cloud and SaaS solutions also risks us becoming overly dependent on particular suppliers, which could adversely affect the pricing we receive from such suppliers and limit our ability to transition away from such suppliers in the event of service-quality issues.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Downturns in the financial sector, global financial markets, and global economy may hurt our results, resulting in lower revenue from asset-based fees, transaction-based revenue, or other parts of our business.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P57_S0	Our business results are partly driven by factors outside of our control, including general economic and financial market trends.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P57_S1	Any unfavorable changes in the environment we operate in could cause a corresponding negative effect on our business results.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P57_S2	As a result, we may experience lower revenue, operating income, and other financial results in the event of a market downturn.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P58_S0	Many of our customers are asset management firms and other financial services companies, which are also subject to external trends and changes.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P58_S1	For example, the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009 led to spending cutbacks among many of the companies to which we sell.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P58_S2	Some institutional clients have implemented additional review processes for new contracts or started providing certain services, such as investment management, in-house rather than hiring outside service providers.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P58_S3	Some institutional clients have also reduced the scope of their operations, and merger and acquisition activity in the asset management sector has in the past, and may in the future, reduce the number of potential asset management clients.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Many companies in the financial services industry have also been subject to increasing government regulation and pressure to reduce fees.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P59_S1	In turn, many of these firms have sought to reduce their operating costs by working with fewer service providers and/or negotiating lower fees for services they purchase.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P60_S0	In addition, our revenue from asset-based fees may be adversely affected by market declines, cash outflows from portfolios that we help manage, and the industry-wide trend toward lower asset-based fees.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P61_S0	In 2017, asset-based revenue made up approximately 21% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P61_S1	The amount of asset-based revenue we earn primarily depends on the value of assets on which we provide advisory services, and the size of our asset base can increase or decrease along with trends in market performance.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P62_S0	In 2017, the U.S. and many international markets experienced substantial valuation increases.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P62_S1	These market trends were highly favorable in terms of the value of assets we have under management or advisement, but there can be no assurance that these trends will continue and, if they do not, our asset-based revenue may be negatively affected.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P63_S0	Asset levels can also be affected if net inflows into the portfolios on which we provide investment advisory services drop or if these portfolios experience redemptions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P63_S1	A drop in net inflows or an increase in redemptions can result from a variety of factors, including overall market conditions and volatility or a decline in investment performance.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P63_S2	If the level of assets on which we provide investment advisory or investment management services goes down, we expect our fee-based revenue to show a corresponding decline.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Our business results may also be hurt by negative trends in Internet advertising sales, which made up about 3% of consolidated revenue in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P64_S1	Many advertisers have shifted some of their advertising spend to programmatic buying platforms that target users on other sites, which has from time to time had a negative effect on advertising revenue for our website for individual investors, Morningstar.com.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P64_S2	We are uncertain whether this trend will continue.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P65_S0	Our structured credit rating business, which made up about 3% of consolidated revenue in 2017, is subject to volatility from trends in new issuance of commercial mortgage-backed securities and other structured credits.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P65_S1	If industry-wide issuance for such securities declines, our revenue associated with this line of business may also go down.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P65_S2	We have also expanded our coverage to include corporate credit issuers and financial institutions, which are also subject to volatility in issuance patterns based on market conditions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P66_S0	Our PitchBook Data business may also be subject to cyclical trends.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P66_S1	Many of PitchBook's clients are investment banks and other participants in the capital and merger and acquisition markets, which are subject to periodic business downturns driven by changes in such markets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P66_S2	During these downturns, they often seek to reduce spending on third-party services as well as the number of employees, which would directly affect the number of prospective clients for PitchBook.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P67_S0	As a data and research provider focusing on the private capital markets (including venture capital, private equity, and M A), PitchBook may also be subject to volatility based on the amount of activity and market interest in these areas.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P68_S0	Our acquisitions and other investments may not produce the results we anticipate.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P68_S1	We have also incurred debt in connection with acquisitions, which may limit our financial flexibility.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S0	We've completed numerous acquisitions over the past 10 years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S1	This acquisition presents several potential challenges and risks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S2	We may not achieve the growth targets that we established for PitchBook at the time of the acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S3	The process of integration may require more resources than we anticipated.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S4	We may assume unintended liabilities or experience operating difficulties or costs that we did not anticipate.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S5	We may also fail to retain key personnel of the acquired business, including PitchBook founder and chief executive officer John Gabbert, which would make it difficult to follow through on our operating goals for the acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S6	If our acquisition of PitchBook does not generate the results we anticipate, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P69_S7	We may also fail to generate enough revenue or profits from this acquisition to earn a positive return on the associated purchase price.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P70_S0	To fund this acquisition, we increased the principal amount available for borrowing under our existing revolving credit facility to $300.0 million and extended the term of this facility to three years.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P70_S1	Under the terms of our agreement with the lender, we are now subject to certain restrictions and financial covenants, which may limit our financial flexibility.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P70_S2	As of December 31, 2017, borrowings in the principal amount of $180.0 million remain outstanding under such facility.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P71_S0	In 2017, we purchased a 40% interest in Sustainalytics Holding B.V. (Sustainalytics), a leading global provider of environmental, social and governance (ESG) research and ratings.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P71_S1	While we obtained various rights in connection with that investment, including representation on Sustainalytics Board of Directors, we do not own a controlling interest in Sustainalytics and the future value of our investment is highly dependent on the management skill of the managers of Sustainalytics.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P72_S0	We expect to continue making acquisitions and establishing investments and joint ventures as part of our long-term business strategy.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P73_S0	Acquisitions, investments, and joint ventures involve a number of risks.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P73_S1	They can be time-consuming and may divert management s attention from day-to-day operations, particularly if numerous acquisitions are in process at the same time.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P73_S2	Financing an acquisition could result in dilution from issuing equity securities, reduce our financial flexibility because of reductions in our cash balance, or result in a weaker balance sheet from incurring debt.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P74_S0	Our future success depends on our ability to recruit, develop, and retain qualified employees.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P75_S0	We experience competition for analysts, technology experts, and other employees from other companies and organizations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P75_S1	Competition for these employees is intense, and we may not be able to retain our existing employees or be able to recruit and retain other highly qualified personnel in the future.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Our future success also depends on the continued service of our executive officers, including Joe Mansueto, our executive chairman and controlling shareholder.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P76_S1	At the end of 2016, Joe changed his role to focus less on our day-to-day business operations, but he remains heavily involved our strategy and overall company direction.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P76_S2	The loss of Joe, our chief executive officer, Kunal Kapoor, or other executive officers could hurt our business, operating results, or financial condition.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P76_S3	We do not have employment agreements, non-compete agreements, or life insurance policies in place with any of our executive officers.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P76_S4	They may leave us and work for our competitors or start their own competing businesses.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P77_S0	Our operations outside of the United States involve additional challenges that we may not be able to meet.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Our operations outside of the United States generated $224.7 million in revenue in 2017, or about 25% of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P78_S1	There are risks inherent in doing business outside the United States, including challenges in reaching new markets because of established competitors and limited brand recognition; difficulties in staffing, managing, and integrating non-U.S. operations; difficulties in coordinating and sharing information globally; differences in laws and policies from country to country; exposure to varying legal standards, including intellectual property protection laws; potential tax exposure related to transfer pricing and other issues; heightened risk of fraud and noncompliance; and currency exchange rates and exchange controls.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P78_S2	These risks could hamper our ability to expand around the world, which may hurt our financial performance and ability to grow.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P79_S0	We don't engage in currency hedging or have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P79_S1	Our reported revenue could suffer if certain foreign currencies decline relative to the U.S. dollar, although the impact on operating income may be offset by an opposing currency impact on locally based operating expense.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P80_S0	We could face liability for the information we publish or the reports and other documents produced by our software products, including information, reports and documents based on data we obtain from other parties.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P81_S0	We may be subject to claims for securities law violations, defamation (including libel and slander), negligence, or other claims relating to the information we publish, including our research and ratings on issuers of structured credits and corporate credits.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P81_S1	For example, investors may take legal action against us if they rely on published information that contains an error, or a company may claim that we have made a defamatory statement about it or its employees.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P81_S2	Clients of our software products used by advisors or asset managers or governmental regulation of such clients may make claims against us based on software or data errors that affect investment reporting or client billing.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P81_S3	Even though most of our contracts for such products contain limitations of our liability in such cases, we may be required to make such clients or their customers whole for any losses in order to maintain our business relationships.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P81_S4	We could also be subject to claims based on the content that is accessible from our website through links to other websites.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P82_S0	We rely on a variety of outside parties as the original sources for the information we use in our published data.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P82_S1	These sources include securities exchanges, fund companies, hedge funds, transfer agents, and other data providers.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P82_S2	We also incorporate data from a variety of third-party sources for PitchBook Data.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P82_S3	Accordingly, in addition to possible exposure for publishing incorrect information that results directly from our own errors, we could face liability based on inaccurate data provided to us by others.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P83_S0	We could be subject to claims by providers of publicly available data and information we compile from websites and other sources that we have improperly obtained that data in violation of the source s copyrights or terms of use, or based on the provisions of new legislation such as GDPR that limits the bases on which businesses can collect personal information from and about individuals.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P83_S1	We could also be subject to claims from third parties from which we license data and information that we have used or re-distributed the data or information in ways not permitted by our license rights.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P83_S2	Defending claims based on the information we publish could be expensive and time-consuming and could adversely impact our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P84_S0	Failure to protect our intellectual property rights , or claims of intellectual property infringement against us, could harm our brand and ability to compete effectively.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P85_S0	The steps we have taken to protect our intellectual property may not be adequate to safeguard our proprietary information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P85_S1	We rely primarily on patent, trademark, copyright and trade secret rights, as well as contractual protections and technical safeguards, to protect our intellectual property rights and proprietary information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P85_S2	Despite these efforts, third parties may still attempt to challenge, invalidate or circumvent our rights or improperly obtain our proprietary information.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P85_S3	Further, effective trademark, copyright, and trade secret protection may not be available in every country in which we offer our services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P85_S4	Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property could harm our brand, devalue our proprietary content, and affect our ability to compete in the marketplace.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P86_S0	From time to time, we encounter jurisdictions in which one or more third parties have a pre-existing trademark registration in certain relevant international classes that may prevent us from registering our own marks in those jurisdictions.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P86_S1	Our continued ability to use the Morningstar name or logo, either on a stand-alone basis or in association with certain products or services, could be compromised in those jurisdictions because of these pre-existing registrations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P86_S2	Similarly, from time to time, we encounter situations in certain jurisdictions where one or more third parties are already using the Morningstar name, either as part of a registered corporate name, a registered domain name or otherwise.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P86_S3	Our ability to effectively market certain products and/or services in those locations could be adversely affected by these pre-existing usages.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S0	We have from time to time been subject to claims by third parties alleging infringement of their intellectual property rights.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S1	Such claims can also be alleged against clients, customers, or distributors of our products or services whom we have agreed to indemnify against third party claims of infringement.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S2	The defense of such claims can be costly and consume valuable management time and attention.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S3	We may be forced to settle such claims on unfavorable terms, which can include the payment of damages, the entry into royalty or licensing arrangements on commercially unfavorable terms, or the suspension of our ability to offer affected products or services.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S4	If litigation were to arise from any such claim, there can be no certainty we would prevail in it.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P87_S5	If any of these risks were to materialize, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P88_S0	Control by a principal shareholder could adversely affect our other shareholders.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P89_S0	As of December 31, 2017, Joe Mansueto, our executive chairman, owned approximately 57% of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P89_S1	As a result, he has the ability to control substantially all matters submitted to our shareholders for approval, including the election and removal of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P89_S2	He also has the ability to control our management and affairs.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P89_S3	This concentration of ownership may delay or prevent a change in control; impede a merger, consolidation, takeover, or other business combination involving Morningstar; discourage a potential acquirer from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain control of the company; or result in actions that may be opposed by other shareholders.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P90_S0	Fluctuations in our operating results may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S0	We believe our business has relatively large fixed costs and low variable costs, which magnify the impact of revenue fluctuations on our operating results.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S1	As a result, a decline in our revenue may lead to a larger decline in operating income.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S2	In addition, because we manage our business with a long-term perspective, we generally don t make significant adjustments to our strategy or cost structure in response to short-term factors.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S3	As a result, our operating results may suffer in the short term.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S4	In addition, we do not provide earnings guidance or hold one-on-one meetings with institutional investors and research analysts.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S5	Because of this policy and limited analyst coverage on our stock, our stock price may not always reflect the intrinsic value of our business and assets.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P91_S6	If our operating results or other operating metrics fail to meet the expectations of outside research analysts and investors, the market price of our common stock may decline.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P92_S0	The future sale of shares of our common stock may negatively affect our stock price.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P93_S0	If our shareholders sell substantial amounts of our common stock, the market price of our common stock could fall.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P93_S1	A reduction in ownership by Joe Mansueto or any other large shareholder could cause the market price of our common stock to fall.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P93_S2	In addition, the average daily trading volume in our stock is relatively low.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P93_S3	The lack of trading activity in our stock may lead to greater fluctuations in our stock price.
1289419_18_ITEM1A_P93_S4	Low trading volume may also make it difficult for shareholders to make transactions in a timely fashion.
1289419_18_ITEM1B_P0_S0	We do not have any unresolved comments from the Staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding our periodic or current reports under the Exchange Act.
1289419_18_ITEM2_P0_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , we leased approximately 457,000 square feet of office space for our U.S. operations, primarily for our corporate headquarters located in Chicago, Illinois.
1289419_18_ITEM2_P0_S1	We also lease another 435,000 square feet of office space in 26 other countries around the world, including approximately 141,000 square feet in Shenzhen, China.
1289419_18_ITEM2_P0_S2	We believe that our existing and planned office facilities are adequate for our needs and that additional or substitute space is available to accommodate growth and expansion.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P0_S0	In August 2017, Michael D. Green, individually and purportedly on behalf of all others similarly situated, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P0_S1	The complaint names as defendants Morningstar, Inc., Prudential Investment Management Services LLC, and Prudential Retirement Insurance and Annuity Co., and contains one count alleging violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).
1289419_18_ITEM3_P1_S0	Plaintiff, a participant in a pension plan, alleges that the defendants engaged in concerted racketeering actions to steer plan participants into high-cost investments that pay unwarranted fees to the defendants.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P1_S1	The complaint seeks unspecified compensatory damages for plaintiff and the members of the putative class, treble damages, injunctive relief, costs, and attorneys fees.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P1_S2	Morningstar has filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which is fully briefed and under advisement by the court.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P2_S0	Although Morningstar is vigorously contesting the claim asserted, we cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P3_S0	Other Matters We are involved from time to time in legal proceedings and litigation that arise in the normal course of our business.
1289419_18_ITEM3_P3_S1	While it is difficult to predict the outcome of any particular proceeding, we do not believe the result of any of these matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.

1289419_18_ITEM5_P5_S0	We paid four dividends during 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM5_P5_S1	Due to timing, we declared two dividends during the fourth quarter of 2017, one at 23 cents per share and one at 25 cents per share.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P5_S2	While subsequent dividends will be subject to board approval, we expect to pay a regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents per share in 2018 .
1289419_18_ITEM5_P6_S0	Any determination to pay dividends in the future will be at the discretion of our board of directors and will be dependent upon our results of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions, restrictions imposed by applicable law, and other factors deemed relevant by the board of directors.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P6_S1	Future indebtedness and loan facilities could also prohibit or restrict our ability to pay dividends and make distributions to our shareholders.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P7_S0	Subject to applicable law, we may repurchase shares at prevailing market prices directly on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions in amounts that we deem appropriate.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P8_S0	We had an ongoing authorization, originally approved by our board of directors in September 2010, and subsequently amended, to repurchase up to $1.0 billion in shares of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P8_S1	The authorization expired on December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P8_S2	On December 8, 2017, the board of directors approved a new share repurchase program that authorizes the company to repurchase up to $500.0 million in shares of the company's outstanding common stock, effective January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM5_P8_S3	The authorization expires on December 31, 2020.

1289419_18_ITEM5_P10_S2	Morningstar will not receive any proceeds, other than proceeds from the exercise of stock options, related to these transactions.
