1289419_18_ITEM6_P0_S0	The selected historical financial data shown below should be read in conjunction with Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. We have derived our Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 , and 2015 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P0_S1	The Consolidated Statements of Income Data and Consolidated Cash Flow Data for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 and Consolidated Balance Sheet Data as of December 31, 2015 , 2014 , and 2013 were derived from our audited Consolidated Financial Statements that are not included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Operating income and free cash flow for 2014 included a $61.0 million litigation settlement expense and corresponding cash outflow.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P2_S0	(2) Non-operating income in 2016 included a $37.1 million holding gain related to the purchase of the remaining ownership interest in PitchBook, which was previously a minority investment.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P2_S1	Non-operating income in 2017 includes a $16.7 million gain related to the sale of HelloWallet.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P3_S0	(3) Free cash flow is considered a non-GAAP financial measure under SEC regulations.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P3_S1	We present this measure as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P3_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P3_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required to be reported under GAAP, nor should this data be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P3_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P4_S0	(4) Cash provided by (used for) investing activities consists primarily of cash used for acquisitions, purchases of investments, net of proceeds from the sale of investments, capital expenditures, purchases of equity and cost- method investments, and proceeds from the sale of businesses.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P4_S1	The level of investing activities can vary from period to period depending on the level of activity in these categories.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P4_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for investing activities.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P5_S0	(5) Cash provided by (used for) financing activities consists primarily of cash used to repurchase outstanding common stock through our share repurchase program and dividend payments.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P5_S1	These cash outflows are partially offset by proceeds from our revolving credit facility, stock option exercises, and excess tax benefits.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P5_S2	Refer to Item 7 Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information concerning cash used for financing activities.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P6_S0	(6) We frequently invoice or collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers and record these balances as deferred revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P6_S1	These amounts represent both current and non-current deferred revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM6_P7_S0	(7) Long-term liabilities in 2016 and 2017 includes $250.0 million and $180.0 million of long-term debt, respectively.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	The discussion included in this section, as well as other sections of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, contains forward-looking statements as that term is used in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P0_S1	These statements are based on our current expectations about future events or future financial performance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P0_S2	Forward-looking statements by their nature address matters that are, to different degrees, uncertain, and often contain words such as may, could, expect, intend, plan, seek, anticipate, believe, estimate, predict, potential, or continue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P0_S3	These statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause the events we discuss not to occur or to differ significantly from what we expect.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P0_S4	For us, these risks and uncertainties include, among others:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	the failure to protect our intellectual property rights or claims of intellectual property infringement against us.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	A more complete description of these risks and uncertainties can be found in Item 1A Risk Factors of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	If any of these risks and uncertainties materialize, our actual future results may vary significantly from what we expected.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P2_S2	We do not undertake to update our forward-looking statements as a result of new information or future events.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P3_S0	All dollar and percentage comparisons, which are often accompanied by words such as increase, decrease, grew, declined, was up, was down, was flat, or was similar refer to a comparison with the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our mission is to create great products that help investors reach their financial goals.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P4_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for individual investors, financial advisors, asset managers, retirement plan providers and sponsors, and institutional investors in the private capital markets.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P4_S2	Many of our products are sold through subscriptions or license agreements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P4_S3	As a result, we typically generate recurring revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S0	We generate revenue by selling a variety of investment-related products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S1	We sell many of our products and services, including Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Research, and PitchBook Data, through license agreements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S2	Our license agreements typically range from one to three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S3	We sell some of our other products, such as Premium Membership service on Morningstar.com, via subscriptions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S4	These subscriptions are mainly offered for a one-year term, although we offer terms ranging from one month to three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S5	We also sell advertising on our websites throughout the world.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P5_S6	In our credit ratings business, we generate transaction-based revenue for our ratings on new issues of commercial mortgage-backed securities and other structured credits.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	Our investment management business has multiple fee structures, which vary by client and region.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S1	In general, we seek to receive asset-based fees for any work we perform that involves managing investments or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S2	For any individual contract, we may receive flat fees, variable asset-based fees, or a combination of the two.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S3	Some of our contracts include minimum fee levels that provide us with a flat payment up to a specified asset level, above which we also receive variable asset-based fees.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S4	In the majority of our contracts that include variable asset-based fees, we bill clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P6_S5	Other contracts may include provisions for monthly billing or billing based on assets as of the last day of the billing period rather than on average assets.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P7_S0	In our Workplace Solutions area, our contracts may include one-time setup fees, technology licensing fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P7_S1	We also offer plan sponsor advice and custom target-date consulting arrangements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P7_S2	Fees for these services may be based on the level of assets under advisement.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P8_S0	For Morningstar Managed Portfolios, we charge asset-based fees, which are based on a tiered schedule that depends on the client s account balance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P9_S0	We invoice some of our clients and collect cash in advance of providing services or fulfilling subscriptions for our customers.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P9_S1	We use some of this cash to fund our operations and invest in new product development.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P9_S2	Deferred revenue is the largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and, at the end of 2017 , totaled $185.5 million (of which $171.3 million was classified as a current liability with an additional $14.2 million included in other long-term liabilities).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P9_S3	At the end of 2016 , the amount of deferred revenue was $179.5 million (of which $165.4 million was classified as a current liability with an additional $14.1 million included in other long-term liabilities).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P9_S4	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill the service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P10_S0	In recent years, our deferred revenue balance has increased at a more moderate rate, partly because we've been issuing more quarterly and monthly invoices versus up-front, annual invoices.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P10_S1	In addition, as we ve discontinued some subscription-based products, we have less subscription-based revenue contributing to the deferred revenue balance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P10_S2	Our acquisition of PitchBook in 2016 also contributed to the increase in deferred revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S0	Our business requires significant investments to create and maintain proprietary software, databases, and content.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S1	While the fixed costs of the investments we make in our business are relatively high, the variable cost of adding customers is relatively low.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S2	This reflects our business focus on Internet-based platforms and assets under management.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S3	At times, we may make investments in building our databases and content that cause weaker short-term operating results.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S4	During other periods, our profitability may improve because we're able to increase revenue without increasing our cost base at the same rate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P11_S5	When revenue decreases, however, we may not be able to adjust our cost base at a corresponding rate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P12_S0	We classify our operating expense into separate categories for cost of revenue, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and depreciation and amortization, as described below.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P12_S1	We include stock-based compensation expense, as appropriate, in each of these categories.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P13_S0	This category includes compensation expense for employees who produce the products and services we deliver to our customers.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P13_S1	For example, this category covers production teams and analysts who write investment research reports.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P13_S2	It also includes compensation expense for programmers, designers, and other employees who develop new products and enhance existing products.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	In some cases, we capitalize the compensation costs associated with certain software development projects.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P14_S1	This reduces the expense that we would otherwise report in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P14_S2	Cost of revenue also includes other expense such as third-party data purchases and data lines.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our sales teams, product managers, and marketing professionals.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P15_S1	We also include the cost of advertising, direct mail campaigns, and other marketing and promotion efforts in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P16_S0	This category includes compensation expense for our management team and other corporate functions, including employees in our compliance, finance, human resources, and legal departments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P16_S1	It also includes costs for corporate systems and facilities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P17_S0	Our capital expenditures are mainly for capitalized software development costs, information technology equipment, and leasehold improvements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P17_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful lives of the assets, which range from three to seven years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P17_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P17_S3	We amortize capitalized software development costs over their estimated economic life, generally three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P17_S4	We also include amortization related to identifiable intangible assets, which is mainly driven by acquisitions, in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P18_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated economic useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P19_S0	As of December 31, 2017, we had majority-owned operations in 26 countries outside of the United States and included their results of operations and financial condition in our consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P19_S1	We account for certain minority-owned investments, including Morningstar Japan K.K. (MJKK), using the equity method.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	When our analysts evaluate a stock, they focus on assessing the company's estimated intrinsic value, which is based on estimated future cash flows, discounted to their value in today's dollars.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	Our approach to evaluating our own business works the same way.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	Our goal is to increase the intrinsic value of our business over time, which we believe is the best way to create value for our shareholders.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	We do not make public financial forecasts for our business because we want to avoid creating any incentives for our management team to make speculative statements about our financial results that could influence our stock price or take actions that help us meet short-term forecasts but may not build long-term shareholder value.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P22_S0	We provide three specific measures that can help investors generate their own assessment of how our intrinsic value has changed over time:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P23_S0	Organic revenue and free cash flow are not measures of performance set forth under GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P24_S0	We define organic revenue as consolidated revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P24_S1	We present organic revenue because we believe it helps investors better compare our period-to-period results, and our management team uses this measure to evaluate the performance of our business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P24_S2	We exclude revenue from businesses acquired or divested from organic revenue for a period of 12 months after we complete the acquisition or divestiture.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P24_S3	Organic revenue is not equivalent to any measure required under GAAP and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P25_S0	We define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P25_S1	We present free cash flow as supplemental information to help investors better understand trends in our business results over time.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P25_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P25_S3	Free cash flow is not equivalent to any measure required under GAAP and should not be considered an indicator of liquidity.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P25_S4	Moreover, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P26_S0	To evaluate how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue, we calculate retention and renewal rates using two different methods.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P27_S0	For subscription-based products, we calculate a retention rate based on the number of subscriptions retained during the year as a percentage of the number of subscriptions up for renewal.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P27_S1	For products sold through contracts and licenses, we use the contract value method, which is based on tracking the dollar value of renewals compared with the total dollar value of contracts up for renewal during the period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P27_S2	We include changes in the contract value in the renewal amount, unless the change specifically results from adding a new product that we can identify.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P27_S3	We also include variable-fee contracts in this calculation and use the previous quarter's actual revenue as the base rate for calculating the renewal percentage.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P27_S4	The renewal rate excludes setup and customization fees, migrations to other Morningstar products, and contract renewals that were pending as of January 31, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P28_S0	We monitor developments in the economic and financial information industry on an ongoing basis.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P28_S1	We use these insights to help inform our company strategy, product development plans, and marketing initiatives.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P29_S0	2017 was a strong year for equities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P29_S1	With the bull market in U.S. equities fast approaching its nine-year anniversary, we ve seen a growing tendency for diversification outside of the United States.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P29_S2	Morningstar's U.S. Market Index, a broad market benchmark, ended the year with a robust 21.5% gain; however, international equities as a group fared slightly better.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P29_S3	Morningstar s Global Markets ex-U.S. Index finished the year up 28.0%, with the Developed Markets ex-U.S. Index up 25.5% and the Emerging Markets Index up almost 36.0%.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P30_S0	The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates three times in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P30_S1	However, all bond categories were still able to deliver healthy returns because the long end of the yield curve was relatively flat in the last year.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P31_S0	Based on Morningstar Asset Flows data, total U.S. mutual fund assets edged up to $18.1 trillion as of December 31, 2017, compared with $15.1 trillion as of December 31, 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P32_S0	ETFs continued to increase in popularity relative to traditional mutual funds.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P32_S1	The U.S. ETF industry closed out 2017 with $3.4 trillion in assets under management based on Morningstar Asset Flows data, up from about $2.5 trillion as of December 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P33_S0	Based on our analysis of fund flow trends, long-term mutual funds and exchange traded products had aggregate net inflows of about $680 billion in 2017, up significantly from about $160 billion in 2016, and outpacing the most recent record of $460 billion set in 2014.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P33_S1	Net outflows in actively managed mutual funds slowed to $7 billion in 2017 versus $340 billion in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P33_S2	Nevertheless, the overall decline remains consistent with the trend of investor preference for passively managed funds, which experienced over $690 billion in net inflows in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P34_S0	In addition to industry developments in 2017, there are several longer-term trends we consider relevant to our business, as outlined below.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P35_S0	In the wake of the financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, regulators have continued to implement new frameworks for financial services companies globally.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P35_S1	Many of these rules relate to financial advisor compensation, fees and expenses, investor disclosure, and the use of hedge funds and alternative investments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P36_S0	In the United Kingdom, for example, the Retail Distribution Review (RDR), which emphasizes increased regulation of advisory fees, higher professional standards for financial advisors, and "whole of market" investment solutions, became effective in January 2013.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P36_S1	The RDR also restricted the use of commission payments for products sold to individual investors, although UK regulators are reportedly considering changes to this restriction.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P36_S2	The UK regulator is monitoring the implementation of RDR and is scheduled to publish a review of its findings in 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P37_S0	In addition to the RDR, the UK regulator and Her Majesty's Treasury (HMT) launched the Financial Advice Market Review (FAMR) in 2015 in light of concerns that the market for financial advice was not working well for consumers.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P37_S1	FAMR aimed to explore ways in which the government, industry, and regulators could take collective steps to stimulate the development of a market which delivers affordable and accessible financial advice and guidance to everyone.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P37_S2	FAMR's final report, published in March 2016, set out 28 recommendations intended to tackle barriers to consumers accessing advice.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P37_S3	The FCA and HMT will review the outcomes of FAMR in 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	In the European Union, the new version of the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive, also known as MiFID II, became effective in January 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	The main provisions include, among other things, limits on portfolio managers' use of third-party research, quality and organizational rules regarding the provision of advice, additional governance requirements for the manufacturing and distribution of financial instruments and structured deposits, requirements for firms to provide clients with details of all costs and charges related to their investments, and new rules for disclosing the cumulative effect of costs on investor returns.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	With respect to indexes, European Union Benchmarks Regulation 2016/1011 came into force on June 30, 2016 with a majority of its provisions having a compliance date of January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P39_S1	The principal objective of the Regulation is to ensure benchmarks used in financial instruments and financial contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds (e.g., a tracking index of a ETF) are free of conflicts of interest, are used appropriately and reflect the actual market or economic reality they are intended to measure.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P39_S2	This Regulation applies to Morningstar s index group as a result of making available its indexes to European investable product sponsors (e.g., ETF sponsors) as the tracking index for their investable product.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	In Australia, in an effort to improve trust and confidence in the financial services industry, the government has announced many regulatory reforms and inquiries ranging from enhanced enforcement powers for the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), new reforms to significantly raise the professional, educational and ethical standards of financial advisors, and a Royal Commission into the alleged misconduct of Australia's banks and other financial services entities with broad terms of reference and the potential to impact many aspects of the financial services industry.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P40_S1	ASIC has been actively enforcing the Future of Financial Advice reforms that began in July 2013 with actions against financial advisors who failed to act in the best interest of clients and a review of the five largest vertically integrated financial institutions and their management of conflicts of interest.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P40_S2	The fund management industry also continues to be an area of regulatory reform with the introduction of the Asia Region Funds Passport and Corporate Collective Investment Schemes, the implementation of new costs and fee disclosure for managed investment and superannuation funds, and a proposed update and overhaul of regulatory guidance for fund managers.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	In the United States, the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) published a final version of a new fiduciary standard that would expand the definition of a fiduciary for certain financial advisors who provide advice related to retirement planning.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	The new rule was previously scheduled to go into effect in April 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P41_S2	Parts of the rule went into effect in June 2017 but full implementation of the rule has been pushed back to July 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P41_S3	The SEC is also considering possible rulemaking in this area.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P41_S4	In December 2017, the SEC released its updated agenda of regulatory priorities in 2018 and beyond, which listed rulemaking regarding a Personalized Investment Advice Standard of Conduct (i.e., a fiduciary standard) as being at the shorter-term proposed rulemaking stage.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	Despite this uncertainty, we believe recent shifts, such as a greater emphasis on serving investors interests and lowering fees, are fundamental changes that will continue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	We've introduced several new product offerings and bundled solutions to help financial advisors determine, demonstrate, and document that their advice is in the best interest of the investor.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P42_S2	We believe Morningstar is well-positioned to help our clients adapt to this new landscape and have had many positive discussions with financial advisors and asset managers about the solutions we can provide.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P42_S3	In particular, we ve increased our manager research coverage in response to growing demand for information that helps financial advisors show investors the thought process behind their investment recommendations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	The tables below summarize our key product metrics and other supplemental data.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	(1) Included for informational purposes only; Morningstar did not acquire full ownership of PitchBook until December 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	(2) The asset totals shown above (including assets we either manage directly or for which we provide consulting or subadvisory work) only include assets for which we receive basis-point fees.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P45_S1	Some of our client contracts include services for which we receive a flat fee, but we do not include those assets in the total reported above.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P46_S0	Excluding changes related to new contracts and cancellations, changes in the value of assets under advisement can come from two primary sources: gains or losses related to overall trends in market performance, and net inflows or outflows caused when investors add to or redeem shares from these portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P47_S0	Except for Morningstar Managed Portfolios, it's difficult for our Investment Management business to quantify these cash inflows and outflows.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P47_S1	The information we receive from most of our clients does not separately identify the effect of cash inflows and outflows on asset balances for each period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P47_S2	We also cannot specify the effect of market appreciation or depreciation because the majority of our clients have discretionary authority to implement their own portfolio allocations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P48_S0	(3) Many factors can cause changes in assets under management and advisement for our managed retirement accounts, including employer and employee contributions, plan administrative fees, market movements, and participant loans and hardship withdrawals.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P48_S1	The information we receive from the plan providers does not separately identify these transactions or the changes in balances caused by market movement.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P49_S0	(5) Revised to include assets from South Africa.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P50_S0	(6) Decline due to client losses related to a strategic shift away from our customized investment management offerings to Managed Portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P51_S0	(7) Includes commercial mortgage-backed securities, residential mortgage-backed securities, other asset-backed securities, and corporate and financial institutions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P52_S0	(8) Revised to exclude temporary employees and part-time employees who work less than 30 hours a week.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P53_S0	(9) Key product and investment area revenue and revenue by type includes the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P54_S0	(10) Revised to exclude Morningstar Office.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P55_S0	Excluding the negative 6.5 percentage point impact of the HelloWallet divestiture, revenue increased by 9.7% for the full year.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P56_S0	(12) License-based revenue includes Morningstar Data, Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Advisor Workstation, Morningstar Enterprise Components, Morningstar Research, PitchBook Data, and other similar products.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P57_S0	(13) Asset-based revenue includes Morningstar Investment Management, Workplace Solutions, and Morningstar Indexes.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P58_S0	(14) Transaction-based revenue includes Morningstar Credit Ratings, Internet advertising sales, and Conferences.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P59_S0	We define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P59_S1	Please refer to the discussion in How We Evaluate our Business for more detail.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P60_S0	In 2017 and 2016 , our consolidated revenue rose 14.2% and 1.2% , respectively.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P60_S1	Our acquisition of PitchBook Data, Inc. (PitchBook) in December 2016 contributed $57.2 million of revenue growth during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P60_S2	Foreign currency movements had no net material impact on revenue in 2017 and reduced revenue by $ 9.5 million in 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	We experienced strong revenue growth across all revenue types during 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	License-based revenue grew 15.6% during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P62_S1	We experienced stronger growth rates for license-based products such as Morningstar Direct and Morningstar Data.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P62_S2	Revenue from Morningstar Direct was the biggest contributor to growth in both 2017 and 2016 , with revenue increasing by $13.9 million in 2017 and $8.8 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P62_S3	The number of licenses for Morningstar Direct increased to 13,884 worldwide at the end of 2017, compared with 12,492 at the end of 2016 and 11,428 at the end of 2015, with modest growth in both the United States and internationally.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P62_S4	Growth in Morningstar Direct reflects additional licenses for both new and existing clients.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P63_S0	Morningstar Data revenue increased $10.9 million in 2017, mainly reflecting new contracts and renewals for managed products data and our market data business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P64_S0	Asset-based revenue increased 10.3% during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P64_S1	Morningstar Managed Portfolios and Workplace Solutions were the primary drivers of the increase.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P65_S0	The asset-based fees we earn are generally based on average asset levels during each quarter.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P65_S1	Average assets under management and advisement (calculated based on available average quarterly or monthly data) were approximately $207.9 billion in 2017 , compared with $192.8 billion in 2016 and $179.9 billion in 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P66_S0	Transaction-based revenue grew 11.1% during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P66_S1	Revenue from Morningstar Credit Ratings (our structured credit ratings business) increased $5.0 million during the year, primarily due to new-issue growth in asset-backed securities partially offset by a slight decrease in ratings on commercial mortgage-backed securities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	Some of the main contributors to the 2016 revenue increase were Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Data, and Workplace Solutions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P67_S1	Positive results for these products were partially offset by decreases in Morningstar Credit Ratings and Internet advertising sales on Morningstar.com.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	In December 2016, we acquired the remaining interest in PitchBook, which contributed $4.1 million of revenue during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	To make it easier to compare our results in different periods, we provide information about organic revenue, which reflects our underlying business excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P69_S1	In 2017, we divested HelloWallet and did not make any acquisitions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P69_S2	During 2016, we acquired Requisight, LLC (RightPond), InvestSoft Technology, Inc. (InvestSoft), and PitchBook Data, Inc. (PitchBook).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P69_S3	We did not divest any businesses in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P70_S0	We exclude revenue from acquired businesses from our organic revenue growth calculation for a period of 12 months after we complete the acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P70_S1	Contribution from PitchBook was treated as acquired revenue through November 2017 and was incorporated into organic growth statistics after December 1, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	For divestitures, we exclude revenue in the prior period for which there is no comparable revenue in the current period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P71_S1	Because HelloWallet was divested in the second quarter of 2017, we excluded HelloWallet's last six months of 2016 revenue from our organic revenue growth calculation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	In 2017 , we had $57.5 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions, primarily from PitchBook.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P72_S1	Revenue in 2016 included $4.4 million of revenue from HelloWallet, which we divested in the second quarter of 2017, and that did not recur in the second half of 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P72_S2	In addition, foreign currency translations had no net material impact on revenue in 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P72_S3	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 7.6% in 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P73_S0	In 2016 , we had $5.5 million in incremental revenue from acquisitions, primarily from PitchBook.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P73_S1	In addition, foreign currency translations reduced revenue by about $9.5 million in 2016 , mainly because of the weaker British pound and Canadian dollar.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P73_S2	Excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign currency translations, organic revenue was up 1.7% in 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P74_S0	The tables below reconcile consolidated revenue with organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations):
1289419_18_ITEM7_P75_S0	Organic revenue (revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P75_S1	The definition of organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P75_S2	Organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P76_S0	International revenue made up about 25% of our consolidated revenue in 2017 , compared with 26% in both 2016 and 2015 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P76_S1	About 60% of our international revenue is from Continental Europe and the United Kingdom.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P76_S2	We also have a fairly large revenue base in Australia and Canada.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P77_S0	Revenue from international operations increased $16.6 million, or 8.0% , in 2017 and international organic revenue increased 8.0% .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P78_S0	In 2016, revenue from international operations increased 2.2% and international organic revenue increased 6.8%.

1289419_18_ITEM7_P81_S0	International organic revenue (international revenue excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations) is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P81_S1	The definition of international organic revenue we use may not be the same as similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P81_S2	International organic revenue should not be considered an alternative to any measure of performance as promulgated under GAAP.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P82_S0	As discussed in How We Evaluate Our Business, we calculate retention and renewal rates to help measure how successful we've been in maintaining existing business for products and services that have renewable revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P82_S1	The graph below illustrates these two metrics over the past five years:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P83_S0	For contract-based products and services (such as Morningstar Data including PitchBook, Investment Advisory services, Morningstar Direct, and Morningstar Advisor Workstation), we estimate that our weighted average annual renewal rate was approximately 102% in 2017 , compared with 96% in 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P83_S1	The increase mainly reflects higher renewal rates for some larger products, including Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Investment Management, Workplace Solutions, Morningstar Research, and PitchBook.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P83_S2	The figure for contract-based products includes the effect of price changes; increasing client bases upon contract renewal; changes to the contract value upon renewal (such as increased users); and changes in the value of variable-fee contracts.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P83_S3	These factors, therefore, can lead to a renewal rate percentage over 100%.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P84_S0	In 2017 , we estimate that our annual retention rate for subscription-based products, including Morningstar.com's Premium Membership service, Morningstar Office, and newsletter products, was approximately 66%, which was unchanged from 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P85_S0	In 2017 , our operating expense was up $124.1 million , or 20.1% .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P85_S1	Foreign currency translations reduced our operating expense by $0.6 million in 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P86_S0	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $76.0 million of operating expense, primarily for salaries, amortization expense, professional fees, commission expense, and management bonus expense during the year.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P86_S1	PitchBook expenses exceeded revenue in 2017, primarily due to $10.6 million of deal-related intangible amortization and $7.9 million of vesting of performance share awards associated with the acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P86_S2	PitchBook also had $4.6 million of capitalized labor during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P87_S0	The remaining increase was primarily a result of higher compensation expense (including salaries, bonus, and other company-sponsored benefits), depreciation expense, professional fees, and production expense, which includes third-party data and infrastructure hosting.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P88_S0	Excluding PitchBook, compensation expense (including salaries and other company-sponsored benefits) increased $16.2 million in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P88_S1	Bonus expense also increased $14.5 million in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P88_S2	Bonus expense was higher due to stronger performance against our internal targets.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P89_S0	Depreciation expense in 2017 includes a $4.1 million impairment charge for certain software licenses due to a shift toward a cloud-based strategy.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P90_S0	Partially offsetting our total operating expense increase was an increase in internally developed capitalized software.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P90_S1	We have accelerated development of our major software platforms, resulting in an increase in capitalized software development, which reduced operating expense.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P90_S2	In 2017, we capitalized $41.7 million, which excludes the PitchBook capitalized labor noted above, associated with software development activities, mainly related to Morningstar Data, Workplace Solutions, and additional enhancements to reporting, financial planning, and other capabilities in our products.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P90_S3	In comparison, we capitalized $28.2 million of software development expense in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P91_S0	We had approximately 4,920 employees worldwide at the end of 2017, compared with 4,550 in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P91_S1	This increase reflects continued investment in our key growth initiatives, including data operations in India and China and PitchBook in the United States and Europe.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P92_S0	In 2016, our operating expense was up $19.6 million, or 3.3%.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P92_S1	Due to the strength of the U.S. dollar, foreign currency translations reduced our operating expense by $11.5 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P93_S0	Compensation expense (including salaries and other company-sponsored benefits) increased $26.2 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P93_S1	We had approximately 4,550 employees worldwide at the end of 2016, compared with 3,880 in 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P93_S2	This increase reflects continued investment in our key growth initiatives and mainly includes technology, sales, and analyst roles in the United States, India, and China.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P93_S3	The growth in compensation expense was partially offset by a $13.1 million reduction in bonus expense during 2016 compared to 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P93_S4	Bonus expense was lower mainly because we did not meet our internal targets for revenue growth during 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P94_S0	Depreciation expense, professional fees, and production expense also increased during 2016 as we continued to invest in our business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P94_S1	We have also accelerated development of our major software platforms and therefore had an increase in capitalized software development, which reduced operating expense.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P95_S0	In 2016, we capitalized $28.2 million of software development expense for ongoing enhancements of key platforms and new development of upgraded software platforms.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P95_S1	In comparison, we capitalized $ 21.8 million of software development expense in 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P96_S0	Sales commission expense decreased $2.8 million in 2016, reflecting declines in new sales closed.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P97_S0	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $7.5 million of operating expense, primarily for salaries, professional fees, and amortization expense during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P98_S0	Cost of revenue is our largest category of operating expense, representing about one-half of our total operating expense.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P98_S1	Our business relies heavily on human capital, and cost of revenue includes the compensation expense for employees who produce our products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P98_S2	We include compensation expense for approximately 80% of our employees in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P99_S0	Cost of revenue increased $42.3 million , or 12.3% , in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P99_S1	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $14.0 million of operating expense in this cost category, primarily for professional fees, salary expense, and capitalized labor during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P99_S2	The remaining increase was largely due to higher salary expense of $13.6 million, mainly driven by additional headcount.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P99_S3	Higher bonus expense, professional fees, and production expense also contributed to the increase in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P100_S0	Partially offsetting these increases was an increase in internally developed capitalized software.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P100_S1	We have accelerated development of our major software platforms, resulting in an increase in capitalized software development, which reduced operating expense.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P100_S2	During 2017, we capitalized $41.7 million, which excludes the PitchBook capitalized labor noted above, associated with software development activities, mainly related to Morningstar Data, Workplace Solutions, and additional enhancements to reporting, financial planning, and other capabilities in our products.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P100_S3	In comparison, we capitalized $28.2 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P101_S0	Cost of revenue increased $14.2 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P101_S1	Higher salary expense of $19.9 million was the largest contributor to the increase and was mainly driven by additional headcount.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P101_S2	Higher company-sponsored benefits and software subscriptions also contributed to the growth in this category.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P102_S0	Partially offsetting these increases was a $9.1 million decrease in bonus expense, as well as an increase in capitalized software development.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P102_S1	As mentioned above, we capitalized $28.2 million associated with software development activities in 2016, compared with $21.8 million included in 2015 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P103_S0	PitchBook contributed $1.3 million of operating expense in this cost category, primarily for salary expense during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P104_S0	As a percentage of revenue, cost of revenue decreased 0.7 percentage points in 2017 and increased 1.2 percentage points in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P105_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $36.7 million , or 37.6% , in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P105_S1	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $34.9 million of operating expense in this cost category, primarily for salary and sales commission expense in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P105_S2	The remaining increase was due to an increase in sales commission expense of $3.7 million, partially offset by decreases in compensation expense (including salaries and other company-sponsored benefits), advertising and marketing spend, and professional fees.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P106_S0	Sales and marketing expense increased $1.0 million in 2016, reflecting a $2.7 million increase in compensation expense (including salaries and other company-sponsored benefits) and a $1.0 million increase in advertising and marketing spend.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P106_S1	Partly offsetting these increases were decreases in sales commission expense of $1.9 million and bonus expense of $1.0 million.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P107_S0	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $2.7 million during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P108_S0	As a percentage of revenue, sales and marketing expense increased 2.5 percentage points in 2017 and was unchanged in 2016 compared to 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P109_S0	General and administrative expense increased $24.6 million , or 23.3% , during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P109_S1	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $16.1 million of operating expense in this cost category, primarily for management bonus plan expense and salary expense during 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P109_S2	Bonus expense, software subscriptions, and rent expense contributed to the remaining increase in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P110_S0	General and administrative expense decreased $1.9 million in 2016, mainly because of a $3.0 million decline in bonus expense and a $2.0 million decline in stock-based compensation expense.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P110_S1	Partially offsetting these decreases was an increase of $3.8 million in professional fees in connection with legal and compliance and other company initiatives.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P110_S2	Compensation expense (including salaries and other company-sponsored benefits) also increased $0.9 million.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P111_S0	PitchBook contributed $2.5 million in 2016, primarily for salary expense, professional fees, and management bonus plan expense during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P112_S0	General and administrative expense as a percentage of revenue was up 1.0 percentage points in 2017 and down 0.4 percentage points in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P113_S0	Overall, depreciation and amortization increased $20.5 million , or 28.9% , in 2017 and $6.3 million , or 9.9% , in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P114_S0	Our acquisition of PitchBook contributed $11.0 million of operating expense in this cost category in 2017 and $0.9 million in 2016, primarily for intangible amortization expense related to the acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P115_S0	Depreciation expense rose $16.3 million in 2017 , mainly driven by depreciation expense related to capitalized software development and computer equipment incurred over the past several years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P115_S1	Depreciation expense during 2017 also includes a $4.1 million impairment charge for certain software licenses due to a shift toward a cloud- based strategy.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P115_S2	Intangible amortization expense increased $4.2 million in 2017 due to additional amortization expense for the intangible assets of PitchBook offset by certain intangible assets from some previous acquisitions that are now fully amortized.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P116_S0	Depreciation expense rose $8.9 million in 2016, mainly driven by higher capital expenditures for computer equipment and additional depreciation expense for capitalized software development.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P116_S1	Intangible amortization expense decreased $2.6 million in 2016 as certain intangible assets from some previous acquisitions are now fully amortized.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P117_S0	We expect that amortization of intangible assets will be an ongoing cost.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P117_S1	We estimate that this expense will total approximately $20.7 million in 2018 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P117_S2	Our estimates of future amortization expense for intangible assets may be affected by additional acquisitions, divestitures, changes in the estimated average useful lives, and foreign currency translation.

1289419_18_ITEM7_P118_S1	Operating margin was 18.6% , down 4.0 percentage points compared with 2016.

1289419_18_ITEM7_P119_S1	Operating margin was 22.6% , down 1.6 percentage points compared with 2015.
