1289419_18_ITEM7_P130_S0	The following table summarizes the components of our effective tax rate:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P131_S0	On December 22, 2017, the United States enacted tax reform legislation that included a broad range of business tax provisions, including but not limited to a reduction in the U.S. federal tax rate from 35% to 21% as well as provisions that limit or eliminate various deductions or credits.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P131_S1	The legislation also causes U.S. allocated expenses (e.g. interest and general administrative expenses) to be taxed and imposes a new tax on U.S. cross-border payments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P131_S2	Furthermore, the legislation includes a one-time transition tax on accumulated foreign earnings and profits.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P132_S0	In response to the enactment of U.S. tax reform, the SEC issued guidance to address the complexity in accounting for this new legislation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P132_S1	When the initial accounting for items under the new legislation is incomplete, the guidance allows us to recognize provisional amounts when reasonable estimates can be made or to continue to apply the prior tax law if a reasonable estimate of the impact cannot be made.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P132_S2	The SEC has provided up to a one-year window for companies to finalize the accounting for the impacts of this new legislation and we anticipate finalizing our accounting during 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S0	While our accounting for the new U.S. tax legislation is not complete, we have made reasonable estimates for some provisions and recognized a $10.6 million discrete net tax benefit in our 2017 Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S1	This net benefit is primarily comprised of a $14.7 million provisional deferred tax benefit from revaluing our net U.S. deferred tax liabilities to reflect the new U.S. corporate tax rate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S2	We have also recorded a provisional tax charge of $7.5 million payable over 8 years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S3	This tax expense is offset by the provisional tax benefit of a $6.4 million reduction of a deferred tax liability previously recorded for our foreign equity method investments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S4	We have also recorded a provisional expense of $3.0 million for the establishment of a deferred tax liability related to changes in our indefinite reinvestment assertion.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S5	However, as of the date of this Form 10-K, we are evaluating the accounting impacts of the legislation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S6	As part of our evaluation, we will continue to assemble and analyze all of the information required to quantify the effects of the legislation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S7	The ultimate impact may differ from these provisional amounts, possibly materially, due to, among other things, additional analysis, changes in interpretations and assumptions we have made, additional regulatory guidance that may be issued, and actions we may take.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P133_S8	See Note 14 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for further details on the impacts of U.S. tax reform.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P134_S0	For a reconciliation of the U.S. federal tax rate to our effective income tax rate, refer to Note 14 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P135_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2017 was 23.9% , a decrease of 4.4 percentage points compared with 28.3% in 2016, primarily because of the provisional tax impacts of the new U.S. tax legislation detailed above.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P136_S0	Our effective tax rate in 2016 was 28.3% , a decrease of 3.8 percentage points compared with 32.1% in 2015, mainly because the $37.1 million holding gain recorded in connection with the December 2016 purchase of the remaining ownership interest in PitchBook was not taxable.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P137_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , we had cash, cash equivalents, and investments of $353.3 million , up $49.3 million from the end of 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P137_S1	The increase reflects cash provided by operating activities and proceeds of $23.7 million related to the sale of HelloWallet.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P137_S2	These items were partially offset by $70.0 million of repayments of long-term debt, $66.6 million of capital expenditures, and $42.3 million used to repurchase common stock under our share repurchase program, of which $0.7 million was repurchased in the fourth quarter of 2016 but settled and paid early in the first half of 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P137_S3	Dividends paid of $39.3 million and purchases of equity-method investments of $24.8 million also offset the cash inflows.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P138_S0	Cash provided by operating activities is our main source of cash.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P138_S1	In 2017 , cash provided by operating activities was $250.1 million , reflecting $226.8 million of net income, adjusted for non-cash items and $23.3 million in positive changes from our net operating assets and liabilities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P139_S0	In November 2016, we amended our credit agreement to provide us with a three-year credit facility with a borrowing capacity of up to $300.0 million .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P139_S1	We had an outstanding principal balance of $180.0 million as of December 31, 2017, leaving borrowing availability of $120.0 million .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P139_S2	The credit agreement also contains financial covenants under which we: (i) may not exceed a maximum consolidated leverage ratio of 3.00 to 1.00 and (ii) are required to maintain a minimum consolidated interest coverage ratio of not less than 3.00 to 1.00.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P139_S3	We were in compliance with the financial covenants at December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P140_S0	We believe our available cash balances and investments, along with cash generated from operations and our line of credit, will be sufficient to meet our operating and cash needs for at least the next 12 months.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P140_S1	We invest our cash reserves in cash equivalents and investments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P140_S2	We maintain a conservative investment policy for our investments.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P140_S3	We invest a portion of our investment balance (approximately $23.1 million, or 51% of our total investments balance as of December 31, 2017 ) in stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, money market funds, or exchange-traded products that replicate the model portfolios and strategies created by Morningstar.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P140_S4	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P141_S0	Approximately 69% of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments as of December 31, 2017 was held by our operations outside the United States, down from about 71% as of December 31, 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P142_S0	We intend to use our cash, cash equivalents, and investments for general corporate purposes, including working capital and funding future growth.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P143_S0	In December 2015, our board of directors approved a $300.0 million increase to our share repurchase program, bringing the total amount authorized under the program to $1.0 billion .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P143_S1	The authorization expired on December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P143_S2	On December 8, 2017, the board of directors approved a new share repurchase program that authorizes the company to repurchase up to $500.0 million in shares of the company's outstanding common stock, effective January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P143_S3	The authorization expires on December 31, 2020.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P144_S0	In 2017 , we repurchased a total of approximately 0.5 million shares for $41.9 million .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P144_S1	As of December 31, 2017 , we had repurchased a total of 10.6 million shares for $714.8 million since we announced the share repurchase program in September 2010.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P145_S0	In 2017 , we also paid dividends of $39.3 million .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P145_S1	In February 2018 , our board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents per share.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P145_S2	The dividend is payable on April 27, 2018 to shareholders of record as of April 6, 2018 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P145_S3	We expect to make regular quarterly dividend payments of 25 cents per share in 2018 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P146_S0	We expect to continue making capital expenditures in 2018 , primarily for computer hardware and software, internally developed software, and leasehold improvements for new and existing office locations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P146_S1	We have commenced migrating our infrastructure to the cloud.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P146_S2	The migration will have some transitional effects on our level of capital expenditures and operating expenses and we expect to maintain certain redundant infrastructure prior to a full transition.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P147_S0	We also expect to use a portion of our cash and investments balances in the first quarter of 2018 to make annual bonus payments of approximately $48.2 million related to the 2017 bonus compared to $38.0 million in 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P148_S0	As described in more detail above, we define free cash flow as cash provided by or used for operating activities less capital expenditures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P148_S1	We present free cash flow solely as supplemental disclosure to help investors better understand how much cash is available after we spend money to operate our business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P148_S2	Our management team uses free cash flow to evaluate our business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P149_S0	Free cash flow is not a measure of performance set forth under GAAP.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P149_S1	Also, the free cash flow definition we use may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P150_S0	We generated free cash flow of $183.5 million in 2017 , an increase of $32.6 million versus 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P150_S1	The change reflects a $36.4 million increase in cash provided by operating activities as well as a $3.8 million increase in capital expenditures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P151_S0	We generated free cash flow of $150.9 million in 2016, a decrease of $33.3 million versus 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P151_S1	The change reflects a $27.8 million decrease in cash provided by operating activities as well as a $5.5 million increase in capital expenditures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P152_S0	We paid a total of $203.7 million , less cash acquired, related to acquisitions over the past three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P152_S1	We describe these acquisitions in Note 7 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P153_S0	We paid a total of $47.5 million related to purchasing additional investments in unconsolidated entities over the past three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P153_S1	We describe these investments in Note 9 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P154_S0	We sold HelloWallet in 2017 and received a total of $ 23.7 million related to this sale.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P154_S1	For more information, please see Note 8 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P155_S0	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P155_S1	We discuss our significant accounting policies in Note 2 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P156_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires our management team to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, expense, and related disclosures included in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P157_S0	We evaluate our estimates on an ongoing basis.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P157_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P157_S2	Based on these assumptions and estimates, we make judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P157_S3	Our actual results could vary from these estimates and assumptions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P157_S4	If actual amounts are different from previous estimates, we include revisions in our results of operations for the period in which the actual amounts become known.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P158_S0	We believe the following critical accounting policies reflect the significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our Consolidated Financial Statements:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P159_S0	Much of our revenue comes from the sale of subscriptions or licenses for data, software, and Internet-based products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P159_S1	We recognize this revenue in equal amounts over the term of the subscription or license, which generally ranges from one to three years.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P159_S2	We also provide research, investment management, retirement advice, and other services.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P159_S3	We recognize this revenue when the service is provided or during the service obligation period defined in the contract.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P160_S0	We make significant judgments related to revenue recognition, including whether fees are fixed or determinable and whether the collection of payment is probable.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P161_S0	For contracts that combine multiple products and services, we make judgments regarding the value of each element in the arrangement based on selling prices of the items when sold separately.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P162_S0	Delivery of our products and services is a prerequisite to the recognition of revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P162_S1	If arrangements include an acceptance provision, we begin recognizing revenue upon the receipt of customer acceptance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P163_S0	We make judgments at the beginning of an arrangement regarding whether or not collection is probable.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P163_S1	We typically sell to institutional customers with whom we have a history of successful collections and assess the probability of collection on a case-by-case basis.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P164_S0	Deferred revenue is the amount invoiced or collected in advance for subscriptions, licenses, or services that has not yet been recognized as revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P164_S1	Deferred revenue is the second largest liability on our Consolidated Balance Sheets and, at the end of 2017 , totaled $185.5 million (of which $171.3 million was classified as a current liability with an additional $14.2 million included in other long-term liabilities).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P164_S2	We expect to recognize this deferred revenue in future periods as we fulfill our service obligations under our subscription, license, and service agreements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P165_S0	The amount of deferred revenue may increase or decrease based on the mix of contracted products and services and the volume of new and renewal subscriptions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P165_S1	The timing of future revenue recognition may change depending on the terms of the license agreements and the timing of fulfilling our service obligations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P165_S2	We believe that the estimate related to revenue recognition is a critical accounting estimate, and to the extent that there are material differences between our determination of deferred revenue and actual results, our financial condition or results of operations may be affected.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P166_S0	Acquisitions, Goodwill, and Other Intangible Assets Our financial statements reflect the operations of an acquired business starting from the completion of the transaction.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P166_S1	We record the estimated fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the date of acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P166_S2	Allocating the purchase price to the acquired assets and liabilities involves management judgment.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P167_S0	We base the fair value estimates on available historical information and on future expectations and assumptions that we believe are reasonable, but these estimates are inherently uncertain.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P167_S1	Determining the fair value of intangible assets requires significant management judgment in each of the following areas:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P168_S0	Identify the acquired intangible assets: For each acquisition, we identify the intangible assets acquired.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P168_S1	These intangible assets generally consist of customer relationships, trademarks and trade names, technology-related intangibles (including internally developed software and databases), and non-compete agreements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P169_S0	Estimate the fair value of these intangible assets: We consider various approaches to value the intangible assets.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P169_S1	These include the cost approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the cost to reproduce it or replace it with another asset of like utility; the market approach, which values the asset through an analysis of sales and offerings of comparable assets; and the income approach, which measures the value of an asset based on the present value of the economic benefits it is expected to produce.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S0	Estimate the remaining useful life of the assets: For each intangible asset, we use judgment and assumptions to establish the remaining useful life of the asset.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S1	For example, for customer relationships, we determine the estimated useful life with reference to observed customer attrition rates.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S2	For technology-related assets such as databases, we make judgments about the demand for current data and historical metrics in establishing the remaining useful life.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S3	For internally developed software, we estimate an obsolescence factor associated with the software.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S4	We record any excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the net assets acquired as goodwill, which is not amortized.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S5	Instead, it is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist, based on a discounted cash-flow model.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S6	We review the carrying value of goodwill for impairment at least annually based on the estimated fair value of our reporting unit.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P170_S7	If we determine that goodwill is impaired, we reduce the goodwill balance to reflect the revised fair value.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P171_S0	For purposes of performing the impairment test, we determine fair values based on a discounted cash-flow methodology.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P171_S1	This requires significant judgments including estimation of future cash flows, which, among other factors, is dependent on internal forecasts, long-term growth estimates, and determination of weighted average cost of capital.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P171_S2	We believe the accounting estimates related to purchase price allocations and subsequent goodwill impairment testing are critical accounting estimates because changes in these assumptions could materially affect the amounts and classifications of assets and liabilities presented in our Consolidated Balance Sheets, as well as the amount of amortization and depreciation expense, if any, recorded in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P172_S0	We include stock-based compensation expense in each of our operating expense categories.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P172_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense primarily reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, performance share awards, and market stock units.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S0	We measure stock-based compensation expense at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and recognize the expense ratably over the award's vesting period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S1	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the market price of the underlying common stock as of the close of trading on the day before the grant.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S2	We estimate expected forfeitures of stock-based awards at the grant date and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S3	We later adjust this forfeiture assumption to the actual forfeiture rate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S4	Therefore, changes in the forfeiture assumptions do not change the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the vesting period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P173_S5	Instead, different forfeiture assumptions would only affect the timing of expense recognition over the vesting period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P174_S0	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense to reflect those awards that ultimately vested and update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P175_S0	We believe the estimates related to stock-based compensation expense are critical accounting estimates because the assumptions used could significantly impact the timing and amount of stock-based compensation expense recorded in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P176_S0	On December 22, 2017, the United States enacted tax reform legislation that included a broad range of business tax provisions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P176_S1	As a result of the U.S. tax reform and the related SEC guidance, we included provisional estimates in our consolidated financial statements for some impacts of the new tax legislation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P176_S2	See Note 14 of the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion of the provisional amounts related to U.S. tax reform included in our Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P177_S0	Our effective tax rate is based on the mix of income and losses in our U.S. and non-U.S. operations, statutory tax rates, and tax-planning opportunities available to us in the various jurisdictions in which we operate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P177_S1	Significant judgment is required to evaluate our tax positions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P178_S0	Because of timing differences required by tax law, the effective tax rate reflected in our Consolidated Financial Statements is different from the tax rate reported on our tax return (our cash tax rate).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P178_S1	Some of these differences, such as expenses that are not deductible in our tax return, are permanent.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P178_S2	Other differences, such as depreciation expense, reverse over time.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P178_S3	These timing differences create deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P179_S0	We determine our deferred tax assets and liabilities based on temporary differences between the financial reporting and the tax basis of assets and liabilities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P180_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , we had gross deferred tax assets of $34.5 million and gross deferred tax liabilities of $56.1 million .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P180_S1	The deferred tax assets include $3.1 million of deferred tax assets related to $14.8 million of net operating losses (NOLs) of our non-U.S. operations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P181_S0	In assessing the realizability of our deferred tax assets, we consider whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P181_S1	We have recorded a valuation allowance against all but approximately $5.4 million of the non-U.S. NOLs, reflecting the likelihood that the benefit of the NOLs will not be realized.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P181_S2	We have not recorded a valuation allowance against the U.S. federal NOLs of $9.1 million because we expect the benefit of the U.S. federal NOLs to be fully utilized before expiration.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P182_S0	In assessing the need for a valuation allowance, we consider both positive and negative evidence, including tax planning strategies, projected future taxable income, and recent financial performance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P182_S1	If we determine a lower allowance is required at some point in the future, we would record a reduction to our tax expense and valuation allowance.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P182_S2	These adjustments would be made in the same period we determined the change in the valuation allowance was needed.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P182_S3	This would cause our income tax expense, effective tax rate, and net income to fluctuate.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P183_S0	We use judgment to identify, recognize, and measure the amounts of uncertain tax positions to be recorded in the financial statements related to tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P183_S1	We recognize liabilities to represent our potential future obligations to taxing authorities for the benefits taken in our tax returns.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P183_S2	We adjust these liabilities, including any impact of the related interest and penalties, in light of changing facts and circumstances such as the progress of a tax audit.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P183_S3	A number of years may elapse before a particular matter for which we have established a reserve is audited and finally resolved.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P183_S4	The number of years with open tax audits varies depending on the tax jurisdiction.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P184_S0	We use judgment to classify unrecognized tax benefits as either current or noncurrent liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P184_S1	Settlement of any particular issue would usually require the use of cash.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	We generally classify liabilities associated with unrecognized tax benefits as noncurrent liabilities.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P185_S1	It typically takes several years between our initial tax return filing and the final resolution of any uncertain tax positions with the tax authority.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P185_S2	We recognize favorable resolutions of tax matters for which we have previously established reserves as a reduction to our income tax expense when the amounts involved become known.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P186_S0	Assessing the future tax consequences of events that have been recognized in our Consolidated Financial Statements or tax returns requires judgment.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P186_S1	Variations in the actual outcome of these future tax consequences could materially impact our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P187_S0	We are subject to various claims and contingencies related to legal proceedings and investigations.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P187_S1	These legal proceedings involve inherent uncertainties including, but not limited to, court rulings, negotiations between affected parties, and government actions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P187_S2	Assessing the probability of loss for such contingencies and determining how to accrue the appropriate liabilities requires judgment.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P187_S3	If actual results differ from our assessments, our financial position, results of operations, or cash flows would be affected.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	On May 28, 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , which requires an entity to recognize the amount of revenue to which it expects to be entitled for the transfer of promised goods or services to customers.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P188_S1	The ASU will replace most existing revenue recognition guidance in U.S. GAAP when it becomes effective.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P188_S2	The original effective date for ASU No. 2014-09 would have required us to adopt it beginning on January 1, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P188_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers Deferral of the Effective Date , which defers the effective date of ASU No. 2014-09 for one year and permits early adoption as early as the original effective date of ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P188_S4	We elected the deferral, and the new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	We have obtained an understanding of ASU No. 2014-09 and have substantially completed our analysis of the impact of the new standard on our financial results.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	We have completed a high-level assessment of the attributes within our contracts for our major products and services, and we have assessed the impacts to our internal processes, control environment, and disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P189_S2	We have determined that the adoption of ASU No. 2014-09 will not result in a material change to the timing of when revenue is recognized and we intend to retain similar accounting treatment used to recognize revenue under current practices.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P189_S3	We have identified that there will be certain changes in accounting treatment related to delivery of third-party content (principal vs. agent) and costs to obtain contracts (e.g., sales commissions).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P190_S0	The change related to delivery of third-party content (principal vs. agent) is expected to result in no impact on our consolidated operating income; however it will result in a increase in both revenue and cost of revenue versus prior periods of approximately $6 million to $7 million as revenue will be recognized on a gross rather than net basis for certain arrangements.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P191_S0	The change related to the capitalization of cost to obtain contracts is expected to result in an increase to retained earnings of approximately $25 million to $30 million for commission expenses which were previously expensed.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P191_S1	We expected to amortize this adjustment over a period not to exceed three years and expect 2018 commission expense resulting from this change will range between $14 million and $16 million.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P191_S2	Additionally, in 2018 we will expense any discretionary payments made under our commission plans as well as pro-rata portions of any new commission amounts paid in 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P192_S0	The standard allows for both retrospective and modified retrospective methods of adoption.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P192_S1	We plan to adopt using the modified retrospective transition method applied to those contracts which were not completed as of January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P192_S2	Upon adoption, we will recognize the cumulative effect of adopting this guidance as an adjustment to our opening balance of retained earnings as noted above.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P192_S3	Prior periods will not be retrospectively adjusted and we will discuss the comparability of these adjustments within our 2018 results against the prior periods.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P193_S0	We are continuing to evaluate the effect that ASU No. 2014-09 will have on our consolidated financial statement presentation and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P193_S1	We expect expanded disclosures related to the revenue recognized in the reporting period that was included in the contract liability (i.e., deferred revenue) balance at the beginning of the period.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P193_S2	We also plan to provide additional disclosures on our unsatisfied performance obligations at the end of the period and expected timing of when that contract liability will be recognized into revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P194_S0	On March 17, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-08, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Principal versus Agent Considerations (Reporting Revenue Gross versus Net) , which provides guidance on assessing whether an entity is a principal or an agent in a revenue transaction and whether an entity reports revenue on a gross or net basis.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P194_S1	On April 14, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-10, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Identifying Performance Obligations and Licensing , which provides guidance on identifying performance obligations and accounting for licenses of intellectual property.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P194_S2	On May 6, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-11, Revenue Recognition and Derivatives and Hedging: Rescission of SEC guidance because of ASU No. 2014-09 and ASU No. 2014-16 pursuant to staff announcements at the March 3, 2016 EITF Meeting , which rescinds the following SEC Staff Observer comments from ASC 605, Revenue Recognition , upon an entity's early adoption of ASC 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers : Revenue and expense recognition for freight services in process, accounting for shipping and handling fees and costs, and accounting for consideration given by a vendor to a customer (including a reseller of the vendor's products).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P194_S3	On May 9, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-12, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Narrow-Scope Improvements and Practical Expedients , which makes narrow-scope amendments to ASU No. 2014-09 and provides practical expedients to simplify the transition to the new standard and clarify certain aspects of the standard.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P194_S4	On December 21, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-20, Technical Corrections and Improvements to Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , which makes narrow-scope amendments to ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P195_S0	The effective date and transition requirements for ASU No. 2016-08, ASU No. 2016-10, ASU No. 2016-11, ASU No. 2016-12, and ASU No. 2016-20 are the same as the effective date and transition requirements of ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P195_S1	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-08, ASU No. 2016-10, ASU No. 2016-11, ASU No. 2016-12, and ASU No. 2016-20 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P196_S0	On February 25, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases , which will require lessees to recognize almost all leases on their balance sheet as a right-of-use asset and a lease liability.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P196_S1	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P196_S2	The new standard must be adopted using a modified retrospective transition and provides for certain practical expedients.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P196_S3	Transition will require application of the new guidance at the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P197_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-02 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P198_S0	On August 26, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows: Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments , which reduces diversity in practice of how certain transactions are classified in the statement of cash flows.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P198_S1	The new guidance clarifies the classification of cash activities related to debt prepayment or debt extinguishment costs, settlement of zero-coupon debt instruments, contingent consideration payments made after a business combination, proceeds from the settlement of insurance claims, proceeds from the settlement of corporate and bank-owned life insurance policies, distributions received from equity-method investments, and beneficial interests in securitization transactions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P198_S2	The guidance also describes a predominance principle in which cash flows with aspects of more than one class that cannot be separated should be classified based on the activity that is likely to be the predominant source or use of cash flow.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P199_S0	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P199_S1	Early adoption is permitted, including adoption in an interim period, but requires all elements of the amendments to be adopted at once rather than individually.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P199_S2	The new standard must be adopted using a retrospective transition method.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P200_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-15 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P201_S0	On January 5, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-01, Business Combinations: Clarifying the Definition of a Business, which revises the definition of a business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P202_S0	When substantially all of the fair value of gross assets acquired is concentrated in a single asset (or a group of similar assets), the assets acquired would not represent a business.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P202_S1	To be considered a business, an acquisition would have to include an input and a substantive process that together significantly contribute to the ability to create outputs.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P202_S2	The new guidance provides a framework to evaluate when an input and substantive process are present (including for early-stage companies that have not generated outputs).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P203_S0	To be a business without outputs, there will now need to be an organized workforce.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P203_S1	The new guidance also narrows the definition of the term outputs to be consistent with how it is described in Topic 606 , Revenue from Contracts with Customers .
1289419_18_ITEM7_P203_S2	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P203_S3	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-01 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S0	On January 26, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04, Intangibles Goodwill and Other , which simplifies the accounting for goodwill impairment.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S1	The guidance removes Step 2 of the goodwill impairment test, which requires a hypothetical purchase price allocation.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S2	A goodwill impairment will now be the amount by which a reporting unit s carrying value exceeds its fair value, not to exceed the carrying amount of goodwill.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S3	All other goodwill impairment guidance will remain largely unchanged.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S4	Entities will continue to have the option to perform a qualitative assessment to determine if a quantitative impairment test is necessary.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S5	The same one-step impairment test will be applied to goodwill at all reporting units, even those with zero or negative carrying amounts.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S6	Entities will be required to disclose the amount of goodwill at reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S7	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2020.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S8	The new standard should be applied prospectively.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P204_S9	Early adoption is permitted for any impairment tests performed after January 1, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P205_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-04 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P206_S0	On May 10, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-09, Compensation Stock Compensation: Scope of Modification Accounting , which clarifies when to account for a change to the terms or conditions of a share-based payment award as a modification.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P206_S1	Under the new guidance, modification accounting is required only if the fair value, the vesting conditions, or the classification of the award (as equity or liability) changes as a result of the change in terms or conditions.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P206_S2	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P206_S3	The new standard should be applied prospectively.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P206_S4	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-09 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P207_S0	The table below shows our known contractual obligations as of December 31, 2017 and the expected timing of cash payments related to these contractual obligations:
1289419_18_ITEM7_P208_S0	(1) The non-cancelable operating lease obligations are mainly for office space.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P209_S0	(2) The minimum payments on the credit facility reflect the current outstanding principal balance of $180.0 million and an estimate for interest and commitment fees.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P210_S0	(3) Represents unrecognized tax benefits (including penalties and interest, less the impact of any associated tax benefits).
1289419_18_ITEM7_P210_S1	The amount included in the table represents items that may be resolved through settlement of tax audits or for which the statutes of limitations are expected to lapse during 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P210_S2	The table excludes $7.0 million of unrecognized tax benefits, included as a long-term liability in our Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2017 , for which we cannot make a reasonably reliable estimate of the period of payment.
1289419_18_ITEM7_P211_S0	(4) U.S. federal income tax on deemed mandatory repatriation is payable over 8 years pursuant to the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our investment portfolio is actively managed and may suffer losses from fluctuating interest rates, market prices, or adverse security selection.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	These accounts may consist of stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, money market funds, or exchange-traded products that replicate the model portfolios and strategies created by Morningstar.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P0_S3	As of December 31, 2017 , our cash, cash equivalents, and investments balance was $353.3 million.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P0_S4	Based on our estimates, a 100 basis-point change in interest rates would not have a material effect on the fair value of our investment portfolio.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We are subject to risk from fluctuations in the interest rates related to our long-term debt.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	The interest rates are based upon the applicable LIBOR rate plus an applicable margin for such loans or the lender's base rate plus an applicable margin for such loans.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P1_S2	On an annualized basis, based on December 31, 2017 estimated LIBOR rates, we estimate a 100 basis-point change in the LIBOR rate would have a $1.8 million impact.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We are subject to risk from fluctuations in foreign currencies from our operations outside of the United States.
1289419_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	To date, we have not engaged in currency hedging, and we do not currently have any positions in derivative instruments to hedge our currency risk.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P0_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Morningstar, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company) as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2017, and the related notes and financial statement Schedule II - Valuation and Qualifying Accounts (collectively, the consolidated financial statements).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P1_S1	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2017, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P2_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB), the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission, and our report dated March 1, 2018, expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P3_S0	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P3_S1	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P3_S2	We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement, whether due to error or fraud.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S2	Our audits included performing procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to error or fraud, and performing procedures that respond to those risks.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S3	Such procedures included examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S4	Our audits also included evaluating the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P4_S5	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P5_S0	We have served as the Company s auditor since 2011.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P6_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm To the Board of Directors and Shareholders Morningstar, Inc.:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited Morningstar, Inc. s and subsidiaries (the Company) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P7_S1	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P8_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB), the consolidated balance sheets of the Company as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2017, and the related notes and financial statement Schedule II - Valuation and Qualifying Accounts (collectively, the consolidated financial statements), and our report dated March 1, 2018, expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P9_S1	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P9_S2	We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P10_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P10_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P10_S2	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P10_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P10_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P11_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P11_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P12_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P12_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P13_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P14_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P15_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P16_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P17_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P18_S0	Morningstar, Inc. and its subsidiaries (Morningstar, we, our, the company), provides independent investment research for investors around the world.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P18_S1	We offer an extensive line of products and services for individual investors, financial advisors, asset managers, retirement plan providers and sponsors, and institutional investors in the private capital markets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P18_S2	We have operations in 27 countries.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P19_S0	We conduct our business operations through wholly owned or majority-owned operating subsidiaries.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P19_S1	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Morningstar, Inc. and our subsidiaries.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P19_S2	We consolidate assets, liabilities, and results of operations of subsidiaries in which we have a controlling interest and eliminate all significant intercompany accounts and transactions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P20_S0	We account and report the noncontrolling (minority) interest in our Consolidated Financial Statements in accordance with FASB ASC 810, Consolidation .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P21_S0	A noncontrolling interest is the portion of equity (net assets) in a subsidiary not attributable, directly or indirectly, to the parent company.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P21_S1	We report the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Balance Sheet within equity separate from the shareholders' equity attributable to Morningstar, Inc.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P21_S2	In addition, we present the net income (loss) and comprehensive income (loss) attributable to Morningstar, Inc.'s shareholders and the noncontrolling interest in our Consolidated Statements of Income, Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income, and Consolidated Statements of Equity.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P22_S0	We account for investments in entities in which we exercise significant influence, but do not control, using the equity method.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P23_S0	As part of our investment management operations, we manage certain funds outside of the United States that are considered variable interest entities.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P23_S1	For the majority of these variable interest entities, we do not have a variable interest in them.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P23_S2	In cases where we do have a variable interest, we are not the primary beneficiary.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P23_S3	Accordingly, we do not consolidate any of these variable interest entities.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P24_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses during the reporting period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P24_S1	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P25_S0	Cash and cash equivalents consists of cash and investments with original maturities of three months or less.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P25_S1	We state them at cost, which approximates fair value.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P25_S2	We state the portion of our cash equivalents that are invested in money market funds at fair value, as these funds are actively traded and have quoted market prices.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P26_S0	We account for our investments in accordance with FASB ASC 320, Investments Debt and Equity Securities.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P26_S1	We classify our investments into three categories: held-to-maturity, trading, and available-for-sale.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P27_S0	Held-to-maturity: We classify certain investments, primarily certificates of deposit, as held-to-maturity securities, based on our intent and ability to hold these securities to maturity.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P27_S1	We record held-to-maturity investments at amortized cost in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P28_S0	Trading: We classify certain other investments, primarily equity securities, as trading securities as these relate mainly to investments tracking the strategies of our newsletter portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P28_S1	We include realized and unrealized gains and losses associated with these investments as a component of our operating income in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P28_S2	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P29_S0	Available-for-sale: Investments not considered held-to-maturity or trading securities are classified as available-for-sale securities.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P29_S1	Available-for-sale securities primarily consist of equity securities, exchange-traded funds, and mutual funds.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P29_S2	We report unrealized gains and losses for available-for-sale securities as other comprehensive income (loss), net of related income taxes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P29_S3	We record these securities at their fair value in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P30_S0	We follow FASB ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P30_S1	FASB ASC 820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P31_S0	Under FASB ASC 820, fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants as of the measurement date.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P31_S1	The standard applies whenever other standards require (or permit) assets or liabilities to be measured at fair value.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P31_S2	The standard does not expand the use of fair value in any new circumstances and does not require any new fair value measurements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P32_S0	FASB ASC 820 uses a fair value hierarchy based on three broad levels of valuation inputs:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P33_S0	Level 1: Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the company has the ability to access.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P34_S0	Level 2: Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P35_S0	Level 3: Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P36_S0	We provide additional information about our cash equivalents and investments that are subject to valuation under FASB ASC 820 in Note 6 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P37_S0	No single customer is large enough to pose a significant credit risk to our operations or financial condition.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P37_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 , and 2015 , no single customer represented 5% or more of our consolidated revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P38_S0	If receivables from our customers become delinquent, we begin a collections process.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P38_S1	We maintain an allowance for doubtful accounts based on our estimate of the probable losses of accounts receivable.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P39_S0	We state property and equipment at historical cost, net of accumulated depreciation.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P39_S1	We depreciate property and equipment primarily using the straight-line method based on the useful life of the asset, which generally is three years.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P39_S2	We amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or their useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P40_S0	Computer Software and Internal Product Development Costs.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P40_S1	We capitalize certain costs in accordance with FASB ASC 350-40, Internal-Use Software , FASB ASC 350-50, Website Development Costs, and FASB ASC 985, Software .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P41_S0	Internal product development costs mainly consist of employee costs for developing new web-based products and certain major enhancements of existing products.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P41_S1	We amortize these costs on a straight-line basis over the estimated economic life, which is generally three to five years.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P41_S2	We include capitalized software development costs related to projects that have not been placed into service in our construction in progress balance.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P42_S0	The table below summarizes our depreciation expense related to internally developed software for the past three years:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P43_S0	The table below summarizes our capitalized software development costs for the past three years:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P44_S0	When we make acquisitions, we allocate the purchase price to the assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and goodwill.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P44_S1	We follow FASB ASC 805, Business Combinations .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P44_S2	We recognize and measure the fair value of the acquired operation as a whole, as well as the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, at their full fair values as of the date we obtain control, regardless of the percentage ownership in the acquired operation or how the acquisition was achieved.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P44_S3	We expense direct costs related to the business combination, such as advisory, accounting, legal, valuation, and other professional fees, as incurred.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P44_S4	We recognize restructuring costs, including severance and relocation for employees of the acquired entity, as post-combination expenses unless the target entity meets the criteria of FASB ASC 420, Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations , on the acquisition date.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P45_S0	As part of the purchase price allocation, we follow the requirements of FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P45_S1	This includes establishing deferred tax assets or liabilities reflecting the difference between the values assigned for financial statement purposes and income tax purposes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P45_S2	In certain acquisitions, the goodwill resulting from the purchase price allocation may not be deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P45_S3	FASB ASC 740 prohibits recognition of a deferred tax asset or liability for temporary differences in goodwill if goodwill is not amortizable and deductible for tax purposes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P46_S0	Changes in the carrying amount of our recorded goodwill are mainly the result of business acquisitions, divestitures, and the effect of foreign currency translations.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P46_S1	In accordance with FASB ASC 350, Intangibles Goodwill and Other , we do not amortize goodwill; instead, goodwill is subject to an impairment test annually, or whenever indicators of impairment exist.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P47_S0	An impairment would occur if the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeded the fair value of that reporting unit.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P47_S1	We performed annual impairment reviews in the fourth quarter of 2017 and 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P47_S2	We did not record any impairment losses in 2017 and 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P48_S0	We amortize intangible assets using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, which range from one to 25 years.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P48_S1	We have no intangible assets with indefinite useful lives.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P48_S2	In accordance with FASB ASC 360-10-35, Subsequent Measurement Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets , we review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P48_S3	If the value of future undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying amount of an asset group, we record an impairment loss based on the excess of the carrying amount over the fair value of the asset group.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P48_S4	We did not record any impairment losses in 2017 and 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P49_S0	We recognize revenue in accordance with SEC SAB Topic 13, Revenue Recognition , ASC 605-25, Revenue Recognition: Multiple Element Arrangements , and ASC 985-605, Software: Revenue Recognition .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P50_S0	We recognize revenue when all of the following conditions are met:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P51_S0	Delivery of our products and services has taken place.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P52_S0	The collectibility of the fees is reasonably assured.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P53_S0	We generate revenue through sales of Morningstar Data, Morningstar Advisor Workstation (including Morningstar Office), Morningstar Direct, Morningstar Research, Premium Membership subscriptions for Morningstar.com, our structured credit ratings offerings, and a variety of other investment-related products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P53_S1	We generally structure the revenue agreements for these offerings as licenses or subscriptions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P53_S2	We recognize revenue from licenses and subscription sales ratably as we deliver the product or service and over the service obligation period defined by the terms of the customer contract.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P53_S3	For new-issue ratings and analysis for commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS), residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS), other asset-backed securities (ABS), and corporate and financial institutions, we charge asset-based fees that are paid by the issuer on the rated balance of the transaction and recognize the revenue immediately upon issuance.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P54_S0	We also generate revenue from Internet advertising, primarily from impression-based contracts.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P54_S1	For advertisers who use our cost-per-impression pricing, we charge fees each time we display their ads on our site.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P55_S0	Our Investment Management business includes a broad range of services.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P55_S1	Pricing for consulting services is based on the scope of work and the level of service provided and includes asset-based fees for work we perform that involves investment management or acting as a subadvisor to investment portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P55_S2	In arrangements that involve asset-based fees, we generally invoice clients quarterly in arrears based on average assets for the quarter.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P55_S3	We recognize asset-based fees once the fees are fixed or determinable assuming all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P56_S0	Our Workplace Solutions offerings help retirement plan participants plan and invest for retirement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P56_S1	We offer these services both through retirement plan providers (typically third-party asset management companies that provide administrative and record-keeping services) and directly to plan sponsors (employers that offer retirement plans to their employees).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P56_S2	For our Workplace Solutions offerings, we provide both a hosted solution as well as proprietary installed software advice solution.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P56_S3	Clients can integrate the installed customized software into their existing systems to help investors accumulate wealth, transition into retirement, and manage income during retirement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P57_S0	The revenue arrangements for Workplace Solutions generally extend over multiple years.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P57_S1	Our contracts may include one-time setup fees, implementation fees, technology licensing and maintenance fees, asset-based fees for managed retirement accounts, fixed and variable fees for advice and guidance, or a combination of these fee structures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P58_S0	Upon customer acceptance, we recognize revenue ratably over the term of the agreement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P58_S1	We recognize asset-based fees and variable fees in excess of any minimum once the value is fixed or determinable.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P59_S0	Some of our revenue arrangements combine multiple products and services.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P59_S1	These products and services may be provided at different points in time or over different time periods within the same arrangement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P60_S0	We allocate fees to the separate deliverables based on the deliverables relative selling price, which is generally based on the price we charge when the same deliverable is sold separately.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P61_S0	We record taxes imposed on revenue-producing transactions (such as sales, use, value-added, and some excise taxes) on a net basis; therefore, we exclude such taxes from revenue in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P62_S0	Deferred revenue represents the portion of licenses or subscriptions billed or collected in advance of the service being provided which we expect to recognize as revenue in future periods.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P62_S1	Certain arrangements may have cancellation or refund provisions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P63_S0	If we make a refund, it typically reflects the amount collected from a customer for which we have not yet provided services.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P63_S1	The refund therefore results in a reduction of deferred revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P64_S0	Through December 31, 2013, we paid sales commissions based on a formula driven by the total contract value of sales opportunities closed, with any subsequent adjustments (such as clawbacks for contract cancellations) reflected in future commission payouts.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P64_S1	We considered the corresponding commission expense an incremental direct acquisition cost and treated it as a deferred charge, which we expensed over the term of the underlying sales contracts.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P65_S0	In the first quarter of 2014, we modified our sales incentive plan.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P65_S1	The revised plan is based on a combination of net new sales and specific business objectives not solely tied to revenue growth.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P65_S2	Because of this new structure and the discretion involved in determining the related incentives, we started expensing sales commissions as incurred instead of amortizing them over the contract terms.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P66_S0	However, we continued to amortize the deferred charge capitalized in connection with sales commissions paid in 2013 and previous periods as part of the previous incentive plan.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P66_S1	This amortization added $0.2 million , $0.6 million , and $3.5 million of sales commission cost in 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P67_S0	Advertising costs include expenses incurred for various print and Internet ads, search engine fees, and direct mail campaigns.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P67_S1	We expense advertising costs as incurred.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P67_S2	The table below summarizes our advertising expense for the past three years:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P68_S0	We account for our stock-based compensation expense in accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P68_S1	Our stock-based compensation expense reflects grants of restricted stock units, restricted stock, performance share awards, market stock units, and stock options.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P69_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units, restricted stock, and performance share awards on the date of grant based on the closing market price of Morningstar's common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P69_S1	For market stock units, we estimate the fair value of the awards using a Monte Carlo valuation model.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P69_S2	For stock options, we estimate the fair value of our stock options on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P69_S3	We amortize the fair values to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P70_S0	We estimate expected forfeitures of all employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P70_S1	We determine forfeiture rates based on historical experience and adjust the estimated forfeitures to actual forfeiture experience as needed.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P71_S0	In some of our operations, we offer employees a sabbatical leave.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P71_S1	Although the sabbatical policy varies by region, Morningstar's full-time employees are generally eligible for six weeks of paid time off after four years of continuous service.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P71_S2	We account for our sabbatical liability in accordance with FASB ASC 710-10-25 , Compensated Absences .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P71_S3	We record a liability for employees' sabbatical benefits over the period employees earn the right for sabbatical leave and include this liability in Accrued Compensation in our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P72_S0	We record deferred income taxes for the temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities for financial statement purposes and tax purposes in accordance with FASB ASC 740, Income Taxes .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P72_S1	FASB ASC 740 prescribes the minimum recognition threshold a tax position is required to meet before being recognized in the financial statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P72_S2	It also provides guidance on derecognition, measurement, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, and disclosure for uncertain tax positions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P73_S0	We recognize interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as part of income tax expense in our Consolidated Statements of Income.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P73_S1	We classify liabilities related to unrecognized tax benefits as either current or long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheet, depending on when we expect to make payment.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P74_S0	In November 2016, we amended our credit agreement to provide us with a three -year credit facility with a borrowing capacity of up to $300.0 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P74_S1	The credit agreement also provides for issuance of up to $25.0 million of letters of credit under the revolving credit facility.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P75_S0	The interest rate applicable to any loan under the credit agreement is, at our option, either: (i) the applicable London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) plus an applicable margin for such loans, which ranges between 1.00% and 1.75% , based on our consolidated leverage ratio or (ii) the lender's base rate plus the applicable margin for such loans, which ranges between 2.00% and 2.75% , based on our consolidated leverage ratio.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P76_S0	The credit agreement also contains financial covenants under which we: (i) may not exceed a maximum consolidated leverage ratio of 3.00 to 1.00 and (ii) are required to maintain a minimum consolidated interest coverage ratio of not less than 3.00 to 1.00.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P76_S1	We were in compliance with the financial covenants as of December 31, 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P77_S0	We had an outstanding principal balance of $180.0 million at a one-month LIBOR interest rate plus 100 basis points as of December 31, 2017 , leaving borrowing availability of $120.0 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P78_S0	The following table shows how we reconcile our net income and the number of shares used in computing basic and diluted income per share:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P79_S0	The number of weighted average restricted stock units, performance share awards, and market stock units excluded from our calculation of diluted earnings per share because their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive was immaterial during the periods presented.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P80_S0	We report our results in a single reportable segment, which reflects how our chief operating decision maker allocates resources and evaluates our financial results.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P81_S0	Because we have a single reportable segment, all required financial segment information can be found directly in the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P82_S0	The accounting policies for our reportable segment are the same as those described in Note 2 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P83_S0	We evaluate the performance of our reporting segment based on revenue and operating income.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P85_S2	These investment accounts may also include exchange-traded products where Morningstar is an index provider.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P92_S0	The table below shows the fair value of our assets subject to fair value measurements that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis using a fair value hierarchy:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P93_S0	Level 1: Valuations based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that we have the ability to access.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P93_S1	Level 2: Valuations based on quoted prices in markets that are not active or for which all significant inputs are observable, either directly or indirectly.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P93_S2	Level 3: Valuations based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P94_S0	Based on our analysis of the nature and risks of our investments in equity securities and mutual funds, we have determined that presenting each of these investment categories in the aggregate is appropriate.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P95_S0	We measure the fair value of money market funds, mutual funds, equity securities, and exchange-traded funds based on quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P95_S1	We did not hold any securities categorized as Level 2 or Level 3 as of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P96_S0	We did not complete any acquisitions in 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P97_S0	In December 2016, we acquired an additional 78% interest in PitchBook Data, Inc. (PitchBook), increasing our ownership to 100% from 22% .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P98_S0	PitchBook delivers data, research, and technology covering the private capital markets, including venture capital, private equity, and mergers and acquisitions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P98_S1	We began consolidating the financial results of this acquisition in our Consolidated Financial Statements on December 1, 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P98_S2	PitchBook contributed $4.1 million of revenue and $7.5 million of operating expense during the one-month period that PitchBook was included in our consolidated results for 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P99_S0	PitchBook's total estimated fair value of $235.1 million includes $188.2 million in cash paid to acquire the remaining 78% interest in PitchBook as well as a $46.9 million fair value related to our previous 22% ownership interest.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P99_S1	The book value of this ownership immediately prior to the acquisition date was $9.8 million , and we recorded a non-cash holding gain of $37.1 million for the difference between the fair value and the book value of our previously held investment.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P99_S2	We used the income approach and a discounted cash flow analysis of PitchBook s projected revenue, operating expense, and other amounts to arrive at the estimated fair value.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P99_S3	The gain is classified as "Holding gain upon acquisition of additional ownership of equity-method investments" in our Consolidated Statement of Income for the year ended December 31, 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P100_S0	The transaction has been accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting, which requires that assets acquired and liabilities assumed be recognized at their fair values as of the acquisition date.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P101_S0	Adjustments recorded in the measurement period to the purchase price allocation were not significant.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P101_S1	The following table summarizes our allocation of the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the date of acquisition:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P102_S0	Accounts receivable acquired were recorded at gross contractual amounts receivable, which approximates fair value.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P103_S0	The allocation includes $60.7 million of acquired intangible assets, as follows:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P104_S0	We recognized a net deferred tax liability of $12.3 million mainly because the amortization expense related to certain intangible assets is not deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P105_S0	Goodwill of $192.0 million represents the excess over the fair value of the net tangible and intangible assets acquired with this acquisition.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P105_S1	We paid this premium for a number of reasons, including the opportunity to offer comprehensive data coverage across the full life cycle of private market transactions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P105_S2	The goodwill is not deductible for income tax purposes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P106_S0	The following unaudited pro forma information presents a summary of our Consolidated Statements of Income for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 as if we had completed the PitchBook acquisition as of January 1, 2015.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P107_S0	This unaudited pro forma information is presented for illustrative purposes and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the actual results of operations of the combined company that would have been achieved had the acquisition occurred at the beginning of the earliest period presented, nor is it intended to represent or be indicative of future results of operations.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P111_S1	We began consolidating the financial results of InvestSoft in our Consolidated Financial Statements on May 31, 2016.
