1289419_18_ITEM8_P112_S1	Because we previously owned more than 50% of the company, IAJ's financial results were consolidated in our Consolidated Financial Statements prior to acquiring the remaining interest.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P113_S0	In November 2015, we acquired Total Rebalance Expert (tRx), an automated, tax-efficient investment portfolio rebalancing platform for financial advisors.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P113_S1	tRx streamlines the rebalancing process for advisors and automates the complexities involved in rebalancing and managing portfolios.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P113_S2	We began consolidating the financial results of tRx in our Consolidated Financial Statements on November 2, 2015.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P122_S0	In June 2014, we acquired the remaining 81.3% interest in HelloWallet Holdings, Inc. (HelloWallet), increasing our ownership to 100% .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P122_S1	This valued HelloWallet at $54.0 million , an amount that included $39.2 million of goodwill and $9.5 million of intangible assets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P123_S0	On June 30, 2017, we sold HelloWallet to KeyBank National Association, a bank-based financial services company.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P123_S1	We recorded a noncash gain on the sale of $16.7 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P123_S2	This gain mainly represents the sale proceeds of $23.7 million less $2.4 million of goodwill and the write-off of the remaining net book value on the acquired intangible assets.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P123_S3	As some aspects of HelloWallet had been integrated into Morningstar's single reporting unit, the goodwill attributable to this transaction was calculated using a relative fair value allocation method.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P124_S0	The sale of HelloWallet did not meet the criteria to be classified as a discontinued operation because the divestiture did not represent a strategic shift that has, or will have, a major effect on our operations and financial results.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P149_S0	In accordance with FASB ASC 718, Compensation Stock Compensation , we estimate forfeitures of employee stock-based awards and recognize compensation cost only for those awards expected to vest.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P150_S0	Most of our larger annual equity grants typically have vesting dates in the second quarter.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P150_S1	We adjust the stock-based compensation expense annually in the third quarter to reflect those awards that ultimately vested and update our estimate of the forfeiture rate that will be applied to awards not yet vested.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P151_S0	Restricted stock units represent the right to receive a share of Morningstar common stock when that unit vests.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P151_S1	Restricted stock units granted to employees vest ratably over a four -year period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P151_S2	Restricted stock units granted to non-employee directors vest ratably over a three -year period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P152_S0	We measure the fair value of our restricted stock units on the date of grant based on the closing market price of the underlying common stock on the day prior to grant.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P152_S1	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense, net of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P153_S0	The following table summarizes restricted stock unit activity during the past three years:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P154_S0	In March 2015 and 2016, executive officers, other than Joe Mansueto, and certain other employees, were granted performance share awards.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P154_S1	These awards entitle the holder to a number of shares of Morningstar common stock equal to the number of notional performance shares that become vested.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P154_S2	Each award specifies a number of performance shares that will vest if pre-established target performance goals are attained.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P154_S3	The number of performance shares that actually vest may be more or less than the specified number of performance shares to the extent Morningstar exceeds or fails to achieve, respectively, the target performance goals over a three -year performance period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P155_S0	We base the grant date fair value for these awards on the closing market price of the underlying common stock on the day prior to the grant date.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P155_S1	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense ratably over the vesting period based on the satisfaction of the performance condition that is most likely to be satisfied over the three -year performance period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P156_S0	The table below shows target performance share awards granted and shares that would be issued at current performance levels for performance share awards granted as of December 31, 2017 :
1289419_18_ITEM8_P157_S0	Market Stock Units In May and November 2017, executive officers, other than Joe Mansueto, and certain other employees, were granted market stock units.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P157_S1	These market stock units represent the right to receive a target number of shares that will vest at the end of a three-year performance period depending on the company s total shareholder return over that three-year period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P158_S0	We measure the fair value of our market stock units on the date of grant using a Monte Carlo valuation model.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P158_S1	We amortize that value to stock-based compensation expense ratably over the vesting period.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P161_S0	In connection with our acquisition of PitchBook, we adopted a management bonus sub-plan under the 2011 Plan for certain employees of PitchBook (the PitchBook Plan).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P161_S1	Pursuant to the terms of the PitchBook Plan, awards having an aggregate target value equal to $30.0 million will be available for issuance with annual grants of $7.5 million for 2017, $7.5 million in 2018, and $15.0 million in 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P162_S0	Each grant will consist of performance-based share unit awards which will vest over a one -year period and will be measured primarily based on the achievement of certain annual revenue targets specifically related to PitchBook s business.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P162_S1	Upon achievement of these targets, earned performance units will be settled in shares of our common stock on a one -for-one basis.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P162_S2	If PitchBook exceeds certain performance conditions, the PitchBook Plan participants may receive payment for performance units in excess of the aggregate target values described above.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P162_S3	If PitchBook fails to meet threshold performance conditions, the PitchBook Plan participants will not be entitled to receive payment for any performance units.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P162_S4	In certain circumstances, the PitchBook Plan participants may be able to receive a catch-up award with respect to 2017 or 2018 if certain additional performance conditions are met in a subsequent year.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P164_S1	Grants to our non-employee directors vest ratably over a three -year period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P164_S2	All grants expire 10 years after the date of grant.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P172_S0	The following table shows our income tax expense and our effective tax rate for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 , and 2015 :
1289419_18_ITEM8_P173_S0	On December 22, 2017, the President of the United States signed into law the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act ("Tax Reform Act").
1289419_18_ITEM8_P173_S1	The legislation significantly changes U.S. tax law by, among other things, lowering corporate income tax rates, changing to a territorial tax system and imposing a transitional tax on deemed repatriated earnings of foreign subsidiaries.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P173_S2	The Tax Reform Act permanently reduces the U.S. corporate income tax rate from a maximum of 35% to a flat 21% rate, effective January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P174_S0	On December 22, 2017, the SEC staff issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 118 ("SAB 118") to address the application of U.S. GAAP in situations when a registrant does not have the necessary information available, prepared, or analyzed (including computations) in reasonable detail to complete the accounting for certain income tax effects of the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P174_S1	We have recognized the provisional tax impacts related to the changes under the Tax Reform Act and have included these amounts in our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P174_S2	The ultimate impact may differ from these provisional amounts, possibly materially, due to, among other things, additional analysis, changes in interpretations and assumptions that we have made, additional regulatory guidance that may be issued, and actions that we may take as a result of the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P174_S3	The accounting is expected to be complete when our 2017 U.S. corporate income tax return is filed in 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P175_S0	We use the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P175_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P175_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to reverse.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P175_S3	As a result of the reduction in the U.S. corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% under the Tax Reform Act, we revalued our ending net deferred tax liabilities at December 31, 2017 and recognized a provisional $14.7 million tax benefit in our Consolidated Statement of Income for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P176_S0	With respect to the transitional tax related to the change to a territorial system, the Tax Reform Act provided for a one-time deemed mandatory repatriation of post-1986 undistributed foreign subsidiary earnings and profits ("E P") through the year ended December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P176_S1	We had an estimated $183.7 million of undistributed foreign E P subject to the deemed mandatory repatriation.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P176_S2	After the utilization of corresponding tax credits, we have recorded a provisional tax charge of $7.5 million on the deemed mandatory repatriation of earnings of our foreign subsidiaries payable over 8 years.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P176_S3	We have also recorded a provisional reduction of a deferred tax liability of $6.4 million previously recorded for our foreign equity method investments.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P176_S4	The transitional tax charge of $7.5 million offset by the reduction of the $6.4 million deferred tax liability results in a net tax expense of $1.1 million on the deemed mandatory repatriation of earnings of our foreign affiliates.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S0	We are continuing to assess our indefinite reinvestment assertion as a result of the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S1	We have recorded a provisional estimate of deferred taxes in the amount of $3.0 million for foreign withholding taxes that would be due upon remittance of dividends from certain of our foreign affiliates.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S2	We are still evaluating whether to change our overall indefinite reinvestment assertion in light of the Tax Reform Act and consider our conclusion to be incomplete under SAB 118.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S3	Accordingly, we consider that most of our remaining foreign outside basis differences to be indefinitely reinvested.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S4	Accordingly, we have not recorded deferred taxes on those outside basis differences.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S5	As part of our continuing evaluation, we will need to gather additional information to compute outside basis differences for our foreign affiliates in order to assess whether any new deferred taxes should be recorded.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S6	We will also need to account for any prospective interpretive guidance issued on the Tax Reform Act as part of our evaluation.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P177_S7	If we subsequently change our assertion during the measurement period allowed under SAB 118, we will account for a change in assertion as part of our accounting for the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P178_S0	The Tax Reform Act also establishes other provisions that may affect our 2018 results, including but not limited to, the creation of a new minimum tax called the base erosion anti-abuse tax (BEAT); a new provision that taxes U.S. allocated expenses (e.g. interest and general administrative expenses) as well as currently taxes certain income from foreign operations (Global Intangible Low-Tax Income, or "GILTI"); a new limitation on deductible interest expense; the repeal of the domestic manufacturing deduction; and limitations on the deductibility of certain employee compensation.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P179_S0	The BEAT provisions in the Tax Reform Act eliminate the deduction of certain base-erosion payments made to related foreign corporations and impose a minimum tax if greater than regular tax.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P179_S1	We are still evaluating the BEAT provisions which are applicable after December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P180_S0	While the Tax Reform Act generally eliminates U.S. federal income tax on dividends from foreign subsidiaries going forward, certain income earned by certain subsidiaries may be included in our U.S. taxable income under the new GILTI inclusion rules (as a result of U.S. expense allocation rules).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P180_S1	Because of the complexity of the new GILTI tax rules, we are continuing to evaluate this provision of the Tax Reform Act and the application of U.S. GAAP.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P180_S2	Under U.S. GAAP, we are allowed to make an accounting policy election and either treat taxes due from GILTI as a current-period expense when they are incurred or factor such amounts into our measurement of deferred taxes.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P180_S3	Our selection of an accounting policy with respect to the new GILTI rules will depend in part on analyzing our global income to determine whether we expect to have future U.S. inclusions in taxable income related to GILTI, and if so, what the impact is expected to be.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P180_S4	We have not yet computed a reasonable estimate of the effect of this provision, and therefore, we have not made a policy decision regarding whether to record deferred taxes related to GILTI nor have we made any adjustments related to GILTI tax in our year-end financial statements.

1289419_18_ITEM8_P191_S0	We conduct business globally and as a result, we file income tax returns in U.S. federal, state, local, and foreign jurisdictions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P191_S1	In the normal course of business, we are subject to examination by tax authorities throughout the world.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P191_S2	The open tax years for our U.S. Federal tax returns and most state tax returns include the years 2008 to the present.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P192_S0	We are currently under audit by federal, state and local tax authorities in the United States as well as tax authorities in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P192_S1	It is likely that the examination phase of some of these U.S. federal, state, local, and non-U.S. audits will conclude in 2018 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P193_S0	It is not possible to estimate the effect of current audits on previously recorded unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P194_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of $8.7 million and a non-current liability of $7.0 million for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P194_S1	As of December 31, 2016 , our Consolidated Balance Sheet included a current liability of $8.9 million and a non-current liability of $5.4 million for unrecognized tax benefits.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P194_S2	These amounts include interest and penalties, less any associated tax benefits.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P195_S0	The table below reconciles the beginning and ending amount of the gross unrecognized tax benefits as follows:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P196_S0	In 2017 , we recorded a net increase of $2.9 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits before settlements and lapses of statutes of limitations, of which $2.9 million increased our income tax expense by $3.1 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P196_S1	In addition, we reduced our unrecognized tax benefits by $2.6 million for settlements and lapses of statutes of limitations, of which $2.6 million decreased our income tax expense by $2.2 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P197_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , we had $18.7 million of gross unrecognized tax benefits, of which $15.0 million , if recognized, would reduce our effective income tax rate and decrease our income tax expense by $14.4 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P198_S0	We record interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions as part of our income tax expense.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P198_S1	The following table summarizes our gross liability for interest and penalties:
1289419_18_ITEM8_P199_S0	We recorded the increase in the liabilities for penalties and interest, net of any tax benefits, to income tax expense in our Consolidated Statement of Income in 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P200_S0	In August 2017, Michael D. Green, individually and purportedly on behalf of all others similarly situated, filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P200_S1	The complaint names as defendants Morningstar, Inc., Prudential Investment Management Services LLC, and Prudential Retirement Insurance and Annuity Co., and contains one count alleging violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P201_S0	Plaintiff, a participant in a pension plan, alleges that the defendants engaged in concerted racketeering actions to steer plan participants into high-cost investments that pay unwarranted fees to the defendants.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P201_S1	The complaint seeks unspecified compensatory damages for plaintiff and the members of the putative class, treble damages, injunctive relief, costs, and attorneys fees.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P201_S2	Morningstar has filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which is fully briefed and under advisement by the court.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P202_S0	Although Morningstar is vigorously contesting the claim asserted, we cannot predict the outcome of the proceeding.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P203_S0	Other Matters We are involved from time to time in legal proceedings and litigation that arise in the normal course of our business.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P203_S1	While it is difficult to predict the outcome of any particular proceeding, we do not believe the result of any of these matters will have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, or financial position.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P204_S0	We had an ongoing authorization, originally approved by our board of directors in September 2010 and subsequently amended, to repurchase up to $1.0 billion in shares of our outstanding common stock.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P204_S1	The authorization expired on December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P205_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , we had repurchased a total of 10,574,857 shares for $714.8 million under this authorization, leaving no shares available for future repurchases as the plan expired on December 31, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P205_S1	On December 8, 2017, the board of directors approved a new share repurchase program that authorizes the company to repurchase up to $500.0 million in shares of the company's outstanding common stock, effective January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P205_S2	The authorization expires on December 31, 2020.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P206_S0	We may repurchase shares from time to time at prevailing market prices on the open market or in private transactions in amounts that we deem appropriate.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P207_S0	On May 28, 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , which requires an entity to recognize the amount of revenue to which it expects to be entitled for the transfer of promised goods or services to customers.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P207_S1	The ASU will replace most existing revenue recognition guidance in U.S. GAAP when it becomes effective.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P207_S2	The original effective date for ASU No. 2014-09 would have required us to adopt it beginning on January 1, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P207_S3	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers Deferral of the Effective Date , which defers the effective date of ASU No. 2014-09 for one year and permits early adoption as early as the original effective date of ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P207_S4	We elected the deferral, and the new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P208_S0	We have obtained an understanding of ASU No. 2014-09 and have substantially completed our analysis of the impact of the new standard on our financial results.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P208_S1	We have completed a high-level assessment of the attributes within our contracts for our major products and services, and we have assessed the impacts to our internal processes, control environment, and disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P208_S2	We have determined that the adoption of ASU No. 2014-09 will not result in a material change to the timing of when revenue is recognized and we intend to retain similar accounting treatment used to recognize revenue under current practices.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P208_S3	We have identified that there will be certain changes in accounting treatment related to delivery of third-party content (principal vs. agent) and costs to obtain contracts (e.g., sales commissions).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P209_S0	The change related to delivery of third-party content (principal vs. agent) is expected to result in no impact on our consolidated operating income; however it will result in a increase in both revenue and cost of revenue versus prior periods of approximately $6 million to $7 million as revenue will be recognized on a gross rather than net basis for certain arrangements.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P210_S0	The change related to the capitalization of cost to obtain contracts is expected to result in an increase to retained earnings of approximately $25 million to $30 million for commission expenses which were previously expensed.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P210_S1	We expected to amortize this adjustment over a period not to exceed three years and expect 2018 commission expense resulting from this change will range between $14 million and $16 million .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P210_S2	Additionally, in 2018 we will expense any discretionary payments made under our commission plans as well as pro-rata portions of any new commission amounts paid in 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P211_S0	The standard allows for both retrospective and modified retrospective methods of adoption.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P211_S1	We plan to adopt using the modified retrospective transition method applied to those contracts which were not completed as of January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P211_S2	Upon adoption, we will recognize the cumulative effect of adopting this guidance as an adjustment to our opening balance of retained earnings as noted above.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P211_S3	Prior periods will not be retrospectively adjusted and we will discuss the comparability of these adjustments within our 2018 results against the prior periods.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P212_S0	We are continuing to evaluate the effect that ASU No. 2014-09 will have on our consolidated financial statement presentation and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P212_S1	We expect expanded disclosures related to the revenue recognized in the reporting period that was included in the contract liability (i.e., deferred revenue) balance at the beginning of the period.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P212_S2	We also plan to provide additional disclosures on our unsatisfied performance obligations at the end of the period and expected timing of when that contract liability will be recognized into revenue.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P213_S0	On March 17, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-08, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Principal versus Agent Considerations (Reporting Revenue Gross versus Net) , which provides guidance on assessing whether an entity is a principal or an agent in a revenue transaction and whether an entity reports revenue on a gross or net basis.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P213_S1	On April 14, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-10, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Identifying Performance Obligations and Licensing , which provides guidance on identifying performance obligations and accounting for licenses of intellectual property.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P213_S2	On May 6, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-11, Revenue Recognition and Derivatives and Hedging: Rescission of SEC guidance because of ASU No. 2014-09 and ASU No. 2014-16 pursuant to staff announcements at the March 3, 2016 EITF Meeting , which rescinds the following SEC Staff Observer comments from ASC 605, Revenue Recognition , upon an entity's early adoption of ASC 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers : Revenue and expense recognition for freight services in process, accounting for shipping and handling fees and costs, and accounting for consideration given by a vendor to a customer (including a reseller of the vendor's products).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P213_S3	On May 9, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-12, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Narrow-Scope Improvements and Practical Expedients , which makes narrow-scope amendments to ASU No. 2014-09 and provides practical expedients to simplify the transition to the new standard and clarify certain aspects of the standard.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P213_S4	On December 21, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-20, Technical Corrections and Improvements to Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , which makes narrow-scope amendments to ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P214_S0	The effective date and transition requirements for ASU No. 2016-08, ASU No. 2016-10, ASU No. 2016-11, ASU No. 2016-12, and ASU No. 2016-20 are the same as the effective date and transition requirements of ASU No. 2014-09.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P214_S1	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-08, ASU No. 2016-10, ASU No. 2016-11, ASU No. 2016-12, and ASU No. 2016-20 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P215_S0	On February 25, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases , which will require lessees to recognize almost all leases on their balance sheet as a right-of-use asset and a lease liability.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P215_S1	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2019.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P215_S2	The new standard must be adopted using a modified retrospective transition and provides for certain practical expedients.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P215_S3	Transition will require application of the new guidance at the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P216_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-02 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P217_S0	On August 26, 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows: Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments , which reduces diversity in practice of how certain transactions are classified in the statement of cash flows.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P217_S1	The new guidance clarifies the classification of cash activities related to debt prepayment or debt extinguishment costs, settlement of zero-coupon debt instruments, contingent consideration payments made after a business combination, proceeds from the settlement of insurance claims, proceeds from the settlement of corporate and bank-owned life insurance policies, distributions received from equity-method investments, and beneficial interests in securitization transactions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P217_S2	The guidance also describes a predominance principle in which cash flows with aspects of more than one class that cannot be separated should be classified based on the activity that is likely to be the predominant source or use of cash flow.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P218_S0	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P218_S1	Early adoption is permitted, including adoption in an interim period, but requires all elements of the amendments to be adopted at once rather than individually.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P218_S2	The new standard must be adopted using a retrospective transition method.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P219_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2016-15 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P220_S0	On January 5, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-01, Business Combinations: Clarifying the Definition of a Business, which revises the definition of a business.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P221_S0	When substantially all of the fair value of gross assets acquired is concentrated in a single asset (or a group of similar assets), the assets acquired would not represent a business.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P221_S1	To be considered a business, an acquisition would have to include an input and a substantive process that together significantly contribute to the ability to create outputs.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P221_S2	The new guidance provides a framework to evaluate when an input and substantive process are present (including for early-stage companies that have not generated outputs).
1289419_18_ITEM8_P222_S0	To be a business without outputs, there will now need to be an organized workforce.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P222_S1	The new guidance also narrows the definition of the term outputs to be consistent with how it is described in Topic 606 , Revenue from Contracts with Customers .
1289419_18_ITEM8_P222_S2	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P222_S3	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-01 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S0	On January 26, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04, Intangibles Goodwill and Other , which simplifies the accounting for goodwill impairment.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S1	The guidance removes Step 2 of the goodwill impairment test, which requires a hypothetical purchase price allocation.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S2	A goodwill impairment will now be the amount by which a reporting unit s carrying value exceeds its fair value, not to exceed the carrying amount of goodwill.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S3	All other goodwill impairment guidance will remain largely unchanged.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S4	Entities will continue to have the option to perform a qualitative assessment to determine if a quantitative impairment test is necessary.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S5	The same one-step impairment test will be applied to goodwill at all reporting units, even those with zero or negative carrying amounts.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S6	Entities will be required to disclose the amount of goodwill at reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S7	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2020.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S8	The new standard should be applied prospectively.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P223_S9	Early adoption is permitted for any impairment tests performed after January 1, 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P224_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-04 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P225_S0	On May 10, 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-09, Compensation Stock Compensation: Scope of Modification Accounting , which clarifies when to account for a change to the terms or conditions of a share-based payment award as a modification.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P225_S1	Under the new guidance, modification accounting is required only if the fair value, the vesting conditions, or the classification of the award (as equity or liability) changes as a result of the change in terms or conditions.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P225_S2	The new standard is effective for us on January 1, 2018.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P225_S3	The new standard should be applied prospectively.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P225_S4	We are evaluating the effect that ASU No. 2017-09 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P226_S0	(1) Non-operating income in the fourth quarter of 2016 included a $37.1 million holding gain related to the purchase of the remaining ownership interest in PitchBook, which was previously a minority investment.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P227_S0	(2) Non-operating income in the second quarter of 2017 included a $17.5 million gain on the sale of HelloWallet.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P227_S1	We recorded an immaterial adjustment to this gain in the fourth quarter of 2017.
1289419_18_ITEM8_P228_S0	(3) Tax expense in the fourth quarter of 2017 includes a net benefit of $10.6 million related to the impact of the Tax Reform Act.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We design disclosure controls and procedures to reasonably assure that information required to be disclosed in the reports filed or submitted under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC's rules and forms.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Disclosure controls and procedures include, without limitation, controls and procedures designed to reasonably assure that information required to be disclosed in the reports filed under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to management, including the chief executive officer and chief financial officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P1_S0	We carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Exchange Act, as of December 31, 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, participated in and supervised this evaluation.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Based on that evaluation, our chief executive officer and chief financial officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in the reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act meets the requirements listed above.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P3_S0	We carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework set forth in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Based on that evaluation, our management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2017 .
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P5_S0	KPMG LLP, our independent registered public accounting firm, has issued its report on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting, which is included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K under the caption Financial Statements and Supplementary Data and incorporated herein by reference.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P6_S0	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2017 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1289419_18_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Internal control over financial reporting now includes the internal controls of PitchBook Data, Inc., which was not included in our assessment as of December 31, 2016.
1289419_18_ITEM9B_P0_S0	There is no information that was required to be disclosed in a report on Form 8-K during the fourth quarter of the year covered by this Annual Report on Form 10-K that was not reported.
